scripture teache v prophane doctrine might inſtruct v homer ſhevveth god throvveth ſhielde vvarre defende prince harme appoynteth euerye gouernour peculiar god protection hovv god plagueth conſpire againſte theyr prince hiſtorie declareth full coniured againſt caius caeſar one eſcape violent death vvhich author hathe pleaſure declare bycauſe vvould affray men diſloyaltie tovvard soueraigne greateſt ſeruice men doe ſaue theyr countrey daunger romanes gaue crovvne ſaued one citizen hovv many crovvnes deſerueth helpeth ſaue number vſed make coyne commendation vvith inſcription senate people rome citizen ſaued cicero vvas called father countrey bycauſe hee kept decay theyr conſultations ſeeke like benefite countrey doe deſerue like revvard prayſe teſtimonie good mēs heart ſure haue ſeeyng authoures onely purpoſe extoll princely rule procure ſafetie people haue preſumed make preſente hym youre honoure caſe like good maye receyue ſame triumph deſert hovv vvorthy vvryter redde referre vvitneſſe one vvorthy reuerend father god c biſhop lincolne booke entituled theſaurus lingua latinae britannicae prelate lāde vvho ſayd plato ſhal ſuffice multitude vvith manner authoures vvriting doe meane trouble himſelfe ſhall tell honour ſuch caſe may bring paſſe deſireth glory god honour prince benefite countrey renoume ſelfe honoures ſeruaunt moſt duetifully bounden h binniman euidently bente againſt bringing many time weapon one officer diuiſiō diſpatched temple aſſemblies court tribune pretor conſuls eyther prouoking working occaſion uncomely contumely euery trifle foule contempt law right euer play part euil growing great manifeſt inſurrections wer made againſt ſtate mightie fierce armyes rayſed againſt countrey baniſhed mē ſtriuing reſtitutiō magiſtrates contending among themſelues office home army abroade power like prince monarkes made leader ſeditious army ſome would leaue army deliuered people ſome without authoritie would leuie ſtraunge ſouldiers againſt enimies ſtriuing whether thē ſhould firſt get citie word againſt cōtrary factiō déede againſt ye countrey inuaded enemy cruell murder vſed ſome others proſcriptions deathe baniſhments conſiſcations torment intollerable ſo kinde crueltie left undone till cornelius sylla one mightie captaines rebellion fifty yeares gracchus healing euil euil made himſelfe monarke time kinde officer called dictator vſed moſt daungerous time commonly giuen ouer ſixe monethes ended sylla déede dictator force dictator vvas ruled alone yet battell might horſebacke perpetuall yet ſpeach pretending elected fill rule alone firſt man thinke durſt fréely giue ouer tiranicall power affirming woulde aunſwere doings woulde accuſe ſighte ſortes priuate man many time went common place returned home againe without hurte suche feare yet aucthoritie beheld hym aſtoniſhmente reſigning reuerence hée offered aunſweare hys doyngs ſome curteſie conſideration acknowledging tyranny haue bene profitable countrey thus ſedition ceaſſed sylla remedie euils sylla done hym began againe caeſar conquered fraunce paſſed floud • e •• ſayled england til caius caeſar election ſent gouerne fraunce long time cōmaūded senate giue ouer aunſwered pompey enimie leading army italy repining authoritie fraunce ſought remoue senate yet notwithſtāding propounded cōditions eyther ſhoulde reteyne armyes anoyde caeſar offreth condition ſuſpition perill pompey alſo ſhould leaue power liue priuate life according lawes obteyning neyther theſe marched fraunce againſt pompey countrey inuated hymthe place vv • called • harſalia vvhich pompey fled egypt vvhere vvas killed yong king counſellers fledde purſued theſſalie ouercame verye victoriouſly valiant battayle fléeing thence hée followed egipt ſlaine countrey men hadde tarried ſet ſtay among prince egipt ouerthrown greateſt enemy worthyneſſe warres ſurnamed great man nowe pompey hys valiantneſſe name megnus great giuen vnto bolde anything againſt returned rome choſen ſecond dictator perpetuall sylla al ſedition ceaſſed hande tyll brutus caſsius eyther enuye greatneſſe zeale countrey kylled thebrutus caſ • ius senate houſe moſt accepted people auguſtus firſte ſo title ſhewed himſelfe another caeſar yea mightie caeſar wel touching ſubication owne countrey nation néeding election forme creation pretence doings continuance time ſetled ſtate thing happy beloued left behind ſucceſſion lynage raigne likewiſe thus common welth romaine diuerſe debate came vnitie rule one theſe thing done haue written gathering moſt notable matter lyſte may ſée vnſatiable ambition men gréedy deſire kingdome ioyned intollerable paynes innumerable kindes calamity haue rather takē hand bicauſe dealing hiſtorie egipt al theſe thing going ending compelled make reherſal thē occaſion egipte alſo conquered cleopatra order ſtory vvhiche left italian tranſlation vvhen caeſar octauian ouercome antony cleopatra made egipt prouince empire rome made one cornelius gallus lieftenant token conquering countrey firſte hee coyned money vvhiche vvas picture crocodile vvhich ſeene floud nilus chayned palme tree tree palmes laide ouer vvith inſcription col nem c • lligauit nemo ſignifiyng hee triumphed egipt ſprinkling vvith deavv inſtead rayne vvhich none toke parte antony bycauſe multitude matter haue deuided thus firſt ſhall ſhewe thyngs done sempronius gracchus cornelius sylla ſeconde ſhall conteine al actes time vnto death caeſar reſt ſhall declare diſſention betwéene thrée men one againſt citizen rome vntill laſt greateſt feate ciuill force whyche auguſtus ouercame antonie cleopatra actio time chronicle egipt ſhal take beginning ¶ hiſtorie appianus alexandrinus ciuil diſſentions romaine firſt booke romaine firſt conquered italy vvas 500 yeares romaine could conquere italy manner inhabitant called colony vvhich vvere taken lot greeke vvorde expreſſeth vvhich 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 whych little little toke part land buylded new city ſent owne people inhabite old meane might ſure countrey grounde tilled eyther diſtributed ſold let ferme inhabitant waſt reaſon warre much hauing euer leyſure make diuiſion proclaymed ſort would manure yearely increaſe ſéede grounde required thethe romaine order inhabiting groūd tenth part place planted trées woode would haue fifth part cattel eyther great ſmall appointed tribute accordingly thys maintenaunce italian nationthe romaine make account italian nation accounted men beſt ſeruice might always war haue vſe owne came ſoone otherwiſe paſſe ye rich mē hauing got ye greater part vndeuided lande proſumed vpon long preſcription time man would moleſt poore men ſmall portion lying nygh either boughte little perſuaſion encroched violence oppreſſion ſo ſteade manour place whole country bycauſe would haue huſbandemen called anye time awaye warres bought theyr hynes herdes laboure ground would ſette countryman worke reaſon whereof theyr gaine incredible well yearely profit poſſeſſions multitude encreaſe thoſe ſlaues whycheincreaſe ſlaues decay italian neuer called y• warre thus great mē grew excéeding riche euery place ful • crutle generation italian fel decaye wante men alſo oppreſſed pouerty occaſion continuall preſſing war dayly exaction put vpon time eaſed theſe felt incōueniēce land owne rich mē lord al vſing labour bondman ſteade frée men italian vtterly corrupted reſt ydlenes people rome much offended herewith bicauſe could haue ſuch ſeruice italian whenſoeuer made expedition abroade without daunger great multitude bondemen home could tel remedy matter eaſy altogither equal thruſt poſſeſſion ſo long continuance landes houſes ſo wel planted prouided length wyth much adoe tribune toke matterthis vvas called lex licini • hand ordeyned man ſhould kéepe aboue fiue hundred acre landean acre vvas ſo much ground payre • en could arie day meaſure vvhereof 240 foote length 120 breadth meaſure foote vvas 4 handes one hand vvas foure finger meaſure ſinger according geometry three barely cornes added 〈◊〉 italian tranſlation man ſhoulde féede aboue one hundered greate cattel man ſhould féede aboue fiue hundred little cattel better obſeruation hereof appointed number fréemen marke done make declaration ſame time time law allowed penaltie aſſigned commiſſioners ſworne ſuppoſing meane ſome lande would lefte ſmall price might awarded poore regarde none neyther lawe othe ſome ſéeme manner ſake obey lawe make counterfeyte deuiſion neyghboures moſte parte dyd vtterly contemne lawe tyll tiberius sempronius gracchus goodlye noble man honourable eloquentethys gracchus vvas ſent pretor numantia vvhere cō ſul mancinus vvas ouerthrovvne ſeking peace numantines vvould graunt none excepte gracchus vvere ſent thē vvhiche done peace vvas made vvhiche senate approue though xx citizen vvere ſaued thereby beſide ſlaues raſcals ſo much conſul vvas ſent thither againe naked bounde gracchus people prayſed ſaued ſo many citizēs vpon vvhich occaſion became enemye senate friend people whereby notable al tribune made ſolemne oration prayſe italian people lamentyng ſo warlike nation romaine alliaunce ſhoulde ſhortly diſpeopled brought penurie without hope remedy inu • yed againſte ra • e slaues vnfitte warre vntruſtye lordes called remembraunce freſh affliction cicelie ſlauiſh ſeruauntes againſt maiſters increaſe alſo vſed countrie buſineſſe romaine could ſubdue without long ſharpe warre full variable daungerous ſucceſſe hauing ſpoken effecte hee renewed law manne ſhoulde haue fiue hundered acre child ſhould haue halfe ſo muche added old lawe thrée men choſen changeable euerye yeare ſhoulde make diuiſion poore riche men toke matter verye grieuouſlye nowe coulde illude lawe dyd bycauſe appointed deuiſion purchaſe theyr landes hadde theyr partes aſſigned gracchus hadde prouided forbydding manner ſale aſſembled togyther ſeuerall company fyndyng faulte wyth lawe marueylous diſdaine griefe poore ſhoulde poſſeſſe theyr auntient inheritaunce planting building ſhold forgot purchaſe land payd ſome neyghbours others repyned loſſe forefather syrian ſlaue sicelie mad ſorte raging vvith deſire make rebellion pretended religion honor goddeſſe syria called bondemen libertie armes might ſeeme vvil god held nutte mouth ſtuffed vvyth sulphure fire vvhich vvhen ſpake caſt forth flame olde romaine bury poſſeſſiōs vvas long chriſt ere mē vvere buried ſacred place sepulture conteyned within groundes p • rtitions theyr portion lefte theyr parentes obiected theyr wyues marriage money conſumed vppon ſame lande inheritaunce theyr child ſome declared debt fallen reaſon intereſt ſo great diſorder quarelling indignation among poore men contrary ſide complaine werethe poore offended brought good wealth extreme want thereby decay continuaunce able bring vp child ſhewed many tymes bin warfare winne thys land myght beare • eſt publike portiō rayled riche ſteade frée men citizen ſouldiers choſen bonde ſeruauntes generation euer vnfaithfull ſtubborne therfore fitte warre thus one reuiling vpbrayding multitude either romaine foundation owne gouernement al wayes partaker lande fearing loſſe therof reſorted togither deuided wyth one ſo enbolded number waxed fierce ſtirring rebellion abiding til law ſhould diſcuſſed one mean ſuffer preuaile might take place vttermoſt ſides ambitiouſlye bent ſequele againſt appointed day preparedthe latin tranſlation p candidus italian differeth greeke themſelues gracchus minde ſtoode vppon reſolution aboundance rich encreaſe men procuryng commoditie muche magnifyed himſelfe trauell italie could honor importance difficultye wherof conceiue day making lawes come made long plauſible preface aſked wer right yt publike thing ſhold deuided gracchus talke common citizen preferred ſeruant ſouldier profitable vnapt war partaker publike profit wel willing tarying lōg compariſon néedleſſe ſtreight turned tale vtter hope feares countrey warre wonne ſo muche lande enemy good hope get reſt earth woulde nowe put aim hazarde whether conquer al remayned increaſe fytte mē loſe want owne enuie enimies ſet forth glory wealth one daunger doubt exhorted rich regard profite gratifie people land bring vp childrē hope wealth come ſtriue trifling matter neglect greater thing hauing ſufficient recompence charge beſtowed poſſeſſion fiue hundred acre choyce frée certen land euery child anye halfe ſo much ſort gracchus ſpeaking much kindling pore ſtoode vpon reaſon rather deſire poſſeſſion commaunded clearke pronounce law marcus octauius tribune whome poſſeſſioners octauius • iſteth lavve made reſiſt romaine euer able forbidde commaunded clearke ſilence gracchus greatly blaming deferred court till next day hauing prepared ſufficient force compell octauius commaunded clearke threates propound lawe people octauius forbadde againe put ſilēce tribune fell chafing one ſo lawe could take place tumult wherefore great men required committe difference senate gracchus toke gracchus senate holde offer thinking euery reaſonable man wylling lawe ranne y• senate houſe reproued rich among chiefe men vvord ſignifyeth great men • ſtreight ſtraight hée ranne agayne commō place ſayd woulde deferre tryall till next dayes aſſemblie law authoritie octauius whether order tribune reſiſting law mighte reteyne office ſo whyche time octauius nothing abaſhed made reſiſtance againe wherefore gracchus put matter firſte vayces one company giuen againſt octauius gracchus turned prayed leaue purpoſe cared ſo procéeded fiue thirtie company whereoffiue thirtie company •• rome ſeauentéene giuen againſt greate furie y• eyghtenth ſhould haue determined matter gracchus againe ſighte people lamentably deſired daunger woulde hynder ſo profitable honorable acte italy withſtande ſo greate deſire people gracchus excuſeth himſelfe depriuation fellovv whyche ought béeyng tribune ſuffer diſgrace loſing hys office thus hée ſpake called god witneſſe agaynſte hys wyll hys fellowe depoſed perſuaſion woulde ſerue hée made decrée octauius béeyng depriued ſecretely conueyed hymſelfe away octauius depri • ed q mummius choſen lavv landes officer lavv appius claudius▪ quintus mummius choſen tribune place lawe landes pronounced firſte officer appoynted ſée executed gracchus hymſelfe lawmaker brother hys name appius claudius hys father lawe muche dyd people feare laboure lawe ſhoulde bée loſt vnleſſe gracchus hys familie hadde execution gracchus maruellouſly magnifyed thys lawe accompanyed people houſe preſeruer one citie countrey nation italy thys béeyng done day returned landes countrey whence came purpoſe loſt day remayned diſcontented talked gracchus ſhoulde eſcape blame ſhoulde bée office durſt violate magiſtrate ſo greate authoritie gyue occaſion ſo manifeſt ſedition italy nowe sommer tyme chooſing tribune hande ſéemed ryche woulde ſo laboure office ſhould bée gyuen ſome gracchus greateſt enimies tryall béeyng hande hée afrayde hée ſhoulde bée elected tribune yeare come called people countrey gyue voyce election béeyng occupyed sommer buſineſſe daye drawyng nygh hée gracchus labour people compelled make people citie hys refuge wente aboute euery one aparte deſire make hym tribune agayne béeyng daunger theyr ſakes daye come two firſte companyes choſe gracchus ryche men cryed lawfull one bée tribune twyce togyther rubrio tribune whoſe turne came bée chiefe election doubted matter mummius doubt thē election ſucceſſor octauius prayed hys fellowe committe order election hym whyche hée dyd tribune affyrmed thys muſt tryed lotte rubrio hadde hys turne appoyntmente dyd apperteyne contention béeyng greate gracchus hauyng worſe deferred diſcuſſing tyll nexte daye béeyng vtterlye diſcouraged although yet office remayned reſt whole daye common place beſéechyng euerye man bée hys helpe though ſhoulde ſtreyghte haue bin deſtroyed hys enimies poore men moued wyth compaſſion conſideryng vſed indifferently citizen rather ſlaues luſt ryche fearyng gracchus ſtate ſuffered theyr ſake lamentation broughte hym hys houſe nyghte bade hym bée good chéere agaynſte nexte daye gracchus béeyng thus encouraged aſſembled hys parte nyghte gaue watchworde fyghte néede required hée went temple capitoll election ſhoulde bée aſſemblie come togyther hée myddeſt ſome tribune ryche men woulde ſuffer election procéede hym wherefore hée gaue hys watche worde priuie made greate ſhoute beganne fray ſome ſtoode aboute gracchus tumult b • gracchus guarde hys perſon ſome tore ſeates ſome wrang roddes mace sergeantes handes ſome rente aſunder euerye thyng bet ryche menne place wyth ſuche tumulte terroure tribune ranne awaye prieſtes ſhutte temple dores flying running confuſed ſpéeche well vnderſtanded thoughte gracchus hadde depoſed tribune ſpying none lyke bée ſo thoughte hée hadde made hym ſelfe tribune agayne wythoute anye election meane time senate aſſembled temple faith surely maruell office one ruler hadtemple fayth many time preſerued ſtate like trouble dyd chooſe dictator former time foundedictator moſt neceſſarie nowe neyther memorie cared senate wel could reſolued done went vp capitoll cornelius scipio naſica name chiefe biſhop led way ſpake withchiefe biſhop p scipio nafica loude voice ſhould follow would haue countrey ſafe pulled ſkirte gowne ouer hys head eyther giue token garmēt might followe hint ſigne ſawe woulde fight would hide god whatsuperſtition meant come temple thruſting among gracchus route gaue place vnto moſt worthy man whome ſawe senate follow dyd company wring weapon others handes andthe fray gathered péeces broken ſeates thing could get place bet gracchus part ſo violently droue brinke hill whyche tumulte gracchus ſlayne many temple gracchus ſlayne vvho vvas gentle curteous man ſober eloquent vvith modeſtie dores image king thus gracchus béeyng ſome gracchus bin twice conſull whoſe mother cornelia daughter scipio conquered cornelia ſuſpected scipio death vvas scipio iunior africanus nephevv scipio affricanus ouerthrevv anniball seruauntes confeſsion daughter married vnto scipio whome ſhe loued hir ſhe foule barren rather ſome thynke hée kylled hymſelfe bycauſe could fulfill hys promiſe ſaye hys ſeruauntes béeyng racked confeſſed certayne ſtraunge men vnknowen lette backe dore choke maiſter bycauſe ſawe people angry bée glad deathe durſt bewray thus dyed scipio thoughte worthy publike funerall although done ſo great ſeruice countrey muche could preſenteingratitude diſpleaſure preuayle ouer benefytes paſſed happe gaue courage gracchus faction although diuiſion landes diuerſlie deferred poſſeſſioners wherof ſome thought good companion warre ſhoulde called fréedome citie make benefyte common andfreedome citie ſo leaue contention land italian accepted gladly preferred fréedome citie lande countrey fuluius flaccus conſull diuider offuluius flaccus land great doer matter senate allowe inferiours ſhoulde become fellowes ſo deuice tooke place people hope diuiſion vtterly diſcouraged till caius caius gracchus ſeconde tribune gracchus brother made lawe landes thoughte moſt méete man tribune ſince hys brother deathe liued reſt though many senate enuyed hym yet ſtoode office obteyned great glory deuiſed deceyue senate makyngdiſtribution lawe people ſhould haue diſtribution monethes corne common great feare though ſtate ſhould ſtreyghte haue bin changed hauing name gentlemē authoritie proceſſe time ouerrule senatours open ſpight againſt lawe dealte matter corruption felte ſo continuall gayne baniſhed wherefore decrée baniſhmente made proclamation conſull man ſhould ſuccoure metellus neyther wyth fyre water one day giuen deliberation matter people citie offended andthe moderatiō metellus two former made two gracc •• begunne apulesus thirde ſedition working muche trouble romaynes ended meane tyme kyndled ſtirre called fellowes warre whiche ſodayne ſo ſhortlye grewe verye great cauſed italian aſke fréedome rome ſubiectes myghte bée coequall authoritie bycauſe hée ſo earneſt cauſe senatoures ſente hym forrayne warre hée laboured bée tribune flaccus ſe •• •• beria hys office ſhoulde ende broughte paſſe hée choſen tribune wyth gracchus yonger whyche going aboute make lawes fauoure italian ſlayne yée haue hearde whereby italian ſharplyeſette takyng gréeuouſlye rather vſed lyke vnderlyngs fellowes fuluius gracchus theyr ſakes ſo deſtroyed whome liuius druſus aliuius druſus noble man tribune hadde promiſed italian make lawe theyr fauoure touchyng freedome citie whereof verye deſirous onely meane seruauntes bée made superioures gratifye people rome tribune ledde newe inhabitances well italie sicelie determined tyll tyme deferred hée alſo tooke hande make pacification betwéene senatoures gentleman whyche fallen authoritie iudiciall matter hée ſawe hée coulde directlye reſtore senate theyr former iuriſdiction vſed policie wyth senate reaſon ſedition ſcarcely number thrée hundred hée deuiſed ſo many ſhoulde bée choſen gentleman judge bee choſen tyme toencreaſe senator come heare matter corruption whyche nowe regarded men waxen ſo ſhameleſſe thoughte faulte thys policie hadde contrarie ſucceſſe senate gréeued ſo many gentleman ſhoulde ſo ſuddaynely bée made theyr fellowes béeyng vnlyke lyke authoritie would agrée gentleman afrayde whole order iudgementes ſhould senate thing hauing taſted great gaine much authoritie began without cauſe ſuſpect beſideforth emulation grew among themſelues thē ſhoulde thought worthier choſen thrée c ſure enuied nothing trouble triall corruption ſhoulde called agayne ordinary court vſe senate gentleman though agréed druſus ſaid vvas nothing novv left deuided earth ayre • among themſelues yet conſpired agaynſte druſus people pleaſed wyth theyr newe habitation italian whoſe ſakes tribune hadde begunne theſe thing could away placing newe habitacionsit ſeeme ſome vvould haue reuoked certayne inl •• b • tancies tuſ people hapned ſo cryed hurt y• word fell downe dead found yt ſtrickē shomakers knife y• flanke thus druſus ye tribune druſus flayne ſlayne gentleman determination tooke occaſion picke quarels againſt enimies induced q valerius q valerius tribune take vppon accuſe eyther priuily apertly furthered italian publique matter hoping thereby great men ſhould haue bin brought ſlaunders diffamation judge whych ridde away ſhoulde yet haue greater power common wealth whereas tribune refuſe propound lawe gentleman ſwords hand cō paſſe place cauſed law made ſoone obteyned brought accuſers againſte senatours whereof one bestius woulde obey wente voluntarie • beſtius exile himſelfe cotta vvillingly exiled baniſhment would giue himſelfe hand enimies cotta appeared iudgement hée boldly declared ſeruice common wealth reprehended gentleman ſhoulde caſt decrée wente away willingly mummius euercame greece promiſed gentleman releaſed deceyued mummius exiled vvho ouers threvv cornelius thereof vvas called ac •• icu bycauſe ſtoode achaia forced ſhame flée iudgement leade lyfe ile delos people began gréeued diſorder increaſing dayly againſt beſt men lamenting ſo many ſo good citizēs ſhould ſo ſuddainely taken italian hearing druſus death cauſe ſo many men exile thinking longer ſuffered ſuch ſort chiefe patrones ſhould thus vſed hoping way obteyne fréedome citie determined leaue romaine whiche marking yong man citie aſcolo thys citie part called abruzzo neere territorie 〈◊〉 apperteyning pope another thys name apulia called aſcolidi sairiano difference preſidents hadriane emperoure proconſulles seruilius killed aſculi • onteius killed marſians campania di rom maliniās campania felici veſtinians abruzzo maruſians • bruzzo picentines campanites di lauoro ferentines cati • hirſians abruzzo pompeyans terrad lauoro venuſians apulia lapigianes otrāt • ▪ samnite abruzzo theſe natiōs beyōd rome aſculi deliuered citie pledge vtter seruilius preſident prouince time ſhould ſéeme romaine preſidents diuers partes italy whiche manner hadriane emperoure deſired renue cōtinued lōg time seruilius came great anger aſculi feaſt ſharply rebuked wherevpon killed bycauſe diſcouered hym killed alſo fonteius yt legate ye name legate among romaine ſent commiſſion preſidents countrey theſe two ſlayne little courteſie ſhewed reſt romaine al killed goodes ſet ſpoyle conſpiracie opened neighboures aſculi wente armes marſians malinians veſtinians marucians beſide picentines ferentines huſians pompeyans venuſians lapigianes samnite whiche people euer bin enimies ionia ſend theyr embaſſadors romaine complayning senate vſed ſeruice trauell alwayes getting theyr great empire made regard paine thought worthy partaker citie whome senate ſharply anſwered repented cato theſe deuidyng theyr armyes togyther wente agaynſte romayne captaynes many tymes aduantage many tymes wyth loſſe chiefe whyche brieflie declare theſe vetius cato putte flighte sextus iulius beyonde naples nuceria beſ • eged thirtie mile naples acerre citie campania vvhiche anniball burned people beeyng eſcaped oxintha ſonne iugurth venuſio apulia numidian rome cauſed priſoners captyues ſerue hys campe burned aboute compaſſe nuceria whyche cauſed nexte city yéelde feare hée requyryng armye ſente hym tenne thouſande menne one thouſande horſe wyth whyche hée beſéeged acerre▪ sextus caeſar wyth tenne thouſande frenche footemen manye numidian horſemenne approched acerre papius broughte venuſio oxintha ſonne iugurthe ſometyme kyng numidia hée kepte romaine claddyng hym wyth purple ſhewed hym manye tymes numidianes wyth caeſar whyche manye fledde thycke vnto hym theyr kyng wherefore caeſar ſente awaye reſt ſuſpected theyr countrey whiche papius came vppon hym wyth contempte bette downe parte hys trenche hée ſente hys horſemenne aboute whyche kylled ſyxe thouſande papius papius loſe ••• souldyoures whiche done caeſar remoued campe acerre iudacilius iapigia canuſians venuſians manye cyties dyd yeelde ſome woulde hée ouerc • manye noble menne romaynes founde hée ſlewe common ſlaues hée vſed hys 〈◊〉 rutilius conſull c marius made brydges farre aſunder paſſe ouer riuer liris vetius cato camped nigh bridge marius layde ambuſhe ouer agaynſte conſuls bridge morning ſuffered paſſe ouer ſet vpon ſleyght many people killed lande many alſo drowned flaud conſull conflict hurt head dyed ſhortlyethe conſull killed marius marius bridge perceyuing y• chance bodyes brought ſtreame paſſed floud great ſpeede ſet vppon catos camp kept made lodge nighte wonne day whence lacke victuall compelled depart futilius corpſe many gentleman ſent rome burnedheauineſſe rome death conſull heauie ſight ſée conſull ſo many deſtroyed cauſe many day mourning wherefore senate decréede dyed warre ſhould buryed leaſt ſight ſhould made afraide goe fielde ſucceſſor made rutilius yeare bycauſe sextus caeſar leyſure goe election hys hoſt senate appointed caius marius q caepio rule q pompedius lying againſt caepio fledde rūnagate brought pompedius deceyueth caepio two ſlaues pledge cladde purple ſonnes haue credite broughte certayne wedge leade layde ouer ſiluer golde exhorted ſet vpon men without captayne eaſie ouerthrowen caepio ſo light beliefe wente pompedius nigh place embuſhment ranne vp hill oſpie enimie whome giuen token appeared ouerthrew caepio many moe caepio flay •• senate committed reſt army marius sextus caeſar sextus caeſar fleeth marching thirtie thouſand footemen fiue thouſand horſes among hilles rocky ſtreyghtes marius ignatiue fell ſuddaynely vpon compaſſed ſame fledde away litter bycauſe ſicke riuer one bridge paſſe loſt greater part armye threw away armoure whome hardly eſcaped theano armed agayne well could theano end apulia multitude came vnto hand ouer head approched acherre papio beſéeged campes lay hard togither yet feare durſt prouoke one cornelius sylla c marius followe valiantly marſians lay againſt vnto hedge uineyardes marſians much adoe gote hedge whiche marius sylla thought good purſue sylla wayting camp ſide uineyards encountred would haue eſcaped killed manye ſo ſlaughter day aboue ſixe thouſande harneſſe romaine tooke great deale chaunce marſians like madde men fierce armed themſelues againe went prouoke marſi valiant people latio novv campania romaine durſt come hand begin fight nation moſt warlike chance triumph made ſaying neyther triumph without falerio camepania vvhere good vvine prayſed firmo tovvne march ancona mount ealerno iudacilius titus afranius p vē tidius togither ouerthrowe c pompeyus droue citie firmo wente way lefte afranius beſéege pompey armed men ſpéedely woulde come fighte yet comming army ſente sulpitius backe afranius came forthe face fight doubtfull ſides sulpitius ſet enimies camp fire ſawe fledde aſcoli without order obedience afranius killed continuing afranius killed fight pompeyus procéeded winning aſcoli indacilius borne aſcoli fearing loſſe thereof héeiudacilius tooke eyght compantes went toward ſending aſculians ſoone ſaw farre ſhould yſſue vppon enimies mighte aſſayled ſides would none notwithſtanding iudacilius entred camp many could reprooued countreymen vnfaithfulneſſe cowardlineſſe hauingcrueltie • iudacilius hope ſaue citie firſte killed auntient enimies thoſe late cauſed multitude diſobey inſtant done prepared fyre temple ſette bedde vppon banquet hys friendes hadde made merrie dranke hys poyſon layde hym downe ſtrawe iudacilius death bade ſette fyre thus iudacilius deſyrous dye honourablie hys countrey made hys ende sextus caeſar tyme hys office beyng expyred made uiceconſull senate ſette vppon twentie thouſande remoued theyr campe kylled eyghte thouſande caeſar dyeth vnarmed many lying long ſéege aſcoli dyed diſeaſe appoynted c bebius ſerue place theſe thing done italy aboute ionian ſea hetrurians vmbrianes ſyde rome hearyng countreys theyr neyghboures diſpoſed rebell senate béeing afrayde leaſt enimie rounde aboute ſhoulde bée vndefended ſente garriſons frée mace menne coaſt betweene citie cuma cuma campania felici freemade men ſent vvarre firſte tyme admytted ſerue warre wante frée menne thoſe italian remayned good faith made frée citie whyche deſirous thys benefyte ſente alſo hetrurianes receyued fréedome verye friendelye hetrurians novv tuſcanes senate thys curteſie made theyr welwyllers wyllyng putte oute doubte feare cauſed enimie hope lyke bée remiſſe romaine dyd receyue theſe newe citizen fuye thirtie companyes ſo manyethe italian made citizen rome leaſt béeyng olde ſhoulde preuayle election broughte newe companyes deuided tennes whereby laſt election manye tymes theyr voyces vayne bycauſe olde fuye thirtie firſte called halfe whether thys knowen firſte italian contente wyth afterward • cauſe newe contention aboute ienian sea hearyng hetrurianes repentaunce ſente fifteene thouſande menne ayde hetruria long laborious iourneys c pompeius nowe conſull mette wyth kylled fyue thouſande reſt returnyng home wayleſſe place ſharpe ſeaſon wynter eatyng acornes halfe deſtroyed ſame wynter cato pompeius fellowe made warre cato ſlayne vppon marſianes ſlayne sylla laye campe mount pompey l ignatius wyth greate deſpyghte encamped wythin halfe myle hym sylla coulde abyde thys sylla fleeth contumelie ſette vppon hym tarrying hys forragiers dryuen flée hys forragiers come ſette vppon hym agayne putte hym sylla putteth flight flyghte hée camped farther hauing ſupplye frenchman agayne placed hys campe neere sylla armyes beeyng thus nygh togither frenchman mightye ſtature came forthe alone challenged anye romaynesa combate numidian fyghte wyth hym little maruſian aunſwered hym kylled hym wyth whyche frenehmenne ſo diſcouraged fledde theyr way whereby campe béeyng troubled companye cluentuis woulde tarrie wyth conſuſion fledde nola sylla purſued kylled thirtie thouſande chaſe whereas nolanes receyued one gate feare enimie ſhoulde alſo enter ſlewe aboute walles twentye thouſande among whome cluentius manſullye fyghting also cluentius ſlayne ſlayne sylla wente agaynſte hirpinianes beſéeged equilan • hirpini • rutians iucanes novv paſibcata looking lucanes ayde daye deſired reſpite conſider hee perceyuing theyr crafte gaue one houre meane tyme ſette ladder walles whyche made woodde aquilano taken citie brut •• ende houre ſette fyre abruzzo brianes came wholly againſt sylla ſente aboute certayne whome willed take fortreſſes coulde ſignifye ſmoke whiche done gaue hote aſſault front thrée houres togither gote towne theſe thing venutians aſculans inuaded podiceans whome wanne two dayes cecilius metellus became ſucceſſor army went againſt iapigians ouerthrew battayle pompedius one pōpedius killed generalles reuolted people marius sylla hys souldyers citie sulpitius propounded lawe c marius whome done aſſigned rule warre agaynſte mithridates sylla hys place sylla hearing 〈◊〉 determining trye fight called hys souldyoures togyther whyche deſirous goe thys iourney gayne thereof knewe marius woulde vſe souldyoures declared vnto ſpyghte sulpitius marius hadde done hym ſhewyng playnely hys meaning hée durſt yet make mention ſuche warre exhorted bée readye occaſion ſhoulde requyre vnderſtanding hys intente afrayde preuented thys warfare opened syllas cogitation badde hym boldly leade sylla • ur •• e ••• rome armes rome hée beyng gladde thereof marched wyth ſyxe legion officer hys campe one treſourer poſted rome coulde abyde goe agaynſte theyrofficers good cōſcience countrey embaſſadoures came hym way aſked hym wyth armes hée dyd inuade hys countrey aunſweredaunſvvere sylla delyuer tyrauntes hée made thys aunſwere twice thrice ſeuerall embaſſadors wythall required senate wyth marius sulpitius myghte méete hym flelde mar hée woulde doe counſell ſhould ſéeme good hée come nygh pompeyus hys fellowe reſorted hym allowing prayſing hys doyngs ioynyng wyth hym thynges marius sulpitius prepared ſo ſhorte diſtaunce ſente embaſſadoures directed senate wyllyng hym come nygher fyue myles citie tyll hadde conſulted preſente ſtate sylla pompey well vnderſtandyng theyr meaning promiſed ſo doe yet followed ſoone gone sylla tooke gate called celimontana wall nexte • one legion pompey celimontana gate collina gate tooke collina gate wyth thyrde hée placed bridge wodde fourth left warde vnder walles reſt fiſhermans bote tooke away ſpight téeth tempeſt aroſehard happe marius eſcaping cutte cable hoyſted ſaile committed himſelfe fortune ſo came iland founde shippe friendes whome ſayled lybia béeing reiected thence sextus preſidente enimie liued winter sea vnder mountaynes numidia thus againe ſeaborde knowen hys friend ſayled c ••• egus granius alben • uanus lectorius others ſonne whiche valiant men fledde rome▪ numidian prince afrayde treaſon departed thence theſe good ſet vpon sylla whome thought violently vſe countrey lacking army tarried till occaſion might ſerue sylla béeyng firſt euer entred citie armes able haue made himſelfe rome equall monarch • enged enimie willingly refrayne violēce ſent army capua ruled agayne conſull faction baniſhed chiefly riche menne woman full money defence pompey conſull people pitying caſe appoynted gouernemente italy army vnder c pompeius▪ cneus heard tooke euill yet receyued quintus campe pompey conſull killed next day office cneus wente planted collina gate rome novve salaria hys hoſt gate called collina cinna came alſo encamped caius marius hearing thys paſſed sea hetruria marius returneth fellowes baniſhed seruauntes came aboute fyue hundred hys friendes rome vile apparell long heare moue pitie wente city ſhewing victory honoures agaynſte germanes andthe germanes vvere caled cimbrianes novv thought •• e hys ſyxe tymes conſulſhippe whyche pleaſed beſt promiſed doe lawe election ſo hée gathered ſyxe thouſande toſcanes came wyth cinna gladly receyued hym ſocietie doyngs oſtia ſpoyled mouth tiber tvvelue mile rome arimino part novv called romania next •• • omberdie vvas ••• diuiſion • de italy floud rubicon cee • lius metellus preciſe giueth occaſion aduantage enimie marius entreth rome appius claudius • eceyueth marius citie beyng mette togyther ordered theyr army floude tiber deuided thrée partes cinna carbo ouer agaynſte citie sertorius aboue marius towarde sea made bridge ouer riuer myghte kéepe victual citie marius tooke oſtia ſpoyled cinna ſente take arimeno army ſhoulde come nyghe fraunce conſuls afrayde hauyng néede army bycauſe coulde call home sylla béeyng entred aſia commaunded cecilius metellus aboute remnaunt fellowes warre againſte samnite ſhoulde diſpatche honeſtly coulde come helpe hys countrey inuaded ſtoode muche vpon termes wyth samnite whyche marius hearde graunted theyr demaundes ſo samnite ioyned marius appius claudius captayne kéeper hyll ianiculo walles hauing receyued good turne myndfull benefyte opened gate breake day ſo marius entred cinna followed ſoone repulſed octauius pompey came agaynſte marius repulſed chaunced ſo greate lyghtnings pompey deſtroyed lightning fell vpon pompey armye whereby manye noble menne deſtroyed marius kepte victual citie came sea aboue freſhe water hée rode nigh city anye corne layde antium novv 〈◊〉 aritia tenn • mile rome lanuuis • novv indouina marius keepeth victual rome vvay called appia vvent porta capena br ••• daſe paued vvith foureſquare ſtone mount albano nigh rome vvith lake vvhich propliecie vvent •• • unes victorie romayne ſtore ſuddayne comming antio aritia lanuuio hée tooke ſome city treaſon thus kéeping awaye victual lande alſo hée approched towarde rome boldly way called appia victualles coulde bée broughte anye place wyth cinna carbo sertorius camped twelue myles rome octauius craſſus metellus dyd lye agaynſte mount albano conſidering tyme come although ſuperioure ſtrength number yet hadde compaſſion putte theyr countrey hazarde one battayle cinna ſente trumpettes aboute citie proclayming libertie seruauntes whereby multitude fugitiues came vnto hym senate afrayde thereby doubtyng people bycauſe want thyngs citie chaunged theyr mynde ſente embaſſadoures cinna reconciliation hée aſked firſte whether came hym conſull priuate perſon doubted anſwere returned rome nowe many fréemen came vnto ſome faction ſome feare famine ſée ſequeale andreſort • 〈◊〉 nowe proudely approched walles camped within arrowe ſhotte octauius feare doubte ſlowe fighte bycauſe runnawayes ofte ſendyng betwéene senate greately amazed thoughte vniuſt depoſe lucius merula iupiters prieſte choſen cinnas place hadde offended béeyng oppreſſed wyth greate myſeries ſente cinna conſull looked greatethe senate ſendeth cinna conſull doubriull aunſvvere good thereby ſo requyred cinna ſweare hée woulde commytte murther hée reſuſed ſweare promiſed willinglye hée woulde bee cauſe manſlaughter hée wylled alſo octauius came gate ſhoulde gette hym away leaſt ſome diſpleaſure mighte done hym agaynſte hys wyll thys aunſwered hygh throne conſull embaſſadoures citie marius marius ſtandyng nexte senate ſilente hys cruell countenaunce perceyued bente murther senate accepted thys willed cinna marius enter well knowyng marius dyd cinna aſſented marius ſpake ieſtyng wyſe marius ſcorne •• lawfull baniſhed manne enter wherefore tribune dyd reuoke baniſhmente diſſolue decréethe banishment marius reuoked marius cinna giue oth octauius counſelled flee made againſte hym sylla entred citie wyth feare receyued made ſpoyle contrarye parte wythoute ſtoppe cinna marius ſente theyr othes octauius southſayers diuiners badde hym truſt hys friendes counſelled hym flée hée proteſting neuer leaue citie whyles héethe conſtancie octauius conſull wente among ianiculo noble men parte armye hée remayned ſate downe ſeate cladde robe rule wayted vpon wyth roddes ax conſulles wont cenſorinus cenſorinus commet • kill octauius contrary oth came agaynſte hym certayne horſemenne hys friendes perſwadyng hym flée hys armye bringing hym horſe woulde allowe ryſe abode deathe cenſorinus cutte hys heade octauius conſull headed broughte cinna fyrſte conſulles head ſette vppe common place head ſlayne ſet vp alſo marcus antonius orator fledde forme antonius orator bevvrayd vintner houſe kéeper whereof receyued gentlye hydde hym ſendyng seruaunte wyne tauerne oftner hée wonte tauerner aſked hym hée boughte wyne ſo ofte tolde hym ſecretely eare vintner ſente one ſtraighte marius opened matter whereof hée ſo glad mynded haue gone marius glad haue antonius killed kylled hym hymſelfe béeyng ſtayed friendes captayne bande appoynted ſente hys souldyoures houſe whome antonius béeyng ſo ſingulare orator dyd deteyne wyth ſwéete ſpéeches dyuers wayes mouyngeloquence pitie captayne maruellyng matter wente houſe founde attentiuely hearkenyng hys tale wherefore hymſelfe kylled hym yet eloquente ſpeakyng ſente hys head marius cornutus lying hydde cotage hys menne carefullye kepte cornutus ſaued seruauntes hym founde dead bodye whyche threwe fyre hadde made ſearchers came ſayde theyr maiſters bodye whome hadde fyrſte ſtrangled thus hée ſaued hys seruauntes q ancharius wayted marius ſhoulde make office whiche tooke without diſpleaſure cinna againſt catulus luctatius felow marius catulus luctatius▪ warre agaynſt gimbrians ſaued marius thought vnthankfull ſore agaynſt baniſhed kept cloſe pryſon till court day called iudgement muſt foure time cited certen diſtaunce houres merula meane time cut hys vaynes wryting made teſtifie layde prieſtly attyre cut merula dieth vaynes lawfull prieſt die vpon catulus choked himſelf chamber new made moyſty catulus dieth ſmoke thus two died bondman came cinna proclamation al made frée ſeruyng soldiours onely runne aboute ſpoyle euery houſe alſo ſlew whome ſoeuer mette ſparyng olde mayſters cinna many time moniſhe thē cinna killeth free made neuer better wherefore night reſt ſent ye french bandes killed euery one thus theſe flaues receyued worthy puniſhment theyr vnfaithfulneſſe agaynſt mayſters yeare folowyng cinna ſeconde tyme marius vij tyme choſen conſuls baniſhment proclamation man might kill token ſeuen egles appeared agayne vnto bent extremitie agaynſt sylla died firſte ikoneth marius dyeth ſeuēth cōſulſhip cinna tooke valerius flaccus hys place ſente aſia beyng dead alſo choſe carbo 〈◊〉 marius place dyeth aſia felow office sylla thynkyng long returne agaynſt hys enimies made ſhorte ende mithridates wée haue ſayde inactes sylla aſia thrée yeares complete deſtroyed one hundred thréeſcore thouſande menne reſtored romaine empyre graecia macedonia aſia ionia nation mithridates oppreſſed hée tooke hym hys nauie ſhutte hym within compaſſe father kyngdome hée returned arinie mightie obedient experte coragi • u theyr doyngs paſte brought alſo multitude ſhippes money furniture thyngs fitte whereby hée feared hys enimies cinna carbo beyng perplexed ſente diuerſe ouer ital •• prouide money menne victuall ryche menu theyr diligence sylla haughty harte wrote senate himſelfe ſhewyng hée done lybia treaſourer agaynſt iugurth kyng numidia agaynſt cimbrians cicelie admirall felowes warre conſull late affayres done agaynſt mithridates chiefly extolled rehearſing large infinite ſorte nation taken hym made ſubiecte romaynes notwithſtandyng sylla vvrighteth senate whiche bycauſe hée receyued certayne afficted gentleman rome baniſhed cinna comforted calamitie hée hys enimies proclaymed rebell hys countrey hys houſe pulled downe hys friendes ſlayne wyfe chyldren coulde ſcarcely ſaue themſelues flée vnto hym nowe woulde come au • nged whole cittie theyr doyngs citizen newe made woulde blame theſe letter redde euery man afrayd ſent embaſſadours treate attenement aduerſaries requyred aſſuraunce senate woulde fulfill commaunded cinnas officer leaue gathering mē till syllas aunſwere heard promiſed ſo embaſſadors gone made themſelues conſuls nexte yeare bycauſe woulde returne ſuddayne election wente aboute italy gathering men whiche ſente lyburnia ready intending ſette vpon sylla firſte wente dalmatis novv part slauonia proſperous iourney nexte beaten tempeſt ſo came lande returned euery man theyr countrey though woulde willingly ſerue agaynſtethe souldyers refuſed goe againſt countreymen citizen hearing thys refuſed ſayle lyburnia cinna diſpleaſed warned aſſemble mynding compell anger wente thynking reuenged one sergeantes makyng way cinna hitting one souldyers ouer legges army ſtroke sergeant agayne cinna commaunding taken made great ſhoute fell throwing ſtones next drew ſwordes kylled thus cinna conſul murthered carbo called frō cinna killed carbo afrayde goe rome lyburnia yt ſayled thither afraid theſe doings woulde returne rome albeit y• tribune earneſtly require come y• norbanum norbanus loſt vj men sylla lxx many moe wounded norbanus fledde capua sylla metellus theano lucius scipio came armye verye faintly deſired peace might made wyth sylla ſent scipio agrée vpon article ſo much hoping ſo good bycauſe thought army woulde rather reuolt reaſon diſcouragemēt yet met scipio tooke hoſtages agréemēts went came field thrée eyther ſide conferre ſo knowen dyd scipio thought good ſend sertorius norbanus felow ſignifie ſpoken army remaining quiet loking anſwere sertorius iourney tooke sweſſa towne ••• ſſa taken time treatie sertorius citie campania nigh mon • maſsico syllas sylla ſent meſſenger complaine scipio either priuie fact doubting anſwere thing fitte sertorius ſent hoſtages againe sylla army offended déede sertorius time treaty ſending againe ye hoſtages required layde al blame scipio con • ull betrayd army vpon conſuls priuily cōpacted reuolt sylla would draw néere al wēt vnto leauing scipio conſull lucius ſonne tente taken sylla thinke ſtrange thing farre vnfitte captayne ignorāt ſuch practiſe whole army whē sylla could perſuade scipio let ſonne goe without hurte ſent mē norbanus treate condition eyther bycauſe afraid ye force italy y• conſpired conſuls y• went deceiue done scipio man cōming anſwer bycauſe ſéemeth norbanus feared like blame army sylla marched toward waſting al thing enimie norbanus like toke wayes carbo made haſt citie proclaimed metellus gone sylla rebel time ye capitoll fire ſome iupiters temple capitoll fire ſay carboes worke conſuls ſome ſay sylla ſente certētie vnknowen could neuer learne way came sertorius choſē pretor iberia sertorius fleeth spayno deteined sweſſ • fled prouince former prefors receiuing cauſed romaine haue much army y• conſuls encreaſed euery day frō part italy hither ſide france aboute eridanus riuerriuer po • sylla idle ſente ſome euery place italy gote many loue ſome feare ſome money ſome hope thus reſt sommer conſumed yeare folowing paptrius carbo agayne marius floud aeſis frō morning tyl midday greate battaile fought betwixt metellus carinna one carbos pretor carinna loſing manye fled away ye countrey yéelded metellus forſe • ke conſuls carbo came vpō metellus beſeged til heard y• marius conſull great ouerthrow preneſte remoued cāp toward arimino y• rereward wherof ſet ••• neſte farre rome 〈◊〉 novv roman • se •• farre 〈◊〉 battayle betvveene sylla yong marius pompeius greately diſtreſſed sylla tooke sett • marius lodged nigh withdrew little little til come place called holy port ſet mē order gaue sylla battel y• fought fearcely til left wing great biſhop romaine theſe two ſlayne coūſell marius commanded domitius fléeing ſtrickē going sceuola ſlaine little ye senate houſe body caſt ye riuer vſe burie thē killed sylla ſent army ſeuerally diuers wayes rome willed thē take gate citie repulſed retyre oſtia city receiued thē came great feare opened gate whē would come whē came citie ſelfe opened gate pined wyth hunger oppreſſed deſperation preſente euils vre ſuffer mightier power whiche sylla hée knew came forward camp planted fielde sylla entreth rome mar gate entred contrarye faction fléeing citie goodes made common cauſed ſold trumpet called people counſell lamenting preſent time badde good chéere sylla people woulde ſet quiet bring common wealthe better eſtate whatſoeuer ſhould ordeyne ſhould cluſio vnder dominion sena vvhere porſena king tuſcane helde court spaniſh horſemen clani • clanius farre frō naples citie acerra beſt hauing thus diſpoſed matter leauing certayne friend garde citie went cluſio remnant reléeue carinna hoſt sylla vnderſtanding placed embuſhment paſſing deſtroyed two thouſand carinna darke nighte full rayne ſhowers although enimies perceyued cared foule tempeſt fiedde away carbo vnderſtanding marius fellowe diſtreſſed hunger preneſte commaunded martius goe thither eyght legion agaynſte whome pompeius lying awayte ſtraighte put iourney hauing killed many held beſéeged vpon hill vppon martius without companion fiers ſtill kept fledde away army laying blame deceyte vpon fell diuiſion one whole legion vnderthe • • olte li martius enſignes without anye commaundement marched samnite capuanus gutta leading ſeauenty thouſande men came deliuer marius ſéege sylla vnderſtanding kepte backe ſtreight muſt néedes paſſe marius vtterly voyde helpe withoute made forte playne large aboute twenty thouſand men whiche loſſe reſt returned owne countreys carinna martius damaſippus samnite met ſtreightes paſſe force could marched toward rome thinking voide men ſtrēgth lacke victual remoued wēt alone friend middeſt people multitude beholding amazed thing went home sylla ſuffereth yong man 〈◊〉 yong man reuiled bycauſe man forbid hée tooke courage giue euill lāguage til came houſe ſo ſo furious againſt greateſt men city could patiently ſuffer yong man thus hée ſaid entring houſe either natural reaſon diuinatiō thing come yong man let otherthe aunſvvere sylla man hauing syllas corpſe •• tter gold armed multitude followed al captaines lieutenāts ſerued vnder came po • p frō euery place armour came ſo ſet order multitude alſo repaired neuer bin ſeene buſineſſe vnderfunerall oration fauſtus ſonne vnder age field mars▪ none buryed king age nobleſt senate take litter beare fielde mar none wonte buryed king horſemen army marched aboute fyre while body conſumed senate fearingthe conſuls bound oth falling bind oth ſhoulde contende armes lepidus appointed lotte prouince france beyond alpes returne election lepidus refuſeth returne election bycauſe intended next yeare make warre vpon sillas faction without reſpect oth ſéemed fulfilled hys promiſe kéeping office purpoſe ſecreate senate ſent lepidus maketh vvarre ignorant called came al hys army though would haue entred rome therewith beyng forbidden proclaymed warre trumpet catulus ſide like long making aa battel betvvene conſuls lepidus ouercome dyeth sardinia ſea libya called sanda liotis bycauſe like • ole foote sertorius battel field mar lepidus ouercome without great chace fled sardinia beeyng vexed wyth conſuming diſeaſe dyed hys armye diſturbed ſundry partes diſſolued greateſt part perpenna led spaine sertorius laſte worke left sylla thys warre sertorius continuyng eyght yeares difficultie romaine agaynſte spaniardes one another againſte sertorius ruled sertorius occaſiō nevv vvarre iberia carbo sylla warre tooke citie sueſſa compoſition haue ſaid fled thence office leading wyth hym armye italian gathered celtiberians wyth whome hee expulſed officer sylla woulde admit hym fought valiantly metellus ſent againſt hym sylla couragious anye feate elected senate thrée hundred preſent friend called romaine sertorius maketh senate spayne senate diſpight whereof hee named choice counſell sylla dead hym lepidus sertorius hauing another army italian perpenna brought vnto pretor ofperpenna lepidus opinion able make warre vppon italy senate fearing ſente another armye another pretor whiche pompey army iberia pompey spayne yong gentleman renowmed ſeruice done vnder sylla libya italy paſſed alpes boldly way anniball ſo notablye rodanus roſne fraunce eridanus poo italy brake another way fountaines rodanus eridanus whiche floudes haue theyr ſprings far aſunder high alpes rodanus runneth frenchemen beyond alpes tirr • ne ſea within alpes flowing ionia ſtéede eridanus called padus come iberia sertorius ſtraight ouerthrowe one legion goyng foraging baggage ſlaues citie iuſtice vv •••• • 〈…〉 lau • one pompeius ſighte ſpoiled ouerthrew ſiege woman miſſuſed ſouldior courage beyonde nature hir kinde pulled hys eies sertorius vvhole bande put deathe hauing vnderſtanding chaunce putte death whole bād counted corrupted like thing though al romaine winter comming reſted spring pirenei mountaines diuide spaine frō irāce▪ luſitania portugall battel sura novve sucrone approching came forth metellus pompey frō mount pirinei sertorius perpenna luſitania met citie called sura giuing battell though horrible thunder y• clere aire maruellous lightning reaſon flaſh vpon thē yet expert ſouldiors without fear • kept y• fight made great murder one another til metellus metellus ouerthrovveth perpenna sertorius ouercōmeth pompey ouerthrown perpenna ſcattered men sertorius ouercome pompey hurt y• thigh darte eſcaped wyth much dāger end firſt battel sertorius white harte tame louing loſtea vvhite harte thinke battel vvas fought segobrida tovvne part spaine alſo segunti • novve called muruidero tooke euill token woulde come forth griefe thinking hart bin takē enimies ſcorned y• hart ſéene came running y• prouoked ſet vpō enimies made diuers light fightes shortly fought great battel sagūtia frō noone till night y• ouercame pompey battel mithridates y• eaſt rouers ouer al yt ſea ſtir creta tumult fēceplayers italy ſodain ſharp romains diuiding power purpoſe ſet ijtrouble legion iberia come metellus pompey remoued frō wintrings y• mount pirenei iberia sertorius perpenna came frō lu • itania time many fled frō sertorius metellus sertorius grieued hādled many sertorius remoueth romains guard perſon sertorius cruell cruelly barbarouſly wherby grew hate army rather yt remoued romains frō cuſtody hys body put celtiberians place could abide reproued vnfaithfulneſſe though ſerued ennimy rome thing chiefly grieued thē countedgriefe romains rebel coūtry ſake yet ſuſpected ther difference betwene fugitiue faithful celtiberians alſo vſed thē diſpitefully taunted vnfaithful notwithſtāding romains vtterly forſake himaragon bycauſe commodity valiāt fortunate captaine hee ſomuche celtiberians woulde call hym anniball hys promptneſſe moſte politicke forwarde capitayne coulde rehearſe sertorius compared anniball ſort ſtoode army sertorius metellus people daily moleſt city cōpell many yéelde vnto thē pompeius beſieged palantia wyth tymber made waye ſcale wall sertorius came reliefe remoued ſiege▪ pompey burned hys timber worke deſtroyed walles retyred metellus sertorius repaired citie ſpéedilye wēt toward calagyrus encoūtring thē yt lay killed 3000 theſe ye doings iberia yere yere following romaine capitaines greater courage ſet vpō city yt held sertorius tooke ſome thē ſought get pollicie vſing theyr whole force euery attēpt ye yere folowing came ſtronger field thing confidēce nowe sertorius sertorius decayeth began decay god againſt hym hee omitting law trauailes captain gaue himſelfe delicateneſſe womē feaſting drinking theſe cauſes many time ouercome falling fury rage euery trifle ſuſpected euery man wherefore perpēna y• faction aemilius perpe •• conſpiracie came vnto wt gret army begā doubt conſpired againſt wyth tenne béeyng diſcouered ſome hanged ſome eſcaped perpenna beeyng named maruellous good hap perſeuered rather hysdeath sertorius purpoſe deſired sertorius banquet although neuer wente withoute hys guarde yet ſeaſte little reſpect hee ouerladen wine perpenna cut heade place feaſted armye wyth great ire tumulte roſe againſte perpenna chaunging theyr hate loue capitaine though hadde u greate lykyng hym hee deade remembraunce vertue tourned mindes pitie thys preſentmiſerie cauſeth pitie caſe contemned perpenna priuate man thinking weale conſiſt sertorius could abideportugales perpenna luſitanes barbarian thought much whome sertorius chiefly vſed warre table teſtament vnſealed perpenna founde heyre euerye man hated hym bicauſe hee onely traytour hys capitayne hys friende benefactour hadde helde theyr handes perpenna hydde hymſelfe pleaſed ſome perpenna founde heyre sertorius gift ſome promiſe ſome made afrayde feare ſome ſharpely vſed terror common ſorte humbled himſelfe ſuche pryſon sertorius deliuered luſitanes reſtored pledge perpenna cruel wherfore content take captain honor sertorius yet without great difficultie cruell ſoone fel ſharpe puniſhing romaine came hym killed thrée nobleſt ſorte hys nephew metellus gone ſide office hee ſtrayghte coueted another clodius accuſed cicero hée hadde contrarie lawe putte 〈…〉 〈…〉 ▪ death lentulus cethegus senate giuen ſentence cicero matter vſed moſte noble courage nowe called anſwere verye fainte harted hee put mourning veſture ful wéeping ſorrowe humbled himſelfe met ſtreates beeing aſhamed trouble neuer knew ſo behauior ſo vnſéemely yt ſhould haue pitied laughed ſcorne ſo great fearfulneſſe one cauſe owne fallen yt life done moſt gloriouſly others euen ſay demoſthenes athes able anſweredemoſthenes cauſe condēned fled away clodius ſpite mock lowlineſſe mē abroad whereby brought deſperatiō alſo tooke volūtary baniſhmēt many friend going forth senate recommending city king prince clodius pulled downe hys clodius pulleth dovvn • 〈…〉 houſes citie country pleaſed hymſelf ſo well thys act would néeds compare pompey greateſt auctoritie citie wherfore called milo fellow clodie bolder man hee putting hym hope conſulſhip againſte fellow make decrée cicero returne ſuppoſing cicero woulde nowe deale matter action againſt clodie buſy hymſelf ſpeaking againſt preſente auctoritie thus cicero pompey caſte oute ſame called home ſixteenth moneth baniſhment hys houſe fermes builded common coſte receyued 〈…〉 great glory euerye man wayting hym gate ſpending one whole daye embracement welcom • euen hapned demoſthenes returne • r ••• meane tyme caeſar done milo pretencethe name milo pretence miſchiefe many dayes doe miſchiefe fire force senate feare aſſembled bent vpon pompei ſome would haue dictator bycauſe preſent time apeared haue néed remedy catos catos perſwaſion pompey cō ſull alone perſwaſion choſe conſull without felowe ſhould haue authoritye dictator ruling alone yet anſwerable bicauſe conſul y• firſt conſul two great prouinces armye money monarchie citie conſull alone cato appointed decrée go ciprus ſhoulde trouble pompey home put pto •• lomie kingdome former lawe made clodie taken pyrates pto •• lomie nigardiſe ſent two talent ranſome pto •• lomie heard thys decrée threw money ſea kylled hymſelf cato ſet country order pompey giue puniſhments many offence ſpecially pompey lavves againſt briberie bribery corruption thought y• common infection citie roſe thys therefore néede preſent medicine alſo decréed man would might cal men account firſt conſulſhip time twentie yeares caeſar conſul caeſars friendes ſuſpecting done pompeis ſouldiours wherby people ceaſſed scaurus alſo baniſhed al eriles recorded gabinius confiſcate baniſhment senate giuing open prayſe pompey appoynted two legion vnto continuāce prouinces pompey • father lavv accuſed memmius condemned briberie pompeius lawe giuing releaſe accuſed called l scipio father pompey putteth mo •• ning vv •• • lawe pompey like iudgement corruption wherefore pompey putting garment condemned ſort many iudges like memmius contempt pompey taketh ſelovve ſtate gaue ouer y• accuſation pompey hauing made direction belonged monarchi • toke scipio ſelowe reſt yeare hym though others receiued office neuertheleſſe ouerloked ruled rome goodsenate eſtemeth pompey wil senate much enclined deſpite caeſar conſulſhip ſéeking priuate pleaſure ſéemed make none accompt thē pompey quickly recouered ſicke cōmon wealth without moleſting h •• dring man furder office baniſhed menban ••••• 〈…〉 flye caeſar fledde ſtill caeſar bad beware pompey law corruption moſt made againſt caeſar comforte yet ſayde well pompey laboured •• tribune make lawe might lawfull caeſar aſke ſeconde conſulſhip hys abſence pompey beyng yet office reſiſtyng graunted yet vnderſtandyng senate worke againſt fearyng enemy would make pryuate man deuiſed kéepe ſtrength ſtill till ſhould declared conſul requeſted senate little longer tyme hys office fraunce leaſt parte marcellus marcellus conſull pompey agaynſt whiche tolde caeſar layde hys hande vpon hilte ſworde ſay anſweared thus ſhall gyue anſvvere caeſar he buylded newe como night vnto alpes priuiledges italie whiche ſo many officer yéere ſhall cittizens rome whiche greate prerogatiue italie one newe como thus borne office thereby thought frée rome marcellus deſpight caeſar diddiſpight marcellus beate roddes whiche romaine doe ſuffer formo cauſe rage bewraying harte bad take token hoſpitalitie goe ſhewe caeſar ſpight vſed marcellus perſwaded ſende ſucceſſours prouincesmarcellus time expyred pompey agaynſt vnder ſhewe conueniencie beneuolence pompey pretendeth regarde caeſar méete ſo noble man ſo many wayes profitable hys countrey ſhoulde thus maligned ſo ſhorte tyme decréed tyme caeſar ſhoulde gyue ouer hys rule caeſars chiefe enimies choſen conſuls aemilius paulus calidius marcellus couſin paulus c • vvon money former marcellus curio greate enimie caeſar elected tribune well beloued people great ſpeaker caeſar coulde winne claudius money paulus made hys friende hundered fiftye talentes ſhoulde neyther doe wyth hym againſt hym coſte win curio bycauſe ſo muche debt wyth money paulus builded publique place called paulus palaice one fayre workes rome curio ſhoulde 〈…〉 diſcouered change ſodaine required office making pauing many long high wayes ouerſéer ſame fiue yeares togither knowing ſhould obtaine none theſe truſting pompey friend would ſpeake againſt ſo haue ſome pretence againſt pōpey thing cōming paſſe indéed thought occaſiō offēce claudius propounded ſend ſucceſſours caeſars prouinces time hand paulus ſaid nothing curio ſeeming calidius 〈…〉 queſtion caeſar propoūded diſſēt frō praiſed claudius opinion agréeing ſaid meete pompey ſhoulde giue ouer prouince armye well caeſar ſo ſhould ſtate citie bée cleare feare bothe ſides many againſt right bicauſe pompey time yet expired curio thē ſhewed himſelfe plainely ſharply reaſon ſende ſucceſſours caeſar vnleſſe pompey giue ouer ſuſpitious one citie ſhoulde neuer haue ſure peace vnleſſe men priuate thus ſpake bicauſe knewe pompey would leaue power bycauſe ſaw offended hys iudgementes corruption thys opinion beyng honeſt people prayſed curio thethe people prayſeth curio man common weale cared neyther diſpleaſure brought home caſting floures vpon champion great difficult cauſe tyme nothyng ſéemed daungerous diſſent pompey 〈…〉 senate paſſing italy ſomewhat ſickely ſubtitlye ſente vnto senate prayſing caeſars actes rehearſing owne frō beginning thirde conſulſhippe giuen hym prouinces army accordingly ſéeke called beyng thought méete redreſſe common wealth quoth receiued vnwillingly doe willingly giue ouer haue time prefixed manner writing wrought good lyking pompey miſliking caeſar woulde giue ouer time ended pompey come citie ſpake muche effect promiſed giue ouer friend welwiller caeſar toke hand hée alſo would leaue glad mind yeares hauing taken greate paine army againſte moſt fierce nation wonne great honor countrey would ſéeke reſt office ſacrifices citie thus ſpake ſucceſſours might ſtraight ſent caeſar ſtanding vpon promiſe curio correcting ſutteltie ſayd curio againſte pompey ynough promiſe giue ouer déede caeſar ſhoulde put armye priuate ſtate neyther ſhoulde commodious mainteyne priuate e • mitie neyther romaine ſuche power ſhoulde one rather eyther woulde hurt citie ſhoulde haue reſiſt nowe holding longer openly reprooued pompey ſéeker tyrannie nowe gaue ouer hys army feare caeſar would giue ouer therfore thought good diſobeyed ſhould declared enimies army gathered againſt talke couered corrupted caeſar pompey gréeued pompey departeth angry threatning went angerly away ſuburbes senate ſuſpected thought pompey tractable caeſar miſliked bycauſe ſuſpition hissenate better liketh pompey conſulſhip therefore thinke ſafe diſſolue pompey power vnleſſe caeſar reſigne abroade aſpiring mind curio againſt expedient pompey caeſar alſo ſhould giue ouer could obteyne brake vp counſell leauyng owne beeyng vnderſtanded y• danger syria went winter capua ſente pompey caeſar tolde many hard tale againſte caeſar made pompey beléeue caeſars army waſted wéer • neſſe long payne deſirous come home come thys ſyde alpes would reuolte pompey thus talked eyther ignorance corrupted euery man ſurethe souldyers caſar 〈…〉 caeſar promptneſſe painefulneſſe continuance ſeruice gaynes grewe victory warre greate liberalitie caeſar himſelfe hée gaue fréely ſerue would haue knowing likewiſe abide pompey giuing credite theſe tale neyther gathered armye prouided ſo greate buſineſſe senate requyre euery man opinion claudius craſtely propounded dyd aſke diſioyntly whether woulde ſende ſucceſſors caeſar whether would pompey power ſhoulde taken 〈…〉 tation caeſar pompey many made denyall caeſar decréed mountaines alpes fiue thouſande footemen three hundred horſemē came rauenna cōfine italy end prouince receiuing curio great curteſie thanking trauayles conſulted preſent ſtate curio thought good ſende army march rome caeſar thought better yet treate reconciliation willed friend compound giuing ouerrequeſt caeſar prouinces army might onely reteyne two legion ill • ria france within alpes till declared conſull pompey thought ſufficient bycauſe cō ſuls reſiſt wrote senate curio running thrée dayes thrée thouſande three hundred furlong gaueafter accompt three hundred myles caeſars letter senate letter newe conſuls entryng senate houſe fyrſte daye newe yeare dyd conteyne ſolemne rehearſall caeſars doyngs begynnyng proteſtation leaue hys armye pompey dyd lyke béeyng yet authoritie pompey woulde gyue vppe woulde forthwith come reuenge hys countrey wyth ſpéede ſeeke hymſelfe whyche euer • e man cryed lucius domitius ſhoulde bée hys ſucceſſourl domitius warre proclaymed domitius went foure lately gathered antonius caſsius tribune curio determination againſt caeſar antonitus caſ •• tribune liking well determination senate earneſtly affirme army pompey theyr ſafetie caeſars deſtruction marcellus lentulus conſuls commaunded antony caſsius go aſſemblie leaſt vſing office tribune mighte happily haue ſome diſpleaſure antonie cryed aloude ranne frō ſeate rage lamēted yt ſhould deface office ſacred antenie lamenteth sanctuary reiect deſpighte gyuen counſell common weale hauing committed offence crime againſt man ſayde lept man inſpiration foreſpeaking warres murder attendures antonie prophecieth baniſhments ſpoyles miſchiefe come vppon proteſting greate execration cauſe curio caſsius went parte pompey army ſéene come beſette senate houſe ſecretely y• night putting ſeruants apparell went caeſar hired wagon caeſar ſhewed ſoone caeſar shevveth tribun • army come vnto army apparell ſtirre ſaid theſe men well made enimies perſons ſuche degrée ſpeaking ſomewhat thus villanouſly baniſhed nowe warre open ſides proclaymed euidently senate thinking caeſar would ſuddainely come army frō frē • h woulde enterpriſe ſo great feate ſo fewe appointed pompey 18 colony ayded romaine againſt annihall rubicon deuideth italy ouer vvhich paſſed armes vvas rebell caeſar ſtayd riuer rubicon ſaying caeſar caeſar entreth italy caeſar taketh arimeno feare caeſar table leauing friendes ſitting ſtill takyng coach ranne arimeno horſemen following certaine diſtāce poſting thus farre floud rubicon deuideth italie ſtayed courſe behelde riuer déepely waying mind miſchiefe might followe paſſed water armes turned friend ſayde refrayning paſſage ſhall beginnyng trouble ſelfe going ſhall vexe world thus ſaid man rapte furie hée flong ouer ſpeaking common word die caſt haſted arimeno tooke earely morning ſo wēt forward leauing garriſon conuenient place way wanne eyther violence gentleneſſe •• éeing renning away euery place muche feare remouing without reaſon caeſar followed domitius corfinio ſent ſu • • eſſoure hauyng aboue foure thouſande beſéeged citie perceyuing domitius woulde flée away kepte gate tooke hym broughte caeſas curteouſly receyued army yéeldyng vnto hym myghte bée encouraged ſame ſuffered domitius vntouched caeſar taketh 〈…〉 ••• eth h • ••• ie goe vvhere ••• wyth hys money ſubſtance goe would thynkyng gentleneſſe woulde haue tarryed durachians coper •• one • theyr countrey accompte hym founder denying dirrachos deſirous hercules bycauſe god ſaye thys fyghte ionius ſonne dirrachos ſlayne hercules chance hercules buryed hys body threwe sea myghte beare ioni •• • phrg •• • aſia •••• e name proceſſe time certaine phrigians gote citie countrey people illiria called ta • lantines whome another people illiria called liburnians •• lantines 〈…〉 na ••• wyth ſwift shyppes dyd ſpoyle theyr néereſt neighboures thys thought romaine call theyr ſwift ship liburnius wherewyth gyue fyrſte onſet fighte sea driuen dirrachio liburnians cor thucidides doth name ſo yet name hath preuayled itt •••• dides called dirrachium conſuls company came thys citie pompey abode brunduſe gathered togither theconſuls •• • ed • rizzo reſt army tarried shippes carried conſuls made towne ſtrong kéepe caeſar walles euening tyde ſayled hys company leauyng bo •• eſt souldyers defende towne whyche 〈…〉 alſo nyghte ſayled ouer wyth g ••• winde thus pompey armye lefte italy ſayled • piro caſar ſtoode doubt whyche way turne begyn warre ſeeyng well force euery ſyde flowed pompey feared army pompey spaine great expert leaſt while followed fléeing enimie ſhould beſet backehalfe therefore thoughte beſt trye fielde firſt theſe iberia deuided power fyue partes ſome lefte brunduſe ſome hidrunto ſome tarento • run luſe hydrunto novve •• r •• tarentum sardinia ••• •• pollio cato guieth place aſinius pollio garriſons italy ſente quintus valerius get sardinia ile plentiful corne gote aſinius pollio ſente cicelie cato lieutenant aſked hym whether authoritie senate people enter violently another man prouince aunſwered lord italy ſente cato aunſwered agayne bycauſe would ſpare inhabitance woulde deferre reuenge till another time ſo ſayled corcyra pompey caeſar came rome comforted people hope caeſar rome promiſes ſtricken feare memorie sylla marius euill time ſaid woulde vſe curteſie enimies taken lucius domitius let go money vnhurt brake locke common treaſure threatned death metellus tribune would caeſar taketh treaſure haue reſiſted tooke away money man dur •• touch layd vp againſt inuaſions france publike execratiō ſtirre remoue vnleſſe warre celtica caeſar ſayd haue ouercome thoſe frenche cel • e haue deliuered citie execration hée made emilius lepidus gouernoure citie marcus antonius •• antonius tribune italy confederate army abroade hée ſent sicilie curio ſuccéede cato quintus sardinia cneus antonius illiria france within alpes appoynted licinius craſſus commaunded two legion yong ſouldyers ready ſpéede lye coaſtes tuſcane venetian ſeas whome captaines ſea hée ſent hortenſius dolabella hortenſius dolabella caeſar spain afranius petreius herda citie aragon floud • ycor • caeſar hauing thus made italy ſtrong pompey enter went spayne firſte encountring afranius petreius lieutenantes pompey ſéemed weake ioyned togyther hande aboute citie •• erda caeſar lay barraine rockey place fayne fetch hys caeſar diſtreſſe victual paſſage riuer sypris ſodayne floud came bare away bridge whereby great number leſt ſtraytes ſlayne petreyus caeſar himſelfe hys army much moleſted harde place hunger ſharpe ſeaſon enimies ſo little better beſieged til ſommer came afranius petreyus went furder parte spaine gather another armye caeſar preuented ſtopping paſſage compelled thē retyre whence came thys compaſſed parte army came take vp grounde theira token yelding campe helde ſhieldes heades token yelding caeſar neyther toke hurt ſuffered caeſars gentleneſſe vntouched goe afranius ſuch meane wanne enimyes hart place hereof manye conuenticles among ſouldiers talke reconciliation whole multitude wherevppon ſéemed good afranius ſome leaue spaine caeſar depart ſafe pompey petreius agaynſte ranne among ſouldiours killed made thoſe petreius furious metings caeſar come killed one hys owne captaines alſo would haue ſtayed furye wherfore mindes inclined caeſar ſo gentle offended petreius ſo paſſionate caeſar kept water petreius neceſſitie came afranius parlée caeſar army beholdyng agréede leaue spayne caeſar ſhoulde conuey ſafe floud varus thence ſuffer goe pompey caeſar come floude called romaine italian ſouldiours thus ſpake vnto enemyes vſing name ſhall better declare minde neyther dyd dyſpatche ſente gette ground campe yelded ſelues neyther dyd hurt parte army whō helde water although petreius diſtray myne toke floud sic • rie haue thankes ſame ſhewe al ſerue pompey campe thus ſayd ſent fréely away appointed caeſar hath spayne quintus caſsius gouernement iberia thus caeſar began lybia actius varus lieuetenant pompey iuba actius varus iuba taketh pompey parte king mauritania aſſiſt curio ſayled againſt sicelie two whole legion twelue galleyes many ſhippes burden landing vtica ſkyrmiſhed wyth certayne numidian horſemen put flight would néedes called generall captaine army beyng yet imperator vvas terme latine ſuch generall entring armes honor giuen captaines name commeth souldiours witneſies worthy ſuch general thys honour captaines olde tyme obtained many great aftayres heare limitation thys title ouerthrowe tenne thouſande men while curio comming ſhippe sicelie lybia thinking glorye name would encampe place called scipio tentes scipio tent • e vvater poyſoned one emulatiō renoune poyſoned water deceyued hope curio lodged army ſicke drunk fight daſeled cloude heuyneſſe ſléepe head many curio armie infected vomites theyr meate ſhrincking ouer body wherefore curio remoued vtica ſelfe leading army féeble ſickeneſſe great ſtrong mariſh grounde heard caeſars victory spaine toke courage agayne placed themſelues nigh ſea ſteyght waye foughte fiercely curio looſing one man var • ſixe hūdred many moe wounded king iuba cōming forth 〈◊〉 falſe rumour rayſed floude bagrada farre returned backe bycauſe hys kyngdome inuaded hys neyghbours leauing hys licuetenaunt saburra wyth fewe floude curio gyuing credite thys tal • ſeruente heate thirde houre day led veſt parte armye againſt saburras ſandy deſerte drye place winter brooke dryedthe diſtreſſe curio vp heate ſunne floud kept saburra king himſelfe yet ſtill preſent curio ranne vp hill toppes choked thirſt heate enimies ſawe ſo euill beſtadde paſſed riuer boldely readineſſe fyght curio vnwiſely vnſkilfully wyth weake army compaſſed numidian horſemē came downe time gyuing place broughte menne within little compaſſe beyng ouercharged hée fledde agayne hyll toppes aſinius pollio beginnyng thys buſineſſe fewe fledde campe vtica leaſt varrus ſhoulde attempte thyng noyſe euill fortune curio made deſperate fighte killed curio killed ſo one left goe pollio vtica ende fighte floudde bagrada curio head cutte brought iuba miſchaunce knowne army vtica flamma admirall fledde hys nauie hée receyued flamma • lieth man lande aſinius tooke boate wente merchauntes porte prayed receyue hys armie conuey away nighte came warde thys purpoſe souldiours wente ſuche number ſome botes drowned vppon sea money merchauntes threwe ſame couetouſneſſecouetiſe merchant thereof happe vppon sea whiche littell better lande lefte nyght mornyng yéelded var • iuba came ſette wall ſhotte death remnaunt romaine souldiours shotte death hys victorie nothyng regarding though varo prayde hym contrarie thus romaine loſte twoo legion ſayled curio libia horſe miniſters venturer campe iuba returned home makyng boaſte hee done ſo greate feate hys friende pompey thys tyme antonius illyria ouercome octauius dalabella pompeyus lieuetenant another armye caeſars placentia reuolte againſte captaines cry holden long war payed fiue poundes caeſar promiſed brunduſe caeſar hearing came poſte maſsilia thus ſpake ſouldiours yet mutenie ſpéede vſe euery thing witneſſe wyth warre holden long v enymies flyeth v fraunce mine autoritye haue gayned wel haue bounde ſelues al 〈◊〉 ſeditious souldiours warre parte nowe myddeſt matter forſake doe doe diſobey captaines goe commaunde whome ought receyue commaū dement wherfore ſufficiente witneſſe ſelfe former affection vnto nowe vſe petreius law nineth legion whence tumulte chieflye aroſe wil put death tenth man greate lamentation made throughout whole legion wherefore theſe captaines knées prayed hym pardon hardly length graūted came anye 120 moſte buſie ſhoulde bee taken lotte twelue captaines bandes put death one twelue whiche preſente medler thys mutenye cauſed hys accuſer ſuffer hym ſorte ſedition placentia appeaſed caeſar went rome people feare choſe hym dictator neyther senate allowing none officer pronoūcing hee refuſing dignitye eyther odious ſuperfluous ruling onely eleuen dayes ſome ſay appointed conſuls reſte tyme hymſelfe seruilius iſauricus preſidents prouinces eyther appoynted altered hys pleaſure marcus lepidus spayne aulus albinus sicelie sardania sextus peduceus newe france decimus brutus people oppreſt famine gaue victualls requeſte pardoned al fugitiues except milo people deſiring alſo cutting debte bycauſe thynges bare price reaſon war ſeditions denyed appointed purueyors victualls whiche ſtéede debte ſhoulde take order betwene creditours ye debtore done ſente hys army brunduſe caeſar maketh vvinter vvarre deade winter himſelfe went forth december tarying election newe officer tyll newe yeare hand people followed prayed hym one pompey euident ouercame woulde ruler alone went lefte nothing done power ſpéede pompey al tyme made ship ſtill gathered greater army money tooke fortie caeſars ſhippes ionian ſea wayted cōming exerciſed people ryding running among euery labor beyond olde yeares whereby got much loue euery man came ſée pompey exerciſes ſpectacle caeſar tenne legion footemen ten thouſand french caeſars army horſemen pompey hadde fiue legion hée • alled oute pompey army italy many horſemen appointed two parthia remnant ſerued craſſus another part gabinius inuaded egipt italian eleuen legion ſeauen thouſande horſemen confederate ionia macedonia poloponeſo boeotia wyth archer creta ſlingers thracia vſe artillerie aboute pontus horſemen weaſte french ſome eaſt sirians ſent antiochus cilicians capadocians ſome armenia leſſe pamphilia piſida al ſight garriſons munition ſeruices ye italian army thus thoughte good vſe thē none italian ſhoulde drawne daye battell army land sea hée hadde ſyxe hundred gallies ſurniſhed ful whereof one hundred romaine conduct whyche hée appoynted leade many hulkes ſhips burden wyth dyuers admiralls whereof marcus bibulus chiefe al theſe thyngs prepared aſſembled many senatours romaine gentleman preſent pompey • os • • army place might harde thus ſaid vnto athenienſes alſo friend dydde leaue citiethe athenienſ •••• e citie • pe •••• ſiō 〈…〉 fighte libertye agaynſte ſpoyled thinkyng houſes men citie doyng whyche recouered againe ſhortly made mor • glorious progenitor likewiſe frenche cel ••• inuaded forſooke cittie cami •• u comming ardea ardea • 〈…〉 reſtore agayne wyſe men thynke countrey liberty whyche wée conſideryng haue ſayled hither leauyng oure countrey preparyng mn • lye defend againſte doeth violently • inuade corruption taketh italy deſolated haue declared enimy ſends preſidents prouinces appoynteth ſome gouernors citie ſom • countrey thys inſolencie hée hathe taken people authoritie doth yet contrition feare one god helpe ſhal bee puniſhed crueltie violence thinke ye wyll hée leaue vndone thus vſeth country get victorye▪ take parte mony gathered fraunce belongeth choſe rather bée ſlaue • liue frée v refuſe fight offer ſelfe ſouldior captaine wyl vſe mée haue experience war felicitie vnſpotted hitherto pray god graunte mée al preſent ſuch defender vnto country danger haue bin aduancing ſame wée oughte putte oure truſt god cauſe hath honeſt iuſt deſire war common wealth countrey abundance prouiſion ſea land whiche already haue ſhal haue take thing hand al nation man may ſay frō y• eaſt y• ruxine ſea al y• greciās barbarian v al king y• friend • romains haue ſente
