therfore neither hauing victuall prouiſion army called thē preſent aſſembly thus ſaid vnto 〈…〉 hys ſould • neither hardeneſſe tyme friend ioyne wyth mée moſte noble enterpriſe neyther delay others want conuenient preparation doe wythdrawexpedition purpoſe ſurely thinke expedition beſt way firſte go firſt matter ſeruants carriage baggage thinke beſte leaue behynde v ſhippes bee nowe may receiue v paſſengers deceiue oure ennimies ſette good fortune againſte euil tyme bold courage agaynſte ſmal number ennimies plenty againſt penury ſhall oure power wée thinke nothing ſhall winne force let v go therfore againſte ſlaues prouiſion victualles while houſes feare winter weather lette v goe while pompey truſts ſpende winter ſhewes ſacrifices conſull knowe take chiefeſteattempts ••• day •• point w hys cam •• thoughe wel aſſured youre good willes yet ꝭ tarry anſwere army cryed great vehemencie hee ſhould▪ leade forth came hys ſeate ſea fiue legion footemen ſixe hundred horſe men choſen lying anker bycauſe roughe ſeas winter sunne loweſt▪ winde kepte 〈…〉 •• ſ •• ved vveather hym backe agaynſte hys euill content tarryed •• brunduſe till firſt day newe yeare came •• hym two legion whome conueyed ouer winter •• hulkes hadde fewe gallies lefte cuſtody sicelie sardinia tempeſt driuen y• mount cer • uno whence ſent hys nauy backe fe ••• reſte hys army night went citie ori •• ori •• hard thinking better lefte behinde preſent reſt goe withoute feare enimie ſides taking theſe paynes pompey came firſte durazzo encamped walles pompey 〈…〉 •• durazzo caeſar▪ getteth agayne ori • alore floude nauie gote orico agayne gaue better guard sea caeſar lay ouer againſt pompey floud alore ſlowing betwéene diuers ſkirmiſhes paſſed floud▪ neuer broughte forthe whole power pompey trayne yong souldyers caeſar looked reſt brunduſe thoughte came forthe spring greate shippes could eſcape galley pompey ſcowred sea wayted come forthe winter enimie muſt many tymes take ilands harborough might themſelues defeate laſt great fight betwéene pompey hisa fight valiantly euerthrow caeſars souldioures followed thē fléeyng campe tooke many enſignes eagle chiefe standerd romaine much ado ſaued bearer regarde throwne caeſar repulſed trench fléeyng ſo notorious caeſar came another company whiche leſſe afrayde though pompey good way yet could abide ſighte ſtayfeare caeſars • n though hard camp neyther goe order obey caeſars commaundements euery one fledde whether hée could neuer looking backe without ſhame without commaundemente reaſon caeſar ranne rebuke ſhewe pompey farre beheld threw downe enſignes fledde muche adoe ſtoode ſtill men amazed looking ground ſhame ſuch confuſion fall vpon one turned enſigne thruſt poynt againſte generall killed caeſars gard yt went camp returne place left forſaken trenche vnkepte thoughte pompey come forth power made end warre ye one feate lauinius god ſo working perſuaded rather purſue fledde pompey victory ••• follovved ſomewhat ſlow himſelfe honored kyngs prince him▪ ſome lacke experience ſome fooliſhe hardyneſſe theyr victory durazzo ſome bycauſe greater number ſome bycauſe woulde r • ther haue ſhort concluſion honorable ende ſome bycauſe wéery warre exhorted fyghte ſhewyng caeſar dyd alwayes prouoke hym inuite hym dyd vſe reaſon againſt themſelues caeſar neceſſary ſo doe delay til occaſion muche better néede droue caeſar doe hée dyd beeyng ſtyll incenſed armye waxed proude victorye durazzo beſt ſorte obiected ambition vnto hym therefore purpoſe ſo ſlowe hée myghte beare rule ouer ſo many good pompey called agamemnon▪ hymſelfe therevppon called kyng agamemnon▪ bycauſe hée commaunded kynges warre hée left hys owne conſideration gaue place theires god ſtriking reſt warre grew pompey alteration ſickly ſlowe contrary nature thing vnwillingly prepared fighte owne deſtruction gaue hym counſell caeſar nyghte hadde ſente three legion gette victual thanking pompey delay thynking would haue changed hys minde alſo ſente aboute foode hearde pompey prepared battell knewe dyd neceſſitie dryuen force armye hée called hys armye forth wyth dyd prepare lykewyſe midnight made sacrifice mar venus hys aunceſſors iulius ••• petigree caeſar venus ſonne ſhoulde ſéeme name houſe iuli •• came vowed dedicate temple vnto hir rome ſhe fauoured hym broughte hym victorie lightning came heauen wente caeſars cam • lightning pompey extinct pompey ſyde thoughte ſome notable thyng ſhoulde come enimies caeſar dyd expounde ſhoulde quenche pompey glorye ſame nyghte pompey sacrifice hoſt fledde away coulde found ſwarme bées lightedtokens vpon aulter whyche little ſtinging flye • daye came ſtraunge feare campe th • whyche pompey came ſearche fell déepe ſléept béeyng awaked friendes hée tolde dream • dedicate temple rome venus victorice • pompey dreame knowyng caeſar hadde vowed ſame friendes hoſt put truſt theſe thinges glad vſed thinges muche contempte fierceneſſe ſo wente thys battayle though bin theyr owne many dyd decke tentes bayes token victorie ſeruauntes prepared good chéere ſome dyd contende caeſars officethe ſecuritie pompey army hygh prieſt pompey man experte warre dyd miſlike though troubled yet diſſemble helde peace doubt feare nowe dyd rule commaunded bycauſe force againſte hys wyll al thing great diſcouragement ſo noble man til day alwayes proſperous hap ſéemed ſodaine fall vppon hym eyther followed hée gaue good counſell pompey • l •••• tion driuen put liues ſo many hazarde owne glory kepte till day vnſpotted ſome diuination euil wyth feare hande day ſhoulde fall ſo great lordſhip onelye hys friend thus ſayde whoſoeuer victorye day ſhoulde cauſe great calamitie y• romains euer ſet order battell hys wordes hée ſpake feare many dyd gather wonne day would haue gyuen ouer rule number whereof manye ſpeake vncertainely caeſars number followe romaine authours write moſt pompey nūber reaſonably italian whome chiefe truſte regardyng ſpeakyng much confederate little affiaunce caeſar two twentye thouſande aboute thouſand horſe pompey double many ſeauen thouſand horſe ſo ſpeake likely ſay thys battel lxx italian write leſſe thréeſcore thouſand make moſte foure hundred thouſande whereof ſome ſaye pompey thrée part ſome thrée part two thus doubtfully haue left matter many ſoeuer chiefe truſt italian straungers caeſar french horſemen alſo french men beyond alpes grecian dolopians acarnians aetolians theſe helpes caeſar pompey al nation eaſte heap horſeconfederates pompey footemen grecian hadde lacedomonians diſtributed vnder owne kyngs reſte peloponeſians boetians athenienſes alſo came • • ••• ▪ ••••• ▪ thys warre althoughe ſides proclaymed ſhoulde • hurte ſacred men lawe maker drawn thither glory battayle wherein ſhould fyghte empire romaine greek fewe ſea towarde eaſt inhabitours came pompey thracian helleſpontians bithinians phrygian jonians lydian pamphilians pyſidianes paphlagonians cilicians syrian pheniteans nation hebrewes arabian alſo mgh vnto theſe cyprian rhodians ſtingers creta ilanders kyngs prince alſo came ayde hym de • ota • u tetrarche 〈…〉 ariarathes 〈…〉 eaſte galatian ariarathes king capadocia armenian wythin euphrates taxiles leade armenian beyonde euphrates magabates lieutenaunte artapa 〈…〉 kyng inferiour lordes reſorted thys trauayle beſide thréeſcore ſhippes egipt ſente prince ſame cleopatra hir brother yet childe theſe notcleopatra vſed warres anye ſhippes laye ydely corcyra wherein ſéemeth pompey euill neglect 〈…〉 ſo great nauy wherewyth hée myghte haue •• feated hys enimies al thynges truſted vpon hys armye land woulde trye wyth theyr continuaunce wyth long experience full courage ſauage people gréedy fight beware miſhap god workyng durazzo ſéemeth bée impediment caeſar fitteſte opportunitie pompey army waxed inſolent made little accompte capitayne tooke hande thys matter verye vnſkilfully god hadde ſo appoynted ſhoulde come ſuche ſtate nowe ouer eyther aſſemblyng theyr armyes exhorted firſte pompey ſaid thus fellow souldioures commaunde captaynes 〈…〉 〈…〉 obey souldiours wheras would haue conſumed caeſar wyl néedes call vpon fyghte therfore appoynters battayle vſe may leſſe vanquiſhers contemne vanquiſhed yong deſpiſe olde luſty may féeble haue youre ſyde power preparation conſcience cauſe trauaile libertye country law good opinion ſuch men bée senatours gentleman agaynſte one man woulde vſurpe gouernment go therfore becommeth good hope haue ſight fléeing away made durazzo howe many enſignes tooke day ſaide pompey caeſar hys men ſpake thus hardeſt friend haue ouercome ſteade caeſars oratic • hunger wante fight wyth men day determineth remember promiſe durazzo ſware one another preſence woulde returne victor theſe souldioures whome wée haue followed pillers hercules theſe bée fledde v italy theſe oure tenne yeares ſeruice ſo many enimies victory harde bée tolde wonne v spayne fraunce britaine broughte v oure countrey well nighe fourtye realmes doth oppreſſe v without rewarde triumphe recempence theſe whome coulde perſwade deſiring ryghte wel thought well knowe whome delyuered vnhurte hoping might haue ſome iuſtice handes theſe togither reuengers thys day euen knowe carefulneſſe faithfulneſſe frée liberalitie harde matter yong ſouldiours vnexperte ouercome paine haue paſt well bin tried proofe se youthfull contempte dyſ • ayne armye agaynſte capitayne ſo diſtruſte hymſelfe whome certainlye knowe goe thys feate vnwilling minde ful feare fallyng hys condition giuen caſe ſlouthfulneſſe nowe ruler ouerruled thus much thinke haue ſpoken vnto italian cōfeder • t care make accempte offer anye earneſte fyghte ſlaues syria phrygia lydia euer ready run away kept vnder certayn • ye knowe ſhall euidently ſée pompey wyll vſe ordered place oſbatta • le •• ye haue • • italian confederate ru •• e vppon like r • • • ggs downe ſpare youre •••• men vſe confederats afray al thing remember maye▪ ſée perſourme haue promiſed▪ maye chooſe eyther victorye • eathe pull downe youre campe trench wee may haue nothing vnleſſe wée wynne lette oure enimies ſee without campe neceſſitie wee muſte encampe theyrs thus ſaide hée ſente oute two thouſande verye olde souldiors charge campe wit forthe digged downe trenche wyth déepe ſilence filled ditch pompey ſawe ſome thoughte made way flée perceyued bolde determination ſyghe pompey ſigheth ſayde vnto hymſelfe thys fyght ſhould wild beaſts oppreſſed famin fit medicine thē dallying thing come ſwordes pointe therefore ſet aboute foure thouſande kéepe campe pla • ed reſte betwéene caeſar enimies ſeyng brought agaynſt beſte horſemen beyng number ſhoulde might encompaſſe caeſar perceyued layd thrée thouſand boldeſt footemen abuſhment whome willed ſawe enimie goyng aboute encloſe ſhoulde leape forth pike driue harde could face knew yong vnexpert would abyde peril face thus deniſe bothe ſides went euery place gyuen order exhorted good hart gaue wordes knowledge caeſar venus conquereſſe pompey hercules vnconquered ready ſtoode good whyle great ſilēce ſtirred looked one vpō amazed men ſhoulde beginne fight multitude hytherto compaſſion pitied ſo greate armie italian ſhould hazarded vertue ſhoulde bée tried vpon themſelues chiefe hurte italian aſtonishment bothe army aga • nſt italian pynche miſchiefe hande deſire glory •• ſed blinded quenched conuerted feare reaſon dyd throughly way affection fame meaſured alſo daunger preſent ſawe cauſe conſiſted contentiō two men whoſe ſuperioritie liues ventured ſo whither euercome coulde ſafe furdeſt place great multitude noble men theyr ſakes remembred auncient friendſhip affinitie howe many thing done owne honour aduancement weare weapōs againſt thēſelues brought ſerue like miſchiefe one nation citizen kin • cmen ally yea ſome brother ſo hapned warre among ſo many thouſands togither one nation diuerſe ſtraunge effectesthe ſtrange abashment ſides muſt happe whiche eyther nowe conſidering ſtriken preſently great repentaunce though day ſhould eyther firſt laſt vpon earth loth beginne ſo doubtful déede fell wéeping ſides standing thus beholding one another daye paſſed italian ſtanding due order ſilence continued pompey perceyuing ſtraungers troubled ſtay doubting leaſt confuſion might follow therof beginning firſt gaue token battayle caeſar like trumpet ſtroke ſounde battayle required ſuch number beſide ſundry part herald captaines hand giue encouragement marched ſtately aſtoniſhment ſilence men ben many like paſtimes hand firſt charge wasthe • nſet giuē giuen archer artillery ſoden onſets horſemen encloſe footemen fro til pompey horſemen hauing better enuiron tenth legion caeſar giuing token lay wayte ſtepped forth againſt horſemen theyr pykes put vp lay face could abyde boldneſſe blowes made theyr mouthes eye confuſedly fled away caeſars horſemen encloſe footemen naked whiche feared haue bene encloſed themſelues whē pompey percepued thys commaunded footemen moue grones fell valiauntlye theyr place appointed confederate though come ſee fight pryſe maruel goedly order harte wondering neyther enter caeſars campe kept fewe olde men thing ſtande gaze lefte wing could italian army perceyuing worſe gaue backe firſt order defending themſelues might enemye ſtill comming vpon hauing victorie alſo turned fle • caeſar vſed great policie y• ſhould gather togither made courſe parthia thinking recouer al againe keping purpoſe cloſe frō friend tyll came much ado ciluia prayed hym cornelia pompeis vvife craſſus daughter beware parthian whiche lately ouercome craſſus whereby inſolent fit bring cornelia ſo fayre woman among ſo vntemperate people eſpecially craſſus daughter thē deuiſed whither ſhould go egipt iuba king barbarie thought good iuba therfore counſelled go egipt nation nygh great dominion fertyl aboundant grayne money nauye whoſe king though child yet friend father ſake ſo cauſe ſayled egipt time cleopatra eiected kingdome hir brother wt fortune wold pompey driuē thither perceiued army aland ſtayed ſhip thought déede king hée ſent vnto ſhewe amity betwéene hys father king thirtéene yeare olde one achillas gouerne army photinus cnuch recreatyng hys wearye armye made theſſalians frée ſerued pardoned athenian ſute vſing theſe wordes howe often hath glorie aunceſtours ſaued whē haue deſerued deſtruction third day remoued towarde eaſt following fame pompeis flighte wante gallies ſayled ouer helleſpont little boates 〈…〉 novve 〈…〉 〈…〉 theſe 〈…〉 europe 〈…〉 covvarde caſsius number gallies met going pharnaces although might gallies haue aduantage thoſe little boates yet feare caeſars felicitie valiantneſſe amazed ſuſpecting caeſar come purpoſe finde helde vp handes came gallies boates aſke hym pardō deliuer gallies much force glorye caeſars felicitie ſée none reaſon iudge meane ſo great difficultie time haue ſuch fortune ſhould ſo afray caſsius valiaunt man comming vppon ſcauent • e gallies vtterly vnprouided durſte medle inhabite greate cherroneſo one name called aſia y• lower forgaue caeſar ſay • e • h egipt ſent embaſſadours craue underſtanding pompey gone egipt went rhodes would tarry reſte armye comming part gallies caſsius rhodes ſuch men preſently hadde toke ſhippe night ſayled forth ſhewing whether commaunding captaines night follow light ſhippe day flag ſame maiſter whereof commaunded ſayled good way ſet courſe toward alexandria ſo thrée day vpon ſea came thither thys place wel receiued king officer king yet mount gaſsius caeſar comming pretended haue nothing ado bycauſe fewe men went citie extant caeſar vve •• vvhen ſee pompey heade cleopatra bin nine moneths ſayled vppon nilus foure hundred ſhippes company cleopatra whoſe pleaſure many thing whiche particularly tolde booke egiptian matter could abide behold pompey heade brought vnto commanded buryed alſo builded little temple citie called temple reuengementtemple reuengement▪ traiane tyme traiane emperoure make warre againſt jewes pulled downe ſerue ſome turne warre caeſar done theſe thing alexandria wente wyth hys army thoroughe syrta againſte pharnace bin caeſar againſte pharnace domitius ouer▪ throvvne • yr • amyſſo citie confines paphlagoma capadocia buſy taken diuerſe romaine prouinces gotten one victory domitius lieutenante caeſar growing ſtoute tooke amyſo citie pontus allied romaine people whereof ſolde ſlaues made child enuchs caeſar came fled farre coulde ſent caeſar peace hys ambaſſadors brought crowne golde offered fooliſhlye kyngs daughter marryage hym perceyuing preſentes meſſages wente wyth army entertayning king ambaſſadors ordinary talke till came nighe encamped ſaid ſhall murtherer father bée yet killed leaped horſe firſt charge pharnace fled awaye caeſar ouerthrewe moſte parte thouſand horſemen firſte kéepe chaſe hym thys caeſar ſaide loude voice happy pompey haddeſt ſuch mē war mithridates man father therby thought called great fight hée ••• vid • vici •• ſp • • part kingdome p •• • ſent thus rome came ſawe conquered pharnace content go kingdome boſphorus caeſar appoynted caeſar ſpent time trifle ſo many battels yet remayning behinde went aſia waye gathered money city troubled wyth tooke paymentes tribute haue ſhewed booke aſia word brought hym ſedition rayſed rome • editiō rome antony lieutenāt kéep common place wyth army therefore ſetting thinges aſide hée made haſte rome whither come ciuill diſcorde ceaſſedsedition caeſars army another began among ſouldiours bycauſe yet neyther receiued promiſe made theyr ſeruice pharſalo reaſō ſhoulde ſtill kept war therfore cried euery man go home promiſed thē reward pharſalo rewardes war libya drac • p ••• e coyne vvaying muche ſterl • ng groat eight groates ovvnce saluſtius danger ſhould ended therfore ſent thouſand drammes apéece promiſe bad promiſe pay al hand lacked little killed criſpus saluſtius ſhifted away caeſar hearde commanded legion antony guarde citie kéepe aboute houſe entry citie fearing ſpoile hée verye boldly men fearing diſwading rage ſouldiors went among mutinie field mar caeſar among ſeditious ſouldioures perceyued ſet high ſeate confuſedly tumulte came running vnarmed maner ſalute generall commeth firſte among commaunded thē thing ſay touching gift ſhoulde ſpeake face while hee preſent durſte ſpeake word feare taking caeſar vvſ • • •• n • ••• • ting sould • • meane way cryed releaſed war hoping bycauſe • e néede men finiſh reſt war would haue ſaide ſomewhat giftes contrarie opinion without ſtay anſwered diſcharge aſt • med hereat ſtanding great ſilence ſaide againe wil giue haue promiſed ſhall triumphe •• reſt word vnlooked appearing ſo curteous ſtrike ſuche conſideratiō emulation thoughte ſhame forſake capitaine middes enimies others ſhoulde triumph place theysouldioures repent remembred loſſe ſhould haue leauing warre libya thought enimies aſwell caeſar hys aduerſaries doubt remained ſilent feare hoping yet caeſar woulde haue giuen rewarde forgyuen faulte hys preſent néede ſate ſilent therefore hys friend wiſhed ſay ſomwhat vnto leaue ſo oft ſerued hym ſo ſhorte ſeuere ſpéech began ſpeake call thē citizen ſtead ſouldiers token diſcharged y• war become former priuate caſe could ſuffer cryed repent prayed mighte taken war caeſar refuſed came ſeate made greater inſtaunce beſéeching hym hadde done amiſſe puniſhe ſtayed neither going forward backewarde ſéeming doubt yet hée returned ſayde hée woulde puniſhe none grieued tenth legion whiche alwaies loued honored ſhoulde giue cauſe ſuche tumulte onely thys ſaide releaſe ſeruice yet wyll gyue haue promiſed come libya giue lande warres ſhall ended sylla dydde ſpoyling hadde cauſing taker loſer liue togither maintayne perpetuall enmitye wyll diuide bothe common mine lacke wyl buy mony showte reioyce made ſauing tenthe legion againſt whiche caeſar ſeemed inexorable thereforethe tenth legiō deſireth bee punished deſired hym might bée puniſhed death lotte ſhoulde fall hauing néede cato kept part army bothe ſea lande v •• ca wyth thrée hundred whiche lyke chiefe counſellers greateſt doer war called senate generall lucius scipio beſt laye adrumeto therfore ſayled againſt scipio came luſtily vpon vpbrayded fearefulnes rebuke caeſar could ſuffer made order battell corduba worde venus pompey pietie ſhoulde goe fearefeare caeſars army vvrighte fight vvas giuen monda vvhich novv muſte pleaſed ſo great loue honour caeſar vſe hym ſome compted hys ſon bicauſe loued wel seruilia catos ſiſter brutus mother therfore got victory pharſalo hée gaue greate caeſars care brutus charge hys captayns wiſe ſhould ſaue brutus brutus either ingrate man ignorant mother faulte diſtruſtfull aſhamed deſirous coūtrys libertie preferring thing deſcended auntient brutus droue king incenſed rebuked people manye thing written vppon image olde brutus inbrutus courte hall brutus ſecretly ſet vp brutus thou takeſt rewardes brutus thou arte dead brutus woulde thou aliue nowe brutus vnworthy poſterity haſt thou brutus thou arte come hym theſe many lyke inflame yong man mind take worke hande progenitor ſame making king ſtill encreaſe woulde counſell little caſsius tooke brutus hand ſayd hée hearte wente calphurnia ſaide onelye thys bycauſe matter touched caeſar much would tarry til came senate knew al wrought againſt one artemidorus hoſte guido ranne vnto counſell houſe found hym newe ſlaine anothera booke conſpiracie booke conſpiracie deliuered made haſte senate whiche founde againe hys hande hée dead came litter laen • wiſhed wel caſſius came vnto hym talked verye earneſtlye wyth ſight wherof trouble thē length thefeare cō ſpiratoures talke made winke one another diſpatche themſelues ſhould taken perceyuing manner laena liker ſpeake himſelfe make ſupplication bewray ſtayed ende ſaw hym giue humble thankes encouraged againe cuſtome ruler citie ſhoulde ſacrificesacrifices went senate agayne caeſars firſte ſacrifice harte ſome ſay heade entrailes whē diuinor ſaid ſigne death caeſar contem▪ neth ſacrifi • e •• il luck hée ſmiled ſayde ſo spaine ouerthrewe pompey diuinor aunſwering perill indéede nowe token manifeſt caeſar bad hym ſacrifice againe nothing appearing better aſhamed y• made y• senate tarry hym haſtned enmies though bin fri • d diſpight enimies went muſt needes come determined left trebonius entertaine antony without dores caeſar ſ ••• hys ſeate ſtoode aboute hys friend weapon hid firſt attilius cymber ſtoodt •••• u made ſute hys brother returne baniſhed caeſar againſt vtterly denying hée tooke hym purple robe would haue made ſute rufdedthe 〈…〉 garment pulled ouer necke cry ſtaye friēds caſca came ouer head firſt thruſt dagger throat miſſing hit y• breaſt caeſar twitching gown frō cimbro catching caſca y• hand flung frō ſeate great violēce layd hold vpon caſca while wreſtling another ſtroke caeſar giue •• ouer vvhe • brutus ••• ken •• ſome vvrite ſayd vvhat thou ••• ſonne ſide laye open caſsius hurte face brutus thyghe bucolinus betwéene ſhoulders yet caeſar rage reare like wilde beaſte ſtepped euery thē brutus hurt thoughe hée diſpaired wrapte himſelf gowne fell comely picture pompey downe vſed ſuch deſpite gaue three twentie woundes many ſo haſtie hurte one another act done theſe murderer ſacred place vpon ſacred inuiolate man fléeing senate houſe citie inconfuſion tumulte ſome senatours hurt men killed muche ſlaughter done citizen ſtraugers purpoſe happeneth ſuch ciuill ſtir one commeth vpō another ignorauntly ſworde player bene armour morning ſhewe certaine playes ranne game place barres senate houſe people came playes driuen feare fledde away ſhoppes ſpoyled al dores ſhutte preparation made defence houſeantony toppes antony went owne houſe entending take aduice caſe caeſars lepidus captaine diſcharged warfare appointed habitation ſome bin dwelling place come go iourney wyth caeſar afrayde alſo lepidus army citie antony conſull leaſte would vſe people leauing senate worke ſome diſpleaſure corne poore brought yt idle néedie vacabonds italy rome nūber olde worne ſouldiers wage deuided coūtries wer wont ſeuerally bicauſe ſome ſerued vniuſt war would go cōmon habitationsmaiſterle •• men take men land houſes remayning togither tēples cōmon place vnder one bāner one chiefe yt might apoint thē prouince ſelling away redy go ſone bought reward therfore hard caſsius gather nūber ſuch men bring ye cōmon place albeit hired yet durſt prayſe yt done feare caeſars glory others deuotion ye cōmon welth ſake cried peace earneſtly exhorted ruler vnto thys deuiſe kyllers worke theyr owne ſafetye coulde bée peace vnleſſe forgetting ſtandyng theſe termes cynna pretor kinſemanne maryage caeſar cynna accuſeth caeſar • beyonde opinion came among hauing hys veſture office threw giuen tiran called caeſar tiranne kylled hym killer tiranne prayſed facte moſte like progenitours thoſe men called capitoll honoured dew rewardes cinna ſayde ſéeing vncorrupted people myxte wyth call capitol anye thing elſe onely exhorted peace dolabella yongdolabella man noble appointed conſull caeſar ben gone reſte yeare hauing garment conſul mace office ſecond ſpake euill pretended priuie deuiſe ſorte hand ſome ſaye hee decréed daye ſhoulde honoured byrth day citie hyred men toke harte ſaw pretor conſul forgiue called caſsius reſt temple glad dolabella yong noble man conſul moſt méete match •••••• caſſius people antony came downe caſsius marcus brutus bloudy hand ſtriuē ſhould giue caeſ • r moſte woundes amiddeſt people ſpake nothing humbly noble euident thing one prayſed another calling citie bleſſed attributing muche decimus ſo fitte time bad ſerued ſwordplayers ſtirred people woulde thing worthy aunceſtours whiche expelled king reigning violence caeſar choſen lawfully alſo propoūded sextus pompey ſonne pompey greate hadde made warre agaynſte caeſar common wealth myght called home beyng yet armes spayne againſte caeſars captaines lykewyſe c • ſetius marul •• depriued baniſhed caeſar tribune people hadde thus ſayde wente vppe againe capitoll dyd truſte verye muche multitude friendes kinſfolke might repaire vnto temple choſe moſt auntient ſend lepidus antony reconciliation 〈…〉 regarde libertie ſaue countrey euils might growe vnleſſe foreſeene much meſſengers require prayſing ye thing done durſt caeſars friend deſired haue borne worthyneſſe doer hate loue countrey pitie citie nowe conſumed continuall ſedition whiche one would vtterly deſtroy good men ſame right hate amongſt ſhoulde worke publike deſtruction rather publike commodity priuate enmity mighte wiped away antonius lepidus ſayde minded reuenge caeſars deathe eyther friendſhips ſake orthe deuice antony lepidus practiſe betwéene deſire rule thynkyng thing would eaſier ſuch notable men might ridde way yet feared friendes theyr kinſfolkes senate enclined moſt decimus whome caeſar hadde appoynted gouerne france theyr neyghboure whereby hadde mighty armye therfore thought beſt tarry better occaſion deuiſe gette decimus army ſo valiant expert laboures neuer left hauing fetch antony thus aunſwered meſſengers priuate diſpleaſure worke nothing antonyes aunſvvere offence matter wherein ſworne caeſar bée kéepers body defend againſt violence requiſite oth follow fact done rather lyue pure daunger thoſe execration yet honor opinion debate senate houſe take way citie common conſent ſhall ſéeme good thus antony aunſwered ſafelye gaue thankes departed ſure hope al ſhould haue gone well senate woulde haue fauoured cauſe throughly▪ antony meane time cauſed officer make watche citie nighte turne kéepe ſeates wante daye haue fire ouer citie meane whereof friend ye offendoures went euery senatoures houſe requeſted themſelues countreys common wealth ranne abroade alſo captaynes ſuche ſhould haue habitation threatning miſchiefe vnleſſe ſome performe lāds place giuen promiſed ſincere ſort citie tooke good hearte perceiuing ſmal number theſe doer enclyned memorie caeſar diuers opinion caeſars money bookes doings carryed antonie caſars money vv • itings ſent antony eyther bycauſe calphurnie danger hir houſe ſend antony ſurer antony ſo commaund done decrée made antony nighte call senate daye temple goddeſſe earth farre owne houſe neyther durſt goe tothe senate temple god earth senate houſe capitoll bycauſe ſworde player gathered bring armye towne troubling notwithſtanding lepidus brought day drawing nigh senatoures came y• temple y• goddeſſe earth cinna pretor hauing agayne garmēt day throwen giuen tyrant made haſt thither whome parte vncorrupted people parte caeſars souldioures ſawe béeyng rage bycauſe daye firſte openly ſpake euill caeſar béeyng hys kinſman threwe ſtones hym anda tault againſt 〈◊〉 droue hym houſe gote woodde haue burned lepidus come army forbydden firſte token whereby caeſars friendes hadde confidence conſpiratoures hyred fellowes afrayde senate houſe fewe pure violence contention moſt parte diuers deuice fauoured manquellers thoughte moſt worthye truſt common conſultation offender make judge whiche antony dyd lette bycauſe knewe woulde come dyd indéede 〈◊〉 〈…〉 ing 〈◊〉 tryall senate ſome earneſtly playnely prayſed facte namyng tyrantkyllers wylled ſhoulde rewarded denyed reward themſelues deſiring hauyng done intente thoughte iuſt ſhould commēded welldoers would allow commendation onely thoughte ynough forgyuen thus deuiſe forecaſt firſte senate woulde encline little little myghte eaſier obteyne reſt vncorrupted company abhorre acte wicked yet reuerence great houſes againſte ſhoulde ſaued yet ſhould honored well doer coulde abide ſpake againſte conuenient ſo haue reſt belōged ſafety ſhuld bée enuyed one ſayde theyr honour ſhoulde bée caeſars diſhonoure aunſwered fytte dead man ſhoulde bée preferred quicke another vehemently ſaying two thing one muſt choſen eyther declar • caeſar tyrante forgiue theſe mercy tooke hold required voyces mighte tryed caeſar oth decrées made neceſſitie ſhoulde preiudice whyles ruled dyd nothyng fréely feare themſelues pompey béeyng ſlayne wyth hym manye thouſande antony markyng thyngs deceytefully perceyuing ample euidente matter ſpéeches offered determined turne theyr cogitation wyth antony▪ •• tte •••• priuate care feare themſelues vnderſtandyng greate parte theſe senatoures appoynted office prieſtehoodes citie gouernements armyes prouinces caeſar tyme come hée ſhoulde bée long foorthe wyth hys armye ſpace fyue yeares commaundyng ſilence conſull thus ſayde woulde haue boyces tryed vpon caeſar muſt know antony • ••• • afore ruled officer lawfully choſen hys actes decrées muſt ſtande force violence wée thinke playd tyrant muſt body caſt y• citie vnburyed actes reuoked wherfore ſée muſt medle wt y• world ſea land many ſuch though would obey v ſhall declare héereafter apperteyneth v alone matter toucheth v put thing eaſ • e platte may ſee ſhew harder thing manner haue borne office vnder caeſar yet doe beare choſen made ſome haue office time come lotte fals know appoynted fiue yeares yearely office citie regimentes countreys army willingly forgoe power would haue firſt determine procéede thus antony kindle fire caeſar themſelues helde peace throng ſhoutes ſtarte vp denyed triall ſhoulde made voyces people thing appoynted ſhould aſſuredly holden ſome vnder age mighte finde reſiſtance election whome chiefly ſtirred whome dolabella conſull one whome lawful conſul election bycauſe fiue twenty yeares age wherefore ſhewed ſuddayne mutation pretended daye rebuking dolabella changed many thought conſpiratours worthy honor office ſhould diſhonored making ſecuritie haue better ſhew put dolabella • eſt hope ſhoulde rece • ue thankes people ſtraight reſume dignity without alteration officer ſhewe lawfuller way common election ſhoulde ornament aduanced well authoritie people appoyntmente one ruler ſooner ſpoken ſome officer deceyue put robe rece •• e ſame agayne lawfully perceyued craft thinke get election already matter ſtanding thus antony lepidus wente senate houſe certaine came running multitude call ſéene aboue ſilēce hardly put made much noyſe one cryed vnto whether owne minde ſuborned bade take héed leaſt ſuffered like antony loſinga nevv ſt • rr • antony gowne ſhewed curet incenſing looker though man coulde ſafe vnleſſe ware armoure conſull ſome cryed fact might puniſhed made requeſt peace thus ſayd conſider ſhall fitte may auayle ſuretie hard found ſince neyther oth execration could profit caeſar called reuenge turned commended carefull othes honeſtie would quoth youre captayne crye conſul whome belongeth rather ſpeake profite iuſtice ſo doe within perſuade v ſo caeſar himſelfe profite citie ſparing hadde taken warre ſame deſtroyed thus wrought antony artificially thoughte fact puniſhed required lepidus would puniſhe lepidus intending ſpeake ſtoode farre prayed hym goe common place might heare indifferently wente ſtraight forth opinion people mind new turned come place ſpéech lamented wéeping thus ſayd heere yeſterday lepidus people caeſar héere enquire caeſars deathe haue done many cryed ſhould reuenge caeſar hyred men cryed peace citie whome hée ſayd ſo peace ſpeake othes ſure countrey othes ha • e ſworne caeſar compted leaſt ſweare haue troden vnder foote turned cryed reuenge▪ caeſar ſayd gone v holy honored man déede afrayd hurte citie left senate treate manye thinkes good cryed alone ſhould take hand wyll ſayd iuſt oth alone ynough alone doe alone fulfill • andling matter thus craft • ly hyred men knowing ambitioue prayſed exhorted take office caeſars prieſthode glad ſayde ſhall remember héereafter ſhall worthy caeſars prieſtoode offered lepidue hired inſtant peace bycauſe liberall ſpéech prieſthoode ſayde although vniuſt wicked yet doe bycauſe ſaid returned senate houſe dolabella time bin importune continuance office antony gathering people humor looked ouer hym wyth ſmiling countenance finding diſſent among themſelues people doe nothing earneſtly hauing beholden ſufficiently determined ſaue mē hiding one neceſſitie another ſhuld ſaued eſpecial grace caeſars actes ſhould cōfirmed decrée senate order take effect therfore ſilence cōmanded ſayd thus citizen offendoures men equall honor conſultation haue ſayd nothing contrarywiſe • • ny senate deſired tryall caeſar put forthe onely one decrées hath withoute cauſe kept contention tyll time doe refuſe thoſe office ſhall confeſſe ſo many worthy men vnworthily haue receyued cō ſider eaſie hard number mindes city nation kingdomes region maye ſay thing frō eaſt weaſt y• caeſar vertue vanquiſhed v power ſubdued ſame law clemencie curteſie made aſſured vnto hym theſe thinke wil beare depriued y• thing haue enioyed vnleſſe wil fyll warres deſirous heale youre countrey nowe moſt féeble wyth diſeaſe thoſe farre kepte downe feare fight wil omitte touch thoſe hād may ſay euen home italy ſome haue receyued reward victory multitude army wherewith ſerued caeſar appoynted habitation ſame inſtitution whereof many thouſand within citie thinke wil take looked haue city countreys thys laſt night ſhew v image matter whē intreate offendoures contrary ranne aboute threatnings thinke abide ſée caeſars body violated torne vnburyed theſe thing law wente done againſte tyrant whiche haue ſerued warres haue gayne gotten victory france england confirmed vnto gyuer ſo deſpightfully handled thinke people rome thinke italian hate ſhal haue god man ſo defile empire enlarged oceane ſea people vnknowen ſhall lacke reproufe blame youre inconſtancie thinke worthy honor killed conſull counſell houſe holye man holy place senatoures doer ſighte god diſhonor enimies moſt honored theſe thing vnlawfull power warne refrayne thys ſentence giue caeſars actes decrées doe remayne firme ſtable offender prayſed wiſe godly iuſt conſonant caeſars actes ratified mercye onely pardon friend kinſfolkes ſake ſo ſo accept thē confeſſe thākeful part antony ſaid great contention vehemency decrée made ſilent content ſhould action caeſars death actes decrées ſhould confirmed ſo commodious citie much adoe friend thedecrees offendoures cauſe added ſafetie kepte iuſtice ſake profite antony gaue place vnto theſe decrées head men ſet habitation deſired priuate decrée common authoritie place inhabitance myghte bée made ſure vntoa decree habitation antony agaynſte ſhewing ſome feare senate decrée made another like went inhabitation counſell thus broken vp ſome perſ • oded lucius piſo whome caeſar leſt teſtamente 〈…〉 ſhould neyther brought forthe body buryed openly 〈…〉 •••• ment leaſt mighte breede ſome newe tumult citie otherwiſe minded threatned called aunſwer defrauded people ſuch ſubſtance due common treaſure agayne making ſignification tyrannie piſo cryed lowde could praying conſuls yet preſent goe counſell againe ſayde haue affirmed one tyrant taken away ſteede ••• people one tyrant vnto v forbidding bury holy prieſt threaten bring forth laſt make confiſcation goodes tirant actes maketh ratifie thoſe hath left himſelfe reuoke brutus caſsius incenſe miſchiefe sepulture lordes teſtament ſhall ſuffer dectyued truſt faith ſome man taketh away breath much ſtirre buſineſſe riſe among ſpecially ſuppoſed get ſomewhat teſtament therefore thought conuenient teſtament ſhould brought abroade body ſhoulde buryed caeſars teſtament openly ſo counſell roſe brutus caſsius vnderſtanding ſend multitude call capitoll many came running thither greate haſt brutus ſayd thus nowe citizen héere yeſterday common court • fleeyng temple 〈…〉 people haue done amiſſe fort hauing committed wée haue ſharpe ſtrāge miſhap cinna haue cōpelled v thus haue herd hath bin obiected againſt v oure enimies touching oth touching cauſe doubt y• peace ſuretie haue ſay herein citizen conferre whome haue concerning common matter caius caeſar frō france inuaded countrey enimies armes pompey ſingulare fauourer people ſuffered euery man knoweth hym nūber good citizen wente iberia libya deſtroyed deſire gaue ſecurity ſhould ſéeme afrayde himſelfe ſeking make tyrāny ſure ſware vnto required v ſwere confirme thing paſt alſo haue bene hys ſlaues time come woulde haue done nowe lie wayte liues ſuppoſe verye romaine indéede wyll rather chooſe certaine death haue oft done othe abyde willing ſeruitude caeſar hitherto haue gone aboute nothing make v ſeruile confeſſe haue broken othe neyther office citie prouinces y• country army dignity church aſſigning inhabitance honour left v cōſent senate allowance people owne commaundement ambition neuer ſatiate syllas ouerthrown enemy reſtored v common wealth making another armye long time toke awaye election fiue yeares libertie hope coulde appeare ſhould ſay people chiefe officer seſetius marullus contumely thruſt frō ſacred inuiolate office lawe othe aunceſtours ſuffer actiō made againſt y• tribune yet caeſar baniſhed ſhewed cauſe whither thē haue offēded againſt holy tribune caeſar ſacred inniolate man willingly neceſſitie graunted theſe thing came agaynſt country armour killed ſo many noble citizen office tribune holy inniolated whiche father time common welth dyd ſweare without cō pulſion intent haue euerlaſting reuenewe accompt empire became brake open treaſure houſe againſt will caught money vntouched vnremouable thretned death tribune reſiſted oth ſaye ſhall ſufficient preſerne peace tyranne needes oth forefather neuer néede anye wil aſpire tyrannie fayth othe romames tiranne thus ſpeake perill euer ſpeake country honoure ſafety caeſar preferred honour countrey owne wel vſe calumniation againſte v ſtirre habitation preſent eyther y• hath ſhalbe appointed thoſe inhabitance pray ſo much requeſt giue token ſelues many dyd ſo ſayde oh well done good men come conuenient indifferentlye doe trauayle laboure youre countrey ſhoulde receyue equal reward ſame people rome appoint caeſar againſte engliſh french men therefore reaſon hauing done good ſeruice receyue good reward bound oths vnwillingly led againſt citie led likewiſe againſt beſte citizen libya likewiſe againſt wils trauayle ben paraduenture would haue bin aſhamed aſhe recompence ſeruice france england enuie time obliuion man put memorie theſe beſte recompence people wont giue old ſouldiers taking away men landes houſes offended giuing one others thinking ought recompence iniuſtice conquered enimies friend yeare yeare yet yong ſent caeſar velona apply booke trayned feates warre remayne whileſt wente againſte enimies exerciſe himſelfe band horſemen came macedonia great captaynes armie reſorted thither viſit hym caeſars kinſman whereby knowen many wanne loue army receyued came great curteſie hauing bin ſixe monethes velona euening told caeſar ſlayne senate houſe loued beſt might doe moſt hym matter nothyng yet tolde ſtoode feare doubt whether whole publike worke senate ſome priuate practiſe whether doer puniſhed parte whoſe acte whether multitude ioyne thys friendes ſente hym rome wiſhing goe hoſt macedonia ſuretie place ſhuld knowen common fact might terror enimies reuenging caeſar diuers captaynes promiſed woulde come woulde ſée hym ſafe mother philip father lawe wrote vnto take nothing vpon encouraged remembring caeſar hadde ouercome enimies thus vſed déereſt friendes priuate life proſent octauius ſayleth italy perill nowe rather choſen rome ſhould well kept octauius theſe perſuaded without knowledge done caeſars deathe embracing captaynes ſayled ouer ionian sea taking land brunduſe bycauſe truſt army therefore well ware another citie farre called lupio ſtayed receyued thy debtor thankes wherein maye blame thée ſpeake frankely dolor doth thereto driue ſlayne thou waſt preſent quellers holding thée withoute dores eyther ſhouldeſt thou haue ſaued haue bin like daunger thy ſelfe whych latter muſt haue happened well thou waſt abſente ſome decréed honored againſte tyrant▪ thou denyedſt effectually whych know thou 〈◊〉 ſucceſſour 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 deſerueſt cléere thankes thou knoweſt thoſe men conſpire thy death one woulde reuenge caeſar thinke tyrantkillers fled capitoll sanctuary like offendors crauing merc • e ſorte enimies ſtrength wherefore obliuion acquitall murther required thē though ſome senate people corrupted thou hadſt bin otherwiſe minded thy office require thee puniſh ſo great fault correct erre yet diddeſt thou ſend pledge thine owne capitoll aſſurance manquellers well graunt corrupted ſort force thée caeſars teſtament redde thou madeſt funerall oration righte people freſh memorie caeſar carryed fire againſte neyghboures ſake ſpared agayne armes twice next day didſt thou help people leader fire armoure puniſhe murtherers puniſhment ought euident offendors thée friende caeſar conſull antony marius amatius commaundement thy great power put deathe quellers thou ſuſferedſt ſlée runne certayne prouinces wrongfully holde hauing killed gaue syria macedonia thou dolabella doyng well thinges ſetled tooke whiche would thanke thée thou hadſt ſtraight appoynted creta cyrene thought fugitiues worthy prouinces euer garriſons againſt decimus hauyng france neybour haue ſuffered alſo made ruler father ſome ſay senate determine yea thou didſt confirme ſateſt chiefe senate thou chiefly others thy ſelfe oughteſt haue reſiſted giue obliuion faul • granting liues aſſigne prouinces honor contumelie caeſar ouerthrow iudgement therefore paſſion dothe carrie peraduenture beyonde due reſpect yeares reuerence thée ſpeake ſure friende caeſar though worthye much honor power alſo one mighte haue bin heire knowen thou hadſt come aeneas rather hercules muche conſider tooke order ſucceſſion tyme come antony god friendſhip dutie caeſar thou wilt change thing done thou muſt thou wilt leaſt help minde reuenged ye quellers people ſuch father friend haue reſpect men senate doth moue thée angry thou knoweſt charge houſe haue theſe matter performing diſtribution father gaue people care thereof delaying might ſéeme vnthankefull yt ſhould receyue habitation countrey ſhoulde conſumed tarrying citie al thée brought immediately ye death caeſar ſafetie danger houſe iewels apparel thinke good thou ſhalt haue al thing thou wilt diſtributiō giue coyned gold gathered determinate warres ſhall ſuffice deuide amōg thrée hūdred thouſand mē reſidue charge may ſo bold eyther thée thy helpe borowe publike money forthwith make ſale priuate ſubſtance whileſt caeſar ſpake thus antony aſtoniſhed courage boldneſſe farre beyond opiniō yeares gréeued ſpéech made without reuerence ſpecially required money anſwered ſharply manner caeſar togither inheritāce name ſonne antonyes aunſvvere 〈◊〉 left thée alſo ſtate thou mighteſt well haue required accompt common thing muſt haue aunſwered romaine haue oth decréed man ſhall receyue rule inheritance man ſucceſſour king whome expell whiche chiefly obiected againſte father quellers affirming killed king captayne ought aunſwere thée touching theſe publike cauſes ſame reaſon deliuer thée gyuing thankes whiche thou oweſt therefore done thy ſake people yet one greateſt actes euer done caeſar thée mine owne boldneſſe hate ouerpaſt honor ſtrikers killer tyrante caeſar bin iudged tyrant whome neyther glory honor eſtabliſhmente actes bin made neyther teſtament ſonne ſubſtāce bin ſtayd bodye bin thought worthy buriall priuate man law doth commaund bodyes tyrant caſt vnburied memorie raced theyr goodes made common fearing contend caeſars immortall glorye publike buriall neyther without perill enuie mine owne perſon men fierce full bloudſhed thou mayſt know conſpiring agaynſte senat could euill beare thy father gouernement thought rather offer ſelfe peril trouble ſuffer caeſar diſhonored vnburyed beſt men moſt fortunate affaire vſing moſt honorably theſe mine onely peril thou haſt preſently theſe ſingulare benefites caeſar bloud▪ name hys dignitie ſubſtance whyche thou oughteſt rather giue thankes reprehende anye thyng done appeaſing senate recompence ſuch deſerued commodity conſiderations ſéeyng thou art yong reſpect therefore ſhall ſufficient thou ſpakeſt héerein thou doeſt glance mée though deſirous rule neuer coueted yet haue bin thought altogither vnworthy thou ſayeſt ſory made heire teſtament yet thine owne confeſſion content petigrée hercules thy neceſſitie thou wouldeſt borrow common treaſure thinke thou didſt diſſemble bycauſe thou canſt ignorant cōſumed thy father ye receypt reuenue ſince came authoritie brought ſteade ye treaſure houſe found ſubſtance whē determined ſearch thē cā wrōg caeſar dead called vniuſt though wer aliue yt required would yéeld thée accōpts whē thou ſhalt find ye many priuate men cōtend wt thée hys goodes thou ſhalt wel perceiue thou c • ſt obteine thē without great controuerſie money thou ſayeſt left wyth neyther ſumme ſo greate nowe handes diſtributed officer magiſtrates tyrant goodes dolabella bréethren onely excepted beſtowed vpō ſuch purpoſes caeſar appointed whē thou ſhalt haue reſt thou ſhalt beſtow rather vpon thē may hinder thée thā people thou béeſt wiſe whome ſende away wiſe habitation people thou oughtſt know lately trayned gréeke letter vnſtable euer mouing waues sea 〈…〉 of▪ antony •• uour octauinus bin caeſar deſired woulde leaue diſpight well cauſe hauing ſerued vnder caeſar receyued ſo many good turnes thing antony conſideryng confeſſing true halfe aſhamed ſhoulde layde vpon hym nowe ſhoulde haue néede octauians helpe prouince france beganne lengthe bée quiet ſhewe antony ••• eth ſome thyngs doone againſte hys wyll bycauſe young manne ſo hawtie thoſe yeares hée dydde reuoke certaine thynges hadde regarde reuerence capitaines olde officer yet theyr ſakes woulde reframe hys anger returne olde condition hée alſo woulde leaue hys inſolent behauiour captaines gladde brought togither declared grief ſet one nowreconciliation antony octaui •• law called vppon france senate againſt entending prohibite antony woulde propounde hée didde require people woulde ſet tribune againſteit ſome woulde haue frée al lieutenant ouer nation ſo muche afraide antony obiect vnto would truſte decimus one caeſars killer diſtruſte hym kill hym wanne prouince made fall knées caſting forth openly againſt al though bin deſirous doone caeſar courte daye come senate willed aſſemblythe senate taketh •• ard • ▪ companyes gathered night ſette vppe tentes common place called bande souldioures deſende happes people offended laboured antony helpe octaui • ſate among tentes entreated 〈◊〉 novve ••••• eth antony hym hée much afraid leaſt decimus ſhoulde gouernoure prouince ſuche importaunce armye ſo greate béeyng one hadde kylled hys father thys cauſe hée beganne fauoure antonie wyth whome reconciled truſting gette ſome good hys hande tribune corrupted antony keping ſilencetribunes corrupted lawe tooke place armye nowe ſea reaſonable conſideration aſſigned antonie one tribune dead octauius much fauoured flaminius againſt next election bycauſe people thought 〈◊〉 ▪ people mindeth make octauius 〈◊〉 himſelfe woulde haue office refuſed aſke bycauſe yong yeares determined neuertheleſſe election make tribune senate enuy encreaſe afraide tribune would accuſe father killer people antonie regarding breake friendſhip octauius whither pleaſe senate quiet mind late lawe made hys prouince antony againſte octauius aga •• ſakes ſhoulde go inhabite conſull hée decréed caeſar ſhoulde deale man lawfullye otherwiſe woulde al mean auctoritie againſt hym thys declaration beyng vnpleaſaunte caeſar contumelious bothe hym people angrye entended make ſtirre election affraye antonie sedition procured helpe tribune reuoke decrée octauius caſar one euidently deceyued ſente manye citties hys father made inhabite ſhew hée vſed knowe mind therin ſent ſome alſo cariers victual antony campe mingle among chiefelye deale wyth boldeſt among reſte ſcatter libells thus hée dydde capitaines chiefe men antony finding time conuenient ſaide thus vnto wée antonie wyth thée haue ſerued caeſar oration capitaynes antony gaue hym chiefe aucthoritie till daye haue remayned aſſured ſeruauntes haue knowne hys killer senate fauouring didde muche hate ſéeke diſpatch v people diſturbe encouraged agayne bycauſe wée ſawe caeſar forgotten lacked friendes deſtitute fauoure yet wee put truſte thée caeſars friende nexte moſt acquainted ſeruice warre nowe generall al reſpects moſt ſit enimies riſe boldly force syria macedonia prepared mony men againſt v senate maintainyng decimus thou conſuming tyme contention caeſar octauius without cauſe afraide tyme come thys diſſention • etwéene woulde raiſe greater warre hathe beene gyue occaſion ennimies woulde againſte v whyche ſeeyng thy ſelfe doeſt vnderſtande beſéeche thee caſars ſake oure loue whiche hath doone nothing offend thée commodity may riſe thée v whileſt thou mayeſt thou wouldeſt agrée octauius whiche onlye ſufficient entending reuenged ſtrykers whiche thing cleare care ſhall ſtay thée aucthoritie place v ſecuritie doubt thée oure ſelues chiefetaynes hauyng ſayde thus muche antony thus aunſwered beneuolence loue haue euer borne caeſar antonius 〈…〉 captaynes hys cauſes offeryng ſelfe moſte perills haue béene souldiour fare preſent euery thing hathe bin done well teſtifie muche loue good ſhewed euen till laſt day ſhall néede repeate quellers waying th • ſe • ut • haue kylled thoughe ••• coulde thinke intentes to▪ conſiſte ſafetye anye manne dydde affraye mynde doone deſire care life reſpecte onelye woulde ſéeme perſecute ennimies diſpatche tyran thinke doe forgette caeſar benefactour haue eſtéemed enimies woulde willingly forgyue death haue ſought mine new caeſar thinketh commeth obliuion deathe aduancemēt prouinces obiecteth againſt senate heare hathe come paſſe caeſar ſlayne senate houſe euery man afrayd moſt caeſars friendſhip ignorance facte neyther hearde comuration vnderſtoode howe manye conſpirancie people tumulte ſtrikers ſwordplayers tooke capitoll made themſelues faſt senate ſide whyche nowe euident bycauſe decréed honor killer tyrant caeſar tyrant muſt haue bin deſtroyed ſtrayght friend tyrante béeyng troubled tumult feare ſorrow coulde vſe reaſon bée without perplexitie maye perceyue conſider one ſide néede boldneſſe vehemente diſſimulation extreame firſte thys done reſidue eaſlie followyng take away honor gyuen ſtrikers againſte th • whiche onely ſtandyng reſiſted senate broughte paſſe greate payne vſing eindente courage onely offering ſelfe perill ſuppoſing wée caeſars friendes ſhould ſuretie • condemned tyrant lyke feare troubled enimies senate iudged tyrant ſhoulde accompted manquellers thys contention thoughte beſt gyue place allow obliuion hys death ſtead honor giuen mighte wynne muche neceſſitie coulde manner doings neyther dyd ſuffer caeſars name aboliſhed ſubſtance bée confiſcate adoption whiche man nowe moſt gloryeth diſſolued teſtament fruſtrated hys bodye cauſed buryed princely honoures due vnto conſecrated immortall actes decrées kept firme ſure hys ſonne friend captaynes souldioures good ſafetie liue honor ſtead rebuke thinke obteyning theſe thynges senate obliuion ſmall trifle doe thynke wythout ob • uion senate would haue graunted whyche theſe cauſes thynke playnely bee performed true dealyng wyth ſtrikers animmortall glory caeſar oure weale ſuretie whyche haue done purpoſe turne courſe contrarye hadde brought senate profitable v allowed killer remayne quiet ouerthrowe obliuion decrée ſtatute coulde earneſt iealouſie people bringing caeſars bodye buryed common place cauſing hys woundes bée ſéene multitude ſhewyng veſture bloudy mangled declaring vertue beneuolence people wéeping made mourning oration called hym name kylled god theſe wordes workes whereby people ſo prouoked ſtead obliuion tooke fire wente quellers houſes ende drone citie howe thys contrarye senate béeyng gréeued wyth euidently ſéene accuſed firſt ambition appoynted prouinces brutus caſsius syria macedonia whyche full greate armyes leaſt ſhoulde ſéeme make haſt theyr tyme gaue pretence prouide grayne citie wherefore greater feare dyd yet trouble lacke appoynted armye menne naked ſyghte wyth ſo manye well armed fellowe béeyng man ſuſpected diſagréeyng one conſpirators agaynſte caeſar appoynted bée héere daye hys deathe theſe thyngs béeyng great trouble ſéekyng ſpéede diſarme oure enimies arme oure ſelues kylled amatius thoughte good call home pompey thys meane mighte ioyne senate agayne yet much truſtyng perſuaded dolobelia aſke syria senate people lawe bée made hys ſute furthered hym friende make hym enimie ſtrikers ſhoulde ſéeme verye vnfytte senate denye macedonia ſéeyng hadde graunted syria dolobella otherwiſe woulde haue graunted mée prouince delyuered armye excepte hadde firſte graunted dolabella ſame goe agaynſte parthian woulde haue taken brutus caſsius syria macedonia vnleſſe hadde appoynted ſome prouinces theyr ſuretie néedes muſt appoynte one another manner one cyrene creta voyde army whyche oure enimies contempte haue lefte vnprofitable violence haue entred whyche wée tooke thus oure armye putte oure enimies dolabella deuice ſleighte exchange prouinces warre muſt thinges bée done lawe béeyng thus broughte paſſe oure enimies gathering another armye hadde néede ſame ſelfe macedonia yet wanted occaſion require fame came getes woulde inuade macedonia whyche béeyng beléeued eſpies ſente vnderſtande truth decreed man ought aſke dictatorſhippe take though gyuen hym whych thyng béeyng chiefly allured appoynted armye dyd thinke ſelfe equall mine enimies theſe euidente octauius thynketh moe number greater power yet appearing done one ſtrikers remayned ſtill hard ſides decimus brutus béeyng gouernoure greate countrey mighty armye verye bolde deuiſed take hys prouince hym yet wyth regarde senate promiſing delyuer macedonia voyde armye senate takyng thyng euill perceyuing ſome deuice bée hadde howe greate matter written decimus knowe ſtirre conſulles agaynſte mée wherefore wyth boldeneſſe dyd practiſe wynne prouince senate people lawe haue armye macedonia come brund • ſ • vſe oportunities▪ god help vſe neceſſitie ſhall compell v thus muche feare wherein firſt turned ſafetie haue doe wyth v boldneſſe agaynſte oure foe whoſe courage beginnes ſhrinke increaſe ſée repentance make decrées payne mée take france gyuen another man knowe wrote decimus perſuaded conſuls agaynſte matter wyth god oure countrey wyth dutifull mynde wyth oure valiante actes whyche caeſar conqueroure wée wyll reuenge labouring bodyes counſelling wyth oure mynds theſe thyngs souldioure fellowes woulde haue ſecrete although howe haue done haue tolde whome participate thyngs worde déede may ſhewe knowe onely octauius except moſt vnthankefull v antony hadde thus ſaide ſéemed captaynes done thing great art policie deceiue quellers whome hated therefore deſirous reconcile caeſar agayne perſuaded méete capitoll long antony cauſe ſome gard apprehended friendes entiſed octauius deſtroy himnevv deſpight • antony againſt caeſar eyther diſcredite octauius thoughte true learning ſuch ſente hys campe declared done coniecture diſpatche hys perſon whiche matter béeyng quietly heard cauſed muche adoe indignation among people fewe grounded vppon reaſon glad antony myghte doe caeſar good alſo hurte hys pleaſure bycauſe hée terrible ſtrikers hée diſpatched myghte wyth ſecuritie doe theyr feates bycauſe senate chiefly fauoured thus wyſer ſorte thinke multitude ſéeyng deſpight hynderance dayly offered octauius thoughte vnlike calumniation yet ſuppoſed good honeſt antony beyng conſull ſhoulde bée daunger hys perſon octauius caeſar greate anger furie wente among thys opinion cryed hée circumuented antony frendſhyppe onely people ranne antonyes houſe exclaymed caeſar exclaymeth agaynſte antony called god witneſſe execration othes prouoking hym come tryall bycauſe bodye came hym ſayde hys friendes contente bée iudged hys owne people brake dores béeyng kepte backe ſware rebuked kepte gate bycauſe ſtopped hym making tryall wyth antony wente hys way proteſted people hurte came vnto hym ſhoulde come antonyes meanes hauyng ſpoken greate vehemencie gréeued people ſome repented theyr former opinion ſtoode doubte • uſted neyther thoughte diſſimulation betwéene better bryng paſſe agréed vpon temple againſte enimies ſome thought antonie deuiſed haue greater garriſon turne men good octauius nowe ſecrete intelligence gyuen hym antonyes armye brunduſe diſcontented armye brunduſe ordinarie souldioures angrye antonie bycauſe neglected caeſars death woulde reuenge power antonie gone haſt brunduſe cauſe octauius afrayde leaſt returning antonyes goyng brunduſe ſuſpected caeſar armye ſhoulde finde hym vnprouided tooke mony wente campania winne city inhabited ſuch▪ ſerued father firſt perſuaded celatia silio two townes capua gaue euerie octauius goeth make men celatia latio silio caſ • ilinum campania farre capua feare citie man fiue hundred drammes tenne thouſande menne neyther armed diſtributed due band order gard perſon vnder one enſigne citie afrayde antony commyng army heard octauius comming another double feare ſome tooke well mighte vſe octauius againſt antony ſawe theyr reconciliation capitoll thought diſſimulation recompence one authoritie perſecute quellers thys diſquietneſſe carnutiw tribune enimie antony friende octauius wente knowe truth whyche 〈◊〉 béeyng done hée declared people playne variance betwéene antony octauius ſtoode hande make octauius theyr friende ſéeyng none armye reſiſt antonyes tyrannie ſayde
