carnutius ſpake firſte againſt antony octauius hymſelfe reuiued memorie hys father ſhewed iniurie antony hadde done hym octauius people whereby forced gette armye hys ſuretie wyth whyche woulde obey ſerue countrey thyngs nowe readye agaynſte antonie hadde thus ſayde counſell broken vp armye thoughte otherwyſe bycauſe theyr reconciliation onely broughte preſerue octauius perſon agaynſte hys quellers ſéemed bée gréeued ſuche wordes ſhoulde bee ſpoken agaynſte antonie béeyng generall armye conſull citie ſome deſired goe home arme themſelues coulde abyde none theyr owne army ſome tolde truth octauius army goeth octauius beganne doubt agayne ſéeyng came otherwyſe paſſe thought therefore gaue place occaſion truſtyng wynne rather gentleneſſe 〈◊〉 giueth 〈◊〉 ſouldyoures force wherefore ſome ſente bée armed ſome theyr home agayne promiſing theyr laboures hydyng hys griefe gaue newe giftes promiſed liberally requite woulde vſe hys enterpriſes rather hys father friendes hys souldioures hadde ſo ſayde one thouſande thrée moſt thys writer vary wanne tarrie reſt wente awaye remembryng toyle tyllage gayne warfare wordes caeſar eaſilie dyd drawe giftes hadde receyued hope ſhoulde receyue variable nature people beganne repent turning occaſion dutie armed themſelues returned went rauenna octauius armye returneth ar • uum citie tuſcane thirty myles florence reuenue hadde gone ouer countrey gotten menne one another ſente arezz • meane time fiue legion macedonie foure come antonie brunduſe accuſing one neglected caeſars deathe bycauſe gaue gréetyng hym broughte hym hys ſeate heare ſomewhat firſte ſayde themſelues offended ſilence antony offended vvith souldioures coulde refrayne rebuked vnthankefulneſſe hym called iourney parthia remayne italie acknowledge anye thankea mutiny antonyes camp blamed bearing raſhe yong man ſo called caeſar woulde diſcouer hym ſuche perſons ſente make difference betwéene woulde fynde hymſelfe intendyng leade wealthie prouince celtica gyue euery one woulde abide hym one hundred drammes souldyoures laught miſerable offer morethe souldyoures laught miſerie antony angry diſorder tumulte wherefore roſe ſayde ſhall learne ruled enquired chiefetaynes ſeditious among romaine vſed note euerye manne writing lawe warre choſe hée dyd kyll euery tenth manne parte thinking fewe affray reſt feare rather anger hate tourned doings whiche thyng perceyued ſente thyther octauius threwe billes aboute campe conteyning niggardneſſe crueltie antonie vnthankefulneſſet 〈…〉 〈…〉 a▪ 〈…〉 〈…〉 ng caeſar dead liberalitie gentleneſſe might help antonie great diligence ſoughte author threatning greate payne dyd diſcloſe coulde finde anye hée muche offended whole army ſhould fauoure hearde extraordinarie band gone caeſar octauius done rome troubled came agayne army ſayde greeue doe done neceſſitie souldious diſcipline taking ſtead many according lawe antony souldyoures well knowe antonie neyther cruell ſparing quoth let anger go let ynough puniſhment offence hundred drammes meante gifte antony fortune requyred otherwyſe welcome fyrſte acquayntance betwéene rather gifte hée wylled haue lawe countrey souldyoures order oughte bée obediente hym thys thyngs thus ſayd yet dyd adde anye ſomme leaſt captayne ſhoulde ſéeme giue place souldioure eyther repentance feare accepted hée changed officer hys campe eyther diſpleaſure thys ſedition ſome ſuſpition reſt ſuche furniture deuiding hoſt ſent ſea arimeno takyng one bande moſt likely men bodye obedience wente towarde rome thence goe alſo arimeno 〈◊〉 ▪ arimeno hée proudely entred citie leauyng one bande withoute citie campe wyth aboute hym armed hée cauſed hys houſe bée garded nyghte hys ſafetie whome gaue watchwordes dyuers part garriſon citie aſſembled senate intending haue accuſed octauius doings entry tolde martiall legion way gone octauius hée ſtoode doubt feare whattvvo legion▪ reuolte octauius frō antony doe alſo ſhewed hym fourthe legion following martial example likewiſe reuolted octauius much troubled entred made ſhew called senate purpoſe tarried long went gate thence cittie alba ſtay reuolters put walles hée retourned legion hée ſente fiue hundred dram tibur • novv • uol • man hadde hée wente tiburo hauyng ſuche prouiſion bee wonte goe agaynſt theyr enimies nowe euident warre woulde followe decimus meante leaue hys prouince antony beeyng thys place almoſte senate manye gentleman came hym honor ſo dyd great part people ſynding hym gyuyng othe hys ſouldiors preſente hadde ſerued béefore whyche reſorted hym greate number fréely ſware antony woulde breakethe senatoures citizen svvorne antony faith beneuolence wyth hym nowe man mighte doubte little hadde ſpoken againſte antony octauius caeſars ſake antony thus wyth great pompe approched arimeno beginning fraunce cel •• ca armye beſide theſe newe souldioures thrée legion macedonia nowe come vnto hym olde souldioures ſerued counted twice ſo good yong hadde antony armye foure legion experte antony armye▪ souldioures beſide ſuche bée wonte followe venturer olde guarde hys perſon wyth n • choſen lepidus iberia hadde thrée legion aſinius pollio twoolepidus▪ aſinius pollio plancus plancus fraunce thrée whyche ſéemed take antony parte octauius octauius caeſar twoo choiſe legion wente antony▪ one yōg ſouldiors two ſerued firſt neyther full number furniſhed armoure yet ſupplyed newe commers gathered theſe togither alba ſent senate dydde ſo muche reioice octauius man myghte doubte anye dydde honoure antony yet theythe senate miſtaked • octauius u antony bothe content legion went hym ſhoulde goe octauius neuertheleſſe prayſed caeſar promiſing ſhortly determine decrée bee doonc newe magiſtrates hadde theyr office euident ende woulde bend againſt antony bycauſe army coulde gather none wythout conſuls auctoritie deferred till newe election caeſars army offred mace sergeant prepared prayed take vpon hym lieutenantſhip leading warre euer vſed ſuch auctoritie thanked honoure referred matter senate wolde haue gone heap purpoſe forbad ſtaied would haue ſent ambaſſadours senate quoth hée maye take order themſelues vnderſtanding offer refuſall hardly beeyng contented waye capitaines conſtruing men ſome ſuſpition declared vnto senate dyd rather encline good feare antony want army til quoth haue diſpatched antony murtherers friend kinſemen senate wil gather power thē whych perceyuing wil pretend obey diſcloſed take power vppon v call violence contumelic wée make daunger peraduenture giue v fearing otherwiſe wée ſhal haue hée hadde thus ſayde hée ſawe twoo legious came antony ſhewing ſhape battaylea • • fight tvvoo legion contending together vehement wiſe thoughe hadde béene fighting indéede kylling onely excepted hée béeing delighted feate glad take occaſion didde gyue euery man fiue hundred drammes anye neceſſitye warre ſhoulde followe hée promiſed hauing better hande fyue thouſande drammes man thus caeſar liberalitie rewarde winne hys hyred menne theſe dooyngs italy fraunce antony commaunded decimus go macedonia antony vvarneth decimus oute prouince obey people ſaue himſelfe decimus ſente letter senate verye well written ſignifying well oughte hée obey senate people antony appoynted hym daye hée woulde vſe hym enimie decimus required hym appoynt longer daye hymſelfe hée ſhoulde ſoone made enimye senate antony good hym fielde yet thoughte better goe vnto city receyued hym decimus béeyng afrayde hée ſhoulde hée would enter anye fayned hadde receyued letter senate returne rome wyth hys army ſo one goyng home italy receiued euery place came mutina plentifull citie ſhutte mutina citie lumbar • rovv modena decimus taketh modena hys defence gate commaunded citizen bring thynges foorthe neceſſarye foode cauſed al beaſts kylled poudred feare ſiege woulde laſte long ſo tarryed antony comming hys armye number swordeplayers thrée legion armed whereof one new souldiours withoute experience two former ſeruice faithfull hym antony anger came againſte decimus caſte trenche aboute cittie ſo decimus beſieged rome conſuls according yeare choſen dydde ſtraighte aſſemble senate ſacrifices temple agaynſte antony cicero friend require might iudged enimie cicero againſte antony bycauſe force armes didde take prouince france contrarie senats pleaſure trouble hys countrey bycauſe brought army italie appoynted hym againſte thracian alleadged alſo againſte hym caeſar ſought rule armed citie ſo many bandleader vſing houſe forte full souldiours enſigns hys dooyngs inſolent became yearely officer lucius piſo one fauoured antony faction man lucius piſo againſte cicero verye notable among romaynes fauoured piſo antony cauſe required hée myghte bée called iudgement bycauſe manner theyr countrey condemne anye manne hée hearde conuenient hée yeſterdaye conſull ſhould thys daye enimy eſpecially hauing bene ſo ofte prayſed bothe cicero senate ſtoode doubtfull cauſe nightsenate againſte antony nexte day morning béeyng agayne aſſembled ciceronians wyth greate inſtaunce hadde decréede antony ennimye hadde saluius tribune diſſolued counſell till nexte daye theſe office hée hathe moſte power maye prohibite ciceronians dydde ſpitefully laboure againſte hym ad • ra againſte antony ranne among people ſtyrre vppon hym cited saluius aunſwere wythoute feare came foorthe till thesaluius senate ſtayed hym fearing leaſte ſhould incenſe people drawe memorye antonie ignoraunte condemned noble manne wythout iudgement people gyuen hym france feare ſtrykers angry hym bycauſe firſt brake lawe obliuion therefore choſe octauius agaynſt ignoraunt therof deſirous diſpatch antony senate thus affected voyces notwithſtanding deferred tribune yet determined decimus ſhoulde prayſed giuē place antonie celtica caeſar conſuls hircius panſa ſhould ioyne ſuch army image gold ſhould made honour might giue voyce among senatours allowed conſullhonours giuen octanius ten yeares lawe legion went antony ſhoulde haue muche giuen treaſure caeſar appointed victorie decréed brake vp euen already antony enemy déede tribune daring ſpeake next daye wherefore wife hys mother wyth ſonne yet yong friendes familiar night went great men houſes beſéech next daye came senate houſe ſuing euerye man falling féete wéeping wayling blacke habite cryed counſel dore ſome lamentable voyces behauiour ſodenneſſe matter moued compaſſion wherefore cicero afrayde ſpake thus vnto senate ought decrée antony yeſterday determine cicero againſt antony gaue honour aduerſaries cō demned enimie saluius impediment againſt v eyther thinketh himſelfe wiſe friendſhip beareth antony ignorāce matter euerye one theſe great ſhame al ſhould haue leſſe wit one alſo saluius prefer friendſhip cōmon wealth whē hath well vnderſtand preſent caſe ſhould haue giuen credite conſul pretor tribune fellowes senatoures number worthineſſe ſo manye oure age experience oughte knowe antonie▪ better salu • publique cauſes iudgementes parte euer hath right cauſes muſte vee knowne nowe learned agayne wyll repeate briefelye touche moſte principall matter caeſar deade antony tooke awaye oure common money rule macedonia hadde v fraunce entred violently without v army delyuered hym againſte thracian hée brought italie againſte v requiring theſe deceitfully v obtayning hee himſelfe brunduſe • ordained princelye bande aboute hym openlye rome men armour dyd guarde watche hym vnder enſignes broughte brunduſe armye cittie readye attemptes aſpiring thing caeſar hée lamented coueted yong caeſar prepared againſte hym another armye hee afrayde wente fraunce place fitteſt vſe force againſte v bycauſe caeſar place inuade v got rule ouer v giuing terrour armye mighte ſticke hys vnlawfull dooyngs lotte hee cauſed dye neither making anye mutinie forſaking charge order battell whiche onelye lawe armes thinke hath appoynted puniſhemente whyche fewe capitaynes ſcarcelye greate perills woulde vſe neceſſitie hee worde ieſte giueth death citizen death deſerue ſuche woulde chooſe wherefore coulde haue forſaken hym yeſterdaye dyd determine rewarde thoſe hadde doone well coulde eſcape awaye feare doe dwell enimies inuade youre lande beſiege youre armye youre generall appoynted remaine fraunce antony commaundeth hym departe whether haue iudged antony ennimye doeth hée vſe v enimyes oure tribune wyll know tyll decimus deade tyll prouince ſo greate ſo nygh vnto v prouince armye alſo decimus maye antony power worke hys hope agaynſte v lyke tribune wyll • ſoone decrée hym ennimye tyll hee bée lorde ouer v whyle cicero thus ſaying hys friendes made greate noyſe continuallye woulde ſuffer anye manne ſpeake agayne tyll piſo roſe vppe senate reuerence commaunded ſilence ciceronians ſtayde piſo thus beganne ſpeake lawe senatours doth allowe accuſed topiſo againſt 〈…〉 haue hys cauſe heard hath aunſwered himſelfe iudged accordynglye cicero moſte vehement oratoure doe chalenge durſte accuſe antony preſente hys abſence hath layde greate matter charge greateſt doubtfulleſt whereof wyll note wyth ſhorte aunſwere ſhewe bée falſe hee ſayeth antony caeſar▪ deathe dyd take publique money hys owne lawe calleth ſuche one • theefe enimye appointyng payne therefore brutus hadde ſlayne caeſar accuſed hym people ſpoyling common money leauing • te ••• nothyng antony decrée matter 〈…〉 • ſearched 〈…〉 approued hys ſentence publique 〈…〉 appointyng rewarde tenthe 〈…〉 woulde declare whych wyll double man accuſe antony thus much concerning money prouince fraunce appoint antony people lawe cicero preſent ſuch ſort manye giuen heretofore gaue ſame caeſar like maner part decrée antony ſhould make warre vpon decimus would giue place vnto army prepared againſt thracian ſtirreth ſhoulde led againſt reſiſted cicero doth iudge decimus enemye maketh warre againſte lawe antony obeyeth lawe condemneth hym hee condemneth made lawe whome hee ought perſuaſion pacific prouoke contumelie neither ought credite place decimus whō people haue banniſhed murder diſcredite antony people haue giuen law good counſel make diuiſion people eſpecially daūgerous time forget belongeth chiefly people iudge friendes foe auntient lawes people lord war peace whiche time notwithſtanding haue appointed commaunded vſed priuiledge ouer v ſaith antony killed certain souldiours general appointed therevnto neuer captaine generall charged wyth offīce lawes haue thought méete captaine ſhould ſubiect souldiours nothing worſe campe diſobedience whiche ſome conquerours haue bene ouerthrowen none puniſhed haue complayned none friendes kinſfolke cicero hath accuſed finding fault death inſtead ſuch honor hath ben wont giuen ſuch executers wil haue antony exclaymed enimy antony army diſordered diſ • ayned hym en • dēt two legion y• fled frō whō cōmanded ſerue vnder • contrary y• law ſouldiers haue fled frō octa caeſar cicero prayſeth alſo yeſterday would haue thē rewarded y• commō treaſure whiche example pray god one daye repent ſuche inconuenience hath enmity caried cicero accuſeth antony tyranny alſo murder ſouldiours wheras ſéeke miſchiefe country euer pleaſe army ſo puniſh thē bycauſe accuſe antony none matter tiranny caeſars rule go wil aſke queſtions euery thing hath antony killed vnharde tyrant ſelfe vnhard daunger condemned whome hath vaniſhed hath caſt hath bin ſo euery particular man hathe layde traynes v cicero decreed forgetfulneſſe thing done man ſhoulde proſecute murder ſearch ſhoulde made common treaſure called home pompey pompeis ſonne wiſhed might recompenced common father ſubſtaunce diſpatched counterfayte marius al prayſed cicero diſprayſe determined dictator ſhould created ſpoken ordayned would ſhoulde dye theſe thing antony v two monethes alone remayned cittie caeſar people purſewed ſtickers afrayde thing come woulde haue taken occaſion haue bene vmuſt coulde haue better yet hée dyd vſe hys power contrary alone rule dolobella gone syria dyd vſe hys army preſte al purpoſes citie whyche appointed hym watch citie himſelf garded night feare enimies occaſiō caeſars death friend benefactour moſt deare people another nere whē body laid mē neyther baniſhed put death rather fauoured much reaſō honeſty coulde enuying theſe ſée romaine greateſt moſt doubtful matter cicero hathg athered againſt hys accuſations ioyneth deuination thoughe antony woulde haue broughte ſo greate armye againſte cittie hee afrayde octauius caeſar preuented hym wyth armye entende onely ſo bee parte manne ennimye doeth hee counte hym one came encamped cittye gaue warnyng antony woulde come howe hapte hee came hée afrayde caeſars thrée thouſande vnarmed hauyng thirtye thouſand well armed came onely caeſar helpe pacifycation betwéene ſaw warre would follow forſooke hym afrayde hée thyrtie thouſande howe came hither one thouſande whyche goyng tibure howe manye dyd wee ſende vnto hym howe manye v wente bee ſworne hym ſworne prayſes dyd cicero make hys good gouernemente vertue howe woulde antony hee hadde knowen thys haue lefte wyth v pledge nowe bee without senate houſe hys mother hys wife hys young ſonne whyche lamente feare nowe antony doyngs common wealthe hys ennimyes power thys haue rehearſed vnto example antony innocencye cicero mutabilitye well wyll conſyder wyll giue thys exhortation neyther charge people antony neyther bring generall enimetie daunger common wealthe beyng ſickely wantyng ſpéed ••• c might relieue make cyttie ſtrong abroade doe ſtyrre anye tumulte whereby wee maye reſiſte anye wyll ryſe againſte v ••• ge wee ſhall thinke good performe wee haue iudged howe thys bée done wee ſuffer antony loue fauour people haue fraunce wee call home decimus wyth hys three legion hée come ſen • e hym macedonia retayning hys legion calling two legion wente antony wee doe require cicero ſayeth caeſar bee citie ſo hauyng fiue legion wee maye confyrme wee decree driuen hang anye man hope thys haue ſpoken hearer without enuye emulation inconſiderately vnaduiſedly ſéeke trouble▪ priuate grudge diſpleaſure ſhall beſéeche judge bée quicke ſwifte againſte ſo greate men leader ſo mightye armyes doe force make warre againſte wyli remembryng marcus coriolanus late caeſar bringing armye likewiſe offring verye good condition concorde wee raſhelye condemned enimye neceſſitie made bee ſo indéede let v beare wyth people earſt ſtirre againſte ſtrykers caeſar ſéeme hys reproch giue prouinces nation prayſe decimus bycauſe hee deſpiſeth people lawe condemne antony bycauſe hee receyueth fraunce people order behoueth bee good iudgement redreſſe goe aſtraye conſuls tribune prouide daungers preſent ſtate thus dyd piſo ſpeake defence cry ſharpe wordes onlye cauſe antony iudged rebell yet coulde obtayne hee ſhoulde haue prouince frenche celtica friendes kinſefolke killer feare lette leaſte warre ſhoulde ceaſſe hee bee one octauius reuenge caeſars deathe wherefore theyr practiſe deuiſe kepe antony octauius ſtyll debate decréed antony ſhould receiue macedonie ſtead lombardie al order eyther ignoraunce purpoſe committed cicero appoint giue anſwere embaſſadours hauing ſentence dyd thus determyne antony ſhoulde ſtreight departe modena andthe decree cuer • againſt amony leaue celtica decimo within compaſſe floud rubicone diuideth italie lombardie daye prefixed committe matter senate thus cicero ambitiouſly vniuſtly dyd appointe determination anye ſo great priuate enmitie ſhoulde ſéeme deſtinye determined trouble ſtate mutation bring himſelfe ſome euill happe ende inſtante come broughte aſhes trebonius deſpight vſed throughly knowne senate eaſilye decrée dolabella bée rebell dolabella declared rebel meſſengers come antony aſhamed ſtrange commiſſion ſayd nothing deliuered decrée vnto him▪ great anger •• ueigh againſt senate cicero maruelling would thinkethe anſvvere antony decree caeſar tyranne king ſo muche augmented ſtate rome accompte cicero ſo whome caeſar toke warre yet kill whereas cicero doeth preferre hys killer friendes hated decimus truſty caeſar loued euer ſince killer would ayde caeſar kept celtica iudge hym rebell people legion aſſigned decrée reuolted senate giueth rewarde none remayne duety ſo corrupt quoth diſcipline war belonging citie quellers could graunt obliuion facte whiche conſente two noble mennes ſake antonye dolobella hee iudgeth enimyes bycauſe wee kéepe giuen v verye cauſe antony senate leaue celtica neither enimy tyranne proteſt diſſolue forgetfulneſſe ſhall verye acceptable hym many thing ſorte ſpake antony wrote thys antony cicero aunſwere decrée senate woulde obey hys countrey cicero wrote commaundement thus ſpake people haue giuen celtica lawe decimus wil obey remoue reuenge matter murther hym senate may purged • aulte antony conde • ned whereof ful ciceroes ſake helpe decimus antony thus ſaide wrote wherefore senate iudged hym enimy armye vnleſſe wente hym macedonia illiria army appointedthe povver marcus brutus aſia macedonia slauonia marcus brutus till common wealth brought better ſtate armye hys owne receyued one appuleius ſhippes bothe gallies hulkes ſixtéen thouſand talent money greate plenty armour founde citie demeatride layde vp caeſar demeatride tovvne theſ • ſalie vvas called pagaſa novve demeatrida syria appoynted caſſius whiche senate confirmed decrée hée mighte vſe benefit hys country syria senate appoynted caſsius commaunded make warre vppon dolobella prouinces army romaine ionian sea eaſte charged obey brutus caſsius wherefore caſsius brutus eſtate ſodainely great fame octauius caeſar vnderſtoode theſe thynges hée doubt thought lawe obliuion procéede conueniēcie humanitie reſpect pitie kinſfolke men like aucthoritie therfore appointed prouinces ſhorte tyme ſecuritie celtica decimus note antony tyranny deuice induce antony meant take armye conſulls fielde néede capitayne onely honour gyuen souldiours reuolted antony hys vnhonoured warre would worke infamy • ng vſed none intent senate deſtruction antony kept conſiderations ſecrete hymſelfe mak • ng ſacrifice charge gyuen hym thus ſayd hys armye honour fellow souldiours may thanke 〈◊〉 ſouldiours onelye nowe tyme gaue mée power ſakes senate haue gyuen • therfore alſo know youre debtor thankes whiche god ſhall gyue v god lucke requite abundantly thus ſpeake win • e hys armye marched foorth panſa one conſuls lead army ouer italy hirtius 〈…〉 conſull diuided caeſar ſecretely inſtructed senate required di • iſion two legion went antony bycauſe counted beſt souldiors caeſar grant euery thing diuided encamped togither wynter ende winter decimus beganne lacke victual wherefore hirtius caeſar wente mutina antony 〈…〉 〈◊〉 one 〈…〉 • italy 〈…〉 〈◊〉 ſhoulde get decimus armye oppreſt famine antony holding mutina ſtraighte force woulde fight hym tarried panſa diuers ſkirmiſhes made whyche thoughe antony hadde greater number horſe yet narrowneſſe fielde ditch riuers kéepe backe multitude horſemen thus went matter mutina rome abſence conſuls cicero dydde al cicero rule • h rome people ruler aſſembled senate euerye daye hée made prouiſion armour compelling workemen without payment gathered money putte great impoſitions vppon antony friendes ſuffered patiently auoide diſpleaſure til publius ventidius ſerued vnder caeſar friende ventidius maketh rome afraid cicero flee antony could abide ſharpeneſſe cicero wente caeſars habitation well knowne gotte twoo legion whyche ledde antonie rome take cicero great trouble grew inſomuche manye wente awaye wyth wiues child feare cicero cicero fleeth fledde oute cittie whyche ventidius knewe hée tourned ſtraighte antony ſtepte caeſar hirtius la •• ca de▪ ancona coūtry ancona hée wente picene gathered another legion ſtayed ſée would come conſull caeſar ſéeing panſa drew nighe hys hoſte could vſe horſemen playne bycauſe fenny place full ditch hidde twoo hys beſte legion fenne waye béeing made hande ſtraighte ſides couered réedes carſuleius nighte paſſing • hys place breake day come way made hand martialls souldioures fyue bandes wente vppon made way cleare ennimyes beholde fenne euerye ſyde ſawe ſtirring réedes ſome glittering terg • t headpéeces began ſuſpect chiefe band antony booke 〈◊〉 hys ep • ſtles carſ • leius bycauſe two fen two fight bycauſe ſtraight place one could ſée vppon verye waye two chiefe bandes beganne another fight betweene themſelues antony men entended reuenged martialls bycauſe fugitiues vſe traytoures martialls woulde bée reuenged ſuſpected theyr fellowes deathes •• unduſe béeyng thus priuie one anothers doings ſtrength eyther armye hoped thys onely feate warre woulde determined one aſhamed two legion ſhoulde ouercome one ſought glorye one legion ſhoulde defeate two ſo ioyned battel anger emulation▪ rather themſelues capitaynes trying owne matter experience neyther made crie though ſtroken one another fight vttered anye voyce neither better worſe fetched compaſſe courſe ſtoode firme fennes ditch could one put another backe ſhorte ſwords claſped togither wreſtling place blowe giuen vaine▪ either woundes ſlaughter followed ſighes ſteede voice fell ſtraight another putte hys place néede exhortation calling euerye man owne experience captayne hymſelfe ouerlaboured woulde ſtaye take breath men place exerciſe ſtraighte cloſe agayne young ſouldiours ſtoode maze ſée thys feate doone ſo good order ſilence theſe continuing beyond man nature chiefe band caeſar ſlaine martialls vnder carſuleius hadde rather vpper hande enimies diſorderedly ray withdrew thē ſelues vnder panſa dyd abide equally ſtoode bothe ſides till panſa wounded darte belly caried panſa 〈…〉 bononia firſte retyred order turned ſwiftely flying yong souldiours ſawe fled confuſion crie campe torquatus pretor prouided whyles fightyng foreſéeing néede whiche new souldiours ran great violence beyng italian well martial exerciſe maketh one nation ſo much differ vertueexerciſe martial dyd enter trench diſhonour ſtoode weary though remayned ready reſiſt aſſaulte abide ende matter antony dyd touche martialles bycauſe knewe valiant young souldiours chaſed made greate ſlaughter among hirtius mutina hearyng fight beyng aboute eyghthirtius myles diſtant came baſte legion fled antony ſunne goyng downe antony souldiours hauing victory went ſinging camp hirtius appeared beyng good order one legionthe fight vvith hirtius 〈…〉 men ſounde valiante order wherefore neceſſitie placed themſelues due ſort ſhewed many valiant noble feates although coragious yet beyng weary ouercome freſhe moſt parte ſlayne hirtius feate albeit folow feare fennes night comming 〈…〉 u • rth • ovven ſeuer fenne moſt place filled harneſſe dead men half dead wounded ſafe diſpaired themſelues wearineſſe horſementhe horſe men antony antony rode al night gathered togither ſome caried themſelues ſome brought home horſebacke ſome badde take holde horſe tayle goe faſter ſéeke ſaue themſelues thus antony hauyng fought nobly loſte force commyng hirtius wherefore abode village fielde without campe village called french market halfe eyther ſyde 〈…〉 t ſlayne c • ſ • r bande perſon vtterly deſtroyed hirti • souldioures left nexte morning remoued camp mutina loſſe antony determined giue battell hys enimies admitte attempt ſame horſemen moleſt daye day till gotten decimus yéelde driuen hunger cauſe hirtius caeſar rather prouoked hym fight whereas perceyue antony woulde come forth keēpyng men order went ſide citie whych bicauſe harder approch leſſe kept y• whole army myght enter force antony made reſiſtance horſemen put backe horſe army paſſing would antony afraid▪ citie brought forth two legious glad thys retired foughte whileſt antony • 〈…〉 ▪ campes ſent •• legion troubled time ſo greate ſuddayne attempt whiche long comming caeſars men ouerthrew antony fight hirtius droue antony campe fighting manfully antony tente ſlayn whoſe body caeſar louing▪ great ſpéed recouered 〈…〉 •• ay •• gote campe till ſhortlye hée repulſed antony watched night armoure antony fallen ſeconde loſſe ſtreighte battell called hys friend counſell thought according former meaning kéepe ſtill ſ •• ge • dena come anye fight loſſes like hirtius ſlayne panſa hurte horſemen better mutina broughte extreame want muſt needes ſhortly giue ouer thus friend thoughte good beſt indede antoni • god ſtriking afraide leaſt caeſar ſhoulde procéede obteyning citie day making walles entrenche hym hauing many pioners purpoſe horſe ſhould good ſaid lepidus plancus wil deſpite one ouercome goe frō modena • tidius wil ſtreight come v thrée legion march • •• ſo ſtrong lepidus pl • ncus take part thus ſaid man afrayde peril leuyed ſéege went ſtraight toward alpes decimus delyuered ſéege began feare caeſar enimie bycauſe conſuls gone wherefore make bridge riuer day ſent acknowledging hymde • meſſengers refuſing thankes decimus gaue quoth came ſaue octauius aunſvvere •• cimus decimus ouerthrow antonie whome reconcyled reaſon come ſpéech fighte decimus nature abhorred let therefore kéepe himſelfe ſo long ſhall ſo ſéeme citie decimus heard farre floud called caeſar name loude voyce redde vnto senate letter giuen prouince celtica • forbad alſo caeſar without conſuls ſhoulde paſſe bridge fraunce none battayle conſulles armyes appoynted decimus panſa béeyng yet aliue lyke ſcape decimus made generall decimus made generall alone agaynſte antonie publike prayer made decimus myghte ouercome antonie ſo greate hate diſpleaſure growen agaynſte antonie • two legion fledde antony confirmed euery souldiour accordyng former promiſe fiue thouſand • ammes common treaſure souldiours fight antony ſhould •••• gh hym theſe done rome panſa beyng poynt death reaſon wounde ſaid thus caeſar ſittyng 〈…〉 friende thy father ſelfe whome coulde 〈…〉 ••• eage beyng ſlayne able reſiſte ſo many whome thou alſo haſte done wiſely obey although thou haddeſt armie firſte fearyng thée antony manne moſte ambitious enclinyng towarde caeſars ſentence haue bene content ſuffer variance conſume ſelues ſawe thou waſt lorde army iyong man ſet thée foorth ſome countenance ſlender honour thou waſt ſtronger eſtimation thou wouldeſt recerue autoritie vnder army gaue thée troubled appoynted thée ioyne v wée mighte take thée twoo legion moſte practiſed hopyng ouercome alone ſhoulde weaker hym deſtroy al caeſars friendes ſet vp pompey ſumme determination hirtius haue done cō miſſion repreſſe antony grewe ſuſpition ouercome wae thought beſte thée one doyng thée benefite▪ remembraunce caeſars amitie onely whiche ſuppoſed thy felicitie tyme come afore time haue giuen thée conſell benefitte nowe antony broken hirtius dead like liue oportunitie ſerueth ſpeake thou ſhouldeſt thanke dead thou beyng borne great felicitie thy déedes ſhewe mighteſt knowe beſte thée chayſe deſtiny hirtius mée armye thou gaueſt v thinke moſt fitte gyue thée agayne ſo yong souldyoures thou couldeſt keepe would alſo giue thée would much offende senate bycauſe officer ſent kéepers v would worke th •• enu • e put thée trouble néedes therefore torquatus pretor ſhall haue thus ſayd deliuered torquatus dyed panſa conſul dyeth senate commaunded ſent decimus caeſar deliuered hirtius panſa funerall greate honor andthe conſuls buryed honourably ſent rome great ſhew syria macedonia time diuers thing happened iulius caeſar paſſed syria left legion myndingcecilius baſſus go againſt parthian cecilius baſſus charge thereof iulius sextus yong man allyed caeſar theiulius sextus dignitie ledde legion without order delitious licentious life baſſus reproued vſed wyth deſpightefulneſſe baſſus againe calling grudgingthe mutiny army syria commaunded ſhould force broughte whē tumult fray made army bearing inlius kylled deſpighte killed iulius whereof ſtreighte repented thē feare caeſar making oth one another vnleſſe forgiueneſſe faith giuen woulde fyght deathe compelling baſſus oth gathered another legion trayned exerciſe thus ſome write baſſus libo writeth baſſus pompey parte battayle liued priuately tyro corrupte ſome legion killed sextus obeyed baſſus howſoeuer matter wente▪ valiantly reſiſted sextius murcus ſente caeſar thrée legion till murcus sextius murcus minutius criſpus bythinia aſia leſſe nexte troy caſ • ius obteyned legion call minutius craſſus ruler bythinia came ayde thrée legion baſſus beſéeged theſe caſsius came great haſt receyued two legion baſſus alſo wanne fire legion beſéeged friendſhip obeyed vnderconſul ſayd decréed ſhould obey caſsius brutus albienus time ſente • lobella aegipt albienus brought thence foure legion whiche ſcattered ouerthrowe craſſus pompey elſe lefte caeſar wyth cleopatra caſsius comming ſuddaynely vpon hym compelled deliuer legion paleſtina afrayd foure legion paleſtina nexte india arabia fighte eyghte caſsius beyonde expectation lord twelue full legion dolobella going aſia caſsius lord tvvelue legion • • dicea noble citie aſia • igh •• ond • • u liodicea frendſhip receyued followed beſéeged whiche thyng senate hearde glad macedonia caius antonius brother antonius marcus dyd make warre brutus hauing one legion armed citizen inferioure brutus layde traynes hym brutus eſcaping catch like traynes nothing taken badde owne souldioures familiar enimies refuſing familiaritie admitting conu • rſation ſuffered freely departe advantage goyng another way appeared ſuddaynely vnto another ſtraight dyd touche p ••• u getteth legion macedonia gently receyued remembring euer thought moſt courteous citizen worthy opinion wiſedome mildeneſſe accepted hys courteſie gaue themſelues vnto caius alſo yéelded hym honor brutus till founde manye brutus gē • le time corruptyng army ſo put away thus brutus former army ſyxe legion prayſing macedonian gathered two legion whome exerciſed italian manner theſe thyngs done siria macedonia itali • caeſar tooke euill decimus made generall agaynſte antonie him▪ hidde hys anger octa •• u deſireth triumph▪ senate denyeth triumph 〈◊〉 deſired hée myghte make triumph feates hée hadde done béeing reiected senate requiring greater thynges belonged hys age hée afraide leaſt antonie ouerthrowen woulde deſpiſe therefore deſired haue conference hym panſa counſelled hym hée dyed souldioures captaynes antony taken hée vſed courteouſly tooke hys owne caeſar vſeth antonyes souldioures vvell woulde ſente antonie ſignification enimie hym ventidius friend antonie hadde broughte thrée legion drewe nygh wyth hys army octa • ius caeſar practi • eth vvith ventidius antonyes friende made hym afrayde nothing hym graunted hym eyther ioyne hym goe antonie fréely hys armie proteſt lacke knowledge • mitted common profite ventidius heard thys wente antonie meane tyme octauius caeſar honoured decius one antony captaynes whome hée hadde taken mutina gaue hym leaue go • antonie woulde octauius ſaying decius captayne antonyes demaunding hys mynde towarde antonie hée ſayde ſhewed ſufficiente manye token coulde perc • yue woulde ignorante woulde ſuffice thus dyd caeſar ſignifye antonie le • idus aſinius playnely ſignifyed deſpight againſt hym myghtie preparation kyllers octauius dealeth vvith iepidus aſinius makyng afrayde increaſe pompeis faction caeſars friendes one another ſhoulde ſerued antonie whych ignoraunce ſuſpition feare longer ſuffer allowed well ſhoulde obey senate octauius pra •••• e vvith antonyes friend faſhion theyr owne ſuretie ſhoulde agrée togyther whyleſt myghte ſhoulde héerein reprooue antony vſe manner legionary departe ſeruice done leaue trade warre diſſeuer leaſte thereby enimie myghte take ſome aduantage rather togither inhabite others place thereto deſirous power ſeuerally euery man countrey conſume owne caeſar ſend lepidus aſinius deci • u armye olde famiſhed full ſickneſſe looſeneſſe bodye decimus army ••• ger 〈…〉 plenty plancus • oyneth vvith decimus newe souldioures yet vnexerciſed▪ plancus ordinarie armye drew nigh vnto decimus wrote senate antonie ſhoulde caught ſnares béeing tyred thing paſt p • mpeys friend hearing maruellouſly reioyce cry time reſtore countreys libertie euerye man made ſacrifices elected tenne men puniſhe antony creation tenne men rome power forme aboliſh caeſars decrées whiche antonie put vre remembrance little nothing himſelfe whiche thing senate well perceyuing occaſion diſanull ſome ſo hoped diſſolue tenne men commaund whoſoeuer hadde receyued anye •• di • tenne men thing antony authoritie contrarye senate ſhould reſtore declare diſobeyed puniſhment threatned pompey ſecte required rule conſuls ſtead hirtius panſa reſt yeare caeſar like senate cicero priuately ſendyng octa • ius requireth conſull vvith cicero exhorting office bycauſe ſage experte better acquainted office would thinke benefyte beare name might haue honeſt pretence leaue armye cauſe required triumph cicero héereby blowen vp ambition ſayde perceyuedthe ambition cicero conſpiracie wrought captaynes abroade therefore thought good pleaſure yong man béeyng well intreated lorde greate armye rather graunte office citie time force armes leaſt might ſomething ſhould content senate wiſhed ſome wiſe antients might appoynted maiſter yong yeares senate laughed cicero ambition kinſmen killer cicero laughed •• againſt • earing caeſar would accuſe ſhould conſull diuerſe lawfull cauſes made delay election antonie tyme paſſed mountaines hauing perſuaded culeo ſuffereth antony paſſe mountaines culeo capitaine lepidus keper paſſage credite hym drewe nighe • ioude lepidus lay without trenche ditche bicauſe would ſhew friend diuerſe meſſages ſent betwéene antony recording diuers friendſhippes pleaſures affirmed hepract • ſe betvvene antony lepidus woulde agrée caeſars 〈◊〉 ſhoulde broughte like calamitie lepidus afraide senate hadde commaunded hym make warre vppon anto •• affyrmed yet 〈◊〉 againſte lepidus army reuer •• cing dignitie antonie perceiuing meſſengers betwéene delighting quietneſſe ſouldiours ſecretly firſte mingled among thē openly fellow citizen ſouldiors forbidden captain making accompte commaundemente made bridge boat ouer riuer mighte better comethe tenth legiō beganne reuo • te lepidus▪ laterenſis togither legion called tenth ſometime wont bée led antonie prepared ten • laterenſis one noble senatoures perceyuing thys opened matter lepidus giuing credite hym willed armye bée diuided diuerſe partes ſent diuers vſes trie treaſon faith lepidus deuided thrée commaunded night • ſhoulde conduct treaſourer armye comming lepidus ſouldioures let antony hand paſſing laſt watch arming themſelues iorney went ſtrongeſt parte campe opened gate antony ranne lepidus tentes armye bringing hym praying lepidus mercie peace afflicted citizen lepidus leapte oute hys antony lepidus ag • ee bed without clothes promyſed ſo • embracing antony excuſed neceſſitie ſaye dydde knéele antonie one cowarde ſmall experience whyche writer • allowe thinke probable hée hadde done parte 〈◊〉 • athe greate povver againe ennimye againſte antony whereby ſhould bée aſrayde hym thus antony riſen agayne greate power béecame moſte fearefull vnto ennimyes hee hadde armye hée ledde modena hée hadde receyued thrée legion waye ventidius newe hadde fellowſhippe lepidus wyth ſeauen legion armed wyth kynde furniture preparation requiſite lepidus bare name among antonie direction ſhewed rome maruellous ſuddayne mutation mindes followed ſome greate boldeneſſe fell feare ſome great feare lifted vppe courage decrées tenne men broken wyth ſpightealteration rome creation conſulles inſtantelye called senate ſtoode doubte doe feared caeſar antonie woulde agrée ſente ſecreatelye lucius panſa brutus andthe senate ſē deth lucius panſa brutus caſsius caſsius viewe publique playes ſette foorthe grecia ſecreatlye required ſoone might bée woulde come helpe libya called twoo thrée legion vnder • xtius thirde commaunded gyuen cornificiu • ruler libya obeyed senate afrayde theſe remembred theythe feare senate hadde ſerued vnder iulius caeſar enclined hys doings doubtefulneſſe droue pointe bycauſe feared newe caeſar woulde conſente wyth antonie nevve caeſar choſen lie • tenāt decimus choſe hym agayne verye vnfitlye lieutenaunte vnder detimus caeſar anger continuallye vſed diſpight ſtirred armye ſhoulde ſente néedye iorney paide fyue thouſande drammes promiſed caeſar ſtirreth ſouldioures againſte senate fyrſte counſelled ſende senate ſent captaines bandes senate knowing wherefore taughte come aunſwered woulde ſende ambaſſadoures vnto whome thus inſtructed ſhoulde priuatelye ſpeake twoo legion wente antonie teache puttesenate ſendeth ſouldi ••• truſte one senate onelye whoſe power eternall ſhoulde goe decimus whither woulde ſende theyr money pretended hadde readye gyue one halfe tenne men ſhoulde appointed payment namyng caeſar eleuenth meſſengers bycauſe legion would ſpoken without caeſar returned vaine caeſar woulde haue ſpeake souldioures tarrye anye longer himſelfe wente armye béeyng aſſembled ſhewed deſpight senate done ment deſtroy euerye one caius caeſars friendes badde beware woulde haue 〈◊◊〉 ſouldioures againſte senate tourne capitayne ſentence god iudged ennimy ſo one ennimye another eyther bée vtterlye deſtroyed debate among themſelues feate mutina common rewarde onelye appointed twoo legion worke ſtrife diſcorde among knowe quoth hée antonie perſecuted pompeyans haue propounded rome agaynſte haue receyued giftes caeſars appointement truſte haue eyther lande money hée gaue ſafetye ſo long kyllers kinſemen doe beare rule senate ſelfe readye take ſuche ende ſhall happen vnto ſhall myne honoure ſuffer father defence ſo manye ſo worthye men whole care béeyng perill father ſake mine know cleare al ambition ſince refuſed authoritie woulde haue giuen ceremony magiſtrate nowe ſee bo •• e oure ſafeties doeth 〈◊〉 deſireth declared 〈◊〉 souldioures conſiſt declared conſull ſo ſhall thing made ſure vnto father hathe giuen landes habitation due vnto ſhall obtaine youre giftes vttermoſte ſéeking puniſhment ſtrihers wyth diſpatche enimies hée hadde thus ſaide armye chearefully made noiſe ſent capitaines againe rome require conſulſhippe caeſar senate obiected againſt hys age captaines inſtructed ſaide olde tyme coruinus conſull hys tyme hymconſulls vnder age coruinus scipio scipio bath firſte ſeconde youth countrey aduaunced comming later tyme broughte forth pompey dolobella caeſar himſelfe graunted conſull tenne yeares béefore hys tyme capitaines ſpeaking thus much boldeneſſe ſome senatoures coulde abide béeyng bandleader ſhould vſe ſuche frée ſpéech senate rebukedthe senate rebuketh ſouldioures menne inſolent became souldioures duety whole armye heard angry deſired might ſtraighte led cittie might make caeſars ſonne conſull famous election whoſe father extolled immortall praiſe octauius ſawe vehemencie octauius • • th againſt 〈◊〉 aſſemblye marched forward eight legion footemē ſufficient number horſemen prouiſion accordingly paſte floude rubicone celtica italy father afore whē moued ciuil war deuided army ij part y• one commaūded follow leyſure ye better toke made much ſpéede minding take vnprouided met part money senate ſent ſouldiours rewarde afrayde bringers gifte ſent • ſecretiye ſome afore afraye whereby wyth theirthe feare rome money fledde awaye report comming rome great trouble tumulte running hyther thyther ſende wiues child carye chiefe ſubſtaunce eyther countrey ſo ſtrongeſt part citie throughly known whyther came onlye aſke conſulſhippe heard came ennimy wyth angry armye afrayde al hand senate greatly ſtroken poweralteration rome ſufficient ſuche feare happeneth one acceſed ſome bycauſe tooke awaye army antony wyth ſuche diſpight ſome bycauſe ſuſpition triumphe whiche right ſome hatred diuiſion money ſome bycauſe appointed eleuenth manne diſtribution ſome bycauſe reward giuē neither ſoone ynough ful ynough ſayd army become enimy▪ blamed contention ſo much ſeaſon brutus caſsius ſo farre antonius lepidus ennimies ſo nygh whome perceyuing redy agrée wyth caeſar made feare grow greater cicero great ſtyrrer nowe cicero ſee •• appeare euerie manne maruellous mutation euerye matter two thouſande fiue hundred dram ſhoulde giuen two legion giue fiue thouſande drammes eight legion ſtéede tenne men make caeſar diſtributour alone graunte hym aſke conſulſhippe abſence ambaſſadours went haſte • inconſtancie 〈◊〉 senate make thys meſſage diligence towne senate repented oug ••• ſo cowardly troubled receiue another •• ran without bloudſhed vſe aſke conſulſhip force captaynes ſhoulde rule countrey pleaſure citie ſhoulde arme themſelues alleage lawes againſte came inuade countrey woulde néedes procéede rather ſuffer ſéege till decimus plancus myghte come better defend themſelues death willingly receyue ſeruitude without redreſſe recyted olde example romanes ſufferance counſell libertie whiche woulde wiſe giue ouer two legion called libya dyd day arriue porte thoughte god exhort mainteyne libertie repenting themſelues woulde reuoke done cicero cicero ſeene agayne appearing among therefore men age appoynted ſerue two legion came libya wyth atvvo legion ••• iue agayne thouſande horſe one legion panſa lefte putte togither whiche deuided one parte kepte hyll ianiculo theyr money lay another kepte paſſage floud officer citie deuiding themſelues ſome hadde broughte money porte shippes boates ouercome myght eſcape sea thus dyd greate boldneſſe ſpéede truſtyng thereby affray caeſar moue hym without army aſke conſulſhippe manfully defende themſelues ſtate myghte change contrarie fortune whyles fyght libertie caeſars mother ſiſter coulde fynde neyther caeſars mother ſiſter ſought priuie open ſearch wherefore made greate ſtirre béeyng ſpoyled ſo great pledge thoughte caeſarians encline bycauſe ſo ſurely hid meſſengers remayning yet wyth caeſar contrarye determination tolde wherefore departed ſhame armye béeyng rather ſtyrred came forwarde wyth greate haſt fearing woman myghte take hurte people tumulte ſente hys horſemen afore willing bée afrayde whereat euery man reioyſing tooke place aboue mount quirinale man daryng encounter reſiſtemount quirinale one ſeuen hilles rome mutation rome hym wherefore maruelous mutation ſéene ſodayne many noble menne wente vnto hym receyued hym common people folowyng vſinghonour gyuen octauian souldiours battayle raye men quiet peace hée leauyng hys armye place nexte daye came cittie ſufficient garde aboute hym cittie mette wyth hym waye euery ſide ſaluted hym omittyng parte humanitie humble ſeruice mother hys siſter temple vestae wythlegions senate goe caeſar octauius holy nunnes ranne embrace hym thrée legion diſpiſing theyr capitaynes ſente embaſſadours vnto yéelde themſelfe cornutus one theyr chiefe capitaynes cornutus himſelf killed hymſelfe truſted hys promiſſe fayth cicero hearyng theſe promyſes practyſed come hym hys friendes whiche beyng done excuſed hymſelfe extolled perſwaſion hée vſed senate cicero 〈◊〉 hys conſulſhippe anſweared onely taunt laſte hys friendes came vnto nyghte ſodayne rumour rayſed twoo legion caeſars martiall fourth reuolted cittie grieued ſhould brought betraye theirlight credite vayne rumor countrey officer senate gaue fayth vnto rumour lightly though army hand thought theſe menne ſo valiant might reſiſt reſte caeſars hoſte till power mighte come place nyghte ſure ſenteancona acilius craſſus picena gather armye commaunded one apuleius tribune runne people wyth thys ioyful tydings senate night came counſell▪ cicero ſtanding dore receyuing greate ioye gladneſſe knowne falſe rumor fledde waye waggon caeſar laughing broughte armye nygher citie place called fielde mar hurt none officer ſo much craſſus yt poſting picene althougheacilius craſſus hee broughte vnto hym ſeruile habite ſpared opinion hys humanitie albeit long put death common treaſure founde ianiculo octauius dealing city place commaunded brought togither al afore appointed cicero diſtributed army two thouſande fiue hundred drammes euery man reſidue promiſed giue done retyred citie till election conſuls choſen q pedius deſired left portion octauius q pedius conſuls caeſars inheritaunce vnto hym came cittie conſul ſacrifiſed appeared twelue gripe romulus token xii vulture builded cittie ſacrifices ended hée gaue himſelfe adoption father according lawe curiate is▪ confirmed adoption people romaine call curia company wardes peoplecur •• phratri • deuided grecian call phratriae fellowſhippes frater • • y vſe among romaine moſt effectuall lawe without father may well legitimate child commaunde kinſefolke frée made men doe adopte one caius caeſars glory manye riche frée made men chiefly cauſe peraduenture thys caeſar firſt adoption teſtament néede alſo diſſolued newe lawe dolobella ſhoulde iudged rebell lawe mighte procéede caeſars killing wherefore accuſations written agaynſte caeſars 〈◊◊〉 againſt 〈◊◊〉 caeſar▪ friend ſtrikers priuie thys obiected againſte ſome ſome bycauſe woulde ſeene caeſar kylled theſe day certayne aſſigned proclamation ſhoulde appeare make annſwere whiche fayling day caeſar himſelfe markyng iudgementes none par •• • ed faulte one noble man hurte butmany conde • ned caeſars death ſhortly condemned deathe wyth thys tyme q gallius brother marius gallius antonyes friende q▪ gallius condemned béeyng pretor citie dyd deſire caeſar lieutenantſhippe libya whyche hadde obteyned wroughte wyles agaynſte caeſar pretor depriued hys office people senate condemned deathe caeſar commaunded hym goe hys brother wyth antony taken shyppe goe neuer ſéene caeſar done theſe greate thing enclined pacification antony hearde brutus▪ hadde twenty legiōs againſt yt would haue antonyes help wente citie towarde ionian sea makyng ſmall iourneys tarried ſée senate would pedius caeſar gone perſwaded grudge ſhould 〈◊〉 councell▪ growe extremitie woulde agrée antony lepidus although perceyued agréement theyr ſake countrey onely helpe caeſar agaynſte brutus caſsius yet neceſſitie determine reuoked ſharp decrées made againſt antonie lepidus souldioures vnder ſende fauourable whyche caeſar wrote letter congratulation vnto promiſed helpe antonie againſte decimus néede senate vſed lyke friendly manner rewardp 〈…〉 cae 〈…〉 gaue harty thākes antonie wrote would plague decimus caeſar pl • n ••• himſelfe ioyne caeſar thus wrote one another whileſt antonie purſued decimus aſinius pollio came vnto two legion practiſed haue pacifyed plancus reconcyled vvith antony wyth plancus plancus thrée legion agréed antony ſo muche nowe antony hadde moſt myghtie power decimus hadde tenne legion whereof foure moſte warlike féebled hunger yet vexed ſickeneſſe newe taken ſyxe legion vnexperte fearefull wherefore decimus doubting fyghte determined decimus driuē flee hys army forſaketh rauenna aquileia flée brutus macedonia paſſe mountaynes rauenna aquileia bycauſe caeſar comming waye hée tooke longer harder r • n • floud italy runneth farre 〈◊〉 iourney paſſe rene goe wilde place barbarous people newe souldioures oppreſſed wante heate forſooke hym wente caeſar foure legion older souldioures wente antony multitude frenche horſemen men béeyng gard hys perſon except gaue leaue woulde goe euery man hys owne gaue ſuch golde hadde ſo came rene decimus forſakē thrée hundred bycauſe paſſage hard forſooke hym ſaue fewe whyche fewe alſo ſhortly dyd leaue hym wyth tenne onely changing hys garmente lyke french man whoſe language coulde ſpeake wente forthe one nation ha • ty iourneys eaſlie aquileia thynking ſo fewe myghte wel eſcape béeyng taken théeues bounde aſked prince 〈◊〉 taken vvith eues lorde parte ſayde camillus muche eſtéemyng name camillus deſired myght broughte hym whocamillus ſawe hym apparance ſpake fayre hym rebuked taker without regard hadde ſo euill entreated ſo noble man priuily ſent vnto antony antony mouedbarbarous 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 killed one camillus commaundemente 〈◊〉 mutation coulde abyde ſée willed camillus kyll hym ſende hym hys head whyche ſawe commaunded buryed thys ende hadde decimus captayne caeſars horſemen • na hym made ruler olde france yeare come elected conſull gouernoure fraunce ſeconde kyllers nexte trebonius puniſhed yeare halfe caeſars deathe verye tyme minutius baſill • one caeſars quellers alſo killed minuti •• baſil •• killed ovvne men hys owne ſeruauntes bycauſe made ſome eunuch puniſhmente ⸪ ende thirde booke ciuill diſſentions ¶ fourth booke appiane alexandria ciuill diſſentions rome thus two caeſars killer ouerthrowen prouinces puniſhment trebonius aſia decimus celtica nowe caſsius brutus chiefe conſpiracie againſt caeſar plagued lordes lande betwéene syria macedonia hauing mighty power sea land twenty armed legtons beſyde horſemen shyppes money wyll thys fourth booke ciuill diſcorde ſhal declare ſame inquiſitions ſearchers appoynted dye proſcription lamentable affliction euerye 〈◊〉 • condemnation 〈◊〉 lavve kill men vvhereſoeuer founde ſyde ſuche neyther among greeke ſeditions tumultes among romaine themſelues hadde bin done remembrance ſauing onely sylla fyrſte proclamation condemned hys foe dye marius onely ſéeke puniſhe whome founde sylla greate rewardes lyke puniſhmentes conceale proſcribed menne 〈◊〉 caughte marius sylla dyd ſhewed matter nowe reſt ſhall follow order caeſ • r antonie enimies made friendes aboute 〈…〉 〈…〉 e 〈…〉 e 〈◊〉 〈…〉 citie modene little playne ilande floude lab •••• eache hauyng fyue armed legion whiche beyng placed one oueragaynſte another eyther wyth thrée hundred came bridge riuer lepidus béeing come afore ſearche ile made token wyth hys cloke come lefte theyr companyes wyth theyr friendes bridge came myddeſt place myghte bée ſéene ſate thrée downe caeſar myddeſt bycauſe office two dayes mornyng tyll nyghte conferred made thys determination • caeſar ſhould gyus ouer hys conſulſhippe ventidius receyue reſt yeare newe office ſhoulde inſtituted lawe redreſſe ciuill trouble lepidus antonius caeſar ſhoulde haue authoritie fyue yeares wyth ſame power conſulles haue ſo thought beſt name peraduenture bycauſe antonyes decrée forbiddyng anye man bée dictator ſhoulde appoynte office citie yeare yeare duryng fyue yeares diuide prouinces antony ſhoulde haue fraunce thys ſyde thenovv narbona pirenei mountaynes excepte whiche call olde celtica lepidus ſhoulde rule spayne caeſar ſhoulde gouerne lybia sardinia sicelie ilande thus theſe thrée diuide romaine empire leauing prouinces beyonde sea bycauſe brutus caſsius gouernoures antony caeſar ſhould make warre vpon brutus caſsius lepidus ſhoulde conſull time come remayne citie occaſions gouerne spayne deputy lepidus ſhoulde reteyne thrée legion owne army defence rome ſeauen ſhoulde diuided betwéene caeſar antony caeſar ſhoulde haue thrée antony foure eyther myghte leade twentye legion warre ſhoulde encourage armyes well rewardes victorie giftes promiſe eyghtéene city italie excelling ſubſtance ſ • yle fayre buyldings landes houſes ſame ſhoulde deuided vnto though bin taken warre amongſt reſt theſe chiefe cap •• reggi • ven • ſia beneuent • nuceria arimeno vibona▪ city italy deuided ſpoyle thus fayreſt partes italie aſſigned souldioures alſo agréed euery ſhoulde diſpatche hys priuate enimies trouble myghte come vppon theſe determination ſhoulde bée gene farre make long warre countrey theſe thyngs ſigned wyth handes caſar conſull dyd declare armye▪ ſauyng onely theyr name appoynted dye souldioures hearde glad embraced togither ioy theſe béeyng done many monſters terrible tokenstokens rome ſéene rome dogges yéelled like wolues fearefull warning wolues ranne common place beaſt wonte ſéene rome oxe ſounded man voyce childe ſpake ſoone borne image ſweate dyd ſweate bloud greate voyces men noyſe harneſſe running horſes hearde nothyng ſéene aboute sunne manye vnpleaſante ſightes stormes alſo ſtones continuall lightning fell vppon temple picture thys cauſe senate ſente southſayers prophetes •• • moſt auntiente whyche affirmyng olde kyngs ſhoulde returne euery man ina rare example southſayer bondage himſelfe alone ſhutte mouth ſtopped hys breath tyll dyed theſe thrée men beyng thus alone themſelues dyd appoynte ſhoulde dye ſuſpected ſome power regiſtred theyr priuate enimies ſome theyr owne familiar friendes gaue dye ſerue eache others turne afterwarde ſo men condemned one another ſome enemitie ſome onely little offence louing hys enimies hatyng hys friendes béeyng riche bycauſe wanted much money maynteyne warre brutus caſsius receyuing rente tribute aſia béeyng alſo holpen kynges prince aſmuche wante bycauſe europe chiefely italie waſted wyth warres paymentes dyd put gréeuous impoſition vpon common ſorte menne woman made artificer workemen pay tribute ſome proſcribed goodneſſe hys land houſes thus theſe condemned dye bée confiſcate whereof thereequites thrée hundred senator two thouſande bée called gentleman among whyche bréethren vncles theſe hadde condemned ſome ruled army vnder many hadde diſpleaſed leader vnder intendyng condemne multitude conference theyr béeyng rome appoynted twelue ſuddayne ſome ſay ſeauentéene chiefeſt bée kylled whereof cicero one ſente aboute foure ſtraight kylled theyr table mette ſoughte houſes temple ſo ſudden trouble al night among cry running andmiſerie rome yelling citie taken knowen menne ſhoulde bée apprehended certenty vppon whome proſcription woulde fall euery man thoughte himſelfe bée ſought made enquirie wherefore confuſion ſome hadde determined burne owne thynges ſome ſette publike place fyre intending good reaſon doe ſome notable feate woulde ſuffer hadde done hande hadde pedius conſull gone aboute proclamation comforted tarrie till truth throughly knowen morning come pedius according ſentence thrée men condemne ſeauentéene ſuppoſed chiefe author ciuill euils onely condemned whereof gaue faith publikely reſt knowing done 〈◊〉 conſull dye •• labour tooke nighte dyed thrée men lepidus antonius caeſar entred rome one himſelfe thrée ſeuerall dayes gardes perſons one legion péece▪ order battell come citie full souldioures enſignes placed fytte aſſemblie whyche publius • tiu tribune people publius • tiu propoundeth nevv rule three men dyd lawe confyrme newe rule appoyntemente preſente fyue yeares thrée men lepidus antonius caeſar equall power conſuls whyche man myghte call reformer greeke manner 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 vvas name among lacedemonians▪ vvhich vvere ruler city caſtels encreaſe condemned mē name lacedemonians gaue directed ſta • e neyther reſpite gyuen approbation ſpeciall daye appoynted voyces vſed hande lawe tooke place nyghte condemnation thirtis beſyde ſeauentéene one hundred ſette vp many place citie ſhortlye another hundred fiftie euer ſome added booke firſte condemned kylled ignorance myghte bée thoughte worthy dye ordered theyr head ſhoulde brought thrée men rewarde appoynted frée man rewarde ſyluer seruantes libertie ſyluer receyued condemnedrevvards man concealed hindred ſearch ſhould bée puniſhed lyke payne euery man myghte declare agaynſte whome hée woulde ſame rewarde proclamation thys ſorte men ſhould ſuffer priuate place ſearched marcus lepidus marcus antonius octauius caeſar choſenthe proclamation three men reformer directoures common wealthe ſaye thus vnfaythfull euill diſpoſed menne hadde bene pitied néeded ſo become enimies benefactours cōſpired againſt ſlayne caeſar whome tooke warre ſaued mercy accompted friend plentifully aduaunced office honour giftes ſhould haue ben compelled thus violently vſe haue ſuche deſpite made proclamation treaſon againſt v euill meaning towarde v worſe working toward caeſar perceyuing humanitie malice made obſtinate haue choſen rather preuent taken tardy let man thinke act vniuſt cruell ſore conſidering caeſar haue ſuffered handes caeſar chief ruler prince holy thing conquerour ouerthrower nation moſt terrible romaine firſt man beyond hercules pillers proue ſea ſayled founde lande vnknowen romanes middeſt ſacred place called senate houſe ſight goodes haue en • io • ſly killed xxi •• woundes tooke priſoners warre onely ſaued liues made ſome heyres liuing reſte ſame wicked purpoſe haue ſente theſe deteſtable offendours ſtéede puniſhment rule prouinces army whiche abuſe ſpoyling common treaſure gatheryng one army againſt v requiring barbarian alwayes enimies ſtate certaine citties belongyng romanes refuſing obey them▪ haue burned ſpoyled raſed others oppreſſed terrible threatnings force agaynſt countrey v wée haue already puniſhed ſome helpe god ye ſhall ſoone ſée reſt haue • ſte deſerte greateſt matter touchyng spayne fraunce home haue commaundement well diſpatched neuertheleſſe wée haue harde ſharpe worke hande make warre agaynſt murderer caeſar • e beyonde ſeas bicauſe wée ſhall make warre abrode thinke ſure neyther v leaue enimies home mighte diſturbe v abſence wayfe theyr time warre ſhoulde haue ſucceſſe neyther make delay haſty expedition rather ridde one hauyng begonne warre agaynſt v iudged v army traytours countrie regardyng neyther enuy manne reuengment god deſtroying ſo many million citizen wée offended agaynſt multitude take enimies haue bene ſo v altogither weigh rich ſubſtaunce dignity kill ſo many chiefe ruler haue done v redreſſed citie 〈…〉 lyke ciuill diſſentions whome lucky doings call happie although muſte néedes enimies thrée one onely worſte moſte wicked ſorte well ſelfes wée entende correct otherwiſe contention betwéene v muſte néedes vtterly deſtroyed neceſſitie armie hath bene ſo iniuried deſpighted haue bene proclaimed publique enimies muſt néedes ſome way comforted hande wée mighte lay handes vppon condemned wée woulde yet thought better pronounce aduentures oppreſſe ſake leaſt rage souldiours mighte exceede vppon touched name beyng comprehended certayne number might leaue reſt decrée good fortune may come conteyned wryting lette manne receyue manne hyde ſende away wonne money 〈…〉 doe ſaue helpe founde pryuye without ſléepe drew garment frō body lay vpon him▪ til ſeruants perceyuing thyng taking bee token god put cicero litter ledde toward sea thicke wood rode ſecreatly many run euery ſide aſking ſawe cicero ſome good pittie ſaide gone ſailed ouer ſea ſhomaker tenaunt clodie thea shomaker • e vvrayeth cicero ſharpeſt enimie cicero tolde laena captayn went fewe ranne ſeing ſeruants manye moe broughte readye place tooke heade hande ſhewed farre maruellous ioyful crowned capitaine gaue honoure great gift ſay two hundred fiftie thouſand 〈◊〉 athens bycauſe diſpatched greateſt buſieſt enimy cicero head hande ſette vppe tyme common place tribunall wonte make oration came ſée heare ſay antony ſette ciceroes head vppon table meale till fill ſighte euill thus cicero man moſte eloquent daye hauing borne office conſul greateſt cauſes moſt profytable countrey thus deſtroied death▪ deſpighted▪ cicero h • ſonne ſent 〈◊〉 hys ſonne ſent grecia brutus qu •• tus cicero ſonne kylled▪ quintus ciceroes brother ſon béeing taken praied ſtrikers kill ſonne hys ſonne deſired contrary wherefore ſouldioures promiſed bothe theyr requeſtes takyng aſunder token killed ignatius father ſonne one inſtante ignatius father ſonne fightyng togither dyed one wounde heades ſtriken body yet embrace balbus ſent ſonne ſea ſhoulde eſpied balbus hys ſonne going togither ſhortely followed aloofe one tolde either malice ignorance ſonne taken went backe ſent killer chaunced ſon drowned sea like calamitie fortune giue aruntius coulde hardelye perſwade ſonne would aruntius ſonne flée without ſaue himſelfe bycauſe yong mother ſent afore gate retourned burye hir huſbande killed ſhe hearde ſhortely afterhis vvife hir ſonne deade ſea hunger ſhée killed hirſelfe theſe example good euill child ij brother condemned called ligari • béeing ligari • tvvo brother hidde fel aſléepe til one found hys ſeruants killed making eſcape hearing hys brother death threwe himſelfe bridge riuer whome fyſhermen ſaued one fell chance purpoſe ſtroue great ſhoulde ſaue threwe himſelfe vnder water ſtronger bringing vppe ſafe ſaide haue ſaued put ſelues daunger death condemned man yet hauing pittie ſaued hym til ſouldiors kepte bridge ſaw ran cut heade two brother one threw himſelfe riuer histvvo brethren▪ ſeruaunt ſéekyng body fiue dayes whiche founde knewe cut head reward brother hid ſakes ſeruaunte bewraye souldioures refuſed goe weapon speares pulled vp body cutte hie head ſuche caſe another vnderſtanding brother proſcribed andtvvo brother knowing hymſelfe ſo ranne cryed kyll hym captayne knowyng truth condemnation thou makeſt reſonable requeſt quoth thou waſt condenmed hym ſo order kylled theſe example broethren ligarius béeyng hydde hys wyfe made one onely maydea good vvife hath euill lucke priuie béeyng betrayed hir ſhe followed bare away hir huſbandes head cry muſt haue like puniſhmente bycauſe haue hydde hym none souldyoures woulde kyll hyr accuſe hir wente bewray hir ſelfe prince bycauſe regarde hyr pitie ſhe deſtroyed hir ſelfe hunger hyr haue thoughte good note thys place bycauſe willing ſaue hir huſbande coulde ſhe kylled hyr ſelfe hunger good lucke good loue theyr huſbandes wyll wrighte among ſaued theyr▪ huſbandes wickedly dyd betray theyr huſbandes one▪that married septimius whyche corrupted loue friende antonyes deſirousan euill vvife hys harlot made wife cauſed hym ſpeake antony haue hir forthwith septimius condemned thing learning wife ignorant euill home fledde hir ſhe ſoeming carefull kéepe ſhutte dores hydde hym tyll ſtrikers came one daye kylled ſhe married salaſſus fledde béeyng wythout hope nyghte refurnedsalaſſus citie abydetyll ſharpeneſſe time myghte ceaſſe came houſe ſolde enely houſekéeper ſold houſe knew broughte hym hys lodge promiſed kéepe hym hidde power hadde call captaynemaſſala refuſed perſuaded gyue place aduerſe fortune ioyne wyth antony wherefore hée greate credite antonie agréed wyth hym tyll hée reproued hym hys wanton dealing wyth cleopa • ra wente ſecretely béeyng betrayed acilius good vvife hys seruaunte souldyoures hée perſuaded hope muche money ſende ſome wyfe wyth token whyche tooke broughte vnto hyr ſtore ſaying ſhe dyd delyuer vnto though woulde performe theyr promiſe yet ſhée knewe whether woulde ſhe deceyued thys good liking hyred ſhippe acilius ſente siceli • lentulus béeyng deſired hys wyfe flée wyth hym lentulus good vvife diligentlye attendyng hym hée woulde putte hyr daunger fledde ſecretely sicelie • éeyng made lieutenaunte pompey hee ſente hyr worde howe hée • ſcaped office hearyng hyr huſbande ſecretely lefte hyr mother good eye vpon hir wyth two seruauntes wyth greate payne wante ſhe ſlaue went till ſhe came meſsina reggi • aboute nyghte eaſilie learning lieutenantes tente ſhe founde lentulus lieutenant poore
