captayne metellus father ſonne vnder antonie actio▪ taken pryſoner vnknowen sonne ſerued caeſar capitaine ſame fielde caeſar gyue ſentence vppon captiues samo yong man preſente olde manne samo • e ouer agaynſt • ho good sonne brought foorth forlorne long heare miſerie wante tranſformed ſame order captiues called crier hys sonne lepte hys ſeate embraced father whome ſcarſly knew teares ceaſed ſorowe hée ſayde caeſar hath bene thine enimie caeſar thy friende thou muſte puniſhe rewarde deſire thée ſaue father mée lette die hym euery man takyng pittie caeſar commaunded metellus ſaued though hys enimie afore deſpyſing many gyftes drawne antonie ſeruauntes marcius good loue fortune marcius good ſeruaunts tyme proſcription dyd kéepe hym within hys houſe till feare ſet aſide marcius came houſe baniſhment hirtius wyth hys menne fléeyng cittie wente aboutehirtius italie deliuered pryſoners gathered togither fledde tooke townes firſte moe number till ſufficient armie ouercame parte brut •• n whence ſendyng army ſayled al 〈◊◊〉 pompey restio thoughte fledde alone seruaunte followed reſtio good ſeruaunt hym ſecretelye beeyng broughte vppe hym aforetyme well vſed euill condition branded restio reſted fenne ſée seruaunte ſo nighe hym afrayde whome seruaunte ſayde hée ſo much remember preſent brandes hée dyd former benefites ſo cauſed hym ſo repoſe caue prouided meate hym well hée coulde • cane ſuſpected souldyours drewe nighe restio hée seruaunte perceyuyng matter followed killed olde man paſſed cutte hys heade souldiours beyng angrye commyng aboute take killer hée ſayde haue kylled mayſter restio gaue mée theſe brandes tooke heade haue rewarde caryed vayne citie seruaunt comforted bye mayſter ſayled hym sicelie appion reſtyng ſtable souldiours ſought hym appion good ſeruant ſeruaunt put garment lay vppon bedde willingly receyued death hys mayſter ſittyng forme ſeruaunt memmius houſe ſoughte souldiours one whoſe seruauntes wente litter hys fellowes bearyng 〈◊〉 good ſeruaunt hym hadde bene theyr maiſter béeyng taken contente die maiſter fledde sicelie iunius hadde frée made manne philemon hadde 〈◊〉 good ſeruaunt fayre houſe hée kepte hys mayſter vaughte whiche woonte laye harneſſe money wrytinges fedde hym nyghte tyll peace made frée made man kéepyng sepulchre hys maſter alſo preſerue maiſters sonne ſame graue togither father lucretius wanderyng twoo faythfull ſeruauntes forlucretius lacke meate returned hys wyfe beyng borne litter hys ſeruauntes citie ſicke man happened one ſeruaunts broken hys legge hée wente tyll hée came gate hys father afore beyng proſcrybed sylla taken souldiours commyng aboute hym hée muche afrayde lucke place wherefore hée fledde ſeruaunte hydde hym graue chaunſing robber sepulcher dyd ſearche graues ſeruaunt offered hymſelfe bée ſpoyled robber whyles maiſter fledde gate tarried tyll hys ſeruaunt came hym whoſe garmentes hée put wente hys wyfe vnder whoſe care beyng kepte hée hidde betwene twoo beames till hée pardoned meanes made ſome thrée menne peace made office conſull sergius hydde antonie hymſelfe tyll hée haddesergius perſwaded plancus conſull proclayme hys reuocation agayne diſſention caeſar antonie antonie declared enimye senate hée onely openly gaue voyce hys acquitall thus theſe ſaued pomponius decked hymſelfe lyke pretor hys ſeruantspomponius lyke sergeaunts ſo went thorough citties wyth mace officer rounde aboute hym hée ſhould bée knowne gate hée tooke publyque coach wente thorough italie euery manne receyuyng hym ſendyng hym pretor appoynted thrée menne make truce wyth pompey whome alſo hée came publike galley apuleius aruntius counterfaiting themſelues capitaynesapuleius aruntius ſeruauntes souldiours ranne gate capitaynes purſued others way deliuered pryſoners receyued ſuche came ſo eyther ſufficient bande enſignes armour ſhe •• e army chancing diuerſe wayes went toward sea bothe camped one hil great feare lookyng one another mornyng hauyng cléere ſight thinkyng eyther bene ſente deſtroy fought fiercely tyll knewe truthe repenting déede threw away weapōs wayled fortune ſhoulde ſo contrarie tooke ſhippe one ſaylyng brutus pompey went pompey vnder brutus preſident bythinia brutus dead deliuered antonie ſaued ſeruaunt ventidius firſte condemned put ventidius good ſeruauntes fetter though woulde haue deliuered hym killer night perſwaded hys felowes cladde lyke souldiours mayſter lyke capitaine wente lyke bande appoynted brought mayſter citie paſſing italy sicelie many tymes méeting capitaynes ſought ventidius another hidde hys mayſter sepulchre hée coulde abyde fearfulneſſe fanſie sepulchre hée hidde homely houſe nyghe whiche souldiour dwellyng coulde abyde feare neyther wherefore turnyng feare extréeme boldeneſſe ſhaued hys head played ſchoolemayſter rome till truce volutius aedile condemned hauyng friendſhip volutius prieſtes iſis vvere clad vvith garment dog head caleni campania sittius prieſt iſis borowed ſtole veſture downe foote put dogges heade maner furious ſeruice paſſed ſafe pompey calenians dyd kéepe sittius citizen liberally ſpent ſubſtance vpon weapon warded rebuking ſeruants kéeping ſoldiours frō walles till furye béeyng paſte ſent thrée men obtayned sittius excluded reſt italy ſhould remainea banished man countrey countrey sittius firſte onelye man ſtraunger outlawe owne countrey varr • philoſopher writer hiſtories hauing doonevarr • good ſeruice warres place lieutenaunt therefore peraduenture ennimie monarchie condemned friend béeyng deſirous receiue andit ſaide antony pardoned varro vvith theſe vvords viuat varro vndoctiſſimus contending hym calenus obtay ned hym kept vineyarde whither antony came ſometyme walke yet neuer one within bewraye varro neyther hys owne ſeruaunts calenus virginius eloquentman taughte ſeruauntes ifvirginius kylled little money danger ſhoulde get hate length great feare ſaued ſhould win ſure glory good hope hereafter money muche abundant certaine wherefore fled fellowe ſeruaunte way béeing knowne fought ſouldiours taken tolde alſo woulde kill hym anye malice onelye hope money ſhoulde haue iuſtlye plentifullye would go hym ſea quoth wife hathe ſhippe mony perſuaded brought hym ſea wife ſhée appointed came ſea bycauſe hir huſbande tarryed thinking bin gone pompey ſhe went hir way leauing ſeruāt ſhore ſhe whim ſo whē virginius come ſeruant ranne vnto ſhewed ſhippe ſayled maiſtreſſe ſaid money left behinde tell ſouldiours perceiuing al true virginius deſired ſtaye til might call wife backe goe hir mony tooke boate great labour rowed sicelie receyuing promiſe woulde goe tarryed till ende certaine marrinet receyued rebulus ſhippe goerebulus sicelie required mony would accuſe didde themiſtocles fledde thatthemiſtocles threatned would accuſe receyuing mony wherefore mariner afrayde broughte vnto pompey murcus lieutenante vnder brutus condemnedmarcus brutus ouercome taken made himſelfe ſeruant whome barbula bought perceyuing himbarbuli • apte made chiefe fellowes gaue money beſtowe ſawe ſtill wiſe diligent common nature ſeruantes put hope one proſcribed men woulde ſaue woulde confeſſe denying earneſtly declaring ſtocke name former mayſters caried rome thinking bene condemned man woulde haue refuſed goe followed chéerefully gate conſuls houſe friend barbulas ſaw murcus • eruile maner wayting vpon ſecretly tell eare agrippa obteined caeſar murcus pardoned remained friende caeſar long happened captaine warre againſte antonie actio barbula capitayne antony fortune camebarbula bothe alike antonie ouerthrowen taken counterfeyted ſeruant whome murcus bought ignorant ſhewing caeſar obteyned hysequall fortune pardon ſo requited former benefit theſe fortune like ſides ſo continued officer togither one dignitie rome balbinus fléeing retourning pompey made balbinus lepidus depoſed 〈…〉 conſull hapned lepidus ſo great prince made priuate man caeſar came neceſſitie y• maecenas accuſe lepidus ſonne conſpiracie againſt caeſar alſo accuſed mother conſenting hir ſonne lepidus himſelfe weake man deſpiſed ſonne ſent caeſar actio mother bicauſe ſhe woman • aryed required ſuretie putte conſull man would hir ſuretie lepidus wayted many time balbinus dores comming ſate judgemente ofte repulſed officer length much ado ſpake thus accuſers confeſſe mine innocencie affirming lepidus ſute vvife neyther conſenting wife ſonne didde proſcribe thée one proſcribers haue reſpect vnto chaunces worlde attende vpon thée giue grace eyther wife may goe caeſar vpon ſuretie bounde goe hyr while lepidus ſpake balbinus conſidering mutation cicero ſon deliuered wife hir bonde yong cicero ſent father grecia foreſeing would come greece went brutus brutus death pompey honoured place lieutenaunt caeſar cléere himſelf cicero iniuriethe bishop old rome vvere magiſtrates iudges religion made ſtraight biſhop long conſul preſident syria whē caeſar ouercame antony actio yet conſul caeſar wrote letter readde people rome ſate ſeate juſtice father head put appius diuided ſubſtance among ſeruants ſayledappius sicelie watching mony ſtorm ryſing put boate might ſayle ſafetie chaunced boate ſaued beyonde hope drowned theyr ſhippe publius treaſurer brutus familie anteny publius requeſted forſake brutus bicauſe would proſcribed yet returned friende caeſar caeſar came woulde ſhewe brutus picture prayſed caeſar theſe thing beyonde hope happening proſcribed men daunger ſafetie many moe omitted thought chiefe declared matter thus paſſed rome place theſe trouble ful enimies great warres fell libya cornificius againſt sextius syria caſsius againſt dolobella sicilia pompey great affliction among citties captiuitie ouerpaſſe leſſe greateſt appeared worthie reſt loadicea tharſus rhodes patareans xantheans euery beginning order haue gathered write theſe romaine call parte yet olde libya wanne carthaginenſes whiche king iuba helde andolde libya gotten caeſar call newe libya may bée numidia sextius preſident new libya vnder caeſar commaundednevve libya sextius cornificius cornificius giue place olde thoughe libya caeſars lot thrée men made diuiſion ſayd knew ſuche diuiſion made thrée men among themſelues woulde deliuer prouince receiued senate onelye againe cauſe made war one againſt another cornificius armye well appointed great number sextius lighte harneſſed fewer whiche comming abroade hée cauſed men reuolte cornificius gaue repulſe ventidius captaine cornificius comming vpon luſtily beſieged laelius captayne cornificius went abrode wan cirta place sextius al ſent arabion cirta cittie numidia vvhere • ugurth kylled adherbal arabion sittius king called sittians take part warre ſo called thys cauſe sittius rome abiding ſentence quarrell fled gathering army came frō italy spaine libya tooke part among libyan king warred togither ioyned gotte victorie called sittian bycauſe army valiantlysittians caius caeſar perſecute pompey friend fyghte libya ouerthrewe sabura iubas lieutenant famous man whiche cauſe sittius rewarded caeſar manaſſa manaſſes king manaſſes land al beſt part manaſſes arabions father confederate iuba lande caeſar gaue sittius bocchus king maruſians one part whereof sittius diuided people vnder arabion fledde iberia pompeis child caius caeſar killed retourned againe libya euer ſending ſome libyan yonger pompey iberia receyuing expert ſouldiours thence tooke hys lande bocchus diſpatched sittius craft ſtill friend pompeyans perceyuing fortune full infelicitie without hope agréede sittius ſoone hym reconciled caeſar sittians alſo father beneuolence wyth caeſar ioyned wyth hym sestius nowe emboldned came ſiege fight ventidius ſlayne army fledde without guyde whome chaſed killed tooke many laelius hearing leuied ſiege cirta wente cornificius seſtius hauty feat went cornificius vtica encamped againſt hauing much people cornificius ſending laelius horſmen take view seſtius ſent arabion horſe againſt laelius face horſe better appointed came vpon ſide diſordred hym ſo laelius thoughe inferior yet fearing retire ſhoulde haue bene ſhutte tooke hill betwéene arabion hée directed kylled manye compaſſed reſte cornificius ſéeing came foorthe wyth hys whole power helpe laelius seſtius ſette vpon back ſodayne charge whome cornificius endeuoured repell great trauaile arabion meane time créeping mē ſtony place came ſecretly ouer mountaines vpon cornificius campe roſcius kéeper campe diſtreſſed offered roſcius kylled hys throate cutte page cornificius wearie fyght went laelius mountaine cornificius killed knowing doone campe arabion▪ horſemen came vpon killed laelius ſéeing al ielius kylleth kyniſelfe vpon hill kylled himſelfe captaines deade army fled ſeuerally ſuche proſcribed men cornificius ſome fledde sicelie ſome whither could seſtius rewarded arabion sit • ians goodly gift citties pardoned obey caeſar ende warre libya betwixte cornificius laelius ſhorte man conſider feates doone wyth ſo great ſpéede brutus caſsius compariſon theſe little wasbrutus caſſius done caius caeſar killed murderer tooke capitoll obi • uion al thinges decréed came people funerall caeſar moued wyth pittie ranne aboute ſéeke quellers driuing backe toppes houſes went prouinces caeſar appointed caſsius brutus beyng yet pretor citie aſſigned alſo caeſar prouinces caſsius siria brutus macedonia bycauſe coulde goe prouinces time abide hate citiebrutus caſſius wente away yet office senate conſideration appointed purueioures prouiſion meane time ſhoulde thought flée away beyng gone syria macedonia apointed decrée antony dolobella conſuls senate béeing muche grieued gaue ſteade thereof creta cirene whiche regarding ſhorte tyme gathered much money men entred syria macedonia thus wroughte dolobella hadde kylled trebonius aſia antonie hadde ouercome decimus celtica senate offended decrée antonie dolobella enimies reſtored brutus caſsius former prouinces added brutus illyria commaunding al ruler romaine illyria added brutus dominion well prouinces army obey brutus caſsius caſsius preuented dolobella entring syria vſed token office gathered twelue legion moſte parte hadde ſerued bin trained vnder casus caeſar one whiche caeſar hadde lefte syria goe thepaſſus sextus iulius▪ war againſt parthian charge secilius baſſus dignitie sextus iulius hadde yong man caeſars kinſman laſciuious ſuffering legion fall riot baſſus reproued wherefore fell baſſus called hym raſcall waxing diſobedient baſſus commaunded hym broughte sergeant whereof tumulte growing baſſus beyng daunger killed armye abiding diſorder killed iulius whiche repenting fearing caeſars diſpleaſure agréed togither vnleſſe forgiueneſſe woulde fyght til death compelled baſſus getting legion trained valiātly ouercame sextius murcus ſente againſte thrée legion caeſar murcus came aide minutius criſpus bythinia murcus thrée legion beſieged baſſus ſixe legion caſsius comming reliefe baſſus receiued hys armye fréely minutius murcus deliuering tominutius hym legion goodwill obeyed thinges y• senate cōmaūded albinus ſent dolobella brought oute aegipt foure legion remnaunt pompeius craſſus diſcomfiture caeſar left wt cleopatra caſsius ſet vpon palestina knowing nothing theſe chaunces ſo ſodainely compelled deliuer armye afraide foure legion fyght againſte eight thus caſsius beyond al expectation lord twelue legion manye parthian archer horſebacke came ſerue caſsius hée known among officer craſſus campe dolobella remained ionia diſpatching trebonius trebonius▪ putting tribute vpon city lucius figulus • figulus hyring nauies rhodes lycian pamphagonians celicians whē ready determined go syria himſelfe land two legion figulus ſea hearing caſsius army tourned hys iorney laodicea cittie friendly hym ioyning cherroneſus fitte al ſurniture 〈…〉 • ore • well paſſage sea citties ph • nitia maketh •• polis tyrus sido • excuſes cleopatra telligence cleopatra ſent many ſhips hadde quéene made excuſe caſsius hunger peſtilēce wherwith aegipt oppreſſed familiarity former caeſar ſhée fauoured dolobella determination ſhe ſente hym four legion albinus ſufficient company ſea bicauſe winde ſtayed rhodians lycian ſaid woulde helpe neither brutus caſsius ciuill warres giuen lyke fade coulde corrupte marſus chiefe watch night wanne marſus loadicea vvon dolobella killed captaines band warded day marſus reſting daye gate opened entred diuers part army citie taken dolobella bad one guard cutte heade carrie caſsius ſaue owne whiche killed himſelfe marſus alſo ridde life caſsius hauyng gotten citie ſware armie dolobella himſelfe laodiceans ſacred publyke thing ſpoyled laodicea ſpo •••• chief citie puniſhed oppreſſed grieuous payment brought citie extréeme miſerie laodicea hée wente towarde aegypt vnderſtandyng cleopatra dyd ſayle greate nauie caeſar antonie thynkyng hée myghte ſtoppe hir voyage reuenged hyr vnderſtandyng aegipt greate diſtreſſe famine hauyng greate army ſtraungers souldiours beyng gone albinius beyng hope determination brutus haſte aduertiſed hym caeſar antonie dyd paſſe ionian sea caſsius vnwillyngly lefte enterpryſe aegipt ſente away parthian archer horſebacke wyth rewardes meſſengers theyr king ayde whiche commyng done ranged syria nighe nation ionia departed caſsius lefte hys nephewe syria one legion horſemenne hée ſente afore cappadocia ſuddenly ſette vppon ariobarzanes diſtreſſed ariobarzanes kyng one meante deceyue caſsius brought money rich caſsius tharſiās beyng debate one parte honoured caſsius comyng tharſue diuiſi • citie cilicia floudde cydno firſte dolobella ſhew city authoritie embracing turne ſerued either ſide ſuch chāgeable citie vſed oth •• extréemely caſsius ouercome dolobella commaunded paye thouſand fiue hundred talentes knowingthe calamitie tharſus doe beyng deſpight requyred souldiours therevnto compelled ſell pryuate iewels holy thing common whiche triumphes ſacrifices whiche ſuffiſing magiſtrates ſolde frée people firſte virgines men child woman olde men pityfully theyr youngmen whereof many killed themſelues caſe caſsius came syria ſtayed pitties caſsius shevveth ſouie pittie ſake releaſed reſt tribute thus tharſus laodicea puniſhed caſsius brutus conſultyng togither ſéemed beſt brutus remoue armie thencecounſell ••• ene brutus caſsius macedonia greater conſideration bycauſe ſayde theyr enimies fourty legion eyght paſt ionian ſea caſsius thought multitude enimie paſſed bycauſe tyme number ſhoulde deſtruction wante therefore ſhoulde ſette vpon rodians licians friend enimies hauing nauies leaſt ſhould come vpon backes agreed deuided army brutus went againſt licians caſsius agaynſt rodians hée brought vp learned gréeke tongue bicauſe ••• novve capo crio ſtrong vpon sea prepared exerciſed hys owne ſhips guido wiſe men rodes afrayd come fight romanes people luſty recounting formerthe rhodes iland ſea called carpathio the▪ vvhich greatneſſe next ieſa • u cyprus feat againſt maner men theſe ſhippes alſo gathered beſte whiche xxxiij done ſo ſente ſome mindo caſsius requeſting woulde reiect rhodes citie euer reuenge ſuch contemned cōuentions betwene rhodians romanes one ſhoulde beare armes againſt alleage thyng ſocietie warre woulde vnderſtande senate rome commaunding ſayde would thus much ſayde anſweared reſt warre muſt iudge ſtéede wordes league cōmaunded ſhould leauie armes one againſt another rhodians conſpire dolobella ayded againſt caſsius cōmaundeth one ſhould help another caſsius requireth vſe ſhifte romane senate ſcatered preſent deſtroyed tyrannes citie ſhould puniſhed ſo ſhould rhodians taking partes onleſſe commaunded thus ſayde caſsius whē knowne rhodes auncient men afrayd people perſuaded one alexāder manaſſes remēbring vnto mithridates came againſt thē wt many moe ſhips demetrius therfore made alexander chief officer called prytan • manaſſes admiral pryta • eu vvas athens chiefe citie autonie neuertheleſſe ſent archelaus embaſſadour caſsius ſchoolemaſter gréeke intreate familiarly taken hande ſpake hys acquayntance thou art louer gréeke language diſturbe archeleus ſcholenaſter •• caſsius gréeke citie rhodes louer libertie deface dorian dignitie neuer yet blemiſhed ſince firſte began forget y• goodly hiſtorie thou diddeſt learne rhodes rome rhodes howe muche citizen ſame haue euer ſtoode defence againſt nation king ſuch thought inuincible demetrius mithridates libertie y• whiche thou ſayſt thou trauayleſt rome haue done wel againſt antiochus great pillers ſet vp monumēts v thus much may ſayd romanes natiō worthineſſe ſtate neuer yet ſeruitude ſocietie choyſe thée caſsius certaine great reuerēce ſay remayneth toward citie thy nurſe thy ſcole thy phiſitian houſe wher thou didſt dwell ſcole ſelf thing wherein toke paynes well requite al vpō countrie y• forced make warre thée nouriſhed brought vp put v y• neceſſitie one two thing either y• rhodians ſhal deſtroyed caſsius ouercome aduiſe thée beſide y• haue prayed thée haſt tak • hand feate ye cōmon welth rome y• thou always make god guydes ſo great cauſe romanes call god witneſſe caius caeſar ye made ſolēne league wt v othe cōfirmed ſame gaue v right hand enimies performe ſhal friēds felowes • refraine god cauſe glory among men ſeing nothing barbarous breach league make offendours ſéeme vnfaithfull friend foe whē old man thus ſayd let caſsius hand go wept wiped eye manner might moue caſsius reuerēce abaſhed wt ſome paſſiō ſayd thus thou diddeſt perſuade rodians doe iniurie thy ſelfe haſt done thou diddeſt exhort aduiſe caſ •• e • helous couldeſt perſuade reuenge thée haue bene iniured euidently firſte bycauſe aſking helpe nouriſhed taught contemned deſpiſed bycauſe preferred dolobella whome neyther taught brought vp haynous onely brutus noble men whome knowe well fledde tirannie ready fight libertie countrie rodianes louers libertie preferred dolobella v ſéekyng take ſame v whome ought fauour pretend deale ciuill warre ciuill couet vnlawfull power opē warre made people rule againſt tirannes ſtate haue popular gouernment forſake ſame labour lawes beare good romanes condemned death without iudgement preſcribed confiſcate haue pitie anſweare vnderſtand senate minde deſtroyed helpe ſelf ye knew senate decréed brutus al inhabitant betwéene ionia eaſt ſhould obey cōmaundements thou makeſt rehearſal haue done v wāts good haue receyued reward againe forget denie help v ſuffer iniurie ſauing liberty ought bene friendſhip betwirt v would haue begon haue ayded cōmon cauſe rome beyng dorean libertie bring foorth alſo league lacking matter caius caſar firſt author tirannie make ſay romanes rodians ſhould help one neceſſities helpe nowe romanes greateſt cauſe moſte perill caſsius romane borne preſident romanes dothe chalenge league accordyng decrée senate whiche commaunde dweller beyonde ionia ſhoulde obey v brutus dothe require ſame pompey kéepyng sea senate ſafetie decrées wée ioyne prayer fledde senate brutus pompey people publike decrée rhodianes ſhoulde help romanes euery one haue neede neyther officer romanes take v fugitiues ſtraungers condemned name v haue proſcribed v haue nothing v romanes rhodianes league may make warre ſtrangers frée confederacie excepte obey v require thus caſsius dallying archelaus ſent away alexander manaſſes captaynes rhodianes thrée thirtie shippes ſayled againſt caſsius myndo preuent ſea hauing hope lightly ouercome bycauſe made voyage guido agaynſte mithridates happy ende warre vſing rowing ſhew ſayled firſt day guido next guido citie like ilande caria ſet vppon caſsianes whereat maruelling encounter ſhewing noble ſtrength ſydes rhodian ſhippes light gaue ſuddayne onſet enimiesbattayle sea betvveene romanes rhodianes retired againe fetched courſe woulde romaine heauie abode ioyned ouerlayde like fight foote caſsius multitude ſhippes ſo beſet enimie could compaſſe retire pleaſure onely aforehande giue charge retire againe commoditie taken away ſtreightneſſe place commyng vpon romanes great ſhippes ſharpe ſtemmes dyd good bicauſe romanes ſtoode vnmouable againſt light veſſels ende thrée rhodianes men taken two broken ſonke reſt ſore beaten fledde rhodes romaine reſorted myndo repaired veſſels myndus ſea▪ coaſt tovvne caria bruſed ende fight sea betwéene romanes rhodianes caſsius behelde mountayne repayred nauye ſayled lorenn • caſtell 〈◊〉 • ame rhodians footemen committed phanius lentulus bée tranſported greate shippes ſayled foureſcore veſſels whyche terrible ſighte rhodians arriued rhodes ſtirred neyther hys nauye hys fotemen thinking woulde haue yéelded came fiercely forthe fyghte hauing loſt two shyppes ſhutte themſelues within porte citie toke armoure reſiſted fotemen phanius hadde ſette ſhore alſo caſsius approched walles next sea vnfitte fight foreſéeyng broughte turret ſet vp aſſayled citie ſea land vnprouided ſo ſuddayne matter muſt néedes eyther force famine ouerthrowen wiſe men citie auoide daunger hadde ſome talke phanius lentulus meane time caſsius goterhodes taken citie choyce army vſing force hys entrie whiche ſome thought pityed famiſhing citie caſsius hauing citie captiuitie ſate downe y• judgemente ſeate pitched ſpeare token thrall badde feare commaunded armye vppon payne death make ſpoyle called 50 rhodians bythe hard dealing caſsius vvith rhodians name whome puniſhed death fiue twenty y• would appeare baniſhed toke money golde ſiluer holy publike appoynted daye euery man bring priuate ſubſtance proclaymed deathe hidde thing accuſer proclaimed third part bonde libertie manye beginning hidde thing hoping ſpoyle woulde haue ſuche ende ſawe men bewrayed brought forth feare hidden ground ſome filthy pittes ſome graues brought firſt thys y• captiuitie rhodes rule whichspoyle rhodes lucius varus left caſsius encouraged ſpéedy taking citie abundance money commaunded nation aſia pay tenne yeares tribute whiche accordingly reported cleopatra great preparation ofcleopatra army nauye would ſayle octauian antony friendſhip former caeſar feare caſsius ſente murcus beſt legionarie men archer morta tanarum promontorie iaconica vvhere hercules tooke vvay hell brutus iycia countrey little aſia betvveene pamphilia carta loca region ende greece illyria great region europe novve called • lanonia foureſcore armed shippes pelloponeſus ſtaying tenaro meant preuention get ſpoyle pell pon • ſo thing brutus licia great thus beganne army apuleius gathered tribute aſia ſixetéene thouſand talentes ſayled b • ecia receyue decree senate ſhoulde vſe ſame gouerne macedonia whyche béeyng knowen tooke hym thrées legion illyria whyche vatinius lieutenante illyria delyuered vnto hym another legion antonyes brother macedonia whyche ioyning foure lorde eyghte legion greater parte whyche hadde ſerued vnder caius caeſar hée hadde alſo greate number horſemen archer ſhotte macedonian hée armed italian manner gatheryng thus hys army treaſure good lucke thracia polemocratia prince wife ſlayne foe came totreaſure prince childe deliuered brutus brutus care hyr ſonne committed hym brutus handes whth hyr huſbandes treaſure deliuered chylde trayned citizenians tyll ſhoulde ſette father ciricus ile propon • vvith citie name kingdome founde treaſure greate maſſies golde ſyluer whyche cauſed coyned make money caſsius come vnto brutus conſulted vpponthe ſeege zanthus citle iycia vvhiche shevved greate manlineſſe agaynſte h • rpagus lieutenant cyrus theyr buſineſſe determined beginne warre vppon licians xanthians beginne zanthians citie cutte ſub •• be brutus ſhould vſe thē haue cōmodity thing compaſſed citie ditche vpon made defence ditche fiftie foote déepe breadth proportionate accordingly upon ſtoode threw dartes arrowes vpō romanes diuided floud impaſſable brutus gote many pioners couered thē leather ouerthrow ditche parted army y• night dayes labour neuer ceaſſing matter great ſpéede vſed ſouldioures cōtend ſhould faſteſt though beginning ſéemed went tedious fruteleſſe worke yet end brought paſſe quickly contrary zanthians opinion whiche thoughte woulde haue bin many monethes done nowe ſhutte vp driuen within gate greate change gaue dayly aſſaultes gate euer changing brutus beateth dovvne trench men reſiſted put freſhe ſounde men place wéery wounded ſo long fortes helde beaten downe broken brutus thinking woulde follow commaunded ſouldioures retire gate zanthians thinking bée done negligence iſſued nighte lightes burne romanes engine encountred romanes laye themthe zanthianes killed theyr gate retired gate kéepers whereof fearing enimie ſhould enter alſo ſhutte whereof followe greate ſlaughter gate long romanes goyng backe againe citizen came fired engine bycauſe former loſſe gate opened whoſe goyng two thouſand romanes thruſt followed entrie gate fell downe eyther ſuddaynely purpoſe matter failing held themthe romanes danger vp romanes eyther killed ſhut gate could opened without ſome engine remoued zanthians threw vpon ſtréetes aboue hauing neyther bowe arrowes gote ſtraight place called sarpedono ſhould vtterly beſette aboute romanes withoute carefull within brutus ranne among ſée help mighte aſſayed gate barred yron could get ſcales tower burned wherefore ſome made ſcalyng ladder preſently wente vp vppon timber vpon ladder ſome tyed forkes rope threwe faſten wall climbed vp coardes • nandians theyr oenandia • citie • al • ra little region •• spand •• neyghboures enimies confederate brutus gate vp ouer rocky place whiche romanes ſaw followed great laboure whereby many fell ſome gote ouer went opē gate layd timber ſo thicke mighte come ouer whiche many brake gate ſtrōg within without helping souldioures entred verye boldly broken gate ouer wall vpon way made timber ſo thruſting euery ſide zanthians greate ſhoutes ſet vpon romanes werethe romaine ſaued serpedono holy place cloſed citie sarpedono romanes gate carefull within without vſed violence make way caried furie bare downe afore making ſuche baſt noyſe mighte know within god working change ſetting sunne citie thus taken zanthians wente theyr houſes burned moſt precious thing wilfully offered throtes cutte lamentation ſo greate brutus fearing ſpoyle called souldiours backe athe taking zanth • trumpet knewe done pitied ſtate liberty ſake ſent truce vnto repelling brought bringing ſtackes hadde made houſes ſet ſame fire burned themſelues therewith brutus ſaued ſacred thing tooke seruants xanthians hundred fifty woman frée wythout huſband thus thrée time zanthians periſhed theirthe oft ſacking zanthus libertie beſéeged arpalus lieutenant cyrus great killed themſelues rather thā would ſlaues citie lefte graue ſay ſuffered like alexander philip ſonne coulde abyde obey alexander though lord ſo many landes brutus wente xantho patarea citie theyr miſfortune counſelling ſée better themſelues patareanes aunſwering nothing xanthians ſpent reſt day conſultation daye béeyng come brutus approchyng cryed frō walles woulde obey hym anye thyng would opened patarea yeelded theyr gate entred neyther killing ſpoyling man theyr golde ſiluer city gathered togyther commaundyng euery mā bryng hys priuate goodes vpon thoſe paynes caſsius ſette vpon rhodians dyd ſo seruaunt dyd accuſe hys maiſter hydyng money ſhewed capitayne ſente golde béeyng carryed away maiſter held peace hys mother wylling ſaue hyr ſonne cryed ſhe hadde hydde money companye vayne ſayled towarde brunduſe tooke ile nexte port kepte reſt enimies army theyr victual macedonia antonie came agaynſte hym thoſe fewe long shippes hadde nygh place annoyed hym wyth antony againſt murcus tower hadde made ſente hys armye partes greate shyppes obſeruyng wynde lande ſhoulde bée intercepte murcus béeyng ſome doubte called caeſar coaſt sicelie matche sextus pompey whyche matter wente ſorte pompey yonger ſonne pompey greate béeing pompey yonger accompted caeſar hys youth like archieue matter remayned spayne companye wyth fewe théeues roued sea knowen pompey ſonne number roners increaſing hauing good bande confeſſed pompey chylde wherefore remnant hys father brother armye reſorted familiar captayne arabion béeyng diſpeopled libya came vnto hym wée arabion ioyneth vvith pompey haue ſayde hée hauyng thys multitude hys actes eſtéemed greater pyrate pompey name ſounded ouer spayne full people ſo officer caeſar durſt meddle wyth hym whyche caeſar hearde ſente carina wyth greater armye ouerthrowe pompey béeyng armed lyghte attemptes ſuddaynely ſette vppon hym troubled hym tooke city ſmall greate whyche cauſe caeſar ſente abnius pollio ſuccéede carina warre pompey whyche time caeſar killed trie power pompey reuoked senate went maſsilia heare done choſen admirall father gathered shippes could get togither kept sea would come rome thrée men power began ſayled sicelie beſeeged captayne bythinicus woulde receyue till hirtius fannius condemned proſcription fledde rome cauſed place giuen pompey thus pompey lord sicelie hauing nauie iland nigh italy great army alſo fledde rome bond frée ſuch city italie ſent giuen pray souldioures theſe deteſt theyr heart conqueſt thrée men much could ſecretly wrote againſt many might get countrey nowe balaron balaron caeſar came gaue greate fayth reggians ipponeans reggio ſurdeſt citie italy nexte sicelie ippona vvas citie ſomtime called vibona vi • falentia novve little tovvne called •• bona ſhould exempt gyuen victorie feared moſt bycauſe ſo nigh narow cut antony ſente hym haſte ſayled brunduſe hauyng lefte hand sicelie entendyng matche pompey murcus caeſar came hée ſhoulde incloſed antony wente little brunduſe waytyng way great ſhippes carried armie macedonia whiche wayted galley winde great euen coulde wiſh ſayled away chéerefully without néede galley whereat murcus grieued wayted returne empty bothe caried ouer army full ſayle tillthe army paſſeth army caeſar antony paſſed murcus thus hindred fortune thought taried paſſages preparation new souldiours italy hinder much coulde prouiſions army lefte domitius oenobarbus one caſsius capitaynes came ſeruice great moment fifty ſhippes one legion archer caeſars army hable victualed otherwiſe ſufficiently italie might thought ſtopped thence thus one hundreth twentie galley ſhippes burden great army ſcoure thoſe ſeas ceditius norbanus whome caeſar antony ſente withantony caeſar viij legion macedonia thence thracia went aboue hilles hundred xl myles tyll came beyonde philip tooke ſtreyghts torpido salapian beginnyng philippi firſt called dathes torpido salapia ſtraights thracia raſcopolinus lande onely knowen liberalitie 〈◊〉 caſ •••• winne mennes harte might well hauyng ſuche plenty richeſſe bycauſe many ſerued vnder caius caſar none ſhoulde make ſtirre ſight name newe caeſar thought méete ſpeake army greate ſeate ſate none senatours pretor reſt wel romanes ſtraungers •• oode glad ſée one another ſtronger ſuppoſed boldneſſe great hope grew ſight army whiche thing increaſeth good wil souldiours captaine hope cōmon getteth beneuolence noyſe hereof made ceaſe trumpet crier caſsius bicauſe elder thā brutus came little foorth thus ſayde army contention souldiour felowes rommon 〈…〉 ation caſ •••• v therfore cauſeth v truſt one ſo conuenient performe haue promiſed whiche greateſt truſt wée fulfill whatſoeuer promiſe hereafter hope conſiſteth vertue souldiours v ſée aboute ſeate ſo many ſo great men senate alſo plentyfull furniture thyngs whiche ſée victuall armure money shippes confederate nation kyngs neceſſitie reaſon muſte bée ready willyng agrée whome prouiſion common cauſe hath ioyned togyther whereof twoo men enimies calumniate v know throughly ſerue v willyngly therefore nowe fitte declare cauſe whiche ſhall chiefly ſhew wée haue beſte moſte iuſte pretence warre haue made caeſar great folowyng hym leading warres continue hys friendes ende ſo ſhall appeare entrapte v enimity mater peace blamed v friendes haue bene honored lawes order common wealth whereof law rule beſt people power remayneth father framed expelled king othe confirmed neuer receyue othe poſteritie ſame minde conſenting puttyng execration thereof could longer endure ſée one man though friende beneficiall conuert himſelſe publique treaſure army election officer frō people gouernments nation senate yet law ſtéede lawes lord ſtéede people prince reſpectes ſteade senate whiche peraduenture doe perfitely know conſider valiantneſſe warre may eaſily learne ye thing touched ſelues people warre obey generalles lord ſame condition receyue v agayne peace senate prouidyng deceyued ſelues judge lawmaker accordyng company ſocieties creatyng conſulles tribune pretor voyces iudging ye greateſt thing puniſhing preferring thought worthie puniſhment preferment retribution citizen hath brought authoritie tothe authority people highe felicitie haue preferred worthy preferred haue rendred like thanke worthineſſe made scipio conſull teſtified scipio made conſull time matter libya made whome woulde tribune euery age ſelues fitte cauſes néede rehearſe many thing already knowe fince caeſar bare rule coulde create neyther conſull pretor tribune officer coulde teſtifie man vertue receyue mutuall teſtification ſelues ſpeake chief man gaue thankes office authoritie iuſtice correction moſte lamented could helpe tribune villanie done ſhoulde retayne power continual make ſure inuiolable ſelfe ſee ought haue bene vntouched authoritie inuiolate ornament ſacred cō demned without iudgement commaundement one onely bycauſe ſeemed grieued woulde haue declared kyng whiche senate tooke moſte grieuouſly ſake tribuneſhip senate yet yée could plainly accuſe man bring iudgement bycauſe hys mightie army whiche belonging publique ſtate chalenged hys priuate pleaſure whiche entendyng reuenged reſte tyrannie coniured agaynſt body ſentence neceſſarily procéede beſte ſeate done fewe ſoone done senate decreed common agréement openly rewardes killyng tirannes might put vre antony ſtaying vnder pretence tumulte thinkyng ſelues worthy rewarde citie rather helpe countrey ſtayed bycauſe would contumely ſhould ſhewed caeſar releaſement tyrannie euery man decreeyng getfulneſſe thing moſte ſuretie matter ſhoulde bee made murder antony litle litle withdrawing people v senate gaue v great office prouinces army commaunding lande betwéene ionia syria obey v whether puniſhing offendours honoring ſolemne purple maſes sergeant whiche reaſon called pompey baniſhment beyng yong man acquaynted thing onely bicauſe sonne pompey great trauayled people rule bycauſe ſecretely spaine auoyde tyrannie reſtored value father goodes common treaſure made ruler ſea mighte haue ſome authoritie beyng people faction acte token senate yée require done ſentence onleſſe inough confeſſe worde ſay togither ſayings rewarde great gift bicauſe whē ſay performe know men hādled proſcribed without iudgement goodes publicate killed without ſentence houſes theyr porch temple souldiours ſeruants enimies drawen priuie houſes purſued euery place ye law permitteth man flée common place neuer enimies head brought armour ſhippe ſtems heds conſuls pretor tribune queſtors gentleman brought rewarde appointed euill inſurrection moſt cruell euer againſt ſortes ſodaine ſlaughter men ſtraunge hate woman child fréemade men▪ ſeruaunts ſo farre ſuche change citie turned author miſchiefe thrée men whiche afore haue proſcribed brother vncles anſwearyng one citie menne ſay taken wilde barbarous yet celtes cut head vſed villany wt thē toke prohibited man hyde himſelf flée yt warre neither euer vſe citie ſo haue takē force neither haue perſuaded yt priuate citie chief al doth ſuffer affirme reforme direct common wealth like thing tarquinius ye iniurie done one woman procéeding loue king baniſhed act could neuer abide kingdome while theſe thrée citizen thus terme v ſeditious ſay wil reuēge caeſar proſcribe thē yt preſent whē killed y• many whō ſée cōdēned rich houſes fauoring ye people gouernmēt ye reaſon pōpey alſo proſcribed wt v beyng far iberia ye déede bicauſe deſcēded father yt loued people ſtate yt called home ye senate made admirall ye ſea theſe thrée men cō dēned death womē conſpire againſt caeſar whome haue condēned paymēt 100000 people whō haue cōdemned pay vpō payne accuſations proſcribed thē onleſſe whereof ought frée yt al haue done cānot yet performe theyr promiſe souldiours haue done wrong haue performed promiſe reſerue time ſhould ſerue thus god hath ſhewed helpe v iuſtly god haue conſider men whō ſée citizen whō haue ſéene pretor cōſuls many time prayſe ſée thē fleyng well doer louers people taking part wiſhing wel reſt yt ſhal take hand iuſt reward propounded v ye preſeruers thē yt would deſtroy thē care v killed c caeſar yt would haue ruled alone others v remain deſpite tirānie take rule thēſelues leaue ye people according country lawes war takē like cauſe make power tirannie whiche haue ſhewed proclamatiō make ſuch matter yt coū trey ſet frée may liue priuatly vnder y• lawes order al good men goddes chiefly iudge cauſe beſt hope y• maketh warre iuſt cauſe let trouble v though haue ſerued vnder caeſar ſerued vnder vnder coūtrie gift giuen caeſars y• coūtries publique neither y• armie b •• tus caſsiw y• romanes felow ſoldiours romane captaynes whiche yt make warre againſt v would vnderſtād euery mā might ſafely lay downe armure rēder army y• citie make choyſe ſuch might profitable deſire ſeing wil choſe y• wicked tyrānie haue ſhewed let v warre felows go ſure hope ſerue frée romane senate people libertie euery mā cried let v go let v go deſire marche hande caſsius glad forwardneſſe cauſed ſilēce made againe thus ſayd god y• lord warre requite war felows faith prōptneſſe vnderſtand prouiſtō captaines haue made men y• fauoured god farre excéede enimies number goodneſſe haue armed legion equall haue fortified place good garde wel horſmen nauies paſſe aliance king prince nation aſia ſurmount thē come vpō v y• face go vpon backe alſo haue pompey sicelie murcus ionia norbanus alſo lieth wt great nauie two legion ſtoppe paſſage ſea place behinde v voyde enimies bymoney ſtrength vvarre land ſea mony whiche ſome call y• ſtrength warre want neither performe promiſe old ſoldiours exact ſo much y• condēned men ſuppoſed bycauſe none frends willing buy y• place haue put ſale otherwiſe get nothing italy waſted ſedition tribute condēnations great care haue got preſent plēty wherewith may gratifie agayne muche collected nation behynde v bée broughte vnto v victuall greateſt wante mighty army haue none onely macedonia mountaine countrie theſſalia ſtraight region whiche great toyle muſte conuey lande thyng brought 〈…〉 parte ••••• iapigia▪ ap ••• affrica lucania iapigia pompeius murcus domitius ſhall ſhutte vp bothe haue ſhall haue sea ilandes place continent euery day without difficultie betweene thracia floudde euphrates without daunger enimy beyng backe • wherefore power doe feate wyth ſpéede doe leyſure conſume enimies hunger thys haue felow souldiours man prouiſion reſte ſhall anſweare order thorough god haue gyuen former matter promyſed requityng fayth multitude gyfts greater labour wée worthily recompence accordyng determination goddes nowe ſhall chéerefully goe feate thys aſſembly exhortatiōs ſake wil giue euen thys ſeate souldiour thouſande fiue hundreth drammes italie capitayne bande fiue tymes ſo muche tribune accordyng proportion hee ſayde thus encamped army worke worde gyftes hée diſmiſſed multitude remayned prayſing br • tus hym muche promyſed doe ſhoulde bée conuenient gaue gyftes hande beſide theſe beſte ſorte many 〈…〉 ployne thracia vvhich 〈…〉 number greate army tokē tvvo egles conſiderations receyued ſente foorth bandes doriſco folowed long thys tyme twoo eagle ſate vpon twoo ſiluer egles ſtanderde beatyng ſome ſay coueryng tarried ſtill fedde publique prouiſion appoynted generalles night day battell flewe away two dayes cōmyng gulfe melana went oeno oeno doriſco place mounte serrio hyll • ••• ta • • serrio ſtretchyng ſea kepte ſtil lande commaunded tullius cymbrus nauie one legion andtullius cymbros certayne archer goe chaſt bin deſerte although land good thracian neyther vſing sea feare receyuing came contrary coaſt grecian calcidonians kéeping ſho • e vſing sea flouriſhed merchaundiſe tyllage thracian agréeyng receypt mountaynes till philip amyntas ſonne ouercome chaldean others ſo nothing ſeene paſſengers onely little chappell deſert place tullius quickly paſſed ouer ſo brutus company eſpyed fitte place meaſured campe kéeping ſame courſe shippes ſo much norbanus lefte ſtreight saporians vnprofitable bée saporia •• tle floud neſtus kept thing happened deſired ſighte theſe shippes norbanus troubled saporia called ceditius turpilio come hym haſt ſo theturpilio ſtreightes turpilio left brutus men wente deceyte appearing norbanus ceditius toke sapeio manfully ſo brutus people could paſſe▪ wherfore afrayde leaſt theysapeio muſt goe aboute ſhoulde haue done begynning paſſe euery place beſette hauing time conuenient bycauſe mountaines ſeaſon yeare standing ſtay raſcopolis ſayde vnto roſcopolis sapei people floude neſtu • way compaſſe mountayne sapeorans thrée dayes iourney neuer gone men ſharp rockes want water thickneſſe wodde therefore woulde goe muſt carrie water paſſe ſtreight way yet paſſable iourney ſolitarineſſe birdes couldsolitary vvay diſcouer fourth day ſhould haue floud arpeſſo arpe •• h • bru • flouds thracia running floud ermo • whence one day going philip mighte ſette enimies ſuddayne whome might ſo ouercome byca • ſe none ſhift souldioures taughte thys way lacke hope take enimies aduantage part ſente lucius bibulus appoynting raſcopolis guide waye greate payne laboure wente made yet courage good hearte rather bycauſe ſame ſent afore returned ſayde ſawe floude farre fourth daye tyred wyth ſharpeneſſe iourney troubled wyth thyrſt water béeing ſpente whiche braughte thrée • ayes bycauſe ſayde therethe h • rd paſſage ro ••• water beganne feare leaſt deceyued dyd beléeue ſayde ſawe floude bycauſe thoughte ledde wrong way therefore beganne exclayme crye raſcopol • came encourage reuiled threwthe dacourage 〈…〉 • age 〈…〉 ſtones hym bibulus humbly beſought woulde paciently abyde reſt iourney little nyghte floude ſéene formoſt way deſcrying done b • utu souldyours maruellous boldneſſe came philippi whyther alſo arriued tullius ſo army 〈…〉 philippi da • e crenida 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 • ing philip builded named 〈…〉 mette thys citie philippi called date fyrſte crenida bycauſe many fountaynes greeke bée called crene flowe mountaynes place fytte thracian philip walled aboute called hys name philippi citie builded vpō hygh hyll greatneſſe whereof compriſed breadth ſame north ſide hathe wooddes hylles whyche raſcopolu brought brutus caſsius army south ſide fenne beyonde sea eaſt ſtreyghtes sapeon torpilos bee sapera ouer way betwéene aſia europe gate thys place fortifyed trenche trench leauing gate middeſt ſéemed one ••• pe floude nygh whyche ſome call ganga ſome gangites behynde gangites thaſus ile nigh thracia ioyning place tray ••• theyr armyantony antony came great haſt inſending get amphibol •• ſtay warre finding poſſeſſed n • r • anus glad lefte furniture warre wyth one legion p •• arius ledde wente boldly camped fielde myle enimies ſtreighte ſéene want abundance army one aboue frutefull ground beneath bottome anto •• e • camp wodde mountaynes theſe fenne water riuer theſe pooles pittes digged time hadde victual thaſo fewe furlong theſe amphipole aboue thaſo ile citie oueragainſt floud n • ſſus antony camp fiftie myles ſéemed antony driuen thus bycauſe good grounde playne béeing hollowe whych reaſon ouerflowyng floud ſometime found water ſwéete ſufficiente making welles pittes thys boldneſſe although procéeded neceſſitie yet aſtoniſhed enimies ſo nygh ſo ſoone encamped ſuche contempte wherefore made manye trench fortifyed euery place walles rampyers caſsius ſéeyng antonyes furie ſo greate entrenched left fenne omitted ſtreighteneſſe ſo parte vndefenced ſyde brutus whyche hyllie caſsius hadde fenne sea reſt béeyng taken trench ditch gate thus placed onely wyth horſemen ſometime ſkirmiſhed thing prouided caeſar yet able fighte came litter hys armye hys captaynes ſette themſelues order fyghte brutus dyd lyke higher place eaſie ſéene yet intended come downe waſte theyr enimie wyth wante either ninetéene legion armed footemen butthe number b ••• • uies brutus ſelver number caeſar thracia horſ mē caeſar ant • nie aboue thirtene thouſand brutus caſsius twenty thouſand ſo multitude men boldeneſſe vertue captaines armoure furniture souldioures moſt goodly ſhew ſides turned • vppon • ification caſsius campe fenne bringing engins ſcales though woulde charge vppon campe betwéene army great boldneſſe brutus souldioures grieued thinking ſhame let ſo eſcape wythoute called honor valiantneſſe led alſo bād guarde two thouſande men foure troupe horſe number gathered together fewe galicyes murcus otnobarbus mette one hundred thirtie long shippes fewe former hulkes fledde good ſayling ſodayne ceaſſing winde ſea calme ſtill caught fortune giuen enimies without feare bo • ged brake hauing helpe fewe galleyes compaſſed ſo many greate diuers trauaile perill linking themſelues togither cable weapon courage putting themſelues order y• enimie ſhould vſe though ouercame murcus threw dart ofn̄re quickly burne byndings ſhips ſe uered aſunder auoid fyre galley ready hinder euery way wherewith ſouldiours beyng grieued eſpecially martialls beyng better valiantneſſe 〈…〉 • ea 〈…〉 c • ſ •• ſhoulde p • r • lacke fyghting ſome kylled themſelues fire ſome leapte enimies galley kylled ſome killed themſelues ſhyppes halfe burned wēt way carying men ſome conſumed fyre ſome wāt thirſt y• cable planck carried y• rockes deſert ſhoars ſome ſaued beyond al reaſon ſome continuing flue dayes eating pitche oſf cable ſayles helde till briuen lande byllows thece many gaue themſelues enimies ouercome calamitie • vij galleyes yéelded whoſe ſouldiers murcus tooke caluinus general came fiue dayes biund • ſe one ſhippe thoughte tocaluinus haue bene loſt happe • onio ſame day fielde philippi whether wil call ſhipwrack ſhipfight euils cōcurring together known cauſed greater feare brutus called army together ſayd thus nothing fellowe ſouldiers yeſterdayes fight butoration ••• tus maketh ſuperiour enimies gaue charge chéerfully warning giuen fourth legion ſo renoumed whome battaile confidence ouerthrew vtterly army droue campe campe firſt toke ſpoyled ſo much haue farre ouercome loſſe laſt batail might haue made ende trauayle choſe rather fall ſpoyle followe enimies ouercome many running ſet vppon ſpoile one haue oure campes haue ſo recompenceof loſſe double hauing aduantage fight much wiſe excéede may learne captiues want victual ſtriuing difficult bringing • euident getting ſo little sicelie sardinia libya iberia haue none pompeius murcus oenobarbus keping thoſe sea two hundreth thrée ſcore ſhippes macedonia haue conſumed haue theſſalia long ſerue therefore ſée offer fight thinke chiefely forced hunger doc chooſe death rather handes let v contrarywiſe foreſée hunger may fight v may take féebler conſumed ſhal fit let v carried affection due tyme thinke flowneſſe quickneſſe experience haue oure eie vppon ſea backewarde miniſtreth v ſuche foode ſeruice ſee victorie without daunger abide diſtruſte thoughe come forth prouoke v ſtronger worke yeſterday ſhewed auoyding feare courage deſire kéepe may ſhew forth ſhal require perfect reward victorie god ſhall haue giuen ſentence v perfect déeds giue vnto yeſterdayes vertue giue euery ſouldiour thouſand drammes capitaines proportion requireth thus ſaid ſtraight diuided gifte euery legion ſame ſay promiſed giue thē macedonia theſſalia ſpoile caeſar antony ſéeing brutus would vnwillingly come fight called people antony ſaid thus yeſterdaies worke men perceiue enimies word diuide antones oration chaſed ſome v ſpoiled campe indéede confeſſe al affirme vnto neither y• next day yet willingly wil come y• fight moſt certain ſurety yeſterdaies fear loſſe y• maner contention force weaker go place dydde gather ſo greate armye mighte inhabite deſerte thracia making walles made defence fearo comming vppon minding kéepe yeſterdaies ouerthrow elder expert captaines deſperation kylled himſelfe whiche greateſt declaration miſerie therefore ſhall prouoke aunſwere come hilles truſte holdes ſtéede handes romaine men enforce againe ye forced yeſterday thinking ſhame giue place fearfull prouoked refraine holden worſe men kéeping come hither liue playne tarryed woulde ſuffiſe v ſpéedy attemptes bée giuen warre wiſe may longer continue peace tymes trauaile muſte foreſée cannot complayne yeſterdayes aſſaulte attempte required ſhewe vertue capitaines grieued yeſterdayes ſpoile rich haue got conqueſt loſt yeſterday remaineth ſafe enimie muſt yéeld v ouercome wil go forth get muſt ſet forth ſight yeſterday tooke ſufficiētly happily ſuſficient owne haue brought togither haue violence ſpoiled oute aſia comming countrey haue lefte home moſte precious thing onelye broughte neceſſaries hadde anye thyng eſtimation compted generalls whyche ready giue thys victorye recompence loſſe ſake giue reward victorie euerye souldioure fyue thouſand dram capitaine bande fyue tymes ſo muche tribune double ſo muche captaine antony thus ſayde ſette order fight ennimie woulde come forwarde antony grieued ſtil ſet battaile ray brutus hadde army good order néeded come fyght taken al wayes prouiſion thing néedefull hill nighe caſsius campe harde enimie take bycauſe nighneſſe made danger archer caſsius entrenched man ſhould place giue bold attempt vnlooked abandoned caſars men take hill brutus caeſars ſoldiors night wt iiii legion tooke carying many hurdle hide reſiſt ye ſhot whē hil led x legion halfe myle towarde ſea firſte foure added two legion take deuiſe thing euen ſea way beſide ſeas fennes mean might diſtreſſe take victual enimie brutus made deuiſes againſt ſetting vp fort againſt camp caſars ſouldiors alſo ſet vp new worke nowe yt famme euidēt increaſed euery day greatneſſe fear 〈…〉 campe caſar 〈…〉 could longer haue ſufficient brought thē ſtō theſſali • frō yt ſea hope ye enimies lord yt ſhips late loſſe ionto beyng tolde bothe afraide winter hande lying fenny plaine deliberation theſe thing ſent legion armed achia prouide neceſſarye victualls 〈…〉 north 〈…〉 p • lopo •••• ſende ſpéede able auoide preſent perill make deuice reſte campe doe anye offend enimie came foorth ſhowts called brutus fight ſcoffing rayling antonie prouoketh 〈…〉 fight doubting whither refraining fight like man beſieged rather man beraught wit knowne beginning beléeued rather bycauſe want loſſe ionto perceyuing enimies one miſchiefe another determined man beſieged way auoide battell rather come hand men driuen hunger deſperation thing hauing onely hope hand army lacke conſideration thinke ſo grieued woman within ſhut vp ydleneſſe feare captain alſo content blamed brutus opinion thinking courage ſouldiors ſooner ouerthrowe ennimie cauſe hereof procéeded brutus ſo courteous milde al mē •••• eſie 〈…〉 hin •••••• vnlyke caſsius ſeuere imperious al thrnges ſo commaundements kept without reſiſtance ſouldiours aſking queſtions reaſoning woulde haue done brutus woulde doe nothing withoute opinion captaines thorowe gentle nature length hys armye company rowtes beganne openly aſke meaneth oure general • wherein haue offended late ouercome tha •• diſtreſſed enimies tooke campe brutus ſuffered purpoſe dyd call ſo • ye aſſemblie leaſt ſhoulde forced vnſeemely rude multitude 〈…〉 beareth purpoſe chiefly hyred ſorte whoſe manner euer lyke vnto vnſtable ſeruauntes hope change maiſters ſet ſafetie contrary faction captaynes alſo angrie wiſhing doubt armye béeing forwardneſſe would ſome notable feate thing hapt amiſſe fighte myghte returne theyr campe defende themſelues theyr wall brutus muche gréeued wyth captaynes fearyng woulde putte hym daunger lyghte dealyng wyth army whereas wythoute doubte ſharpe fortune ſure victorie daungerous conſented hys al deſtruction thus reproouing like pompey greate forced fyghte commaunding •• ut • one r •• led like pompey captayne rather obeying souldyoure thynke ſpake hyde moſt feared leaſt armye ſometyme ſerued caeſar woulde take occaſion reuolte whyche beginning caſsius feared ſo gaue none occaſion offence brutus brought vnwillingly ſette hys men order trenche wylling marche farre byll myghte haue theyr retyre néede nigh bée ſurer eaſie marche agaynſte enimies agayne ſides greate preparation thinges greate deſire feate boldneſſe neceſſitie one feare hunger iuſt reuerence compellyng captayne come forthe ſhoulde worſe theyr promiſe weaker theyr wordes bée thoughte rather gilty payne theyr raſhneſſe worthye prayſe theyr good counſell brutus goyng among horſebacke ſhewed ſeuere countenance exhorted fewe wordes tyme woulde ſerue would néedes fight would needes force otherwiſethe 〈…〉 hauyng victory deceyue neyther ſelues thys hope haue hyll fyghte youre backe youres youre enimies doubtfuli caſe beyng betwéene famine hauyng ſayde thus rode aboute encouraged bandes wyth crye receyuing hym hys greate prayſe caeſar antony goyng aboute theyre offered theyr ryghte handes nexte ſeuerally exhorted dyd hyde theyr hunger myghte ſtirre preſente boldneſſe haue founde men enimies haue caeſar antony 〈◊〉 wée deſired theyr trenche lette none afrayd gyue charge gyue place ſette vpon lette hym rather choſe famine dolorous deſtruction bée auoyded oure ennimies death bodyes whyche youre boldneſſe weapon trauayle eaſily gyue preſente caſe requireth ſpeedineſſe maye deferre nothyng tyll morrowe thys daye muſt determine thynges eyther wyth per •• te victorie valiant deathe haue victory ſhall winne one daye victuall money shyppes campes rewardes victory v thys wée muſt remember gyue charge vpon wée doe fyrſte purpoſe myddeſt theyr force forwardneſſe ſhutte theyr campe dryue playne hylles warre bée begunne agayne oure enimies dryue v idleneſſe agayne whyche theyr faynieneſſe haue hope fighte put theyr truſt retrayning battell caeſar antonius thys ſorte exhorted theyr souldyoures euery man hadde reſpect appeare worthye souldyoures ſuche captaynes ſtyrred auoyde wante ſuddayne loſſe ionian sea thoſe rather wyth payne hope néede abyde vttermoſt conſumed wyth euill cannot bee auoyded matter ſtandyng thus euery one moued agaynſte hym next anger ſides encreaſed much filled boldneſſe inceſſable nowe dyd remember citizen togyther enimies nature bloude threatned one another ſonature countrey forgotten ſuddaynely hadde rage furie quenched nature reaſon prophecyed alyhe ſydes daye feate ſhould iudge romaine cauſes iudgemente gyuen déede day béeyng ſpente preparationtvvo eagle token fight tyll ninth houre two eagle falling betwéene campes ſoughte togyther great ſilence eagle flying toward brutus whereat ſhrill crye made enimies broughte forthe theyr ſtandardes marche fierce vehement little néeded arrowes ſtones dartes manner warre vſed none comming order battell wherein broughte vp buckled wyth naked ſwordesthe vehemē • • souldioures layde eyther ſyde put one another theyr ray one theyr ſafetie rather victorie victory comforte theyr captayne whome prouoked fighte ſlaughter fightes great bodyes beene away put theyr place ſerue former rankes captaynes riding aboute beholding euery encouraged valiante comforted ••• ke paynes continue ſtill laboure thoſe ſhrunke changed boldneſſe fronte myght bée continued length souldyoures caeſar eyther feare famine caeſars fe •• citie brutus men blamed ouercame battell enimies putte backe heape heauie maſſe yet turned agayne theyr place ſlowly wyth order ray broken went away faſter ſecond third bande turned wyth diſorderedly thruſting 〈…〉 one vpon another broken themſelues theyr enimies withoute ſtay purſued tyll • ledde euidently caeſars • ould youres remembryng theyr promiſe chiefly fiercely followyng gaue aſſaulte vppon theyr campe daungerouſly euery •• de ſo ſette vppon compelled ſlée whereof ſome wente towarde sea hylles floude zygat • thys alteration rocky place chacing fledde kéeping fleeyng followed brutus hymſelfe lucinus ſawe ſo faſt running hym ſtayde though bin brutus prayed myghte ledde antonie lucinus acte ſaue brutus caeſar whiche rather thoughte brutus auoydyng hys vnplacable enimie antony vnderſtandyng hée broughte hym wente towarde hym good order conſidering fortune woorthyneſſe vertue man howe myght vſe hym béeyng hande l • cinus méetyng wyth hym verye boldly ſayde brutus taken neyther ſhall vertue euer takenboldneſſe 〈◊〉 vi • e deceyuing theſe men thus thée whiche worde horſemen béeyng aſhamed antony comfort ſayde▪ haue hunted none 〈◊〉 game better thynke ſo muche friende better enimie committed lucinus wayte vpon one friend vſed hym hys aſſured brutus fledde mountaynes conuenient multitude night might returne hys campe take hys way ſea hearde paſſages kepte hee continued people armes ſay hée looked vp starres ſaying iupiter thou knoweſt cauſe theſe euils meaning brutus vvordes meanyng antonie vvhom ſayde punished antony repentance trenche dead body antonie ſay antonie priuate peril confeſſe ſaying might haue ruled brutus caſsius ſlaue octauio night antonie continued armes might haue brutus makyng trench dead body baggage brought togither caeſar labouring till midnight▪ withdrew himſelfe ſickneſſe committyng charge army norbanus brutus perceiuing wayte enimies made hauing foure legious wel warded deſired chiefe hoſt whiche aſhamed repented act ſende ſée might make way paſſe traynes recouer owne kept abādoned tentes vnwilling conſidering brutus men gyueth ouer god agaynſt tolde generall good captaines taking lepidus alſo band whiche kept brutus creta theſe force ſailed murcus oenobarbus gulfe ionia diuiding themſelues part went sicelie sextus pompey part remained oenobarbus priuate faction thus remnant brutus caſsius newe armye made octauian antonie ſacrificed victorie philippi gaue thankes ſouldiors performe promiſe octauian went italy diſtribute lande ſouldiors chooſe health antony wēt among octauian goeth italy antony goeth beyond ſea nation beyond ſeas gathered mony hie ſouldiours diuided betwene land y• lepidus frāce beyonde alpes octauian woulde haue free according determination decrée vncle caeſar lepidus accuſed fauour pompey part lepidus accuſed founde falſe octauian determined giue hym prouinces licenced old ſouldiors except eight thouſand deſiring ſerue part heare thinke wil goe contēted away much gaue enimies two yeares whiche ten yeares tribute ſo much wil require ſauing y• muſt paid one yeare bycauſe neneſſitie ſo exacteth may acknowledge thākes confeſſe puniſhed haue deſerued thus ſpake pleaſe ye ſouldiors promiſed reward méeting modena xl legion ſo many thē cōſumed fully ended tale whē ye grecian ſate vpō tribute put vp grecian ••• ony whoſe land deuided souldiours whiche ſuffered many iniuries theoppreſsion city souldiours citizen cry octauian diuiſion landes nowe cruell proſcriptions lyfe enimies puniſhed innocentes plagued caeſar well perceyue iniurie coulde remedie neyther hée money wherewith pay poſſeſſours lande neyther could rewardes victory deferred warres myght enſue pompey beyng lorde sea pompey aenobarbus mur▪cus lordes ſea cauſed famine cittie victuall beyng kepte away aenobarbus murcus hauyng army gatheryng nauie souldiours vnwillyng excepte haue promyſe kepte ſpace fiue yeares almoſte come ſo muſte haue néede souldioursinſolencie souldiours therefore bare inſolencie ſo muche theatre common souldiour wantyng proper ſeatetheatre place vvhere beholde paſtyme wente ſatte place gentleman people noted caeſar rayſed hym souldiours angry caeſar came paſſe tyme compaſſed requyred felow souldiour whome thought deſtroyed hée came ſayde came pryſoninſolencie souldiours whiche bycauſe hée denied ſayde hée hyred ſo ſay traytour hys company rudeneſſe vſed theatre beyng called diuiſion campe mar comming night angry caeſar tarried ſo long nonius capitayne rebuked tolde dutie put cauſe vpon caeſars ſickeneſſe called nonius kylled soldiours flatterer threwe ſtones vppon droue take water whiche tooke hym vp dead layde hym waye▪ caeſar ſhoulde paſſe moniſhed hys fréendes truſte theyr rage hée • oyde furder inconuenience hys abſence wente héevprore soldiours ſawe dead body nonius went aſide fault layde vpon fewe hée willed hereafter one ſpare another ſo gaue giftes diſtribution land andsufferance liberalitie 〈◊〉 rewarded ſome beyonde owne expectation conſtancie hym ſo lyked requyred kyllers nonius myghte bée punyſhed hée ſayde hee knewe well inough ſatiſfied wyth confeſſion conſcience reſte hee forgaue whyche mercy liberalitie beyng prouoked made greate ſhoutes hys felicitie theſe twoo contempt souldiours among many may ſuffice ſhewed cauſe thys without lawfull authoritiecauſe diſorder among soldiours happeth ciuill warres takyng vppon bée capitaynes led theſe souldiours ſerue countrey themſelues agaynſt enimies agaynſt citizen deſtroyed diſcipline romanes warre souldiour rather deſirous ſerue pryuate affection capytaynes abuſe priuate commoditie onely souldiour whole army bée bought money offence fauour good prayſe aduaunce euill lighte cauſes whole army would go good lawfull leader lewde vſurpyng captayne lyke agréeyng lyke souldiours tooke enimies neuer ſo honeſt capitaynes hated capitaynes haue souldiours hande ſuffred committe thing abhominable without al reuerence lawe iuſtice nowe diſcipline beyng corrupted werediſcipline corrupted compted beſt could rayſe moſte ſedition citie meane time great penurie prouiſion corne beyng theyr ſhoppes withoute officer whiche woulde ſerue thefte ſuffred lucius beyng well affected common wealth lucius taketh parte vvith old husbandemen gréeued power thrée prince continuyng longer time appoynted contended caeſar▪ onely promiſed helpe olde poſſeſſioners making ſupplication officer promiſed ſeruice wherby bothe antony soldiours caeſar himſelf accuſed enimy fuluia alſo ſtirrers warre time manius counſel deuiſe manius preuayled perſuaded fuluia italie quiet antony woulde remayne cleopatra aegipt warres ſtyrred hée woulde come quickly fuluia antony vviſe ſtirreth vvarre fuluia womanniſhe paſſion incenſed lucius caeſar wente place newe inhabitancy antony chyldren lucius wente caeſar ſhoulde haue whole thankes goyng alone caeſars horſemenne ſcoured coaſte towarde sicelie pompey ſhoulde ſpoyle lucius begynnyng • ſuſpition eyther afrayde déede fayning bée afrayde theſe horſemen ſente agaynſt antony child wente haſte inhabitauncies antonie gette garde accuſing caeſar vnfaithfull antony anſwered kept faith friendſhip antonie lucius ſought moue warre y• offended rule thē thrée newe inhabitant might take full poſſeſſion horſemen yet coaſt duty whē teano citie • fia appia apulia condition betvvene caeſar antony ſoldiours antony soldiours vnderſtoode made méeting theano reconciled theſe condition ſhuld deuide lāds ſuch ſerued philippi money condemned men landes ſhould equally diuided among antony souldiours hereafter one alone ſhould leuy men two legiōs antony ſhould ſerue caeſar againſt pōpey alpes towarde spaine ſhoulde open caeſar ſent ſhutte aſinius lucius ſhould put away garde exerciſe office quietneſſe theſe couenants whereof onely two laſt kepte saluidienus paſſed alpes ſpyte kepte preneſte novve pileſtrena citie latio reſt defeated wherfore lucius went preneste affirmyng afrayde caeſar hauyng garde aboute none fuluia alſo went lepidus ſaying ſhe afrayde fuluia fleeth lepidus hir child ſhe truſted better caeſar bothe wrote antonie certaine fréendes carying letter might certifie thyngs copy whereof haue long ſought finde chiefe army agréed take vp thys matter affirmed woulde compell hym vnwillyng ſente lucius friendes come whiche denying doe caeſar accuſed well chiefe army officer city great reſorte made lucius citiegreat reſorte lucius beſéechyng haue compaſſion afflicted italie take ſome man eyther capitaynes might make ende matter lucius regarde ſpake alſo thyngs ſpoken manius manius anſvver ſharpe anſweared ſharpely antonie onely gathered money ſtrange nation caeſar gette men loue preuention army fitte place italy fraude gotten fraunce antony prouince xviij city ſhould giuen soldiours ranſacked almoſte italy alſo gaue money foure thirty legion onely eight twentie fought hys quarrell ſpoyled temple pretence warre agaynſt pompey whiche yet begon greate dearth citie déede winne fauour souldiours agaynſt antonie ſo muche goodes attaynted ſolde giuen thē ſéeketh peace good fayth muſt make accomptof thing hath done hereafter nothing conſent bothe bolde anſweare manius neyther caeſar ſhoulde doe thing alone couenaunts betwéene antonie remayne firme either ſhould haue full authoritie prouinces confirme others actes caeſar ſéeyng ſoughte warre prepared hymſelfe two legiōs wer placed ancona firſtsouldioures ancona labour peace ſerued father antony loue bare ſente ambaſſadors rome pray haue reſpect peace caeſar aunſwered ſwerued antony lucius wyth hym embaſſadors conferring officer antonyes souldyoures ſente common embaſſage lucius requiring hym contente committe hys difference wyth caeſar arbitrement affirmyng woulde take vppon excepte woulde condiſcende hauing obteyned requeſt gabij appoynted place gabij people deſtroyed tarquinius superbus meeting gabij fight chance méeting midde way betwéene rome preneſte prepared ſeate judge two chayres ſhewe cauſe caeſar came firſte ſente horſemen way lucius ſhoulde come eyther ſée lucius dyd whether traynes layde lyghted vpon antonyes horſemen whyche came forerunner lucius ſée cléere fell fight ſome kylled wherefore lucius wente backe feare treaſon ſayde béeingthe daye fruſtrate called chiefe army promiſing hym conducte ſafe refuſed thus pacifyers béeyng deceyued warre threatned wyth bitter wordes betwéene lucius haddethe vvarre breaketh lucius povver ſixe legion leuie whiche toke created conſull beſyde eleuen antonyes vnder captayne caleno thoſe italy caeſar hadde foure legion capua certayne bandes caeſars povver antium vvas citie latio good vpon sea lannuuium novv indo • •• treaſure houſes holy money tibure novve tiuoli nemore • arre aritia pompey increaſeth perſon saluidienus broughte ſyxe legion spayne lucius money prouinces antony pacyfyed caeſar hadde came vnto hym lotte excepte sardinia whyche warre gote much temple promiſing render intereſt capitoli • antio lanuuio nemore tibure whyche city treaſures day holy money italy thing quiet pompey reſorte condemned citizen auntient poſſeſſioners greatly increaſed mighte eſtimation feared life ſpoyled goodes lyked preſent ſtate fledde hym diſagréemente lucius augmented hys credite beſide repayre yong men deſirous gayne ſeruice much money foureſcore shippes another army cephalenia wherefore mē thynke inuaded 〈…〉 sea pompey loſeth 〈…〉 honor pompey sextius italy might eaſily haue gotte afflicted famine diſcord loked pompey saluidienus come spayne throughout italy men muſtered haſt well caeſa captaynes antonyes lucius dyuers 〈◊〉 troubled ouer fightes betwéene iuſt battell ambuſhmentes fauoure italy enclined lucius bycauſe fought againſt new inhabitant onely city giuen pray alſo italy ſtirred fearing lyke calamitie reiecting caeſars ſouldioures borowed holy money partly kylling gaue aide lucius kéeping city contrarywiſe new inhabitant ſtucke caeſar though eyther laboured owne ſtate caeſar called senatoures oct • •• senate gentleman thus ſpake vnto know contemned lucius faction coward afrayde myne owne weakeneſſe contempt increaſed aſſembly haue valiant army iniureth hyndering poſſeſſion alſo aforetime haue ſerued vnder banner reſt ſure except one meaning delighte ciuill warres neceſſary thinke abuſe citizen left deſtroy one another chiefly thys ciuill motion miſerie whereof ſhall tolde macedonia thracia ſhall ſéene italy fielde warre incommodities ſhall ſuffer cauſe yrketh beginne firſt proteſt neyther quarrell antony anye thing ſhould quarrell part ſelues reprooue lucius abettor whome praye reconcile vnto continue obſtinacie ſhall make knowen ſlowe feare conſideration ſhall witneſſes onely alſo antony driuen neceſſitie inſolencie lucius caeſar thus ſaid returned haſt preneste lucius anſwered matter would come tryall ſides ſhortly caeſar diſſembled ſente legion brunduſe ſhould cōplaine y• judge manius vſed many threatnings againe till wētno concluſiō peace away without concluſiō yet y• embaſſadors dyd ſhew y• anſwere caeſar either bycauſe knew particularly authoritie thrée men diſpleaſe 〈…〉 lucius 〈…〉 〈◊〉 tvvo legion thus thys warre followed thys ſort two legion lucius alba made tumulte droue away captaynes readye reuolte caeſar lucius made haſt lucius came fyrſte wyth many fayre wordes promiſes ſtayde furnius broughte hym another army caeſar cutte tayle droue furnius hyll nyght following wente sentia citie hysfurnius beſege • sentia betvveene campania 〈◊〉 lucius entreth citie faction whome ceſar would follow feare traynes next day beſéeged citie lucius went rome wyth al haſt ſent thrée bandes night followyng armye receyued nonius gard gate tooke hys souldyoures ſerue lepidus eſcaped wente lepidus fleeth lucius people rome caeſar lucius aſſembled people put good hope caeſar lepidus ſhoulde puniſhed miſgouernement hys brother woulde willingly giue ouer vnlawfull authoritie take conſulſhip office inſtituted theyr auntient father ſayd thus muche people béeyng glad thinking thrée men authoritie ſhould ſoone ceaſſe ſaluted hym generall done went againſt caeſar gathering way another hoſt place antonyes inhabitance ſettled béeing well affected antony barbatius bin treaſourerberbatius warre ſente hym diſpleaſure tolde people antony angry ſtyrred againſt caeſar common authoritie people béeyng thus abuſed forſooke lucius wēt caeſar lucius marched againſtpeople forſaketh lucius saluidienus brought great power france caeſar andsaluidienus asinius 〈◊〉 agrippa aſinius ventidius antonyes captaynes followed y• tayle ſo coulde goe forward agrippa man moſt truſty caeſar fearing leaſt saluidienus ſhould cōpaſſed tooke lombardy y• place thought lucius could ſpare woulde leaue saluidienus come againſt ſo mighte saluidienus follow y• taile agrippa deceiued whē lucius ſaw deceiued purpoſe repaired aſinius • vētidius whereby saluidienus agrippa frée take aduā tage could whiche lucius perceyued durſte fight went perugia citie wel defenſed 〈…〉 oeth perugia encamped loking ventidius caeſar agrippa saluidienus comming vpō • • ged three army perugia leaſt lucius might eſcape hāds ſent caeſars force deteine aſinius ventidius although made great haſt approued warre noroccaſion hinderaunce lucius ſure antony minde beſide emulation betwéene eyther ſéeking leader lucius thus beſieged neyther durſte giue battel lucius diſtreſſe inferiour number alſo goodneſſe soldiors departe thence ſo manye readye moleſt therfore ſent ventidius aſinius manius perſwade thē come helpe hym thē beſieged ſent alſo titinius four thouſande horſe ſpoyle caeſars landes thereby myght call ſiege ſo haue perugia siege perugia frée winter néede til ventidius companye myghte come caeſar hauing al power togither compaſſed caeſar encloteth lucius place eight mile aboute bycauſe hill made long trenche tiber nothing ſhoulde bée tiberis ſpringeth aboute •• goeth thorough turſ • rome novv tenure plancus brought thence perugia luc •• n lyke ſorte trenched rootes hilles fuluia commaunded ventidius aſinius ateius calenus make haſte helpe beſieged gathered newe hoſte ſente plancus lucius thys plancus waye cutte legion caeſars andplancus whereas aſinius ventidius went ſlowly vncertaine antony wil yet fuluia manius ſake came forwarde caeſar agrippa went méete leauing ſufficient force perugia diſſeuered themſelues one lucius povver dieuerereth ſelues pa • enna fi • deth gulfe •• n • ce arimeno 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 se 〈…〉 rauenna arimeno retired peruſing victual commanded bondman ſhold haue none yet kept thatextremitie ſ •• uine ſhold get ſhew néed y• enimie ran orchard garden eate graſſe leaues theymiſery ſla •• e could find whē late fighte ſo valiauntly 〈…〉 f • 〈…〉 might haue done therfore yéelde ſight death euerye man conſented therfore night ſhoulde giue none occaſion cowardneſſe deſired might go daye ſo lucius led forth breake day many ſcales engins yron fill ditch climbe theaſſaulte trenche trench wyth kind weapon throw thus iſſued great violence filled ditch withoute ſtoppe caſting engins wall ſome beate downe trenche ſome ſet vp ſcales ſome aſſaulted toures without reſpect death fought notwithſtanding great reſiſtaunce made ſhotte contrary parte fight diuers place ſo defeucethe • er • enelle fyght weaker fight fierce vpon bridge paſſed alſo ſcaled rampire like haue done ſome deſperate feate except moſt valiāt caeſars hoſt like courage come reſiſtāce euer relieued freſh men length tyred thrown trench engins broke yet ſtucke without ſhrinking though ſtrength voice fayled yet able reſiſt aſhamed giue place abode lucius repulſed til lucius blow retreat caeſars ſouldiours make great token gladneſſe lucius men ſtroken ſhame tooke ſcales approched wal able good lucius againe cal backe y• ſhoulde caſte away liues vaine heauye hart againſt wils retired end ſharpe aſſaulte caeſar appointed
