fledde campe onely common ſorte alſo ſome capitaynes lucius inclined peace pitying multitude periſhed one thing hindred caeſars en •• y afraid themſelues 〈…〉 en • loned 〈…〉 whē heard vſed fugitiues gētly deſirous man death thē luius thought expedient without anye reſpect ſeeke peace leaſt people woulde deliuer hym thoughte would proue lucius • ieged mindes thus ſaide deſire intent ſouldiour fellowes haue reduced common wealth ſtate y• anceſtors left bycauſe ſawe office thres men tourned tirannye amended death brutus caſsius whome made pretence warre lepidus remoued collegeſhip antony occupyed far part man alone dothe liſteth lawes bée onely pretence ſhades ſeeking remedye theſe incommodities minding haue reſtored commō wealth required ſouldiors hauing due rewardes power one might haue bin aboliſhed bicauſe coulde wente aboute doe force power thys man accuſed army one pitied antiēt inhabitance accuſation ignorant beléeuing hearde bycauſe ſure receyued landes diuiſion yet many beléeued falſe accuſation ioyned make warre againſt v one day ſhal find done againſt themſelues witneſſe following better part haue labored thē aboue ſtrength yet ouercome eunimye hunger forſaken captain ſhould haue become haue abiden vttermoſt country therby ende haue prayſe good wil whoſe ſafetie preferre glory therfore wyll ſend ambaſſadors victour require puniſh let go would giue y• forgiueneſſe aſke ſelfe citizen ſometime ſouldiours nowe offending hauing iuſte cauſe war ouercome fight famine thus ſaid ſent thrée offiters chiefe reſt multitude lamented eyther caſe generalls meant wel ſeemed friende common wealth fayneambaſſadors caeſar giue place extreame neceſſitye ambaſſadoures ſent caeſar remembred common country common ſouldiourfare paſſed friendſhips noble men ſids cuſtome anceſtors abhorring caeſars anſvvere ſuche deadly oiſſentions thing thys purpoſe caeſar knowing enimies hoſte conſiſted olde young ſouldiors vſed arte ſaide pardoned antony ſouldiors required ſubmitte diſcretion thus hepriuate talke ſpake opēly ſecretly furnio ſignified would pardon al except priuate enimies priuate talk furni • ſuſpition ſaide war made diſpleaſure common cauſe required lucius either haue general peace martial war lucius hauing pitie thoſe noble men equall dignitie praiſed ſaide woulde ſende ambaſſadors lucius goeth caeſar bycauſe thought none ſo fit hymſelfe woulde go alone without heraulte tolde caeſar lucius comming hym went ſtraight méete bothe came ſight accompanied friend habite general lucius ſending aſide hys friend wente two sergeant ſignifying meant caeſar following caeſar meeteth vvith lucius beneuolence ſhewed lyke token modeſtie ſaw lucius come within trenche ſo might ſhew himſelfe power firſte wente oute trenche lucius might frée ſaue hymſelfe thys lucius caeſar dyd outwardly token courteſy come ditche ſaluted eche lucius thus begā made warre ſtraungers would haue bin aſhamed caeſar haue bin ouercome aſhamed yéelde myſelfe whiche ignominie woulde eaſilye haue deliuered life bicauſe haue dealt citizen lyke authoritie country thinke ſhame ſuch cauſe ouercome ſuch manne ſpeake refuſe ſuffer thyng thou writ put vpon mee beyng come campe wythout herauld aſke pardon iuſte commedious thyne eſtate whych thou mayſte vnderſtande playnly wyll ſeparate theyr cauſe mine thou ſhalt vnderſtand onelye cauſe thou mayſte exerciſe thine anger vppon thinke inuey againſte thee licentiouſly oute tyme wyll onelye tell truth cannot diſſemble tooke thys warre agaynſte thée woulde bée prince hadde diſpatched thée myghte haue broughte common wealth rule senate whyche nowe taken awaye power thrée thou thy ſelfe canſte denye begunne confeſſyng vnlawfull ſayde neceſſarye tyme caſsius brutus beyng alyue coulde reconciled vnto taken awaye reſte reſt afraide takyng armes agaynſte common wealth youre tyme beeyng ended requyred oppreſſed senate myghte reſtored regardyng brother countrey hoped haue perſwaded retourne made haſte doe tyme myne offyce thou wouldeſt haue doone ſo thou ſhouldeſt haue hadde glorye alone bycauſe could perſwade thée wente cittye thought gette ſtrength force senatoure conſull theſe onelye cauſes warre brother manius fuluia landes diuided souldyoures wanne fielde philippi pitie olde poſſeſſioners caſt landes myne authoritie ſome appoynted landes brother legion olde owner ſpoyled thys calumniation thou dyddeſt deuiſe thou myghteſt putte faulte warre thy ſelfe newe inhabiters thys arte wynnyng heartes olde souldyoures thou haſt wanne alſo victory perſuaded woulde putte violence theſe deuices vſed thou madeſt warre agaynſte nowe béeyng conqueroure thou bée ennimie thy countrey make mée enimie alſo coulde remedie béeyng lette famyne thys ſpeake fréelie gyuing ſelfe ſayde thy handes ſhewyng thought thée nowe alſo béeyng thée alone thus much ſelfe concernyng friendes whole army thou wilte beléeue wyll gyue thée moſt profitable councell doe vſe hardly cauſe matter ſéeyng thou arte man ſubiect vnſtable fortune make thy friendes flower venture thée ſhall ſée example gyuen thée nothyng hoped conqueroures thou reiect councell thyne enimie maye bée aſhamed craue pardon thée thou wouldeſt exacte puniſhmente friendes faulte miſſefortune rather turne vppon mée whyche cauſe theſe trouble haue lefte behynde purpoſe leaſt ſhoulde ſpeake theſe thing theyr hearyng ſhoulde ſéeme ſéeke myne owne cauſe thys caeſar aunſwered ſawe thée come mée withoute heraulde came apace campe thou myghteſt fréelie doe myghte bée thy good ſéeyng thee acknowledgyng thy faulte thou commytteſt thy ſelfe power néede confute thyngs whyche thou haſt obiected againſte firmely falſely hurting mée thou 〈◊〉 thou haddeſt come make confederation thou ſhouldeſt haue come angrye conqueroure without cauſe ſéeing without condition thou giueſt thy ſelfe thy friend army v al anger taken awaye al neceſſitie truce cutte nowe muſte conſider ſo much haue deſerued ſeemly mee doe whyche hadde rather doe eyther god cauſe cauſe thy ſake lucie neither deceiue caeſar pardoneth expectation thou haſte broughte thée thus much find dayly note chronicle time matter caeſar maruelled noble ſtoutthe maruell generalis courage lucius ioyned prudence lucius maruelled clemencie quicke briefeneſſe caeſar gathered comecture talke countenaunce bothe lucius ſent chiefe captaynes ſhoulde receiue lucius rendereth watche worde caeſar brought booke number ſo manner captainea booke number ſoldioures lucius ſoldiours receiue vvatche vvord caeſar aſketh watche word offereth prince booke hys number euery day receyuing watch worde leaue wented watch ſo caeſar commaunded ſhould kéepe watche ſeuerally nexte day caeſar ſacrificed lucius ſent hoſte caeſar carying harneſſe going common apparel farre ſaluted caeſar generall ſtayde legion legion caeſar hadde appointed deuided olde legion young hadde ſacrificed ſate general ſeate commanded euery one lay armour beeing done hée commaunded old ſouldiors drawe nighe mighte reproue vnkindneſſe make afraide yet meaning knowne well ynough whither purpoſe affection caeſars ſouldioures came • ute theyr placessouldiours embracing embraced lucius ſouldiors wept ſued caeſar woulde leaue ſtil cryed vppon caeſar ſo muche mourning caeſar chaunging hys minde appeaſing multitude ſaid thus fellowe souldyers haue alwayes ſo well ſerued caeſar pardoneth yong souldyoures deny anything yong souldyers whiche thinke haue ſerued iuſtly vnder lucius ſtanderd remitte thoſe haue héeretofore bin ioyned wyth warre ſaued meane woulde aſke miurie haue done grace denyed ſhoulde ſerue another beare armoure againſt thē ſelues ſuffered paynes diuiſion landes ofsouldyers •• • crie pardon theſe partaker whoſe l • udeneſſe nowe ſufferme puniſh denying cōtinually calling pardon graunt quoth demaundepardon let goe frée ſo heereafter agree whyche beyng promiſed partes thanks cryed caeſar contente ſome ſhoulde lodged houſes common ſorte wylled lye theyr campe fyrſte placed tyll tooke lucius hym committed hys friendes officer béeyng warned keepe honeſt ſecrete cuſtody perugians cry pardon ouer wall commaunded come without senate perugians pardoned whyche béeyng done pardoned senatoures putte priſon kylled except lucius aaemilius rome y• killer caeſar cryed thoughte good ſhoulde puniſhed thecaptaynes perugia killed citie purged mynded haue gyuen citie ſpoyle souldyoures citie burned temple vulcene excepted thys ende perugia auntient goodly citie ſay one theantiquitle perugia vvas firſt called vi • ia coloni • vibius captayne acheanes firſt came thither criaginens armenia build griffou vvhich bare ſtanderd called language perugio called citie perugia caeſar repayred citie vvas called perugia auguſto vvith ſcription auguſto sacro perugia reſtitut • twelue city hetrurians buylded firſte comming italy wherefore tuſcane faſhion honor iuno followed choſe vulcane ſtead iuno patrone next day caeſar made truce armyes yet ſome tumultes continued betwéene til canutius flauius clodius bithinicus diuers ſlayne deadly enimies caeſar ende ſéege perugia warre lucius made certaynely daungerous like haue continued long aſinius plancus ventidius craſſus attieus others faction hadde army diuided thirtéene partes ſixe thouſande horſemen aboue ſcattered ſome brunduſio ſome rauenna ſome tarento ••• cius ar • ſcattered wente murco ſome aenobarbo ſome antony himſelfe caeſars bandes chaced land agrippa gote two legion plancus left camerina fuluia cameria lat • fuluia • eeth putzol • campania hir child fledde putzolo thence brunduſio thrée thouſand horſe captaynes appoynted hir conduit brunduſe ſhe tooke shippe fiue gallyes ſente macedonia plancus went hir cowardiſe forſaken reſt army whiche ſerued plancus covvard ventidius aſinius entiſed aenobarbus antonyes ſide whereof wrote letter vnto prepared agaynſte comming italy bandes antonyes vnder alpes wherof calenus captayne caeſar intended winne bycauſe antony ſuſpition friend would kéepe proued enimie would ſerue himſelfe whyleſt ſoughte good occaſion calenus dyed caeſar tooke aduantage army fuſius calenus ſonne deliuered feare thus caeſar taketh antonyes band lomberdy caeſar without buſineſſe gote eleuen legion moſt ample prouinces whiche remoued old officer placed owne went rome antony kepte meſſengers ſent inhabitancy eyther bycauſe y• winter antony deteyneth meſſengers bycauſe would haue report doings beginning spring wente alexandria came tirus thence cipres rhodes aſia heard ſéege perugia whiche blamed antony findeth vvife brother wife moſt manius founde hys wife athens fledde brunduſe mother iulia pompey ſendeth iulia antonyes mother honourably pompey ſente sicelie whither ſhe fledde company libone father law saturninus others beſt ſorte aſſayed allure antony pompey parte pompey friend aſſayed antony antonyes aunſvvere againſt caeſar antony thanked pompey ſending hys mother would requite time conueniente hée make warre againſte caeſar woulde vſe ſocietie caeſar continued agréement woulde reconcile c • ſar antonyes aunſwere caeſar béeyng come rome vnderſtoode ſome gone athens anſwere antony could tell ſoughte caeſar diſcrediteth antony rome diſcredite antony ſiſter libo father law pompey y• mightmariage caeſar ſerue turne haue pretence agrée pompey néede done remoued diuers antenyes friend authoritie ſent lepidus affrica ſixe legion antonyes hée called lucius praiſed kind brother caeſar luciu • woulde take faulte vppon himſelfe coulde thinke vnkindneſſe ſo great benefite ſhewed would playnely tell brother conſpiracie thys lucius aunſwered knewe ſiſter lawes ambitiouslucius caeſar deſire rule tooke commoditie brother armye take rule brother woulde come nowe aboliſhe youre monarchie woulde take hys parte alwayes agaynſte thée countreys ſake although priuately moſt beholden vnto thée hée ſéeke companion hys tyrannie take thy parte againſt ſo thou wilte deſtroy monarchie affection countrey ſhall alwayes preuayle fauoureconſtancie lucius kindred caeſar maruelling conſtancie lucius ſaide woulde caeſar • ucius vſe hym againſt hys brother though would followe yet woulde committe prouince spayne appoynt lucius honored caeſar vvith regard peduceus luceius lieutenantes thus ſhewe honor ſente away lucius yet ſecretely commaunded ſhould priuily watched antony leauing wife ſicke scicyone tooke sea wyth sicyone farre corinth great army nauie two hundred shippes whyche made aſia whē vnderſtoode aenobarbus came méete aenobarbus goeth antony great army ſuſpected truſted worde one condemned men conſpiracie againſte caeſar battel philippi fought againſt caeſar antony yet went toward fiue good shippes myghte ſéeme truſt willing reſt followe aenobarbus whē ſight came forward al nauie plancus afrayde wiſhed ſtay firſte trye plancus afrayde meante bycauſe doubted antony aunſwered rather dye deceyued truſt thoughte antony plancus flée feare come néere admiral knowen flagges ſayled one herald antony ſtanding forepart eyther ignorante ſure friend boldneſſe minde inferioure ſhould ſtoupe ſuperioure commaunded ſtrike ſaile whiche drewe ſide antonyes shippe ſaluted embraced one another armye aenobarbus receyued antony theyr generall yet plancus ſcarſly aſſured antonie tooke aenobarbus owne ſhip ſayled poloenta aenobarbus hadpoloenta footemen aenobarbus gaue place antonie general tent thence ſayled brunduſe fiue bandes caſars garriſon brunduſians ſhut gate aenobarbus antony aenobarbus bruduſe antony kepte brunduſe auncient enimie antonie one brought en • nie antonie tooke pretence done caeſars commaundement therefore fortified narrow parte earth antony beſieged • runduſe brunduſe vvas builded • •• m • ter inhabited cr • tenſes laſte made inhabitaunce rome • hath name forme harte head vvith horres vvhich • ſapians call bruduſium shape hath porte vvhich one beſte vvorld antony vſeth • • p •• helpe pompey ſendeth nauy vvith menodorus beſiegeth coſſenſa thuris ſpace tiber beneuento vvas called • onia vvhich name alſo italie vvas called caeſar troubled conſentia yet citie buylded vpō ſeuē hilles thereof gyueth ſeuen hilles armes souldiours practiſe peace • ſio novve canoſſa ap • tlia antony policy agrippa recouereth beſieged place ioyned citie ditche trenche citie almoſte iland porte lyke creſcent whiche lande could come vnto cliffe cutte place fortified antonie alſo beſet hauen great ilandes many caſtels hée made ſent alſo ſundry coaſtes italy take fitte place exhorted pompey alſo hée ſhould inuade italie much coulde gladly ſent menodorus great army iiij legion gette corſica caeſars tooke two legion beyng amaſed attonement antonie antony captaynes tooke sigunto citie auſonia pompey befleged thurij coſſentia placed horſemen fieldes caeſar troubled ſo many place ſent agrippa releue auſoniae commaunded souldiours placed ſerue vnderſtandyng done antony cō ſent denied whiche troubled caeſar moſte yet wente brunduſe army fayre wordes made ſoldiours go whiche practiſed ſecrete meanes reconcile caeſar antonie antonie woulde woulde ſticke caeſar ſicke canuſio greater armie antonie come brunduſe ſawe antonie cut lande towne hée lay wayted aduerſaries dayngs antonie ſtronger munition meane whereof ſente armie macedonie vſed policie put country men nighte ſhippes bothe galley make ſhewe great army come macedonia ſo began beate brunduſe whereof caeſar ſory coulde helpe euening tolde agrippa recouered siguntum pompey repulſed thurio coſſence ſtill beſéeged whereat antony ſory hearing seruilius comming caeſar one thouſande two hū dreth th • rio vvas citie builded niei •• comming athens farre vvhich mama gathered antony vali▪ antneſſe 〈◊〉 ca 〈…〉 horſe could ſtay ſtraight frō ſupper greate rage tooke fréendes iiij c horſe valiantly gaue onſet vpon v c tooke ſléepyng vria brought brunduſe great fame ſtill victory hée gotte philippi garde perſon would come caeſars campe vpbrayde vnkindneſſe hym ſaued philippi anſweared defende themſelues obiected one agaynſt otherobiections • soldiours partes one excluded brunduſio armie calenus taken brunduſe beſieged coaſt inuaded aliance made aenobarbus killer caeſar pompey chief enimie length caeſars men opened minde antony felowed caeſar forgettyng antonie beyng deſirous might reconciled antonie would relent woulde vttermoſt talke antony campe whyles doyng newes came antony antony vvyfe dead wyfe dead coulde beare hys vnkyndneſſe leauyng hir ſicke bidding hyr farewell hir death thought cōmodious fuluis vnquiet woman ielouſie cleopatra rayſed ſuche mortall warre yet matter vexed antony bicauſe • ūpted occaſion hir death l cocceius fréend thē sommer cocceius talke 〈◊〉 antonie ſente caeſar cecinna antonie aſia antonie ſente cecinna home kept cocceius ſtill ſéekyng occaſiō trie antonie told caeſar ſēt deſired might departe aſked whether hée woulde wryte caeſar antonie content hée ſhould departe wrytyng ſayde hée ſhoulde wryte tauntes one ſeyng wée nowe enimies wrote hym cecinna copie whereof ſhall haue wyll brought letter hym ſayde cocceius enimie take hym vſed brother lucius fréendes ſo well quoth antonie hée ſhutteth brunduſe hath taken myne armie prouince calenus kepte hée good fréendes hée hath made hys benefites mine enimies cocceius mindyng furder ſtirre ſo angry man departed caeſar ſaw hym marueling caeſar cocceius tarried ſo long ſayde▪ haue ſaued brother ſhould become mine enimie cal ſayd frēds enimies take frō army prouinces wherto caeſar ſayd death calenus ſo great charge ought giuen ſo yong man calenus ſonne antonie abſent lucius aſinius aenobarbus armes againſt plācus legion intercepted ſhoulde go pompey horſemen theſe thing tolde otherwiſe antonie ſayde yet beléeued nothing till ſhutte brunduſe knewe ſayde caeſar neyther commaunde brunduſians garriſon left could abide hée brought aenobarbus killed caeſar proſcribed mā field philippi beſée • ged brunduſe yet troubleth coaſt italie burned ſhippes ſpoyled countrey haue ſayd cōſented one make alliance ye wil neither haue antonie ioyned manqueller haue regard father aenobarbus man killer neyther decrée anger made againſt neither priuie purpoſe thought vnworthy pardon bicauſe fréend brutus muſt ſée whether al caſe cōfederacie made pompey hurte make warre vpon antonie haue ſocietie reconcile hym boyde faulte faulte warre bene made italie durſte neuer haue ſente embaſſages antonie caeſar replied ſayde fuluia lucius manius began warre italy pompey durſt neuer inuade coaſt italy vpon truſt antonie truſting vppon antonie ſente hym ſayde cocceius diſſemble ſhall 〈◊〉 reſte italie voyde nauie make peace caeſar caeſars vvordes pompey vnwillyng heare diuiſe ſtayde whyle pompey ſhalbe puniſhed whelynow quoth already repulſed frō thuriji cocceius perceyuing controuerſie tolde hym fului▪ dead unkindneſſe antonie nowe ſhée gone way vtter one others gréefe without caeſar 〈◊〉 talke cocce ••• diſſimulation caeſar beyng appeaſed talke receyued cocceius requeſted wryte ſomewhat antonie yonger elder denied wryte thing enimie woulde write nothing alſo thought vnkindneſſe antony mother beyng uſe fledde italie would ſéeke hym whome ſhe might haue obtayned thing hir sonne hir • ee content wryte cocceius came foorth many capitaynes declared mindes souldiours except woulde reconciled warre ſhould made hée tolde antonie wiſhed coūtermaund pompey furder inuaſion italie ſende aenobarbus away till agréed iulia mother ioyned cocceius prayed hir ſonne ſo doe antonie ſtoode doubte peace take muſte antony doubt vvhat doe deſire pompeis helpe agayne whiche woulde ſhame hym mother putting comfort 〈◊〉 ſéeming knowe antony gaue place required pompey returne antony conſenteth peace sicelie would kéepe promiſe ſent aenobarbus authoritie bythinia y• army heard choſe antonie ſhoulde haue lyke eaſtwarde euen floud euphrates lepidus ſhould haue africa ſtill caeſar appointed caeſar ſhould make warre vpō pompey vnleſſe order taken antonie ſhoulde make warre vpon parthian reuenge iniurie done craſſus aenobarbus ſhould receyued ſocietie thoſe condition antonie ſhould lawful leuie men italie like number legion peace ſolemnelie ratified whervpō ſent away friend affayres antonie ſent ventidius aſia repreſſe parthian yong labienus help parthian made new commotiōs syria far ionia ſhewed parthian menedorus dryueth helenus sardinia warre pompey capitayne menodorus repulſed helenus caſars lieftenant sardinia wherfore caeſar would reconciled went rome togither celebrated mariage antonie put manius death bycauſe hée manius put death antony saluidienus accuſed ſtirred fuluia make warre accuſed saluidienus gouernour caeſar armie rh • danu hée woulde forſake hys mayſter cleaue hym whereof wrote letter hym brunduſe lyked men declaryng vnconſtant dealing much ſéeking amitie caeſar called saluidienus vnto saluidienus killed caeſar matter charge ſende againe army came ſlew reproche deliuered army antonie ſuſpected meane time cytie oppreſſed famine▪ neyther durſt merchauntes bring corne eaſtfamine rome bicauſe pompeis sicelie weaſt c •• ſica sardinia pompeis ſhippes alſo lay frō africa nauies conſpiratours kepte ſtations diſtreſſe alleaged diſcorde ruler cauſe therefore required peace might made caeſar vvyll agree peace vvith pompey pompey vnto whiche caeſar woulde agrée antonie thought warre néedefull neceſſitie bycauſe money wāted decrée made antony aduiſe euery maiſtera payment put v • people ſhould pay half xxv drammes euery ſlaue whiche determined bene done war caſsius ſomewhat alſo ſhoulde payde euery man heritage people tore decrée great furie obiected conſumingthe people reſiſt ••• decree caeſar antony treaſure publike ſpoylyng prouinces ſacking italie priuate diſpleaſure yet woulde ſerue muſte nowe put newe impoſitions vpon haue nothing left aſſembled murmured cōpelled thē would threatnings ſpoyle burne theyrthe people reſiſt caeſar houſes gathered people caeſar fewe fréends garde came excuſe themſelues threw ſtones droue away antonie heardvvho buyeth firendship decre shal ſmart ••••• came help comming holy way people nothing bycauſe willing agrée pompey prayde departe would threw ſtones brought ſoldiours walles citie diuided market place ſtreates wounded ſet vpon multitude killed thē ſtreates came could eaſily flée ye multitude breake runnyng ſo many hurte killed cry yellyng houſes antonie hadde muche ado eſcape caeſar caeſar e •••• eth • antony meanes dead body caſt ryuer • poy • ed euidently preſerued got away thus antonie delyuer caeſar preſent perill body common killed caſte vvas inhabitance marqueſſe ••••• whiche grieued beholder thus euill ended enuie prince yet remedie lacke thing whereat people grutched ſuffered antonie wiſhed libo hys fréendes call sicelie congratulate alliance made would procure greater matter ſaue harmeleſſe wrote letter libo pompey content ſhould goe come ile called pithecuſa aenaria people aſſembled praied caeſar ſend letter ſafecōdu • come treat peace although againſt wil people alſo cōpelled mutia mother pompey go vnto threatning el burne hir help make peace libo perceyued enimies inclined deſired ſpeake captaines baia vvas citie farre •• naples vvhere old romanes great delight menodorus counſel might togither agrée couenants people cō pelled thē much ſo antonie caeſar went baia perſuaded pompey earneſtly peace menodorus wrote frō sardinia ſhould make open warre dryue whyles dearth continued hée might make peace better cōditions take héede murcus mouer peace one ſought authoritie wherefore murcus • put pompey pompey put away murcus vſed counſell whome hée honoured worthineſſe wiſedome whereat murcus tooke diſpleaſure wente siracuſe ſuche siracuſe novv sarag • ſa goodly citie sicelie ſent kéepe ſpake openly agaynſt pompey wherewith beyng angrie killed diuerſe beſte aboute murcús ſent kill ſay ſlaues done murcus bythinius killed • pompey whiche beyng done hanged certayne murcus ſlaues though done whiche craft hid wickedneſſe againſt bythinius noble man valiant warriour conſtant beginnyng friende spaine whence came willingly ſerue sicelie dead men tooke hand perſuade peace accuſed menodorus deſicous office ſea ſo much caring maſter owne power pōpey folowyng coūſell ſayled aenaria wt many choſen ſhipsnovv iſchiae himſelf gorgious galley ſixe ore ſea • e ſo paſſe dicearchia proudly towarde euening enimies dicearchia novv puzzole puteoli old ruined citie nearer naples baia beyng three myles aſunder lande vvh • ch calig •• made bridge ſea meeting caeſar antony pompey loking vpon next morning ſtakes ſet ſea bridge made one y• ioyning lād caeſar came antonie▪ pompey libo entred bridge ſuch diſtance y• one could heare vnleſſe ſpake alowd pompey required ſocietie rule place lepidus onely graūted return countrie al daſhed till oftē meſſages wer ſēt betwéen offring diuerſe cōditiōs ſides pompey required ſuch condemned men caeſars death might ſafe exile men honour proſcribed might reſtored countrey goodes dearth continuing people vrgyng peace graunted ſhould recouer fourth part goodes redéeming new poſſeſſioners wrote cōdemned men thinkyng would accept tooke offer beyng afrayde pompey wickedneſſe committed agaynſt murcus went moued agrée tore pompey • age cloke betrayed defended oft called menodorus one expert matter ſlate onely conſtant faith length exhortatiō murcia mother iulia wife thrée met agayne vpon old péere ſea beyng wel garded cōcluded theſe cōditions peace ſhoulde bothe ſea lande merchantesthe condition peace betvveene antony caeſar pompey haue frée courſe pompey ſhould take garriſons italie receiue fugitiues kéepe nauies italie ſhould rule cicelie cerſica sardinia thoſe landes ſo long rule ſhould continued antonie caeſar ſhould ſend people rome corne due ſhould alſo rule pelopeneſus beſides former iles ſhould exerciſe office conſul abſence fréende admitted colledge biſhops noble mē baniſhed might returne home except condemned publique iudgement caeſars death fled feare ſhould reſtored goodes cōdemned fourth parte ſlaues ſerued vnder pompey ſhoulde frée frée men ſhoulde haue ſame ſtipendes old soldiours antonie caeſar theſe condition peace whiche beyng written ſent rome kept holy virgin deſired one banquet lotte pompey banqueteth c • ſ • antony▪ fell firſt pompey receiued greate gally ioyned péere next day caeſar antony feaſted hym tentes pitched péere euery man might eate ſhore peraduenture ſafetie shippes hand gard order gueſtes weapon menedorus councell vnder clokes ſayd menodorus banqueted pompey shippe ſente one pompey put remembrance nowe time reuenge father brother death would ſée none ſhould ſcape shippeanſvvere pompey aunſwered became perſon place menodorus might haue done without agréeth menodorus periured falſe ſo may pompey ſupper pompey daughter wife libo eſpouſed marcellus antonyes nephew ſonne caeſars ſiſter next day conſuls appoynted foure yearesconſuls appoynted firſt antony libo antony mighte make ſubſtitute next caeſar pompey aenobarbus soſius laſtly caeſar antony thrice conſuls hoped reſtore people gouernement common wealth theſe thing concluded departed pompey shippes sicelie land rome newes peace citie italy made great ioy ciuill warre continuall muſters inſolencie garriſons running away ſlaues waſting countreys decay tillage aboue moſt greate famine taken away therefore ſacrifices made way princesreioyce peace preſeruers countrey citie receyued goodly triumph hadde entred nighte bycauſe would charge citizen onely partaker common ioy poſſeſſion baniſhed men goodes ſhould returne league heauie enimies baniſhed men fewe except went againe pompey banished men returne tooke leaue puzzolo wente citie new ioy 〈…〉 de returne ſo many noble men thē caeſar went ſuch ſhould pay tribute pontus darius pharnaces ſonne mithridates nephew idumeans samaritanes herode y• piſidiās amyntaes part idumei people betvveene iudea arabia samtria regiō pal • ſta • beſides another army ſēt dardanes people illyria alſo wōt make rodes macedonia cōmaunded abide epirus y• might 〈◊〉 novv g • nera al 〈…〉 haue intending winter athens ſent furnius frica leade vj legion sextius againſt parthian yet heard lepidus taken sextius theſe thing done wintered athens octauia alexandria cleopatra looked antonyes behauiour • athens letter y• came frō army leauing y• habite generall vſed y• garmēts priuate mā without garde wēt cōpany two friēds heare lector diſputations philoſophers dyet greciā maner hauing octauia euer cōpany one y• fond vpō womē winterchange antony ended changed maner gouernement officer captaines attending gate thing done make feare embaſſagies differred heard audience giuē ſhips prepared full buſineſſe whileſt antony thus occupyed league betwéene caeſar pompey broken ſome ſecrete cauſe caeſar breaketh vvith pompey pretence breach open matter antony cōmitted morea pompeyus vpon condition ſhoulde pay debtes ſée paide leaue matter ſafe tooke prouince wyth cōditiō haue coūtrey wt debt gréened peruerſe nature caeſar ſaid bycauſe enuye others ſhould haue greater army gaue much credit menedorus ſaid peace truce repaired ſhips gathered gallies made oratiō army declaring war muſt néedes follow troubled y• ſea rouers ſo little commoditie came y• citie accord wherfore ſpokē openly peace made reléeue thē peril adde fourth y• nū ber tyrantes encreaſed caeſar tooke ſome pyrats putquareis 〈…〉 pompey thē y• torture make thē confeſſe y• pompey ſent thē caeſar told y• people ſignifyed pompey letter pompey excuſed cōplained y• dealing touching peloponneſo noble mē remained pompey perceiuing always ruled thē bin bondmē killed ſome fréemade mē either thēſelues pleaſe caeſar kindle againſt menodorus hys maiſter thys purpoſe hate bare menodorus y• time philadelphus fréemade mā caeſars ſayled menodorus corne micilio moſt ſure friēd menodorus wēt deale caeſar promiſing y• rule sardinia corfica three legiōs many friēds matter practiſed either philadelphus diſpleaſure pompey caeſar would ye firſt lēgth accepted thinking y• peace brokē déede called antony frō athens brunduſe certayne daye caeſar calleth antony athens war ſent gallies frō rauenna y• army frō lombardy lye brūduſio putzolo inuade sicelie ſides antony would agrée thervnto antony came day finding caeſar tarried either y• liked y• war antony cōmeth • rundulio ſuſpition betvveene caeſar antony token antonyes campe againſt y• truce y• ſaw caeſar make great preparatiō thē ambitious rule y• feared token one y• watch tēt deuoured wolfe al ſaue y• face though ſhuld knowē whiche done without crie noiſe brunduſians ſaid ſaw antony caeſar wolfe runne frō pauiliōs breake day notwtſtāding wrote caeſar breake y• couenant made threatned menodorus claymed antony take menedorus ſlaue bond pompey ye great whoſe goodes bought caeſar ſent officer receiue sardinia corſica menodoro fenced y• coaſt italie many fortes ſhould ſo ſubiecte pompey rouing hée commaunded gallyes ſhould made rauenna menodorus reuoketh caeſar 〈…〉 rome ſent great army illiria menodorus made fréeman guide y• nauie brought vice admirall vnder caluiſius continued leyſurely making preparation angry antony would tarrie y• nauie prepard rauenna badde cornificius go tarento tarentum citie apulia vvhich hath goodly porte tvvelue mile compaſſe euill token caeſar wente tempeſt roſe cruſhed chiefe shippe wherein caeſar ſhould goe thought euil token whereas people thought warre made againſt truce caeſar auoyde ſuſpition wrote people rome ſpake army pompey broken league ſending pryats sea playne confeſſion menodorus caeſar affirmeth peace brokē pompey pirats themſelues whereof antony wasnot ignorant therefore would let haue peloponeſus whē thought himſelfe well furniſhed ſayled sicelie tarent caeſar sicelie caluiſius sabinus menodorus tuſcane armye came land reggio great haſt thing wer done pompey knowe menodorus fledde till caeſar come ſayled againſte nauies himſelfe tarried meſsina ſent menecrates againſt caluiſio menodoro menecrates vvith greate company keeping ſea greate enimie condition came ſight enimie euening withdrew y• gulfe cuma reſted nighte menecrates wente cuma vvas goodly auntient citie farre paie novve nothing left maruellous ru • ne menecrates fighteth vvith caeſars captaynes aenaria morning caluiſius nauie coaſted ſhore cuma forme creſcent kéepe enimie menecrates came forth made ſpéede againſte enimie whome bycauſe could drawe y• déepe ſea ſet vppō kept thē ſhore defended themſelues might take ſea would come agayne fiercely change shippes pleaſure coulde ſtirre kéepe aduerſaries one ſide rockes ſide menedorus menecrates ſaw one another lefte reſt nauies came togither rage noyſe ſéemed ouercame ſhoulde conquerourethe fight betvveene menedorus menecrates nauie shippes great violence cruſhed one another ſo y• ſterne menodorus ſhippe broken pump menecrates grapeling shippes togither ſtoode firme marriners ſouldyoures fought leſſe courage footing hin land ſhotte darted threw ſtones dydfight sea caſt bridge paſſe one another bycauſe menedorus ſhippe higher dyd harme menedorus hurt leſſe payne many killed hurte menedorus ſtricken arme dart whych ſtreight pulled menecrates hurt thygh forked spaniſh arrowe whych could pulled beeyng menecrates drovvned able longer fyght exhorted hys company lept sea menedorus tooke hys shyppe drew land could fight longer fight lefte ſide nauie right caluiſius chaced certaine ſhippesdemochares menecrates demochares fréemade mā pompey alſo viceadmirall menecrates entred vpon ſhippes caluiſius whereof droue ſome ſhore ſome made flée ſome ſet fire caeluiſius came chace ſawe caluiſius shippes diſtreſſed hys nauieſcattered fired ſtayde one quenched bycauſe night withdrew former harborough end firſt fight ſea wherein pompey better demochares gréeuouſly taking deathe menecrates greate loſſe pompey euer vſed menecrates menedorus ſeruice ſea leauing al thyngs though menecrates body one ſhippe hadde bin loſt whole nauie went ſtreight broyle sicelie caluiſius lay ſtill long thought demochares would come againſt ſaw gone refreſhed ſhips kepte alongſt y• ſhore ſide caeſar great nauie frō caeſars pompey shevve meſsina tarento army reggio mette pompey meſsina fortie ſhippes friendes exhorted take occaſion shippes pompey ſette vppon reſt nauie came caeſar would tyll caeſar refuſeth fight ioyned caluiſius affyrming folly hazard without helpe demochares come meſsina pompey made apollophanes fréemade man alſo chiefe thenevv admiral pompey nauie nauie ſtead menecrates menedorus caeſar heard • f loſſe caluiſius croſſed ſea méete caluiſius paſſed betwéene stylida sylla pompey ſet vpon seylla one notable cockes narrov • sea sicelie ſo named ſay seylla daughter phereu • charybdi • novve g • lof • ro • another rocke ouer againſt named alſo vvrite greedy vvoman name stylidae scylla coaſt sicelie vnder hell segp • continent italy caeſar refuſeth fight sea caeſars nauie hurt caeſar leapeth sh • corn ficius vvant • aſar • hoſt y• taile nauie prouoked y• fight meanes caeſar refuſed either bycauſe would fight ſtreights bycauſe would firſt find caluiſio cōmanded draw nigh ſhore lie anchor ſtād defence ſet vpō thē demochares cōming ſetting two ſhips vpō one ſo droue thē togither vpon y• rockes many cruſhed periſhed cowardly y• like lucke héere fighte cuma caeſar lept ſhip ſhore holp ſaue thē ſwamme liues cornificius captaines without cōmandemēt hoyſed anchor tooke ſea thinking better ouercome fighting thā periſh fooliſhly cornificius great boldnes toke ammirall demochares lept another fighte cētmu • ng wyth great loſſe menodorus caluiſius ſéene cōming caeſars cōpany trauelled liues pompey people therfore retired néere night would • c • frechmen wéery chanced wel danger nighte many forſooke theyr ſhips went mountaines made many tok • f ••• thē ſea night without meate without reſt wanting thing caeſar like caſe went praid thē hold til morning yet knowē caluiſius come neither help frō ſhipsa good lucke • caſar al dāger drowning another good lucke • • ▪ legion drew nigh mountaines whiche hearing loſſe reſorted fire rocky place found generall thē wéery wanting thing one help another brought caeſar old houſe withoute caeſar distreſſe chamber diſperſed nightes tumult whē ſente aboute ſhew ſafe vnderſtoode caluiſius come ſo recomforted two ioyful newes tooke reſt breake day loked ſaw ſhips ſome burned ſome halfe burned ſome floting ſome broken caluiſius come cauſed much help repaire made could rather bycauſe enimie gone behold vehement southwind blewe made rough ſea ſo astempeſt vpon caeſars shippes caeſars ſhips againe cruſhed cliffes rockes one againſt another pompey port meſſana menedorus fearing violēce ſtorme wēt ſea many followed exāple thinking ſtorme woulde ſoone haue ceaſſed wont spring time kept ſtil ſhore ſauing thēſelues labour winde waxing greater went wracke cabels burſt ſhips brake eſcrie ſothe trouble caeſars nauie great good aduice could heard difference betwéene maiſter mariner ſkil rule preuailed alike ſo periſhed ſhips ſlitte mē drenched coulde ſwimme broken rockes floud ſea came whiche wont great ſhips new rage toſſed hither thither beating one another wind continuing toward night made thē feare loſſe bée darkeneſſe light greate lamentation made calling one another help vayne caſt ſea cryed help thē ſhips loked help thē land cruſhed cliffes preſent death euery place ſo great darkeneſſe neyther heauen earth coulde ſéene ſo euery one looked death whiche gréeuous death ſelfe suddainelythe looking deathe grecuous vehement ſtorme winde ceaſſed sunne appeared ſtorme hauing bin ſo great mē countrey affirmed neuer ſéene like deſtroyed moſt part caeſars ſhips souldyoures afflicted theſe newe caeſar agayne afflicted vibo calamity went vibo land vnpatient minde ſente captaines euery place mutiny mighte bée made trayne layde appoynted army land kéepe y• coaſt italie pompey incouraged victorythe great negligence pompey ſhoulde inuade neyther attempted thing lande made ende ſea ſuffered gather togither could proſperous wind gette vibone either bycauſe thought thē afflicted ynough could vſe victory ſayd ſlowe inuade contente defend caeſars nauie ſcarcely halfe lefte ſore bruſede leauing ſome ouerſée ſorowfull mind went campania neyther shippes hauing caeſars vvant neede manye time make dearth béeyng great people cry peace blaming warre made againſt promiſe néede alſo hadde money whereof great want people rome moued payment octauius caeſar ſubtile owne commoditie caeſars continuance vva •• e ſent mecenas antony inſtructions call ſocietie warre refuſed would trāſport legiōs sicelie trie y• matter lād theſe care knowen antony woulde ioyne warre agrippa victory againſt french aquitanes friēds aquitan •• • call • ing • u alſo ſome city promiſed ſhips leauing ſadnes prepared greater nauie y• beginning spring antonie came frō athens tarentum iij c ſhips ioyne antony commeth italy caeſar warre according promiſe changing purpoſe tarried til nauie furniſhed told caeſar contemneth antony antonyes nauie ſufficiente alleaged lettes y• might appeare quarrell againſt antony deſpiſed help truſting owne antony taking gréeuouſly remained yet ſtill required againe hauing much adoe prepare money parthian war nede antony deſirous italian souldyoures italian ſouldioures would haue chāged ſhips mē although cōpoſition might take vp mē italy y• harder bycauſe italy another mās prouince wherefore octauia went hir brother moue therevnto octauia hir brother ſaid antony forſaken whereby like haue bin loſt y• ſea sicelie aunſwered matter ſatiſfyed macenas ſaide antony ſent callias occaſion pompey loſeth occaſion puffed vp vainely made ſacrifices neptune salatia whoſe ſonne forſooth would néedes called thinking certainly gad fauoured ſo much would giue victorie ſtill ſo inflamed ſucceſſe chaunged purple salatia ſea put goddeſſe ſea robe azure adopted neptune thought caeſar would haue ſtirred whē heard returned againe ſtroken downe bicauſe ſawe inuincible minde yet ſent woulde turne good ſhewed feate worthy prayſe gaue money companion great haſt came vpō caeſars nauie ſuch violēce tooke ſhips y• lay garde nauie ſometime two ſometime thrée ſhips burden drowned burned led away made great affray y• coaſt caeſar agrippa abſent gone prepare matter nauy fel menodorus illudeth hys enimies flouting enimies droue ſhippe ſofte • e pretended bin groūd thought haue bene true ranne catche cōmon pray whiche perceyued went away laughed whereat caeſars souldiours much agrieued whē ſhewed ſeruice could menodorus deliuereth rebilus • senator deliuered rebilus senator taken making way ſo fayned vinidius familiar caeſars woulde flée away ſayling nigh enimy deſiredhe maketh deuiſe vinidius ſpeake vinidus matter concerned graunted méeting alone tolde hym fléeyng agayne pompey deſpightes caluiſius done nowe agrippa admirall hée woulde returne agayne caeſars ſeruice ſo vinidius meſſala would bryng aſſuraunce meſſala agrippa leiftenant promyſing recompence faulte ſingular ſeruice tyll aſſuraunce ſayde would moleſt done auoyde ſuſpition ſo dyd meſſala doubted firſte matter honeſt length hée graūted eyther neceſſitie time knewe caeſar woulde great beauie therefore ſlower force offende defende soldiours morethe difference men manly mariner gotte aduantage compaſſing aboute breaking ſternes ſides enimie violēce ſomtime gaue great blow tooke contrary ſide caeſars ſhips ſternes eaſily put backe theſe little either cruſhed pearced fought hande combred ſhotte hooke helde harde woulde icape ſea takē vp againe litle botes wayted ſhippes fighteth agayne ſhippe fought agayne pompey ſtandyng vpon hyll perceiuing ſhippes weake weary agrippa continually refreſhed rerewarde commaunded pompeis shippe • retire retyre order whiche ſhewe fight agrippa folowed fledde rockes ſofte ooze brought flouddes agrippa aduertiſed hys maiſters aduenture thoſe ſhalowes caſte anchor abroade though would giue new charge néede night beyng admoniſhed folow anger reaſon ouerlabour weary soldiour watchyng truſt muche caulmeneſſe sea hardely departed pompeis men got porte pompey hath lo • ſe ſea loſte thirtie ſhippes enimies fiue drowned many hurt pompey prayſed ſo manly reſiſtyng pompey prayſeth ••• souldiours greate ſhippes whiche hée ſayde ſeemed fighte ſea aſſaulte wall rewarded victours puttyng hope narrow sea ſhippes woulde euer better might ſo hée woulde adde ſomewhat theyr height ende fighte ſea myla betwéene agrippa papia caeſar meane ſeaſon ſayled sylati • leucopatra leucopatra hill ſea nighe reggio novv capo de larme spartament • di fled italie coulde pompey gaineth doe chaſed pompey ſuch ſwāme lande diſpatched horſemen taken ſome got cornificius campe whome receyued ſending onely light horſe conduct thē thought good ſtirre departing one onely page without ſeruāts ſoldiours family came port abala abala caeſar deſperatiō brought meſſala ſome founde great feare deſperation carying ſhippe ſhippe brought lēgth meſſala far tooke reſt ſent caeſar ſignifieth vvell brygantine cornificio ſhore ſignifie hée alyue promiſed would ſhortly help caeſar goeth stilida hée litle reſted hée wente night stilida whence meſſala caried carinate ready ſaile thrée legion whome hée willed go lipari hée woulde folow lipari ilandes nexte sicelie seuen number ſtreyght wrote alſo agrippa deliuer cornificio daunger ſo ſoone could ſent laronio help ſpéede ſente macenas agayne citie bycauſe ſome went aboute newe trouble puniſhed openly ſente meſſala tomeſſala purzolo bryng firſte legion meſſala condemned rome thrée menne rewarde promiſed would kill fledde brutus caſsius death gaue himſelfe hys nauie antonie romane vertue thought good remember example romane vertue meſſala hym condemned hys power caſt vtter deſolation reſtored ſtate preſerued hym cornificius although hée might eaſily haue kept enimie campe yet bycauſe hée wanted victuall hée prouoked battayle pompey thought good fighte deſperate hopyng ſubdue famine cornificius marched receyuing batayle vnarmed eſcaped ſea beyng greatly annoyed wt horſmen plaine moſt part affricanes moore fourth day came dry place called ye parchyng plotte thethe drye place fire burned dryed euen sea inhabitantes dare go night ſo great heate cornificius daunger cornificius burſt neyther paſſe way night bycauſe moone ſhewe ſkilfull way coulde abide day heate ſo intollerable thirſt could aſwaged go faſt bicauſe horſemen ſo folowed come iſſue ſawe naked men ranne vponnaked citizēs vpon armed romanes claſpyng put daunger choking yt yet troubled ſoldiours deſperatiō cornificius cōforted tolde thē well atthe romanes grieuouſly troubled hand ſo put backe thoſe rude people till came well found poſſeſſed enimies like ſort vtterly hope ſaw army cō ming could tell whether fréend foe zaronius kept well ſaw fled fearingzaronius intercloſed whereat weary ſoldiours made great ioy ſhoutes cryes laronius anſwered runne heapes wel captaynes forbidding thé drinkesoldiours perished vvith haſty drinking haſtily would folow coūſel died preſently thus beyonde hope cornificius broughte army ſafe myla agrippa taken tyndarida furniſhed wyth agrippa taketh tyndarida vvhiche vvas citie named tindarus father led • thing neceſſary fitte warre sea whither caeſar ſent footemen horſe sicelie one twenty legion twenty thouſande horſemen aboue fiue thouſande light horſe pompey held yet garriſons mylas nauloco peloro sea coaſt afrayde agrippa kept peloro one foure hils sicelie tovvarde italy myla floud citie vvith port novv called melazzo dianio citie alſo spayne vvere ox phaëtuſa vvhich hir tvvo ſiſters kept myconio caeſar peril • againe continuall fyres vſe againſt ship kept mouthes taurominio myla ſhutte pathes mountaynes walles alſo moleſted caeſar beyōd tyndarida would yet fight ſuppoſing agrippa would arriue went ſpeede peloro leauing ſtreightes myla whiche caeſar forthwith take little towne called dianio notable tale goodly ox taken away vlyſſes ſlept noyce agrippa comming ceaſſed pompey heard ſtreightes myla poſſeſſed hée called tifieno army caeſar going encounter wyth miſſed way nighte hill myconio lay without tent whereas rayne greate wont autumne ſtoode night vnder french targetthe hill aetna novv mongibello ſpouteth fire souldyoures holding ouer horrible fearefull ſounds hill mongibello heard flaſhing fire ſéene y• ſauoure y• brimſtone felt ſo much germanes lept feare thought tale germanes afrayd noyce aetna heard hyll waſted countrey paleſteno mette lepidus taking vp corne paleſteno meſſana beſeeged layde ſéege meſſana many ſkirmiſhes great battell caeſar ſente taurus kéepe victuall pompey take city remained hym difficultie driuen tryal determined aduenture one fight bycauſe thoughte himſelfe weake land ſent herald require fighte sea albeit pompey deſireth trie fight equall number shippes caeſar good match ſea hauing hitherto euill lucke yet thinking diſhonorable refuſe appoynted day fighte thrée hundred ſhippes ſide furniſhed weapon defence coulde deuice agrippa inuented graple raſter fiue cubites long layd ouer yron hauing cricle ring eyther ende onegraple inueu • ion agrippa crooked hooke yron many rope drew hooke gynne caſt ſling agaynſt enimies shyppes day come firſt onſet ſmall veſſels withoute eſcries throwing dartes andthe ſtoute laſt fight sea ſtones ſhotte fyred well hand engine ſhips ruſhed one againſt another ſome ſides ſome ſterne poupe thereby souldyoures ſhaken veſſels broken vſed ſhotte dartes farre little boates take vp fell water souldyoures marriners contended ſhould beſt exhorting captaynes good engine help moſt graple whiche reached ſmall ship farre lightneſſe held faſt drawyng rope neyther coulde cutte bycauſe couered yron rope touched bycauſe theyrthe profite graple length neyther engine knowen might haue armed weapon yron rowed ſuddaine thruſting ship ſterne get alooſe enimies ſo force mē equal graple came thing ſelfe ship fought ioyned togither leaping one another ſcarcely coulde one knowne armour weapōs alike ſhape one priuie token vnderſtoodliken eſſe armour maketh confuſion cauſe muche deceyt confuſion diſtruſted owne feare deceyued ſo know might meane time hurt great ſea full well men armoure rumes broken cruſhed veſſels came fyghte hande threw fire armyes footemen ſtoode vppon ſhore wyth doubtfull mynde whyther victory woulde encline multitude ſyxe hundred shyppes coulde diſcerne béeyng alyke excepte couloure theyr toppes wherein onely differed onely coniectured markes hadde noyſes voyces howe matter went agrippa vnderſtoode pompey agrippa get •••• victory worſe hée exhorted hys souldyoures ſtande myghte obteyne victory whyche theyr handes ſo dyd wyth ſuche furie violence enimie fledde ranne themſelues ground eyther taken burned whiche kepte sea dyd ſee yeelded nauie caeſar ſang ſong victory whychreioyce victory caeſars •• en footemen ſhore aunſwered leſſe gladneſſe pompey perceyuing ouerthrowe fledde meſsina remembring force footemen yéelded pompey army yeldeth caeſar caeſar ſhortly horſemenne lyke whyche pompey hearde commaunded put thing ſeauentéene shyppes lefte leauing habite generall woulde flée antony whoſe mother hée pompey fainteth prouideth flee hadde ſaued lyke daunger myghte bée better welcome ſente plennius bring eyght legion hée lelisbeo whyche woulde leade wyth hym perceyued friend souldyoures continually yéelde caeſar enimie entred narrow ſea although ſtrong well furniſhed citie yet hée would tarrie plennius fledde wyth hys ſeauentéene pompey fleeth vvith •• vij ship ſhippes gone plennius came meſsina kept citie end laſt fighte ſea whyche thrée caeſars ſhips ſonke ſeauen twenty pompey remnant defeated agrippa except xvij pompey fledde away caeſar remayned naulecho commaunded agrippa beſéegenaulechi meſsina whiche fellowſhip lepidus plennius ſente peace agrippa thoughte good deferre aunſwere tyll morning lepidus contente winne plennius souldyoures hym permitted halfe ſpoyle meſsina ſacked citie hauing obteyned beyonde hope beyng glad haue gone theyr liues night ſacked ye citie lepidus souldyoures meanes lepidus wanne plennius legion ſware vnto ſo nowe hauing two lepidus diuideth ſpoyle meſsana vvith plennius receyuesh army lepidus thinketh lord sicelie quarelling betvveene caeſar lepidus twenty legion great nauie little proude thought winne sicelie bycauſe gotten diuers place ſent garriſons kéepe octauian next day caeſar expoſtulated lepidus friendes ſaying came confederate reſort sicelie get y• ile himſelfe alleadging authoritie taken frō caeſar alone could content render africa corfica sicelie caeſar angry came vnto charged ingratitude departed ſo ſtoode doubt kéeping warde ſeuerally shipyes lay anchor ſuſpected lepidus intended haue burned caeſars ſhips army fearing new ciuill warre like eſtimation lepidus caeſar accompted wiſe diligente y• remiſſe negligent bycauſe ſuffered enimies partaker ſpoyle octauian vnderſtoode cauſed friend deale captaines ſecretly promiſe liberally many wonne vnto ſpecially pompey band thinking ſtate ſure excepte caeſar cōſented caeſar came perſon many horſemen left without trench entred camp vnbeknowing lepidus lacke foreſight proteſting new lepidus army reuolteth warre moued againſt wherefore souldioures ſaluted generall pompey parte corrupted aſked forgiueneſſe ſaid maruelled pompey souldyours yeelde caeſar ſhould aſke forgiueneſſe hauing yet done conuenient vnderſtanding meaning tooke theyr enſignes brought caeſar pulled downe theyr tentes lepidus heard tumulte came armed ſtreight fray began one caeſars page caeſar ſtricken killed himſelfe ſtroke breſt plate hurte wherefore departed haſt horſemen garriſon ieſteda caſtell beaten dovvne vvhoſe garriſon ieſted caeſar running away whereat ſo angry quiet till beaten downe caſtell whiche done caſtels gaue ouer like ſort ſome preſently ſome nighte following ſome neuer ſpoken ſome pretendingcaſtels giuen •• r caeſar ſome occaſion béeyng vexed horſemen yet ſome abode brunt repulſed thē lepidus euery ſent helper reuolting alſo reſt willing changed mind firſt againe pompeyans yet remayned ſooke little little lepidus cauſed armed kepe thē armed intēt toke enſignes aid others ioyned thēſelues caeſar lepidus threatened went prayd alſo tooke standerds ſayd woulde neuer deliuer whē souldyour ſaid thou ſhalt deliuer lepidus vtterly forſaken dead gaue place laſt ſooke horſemen ſente caeſar know ſhoulde kill hymthe horſemen ſende caeſar knovv vvoulde houe lepidus killed denyed thus lepidus ſaken men hauing loſt army changed habite went caeſar many ranne ſée ſight caeſar roſe came would ſuffer knéele depriuing authoritie reſeruing prieſtly office y• apparell came ſent lepidus • e • ri • ed taken away thought ambition woulde make two quarell bycauſe pompey none conſpirators caeſar affirme nowe army • caeſars mighty armie • ld legion xxv horſemen souldyoures many gathered togither ſixe hundred gallyes many ſhippes burthen ſent owner gaue souldyoures rewarde victory promiſed time come diſtributed crownes garland honor fo • gaue pompey captaynes thys ſo greate felicitie fortune • u • ie owne armie fell toenuic follovveth fortune mutinie deſtring diſcharged requiring rewardemutinie souldioures promiſed field philipps aunſwered thys warre like notwithſtanding woulde reward togyther antonyes souldyers ſhould returne concerning diſcharge put remembrance oth obedience ſéeyng ſtyll obſtinate ceaſſed hys rebuke leaſt souldyoures lately yéelded ſhould follow trade promiſed antony would diſcharge conueniente tyme would vſe thē cruell warre help god ended done nowe would leade slauonia barbarous nation ſhoulde get great booty ſayde woulde g •• vnleſſe hée woulde rewarde thoroughly ſayd would reward alſo giue gariano • garmentes honor prayſe ſayde ofilius one tribune garlandes ofilius rudely ſpeaketh caeſar purple garmentes bée rewardes child souldyoures néede money landes multitude ſayde true caeſar gréeued came ſcate ſtoode nexte tribune prayſed rebuked woulde agree wyth ſayde ſufficiente alone defende ſo iuſt cauſe nexte daye ſéene coulde bée knowen become ofilius ſcene agayne souldyoures one feare altogither requyred diſmiſſed caeſar ſpake feare coulde theyr captaynes diſcharged ſerued philippi modena moſt olde souldyoures commaunded depart ile leaſt ſhould corrupt reſt thus much ſayd diſcharged thought • diſcharged themsouldyoures diſmiſſed nowe yet woulde reward speaking hée made wytneſſe periurie departed diſcharged leaue theyr generall prayſed th •• promiſed diſmiſſe ſhortly ſhould repente duetie done nowe woulde giue euery fyue hundred drammes ſette • ſhe vpon sicelie fiftéene hundred talentes appoynted lieutenant sicelie barbarie diuided hys army antonyes shippe • ſent • drent reſt hys army ſent partlie italy partly tooke wyth hym wente ile commyng towarde rome senate receyued hym wyth kynde honor permytting himſelfe receyuehonoured offered caeſar rome whyche would eyther ſome pleaſure mette farrè wyth garlandes well senate people whome firſt brought temple hys houſe daye following made oration senate people declared hys doyngs order adminiſtration caeſar declareth actes senate people caeſars oration published common wealth hys beginning thys day whiche oration written hymſelfe publiſhed wyth many example pronounced peace tranquilitie ſo long ciuill warres tribute vnpayd • hée forgaue lykewyſe gatherer tolles ſynes office honor senate accepted chariot theatre yearely ſolemnities dayes hys victoriesmodeſtic caeſar image golde common place wyth thys inſcription peace gotten ſo many warres lande sea refuſed chiefe byſhopſhippe peopleinſcription peace offered hym whyche auntiente cuſtome vſed taken man aliue lepidus woulde haue hadde hym kylled lepidus enimie denyed wrote manye letter armyes wyth commaundemente bée opened daye appoynted doe commaunded whyche reſtore bondman rome italy maiſters heyres fréedome giuen requeſt pompey whichebondmen reſtored maiſters returned old ſtate like sicelie vnchalenged put deathe citie whence came ſéemed end ciuill warre caeſar caeſar honoured god xxviii yeare age robbery citie eyght twenty yeares age conſecrated god citie sicelie troubled much wyth robber rouers ſuch boldneſſe openly committed lewdeneſſe correct theſe sabinus ſent put manye tosab •• u ſword rich temple iune thence went mitylene father lefte mother made warre caeſar bycauſe antony gone parthian warre intended yéeld returne reported antony ouercome beléeued hée conceiued hope ſuccéede prouinces leaſt part taking example labienus ranne ouer aſia occupyed theſe cogitation heard antony come alexandria prepared himſelfe courſes wrote antony friend fellow meaning pompey vſeth double deuice eſpie doings ſecretely ſente embaſſadours prince thracia pontus minding paſſe armenia obteyne purpoſe wrote alſo parthian hoping would take hym captayne warre béeyng romane againſte antony theyr romane aduerſary prepared shyppes souldyoures ſame pretending afrayde caeſar prepare antonyes vſe antony hearde hys purpoſes hée ſente 〈…〉 ſent againſt pompey antony titius chiefe captayne agaynſte hym receyuing armie nauie syria hée ſhoulde reſiſte pompey hys power rather receyue antony truſte hée ſhoulde bryng honorably embaſſadours pompey made requeſt wée ſent thée pompey hée coulde admitted spaine prouince oweth good pompeis embaſſadours anotonie father ſake liſted make warre whiche holpe hym younger offereth theyr ayde bycauſe hée rather enioy peace thée vnder thy banner make warre néede new intent ruled sicilie inuaded italie ſaued ſente thée home thy mother deſired thy friendſhip whiche thou haddeſt accepted neyther bene driuen sicilie whereto thou diddeſt lende thy ſhippes thou bene ouercome parthia caeſar ſending thée ſuch army promiſed yea thou mighteſt haue brought italie vnder thy power although refuſed time deſireth thée illuded deceyued ſo many fayre wordes affinitie remembryng pompey alſo promiſe contrarie iniuſtly inuaded caeſar ſpoyled portion whereof parte hath redoū ded thée thou onely arte lette hath monarchie hath long thirſted bin war popey bene thou oughteſt foreſée theſe thing thy ſelfe ſo good hée beareth thée rather haue amitio playne liberall man ſubtill crafty fellow pompey angry thou lenteſt ſhippes agaynſt beyng conſtrayned thou mighteſt haue men putteth thée remēbrance much y• army ſent thée hinder thée ſhorte pompey committeth himſelfe thée ſhippes truſty army whiche haue forſaken hym though fledde thou ſhalt purchaſe great prayſe beyng peace thou wilt preſerue sonne pompey great warre broken whiche feared thou mayſt haue confederate ſuch might eſtimation antonie hearde ſayde antonie pompeis embaſſadours pompey meaneth good faith haue giuen commiſſion titius bryng meake 〈…〉 pompe •• meſſengers ſente parthian taken antony officer 〈…〉 meſſengers taken brought alexandria whome antonie learned thyngs ſente propontide comming fielde encamping nigh came lxx ſhippes sicelie ſpryng leſte antonie lent caeſar titius came syria hundred twentie ſhippes greate army arriued proconneſco pompey afrayde burned ſhippes armed mariner hauing truſt lande caſsius parma naſidius saturninus therinus antistius honorable friendes pompey furnius moſte pompey frendes yeelde antonie déere vnto lib • himſelf father lawe ſaw pompey alwayes weake yéelded themſelues antonie thus forſaken went y• midland bythinia entending go arm • nia furnius tituis folowed ſecrete departed tent great iourney ouertooke night ſeuerally encamped aboute hill without ditche trenche beyng late weary pompey aſſayleth eninues night night pompey ſet vpon thrée thouſande men ſléeping put flée naked ſhamefully hée aſſayled whole power folowed pompey loſeth occaſion brokē gotten perfect victory fortune would ſuffer got nothing thereby went iourney recouering horſes folowed kepte victuall ſo beyng dryuen ſpeache hée deſired ſpeake furnius ſome tyme •• fréende hys father man greate dignitie ſt • ndyng banke riuer hée ſayde hée ſente embaſſadours antonie pompey deſireth ſpeach vvith furnius meane ſeaſon wantyng victualles dyd hée done make warre vpon mée 〈…〉 y commaundeme ſeeth wel himſelf receyuing greater warre hang ouer hym vpon owne authoritie pray beſéeche would ceaſie till embaſſadours returne carie ſafely furni committe ſelfe ſo promiſe deliuer ſafe antonie thus much hée ſayde hopyng antonie gentle man ſéekyng paſſe iourney quietly furnius thus anſweared thou wouldeſt haue cō mittedfurnius pompey thy ſelfe antonie thou ſhouldeſt haue done firſt beyng quiet haue looked anſweare •• yiene makyng warre thou haſte brought thy ſelfe caſe thou repenteſt thée blame v antonie hath appoynted titius receyue thée hym therefore committe thy ſelfe thou mayſt require thou requireſt mée commaunded thou playeſt parte enimie kill thée bryng thée honorably vnto pompey offended ti • • vnthankfull bycauſe hée pompey hateth ti ••• made warre agaynſt hym whome tooke ſaued hym therefore pompey grieued come handes méane man whoſe fidelitie ſuſpected eyther behauiour former iniurie hée done pleaſure wherefore agayne yéelded furnius deſired taken graunted pompey yeldeth furnius vvho vvoulde take ſuffer amyntas deſired amyntas • ight take whē furnius ſayde ſhould bycauſe wrong commiſſion antonie ſo brake furnius soldiours forſaken ſides hée pompey yeldeth amyntas vvithout condition yéelded amyntas without condition refuſing ti •••• condition thus yonger 〈◊〉 great pompey taken▪ loſing father yong brother whenthe conn • ing vp pompey toward mane eſtate two taken away lay cloſe great whye vexed spayne wyth priuie robbery tyll hadde good reſcet profeſſed hymſelfe pompey ſonne •• made open rodes iulius caeſar ſlayne moued playne warre béeyng ayded wyth greate multitude force ſuddayne gayning shippes publike treaſure • ppreſſed italy wyth famine broughte hys enimies condition woulde moſt wicked condemnation executed rome ſauedthe good acte • pompey manye noble men enioyed theyr countrey benefyte fortune fauouring hym woulde neuernegligence v • • pompey take aduantage hys enimie neglecting manye occaſions would lye ſtill thys bondage titius commaunded hys army ſweare antony put titius putteth pompey death mil • citie endes ionia caria hym death mileto hadde lyued age fortye yeares eyther remembred late diſpleaſure forgot olde good rurnes ſuch commaundemente antony bée ſaye plancus antony dyd commaundeplancus hym dye whyche héeyng preſident syria antonyes ſignet greate cauſes wrote letter hys name thynke done wyth antonyes knowledge fearyng name pompey cleopatra fauoured pompey great thynke plancus dyd hymſelfe theſe cauſes alſo pompey ſhoulde gyue cauſe diſſention betwéene caeſar antony cleopatra woulde turne hy • auour pompey hée diſpatched antony tooke hys iourney intothe illyrian • novv 〈…〉 con • nuall enimies romanes armenia caeſar agaynſte slauonians continuall enimyes romanes ſame honour humble ſeruaunt h b continuation appian alexandrîa till ouerthrow antonius vvhiche vvas laſte ciuill diſſention whiche octauius caeſar rule romane empire alone octauius caeſar antonius agréed sextus yonger ſonne pompey▪ great▪ determined antonius ſhold make warre vpon parthian reuenge death craſſus wherefore preſently ſent ventidius repreſſe parthian gratifie octauius content marie ſiſter antonie marieth octauia made holy miniſter iulius caeſar dead remayning rome ruling common conſent octauius caeſar well matter cittie whole empire befalleth betwéene ſuch prince make paſtimes play match antonie alwayes worſe antony fortune▪ ouercome▪ caeſars whiche ſomewhat moued company aegiptian ye maner soothſayer eyther pleaſe cleopatra ſhew truth tolde antonie hys fortune obſeured fortune octauius therefore hée aduiſed go furder ſayth whē thou art abrode thy nature noble coragious thou art deiect afrayde antonie whether motion owne inclination content leaue octauius go towarde olde loue aegipt yet carying new wife graecia pretending earneſt deſire reuenge iniurie done craſſus ſorte craſſus pompey caeſar ſuters conſulſhip craſſus pompey caeſar rome agaynſt ſtoode cicero cato craſſus pompey choſen continued caeſars authoritie france fiue yeares longer deſired caſtyng lotte prouinces spayne fell pompey whereof glad beyng giuen pleaſe wife people gladde beyng deſirous haue pompey nigh citie syria fell craſſus whereof craſſus goeth vvarre agaynſt order onely gladde ſory perceyued hée wholy giuen ſpoyle countrie parthia whiche comprehended law prouinces wherfore atteius tribune people forbad craſſus inuade parthia animated caeſars letter fraunce pempeys preſence rome wente forwarde notwithſtandyng tribune gate citie ſtande fire sacrifice coniuryng name moſte ſtraunge ſearefull goddes procéede kinde execrationexecration romanes thinke moſte horrible bothe doth pronounce againſt pronounced craſſus paſion ſeas loſt many ſhippes ſayling due time gotten ſome city accorde wonne one force woulde néedes called imperator mocked bicauſe name notimperator giuen romanes plaine batayle ouerthrowne x ſpending one winter like rent gatherer without exerciſe ſoldiours ſpoyling temple hierapoli • holy citie aſ •• ful maruelous thing hierapoli entry ſonne fell one vpon offred help king armenia would make iourney thorough countrie better way refuſed went raſhly meſopotamia paſſage ouer bridge had▪ made thundred lightned face blew downe parte bridge come ouer campe twice ſet fyre lightning theſe many token might haue moued went forthtokens till ſonne xx romanes ſlaine x taken al deſpite done could deuiſed vpon antonie goeth againſt par ••• an reuēge craſſus antonie better li •• tenant himſelfe ventidius occaſiō antonie leade army againſt y• parthian leiftenāt ventidius gaue great ouerthrow while athens wherfore made great feaſtings among graecians ready go forth ware garland holy oliue fulfill oracle caried veſſel water meane time ventidius gaue ouerthrow y• whiche pacorus y• king ſonne ſlaine although ſeemed ſufficiēt reuenge craſſus death yet gaue thē thirde euerthrow betwéene medium meſopotamia ventidius thought good ſtay leaſt antonie ſhould enuie ſubdued y• reuolted beſieged cōmagenus antiochus samoſatis samoſatis▪ citie vvhere lage▪ maruelous nature antonie refuſeth good offer promiſed giue thouſand talent obey meate ſome ſay twoo lo • gyng apparell kyng ſent moneſes reſtored antonie content offered hym peace ſo hée would •• nder enſignes captiues taken loſſe craſſus tooke iourney arabia armenia increaſed caſt terrorvaine▪ lo •• euen indian vaine loue cleopatra brought none effect deſire come againe hir companie made al thing time order lefte laſte wife octauia hyr child chyldren héeocta ••• ▪ firſt wyfe fuluia octauius caeſar beyng eaſte partes wholy gyuen wanton deſire cleopatra whome hée gaue prouinces cypre caeloſyria cleopatra phaenitia parte cilicia iurie wherewith romanes antonie killeth king iurie vanitie antonie muche gréeued alſo crueltie antigonus kyng iurie vanitie chyldren hée cleopatra callyng one alexander sunne cleopatra moone yet cleopatra fayreſt woman worlde wittie ſull artificiall deuiſes caſte beguyle antonie eaſie ledde haſte hée woulde ſuffer hys armie reſte ſo long iourney haſte hée lefte engine behinde whereof one called ramme foure ſcore foote long haſte héehaſte maketh vvaſte lefte medium paſſyng lefte hande armenia atropatia whiche hée ſpoyled hée beſieged great citie atropatia one part medium phraata hée founde hys errour leauyng hys artillerie behinde therefore cauſe hys men ſomewhat made caſte vp mountes meane tune king 〈◊〉 forth mighty army hearing artillerie left behind ſent great parte horſe men ſlew tatianus ten thouſand left cuſtody enginesthe artillerie romanes taken tooke ſpilled munitiō much diſcourage soldiours cauſed kyng armenia ſoke whoſe cauſe made warre parthian bragge vpon romanes wherefore antonie tooke ten legion horſemen range countrie thereby prouoke enimie fight whē gone one dayes iourney ſaw enimies round aboute therefore campe determined fight yet would ſo ſéeme rayſed campe goe away commaundyng foote men hande horſemenne ſhoulde ſette vppon enimie whiche ſtoode triangle battayle beholde romanes good order ſhakyng dartes tyme ſerued horſemen gaue ſo fierce onſette vppon tooke away vſe theyr ſhotte notwithſtandyng ſtucke foot • men came ſhoute fearefull ſhew parthian horſemen diſordered turned backes antony thinking make ende warre daye gaue chaſe yet tooke xxx kyl • ed lxxx whiche agayne much diſcourage romanes ſince loſt ſo many 〈…〉 ſmall victory cariage wanne ſo little victory next day antony returned camp way firſt mette enimies afterwards laſt ſo much moleſted much adoe got tentes enimie • ſaulted trench diuers feare forſake wherefore antony puniſhed euery tenth man fedde reſt wythpunishment fedde vvith barly vvas punishment among souldyoures barley warre gréeuous antony could goe foraging without great loſſe kyng feared men ſhoulde lye fielde winter would forſake wherefore deuiſed policie noble men parthian ſuffered romanes carrie awayecraſt parthian prayes great commendation worthineſſe king woulde glad peace ſo riding néerer army would rebuke antony kéeping ſo ſtrange countrey whiche though parthian theyr friend ſhoulde harde eſcape antony hearde cauſed enquired whether theſe men dyd ſpeake king conſent aunſwered ſente king woulde reſtore captiues enſignes would depart king ſayd would ſende would depart quickly therefore antony made vp retired going away ſpeake souldyoures wont doe elaquente way whereat many offended committing matter done antony omitteth generalles part mardus domitius aenobarbus way one mardus well acquainted parthian maners whoſe faith romanes proued tolde antony beſt goe ſo hée might haue hilles right hande hazarde hys army laden armour parthian archer horſemen playne way antony conſulted counſell pretending yet afrayde breache peace accepting counſell compendious antony required ſuretie mardw bind till came armenia béeyng bound brought two dayes quietly third day antony loked nothing leſſe parthian vpon romanes parthian mardus eſpyed banke riuer bée broken downe water flowing abroade coniectured done enimie hynder paſſage antony therefore wiſhed antony loke faire antony ſette men order parthian came vppon whome receyued ſhotte muche hurte done ſides till french horſemen brake vpon put day antony taughte hereby went ſquare battel fencing ſame thoroughly ſhotte horſemen commaunded gyue repulſe enimie done cha • e farre parthian trouble romanes parthian theſe foure dayes receyued much hurt done minded retire bycauſe winter hand fifth daye fuluius gallus valiant man deſired antony fuluius gallus taketh euill enterpriſe haue greater bande ſhotte horſemen would ſome notable feate receyued put backe enimie returning armie againe purſuing along without feare whiche leader rerewarde ſée called backe hée would obey whereas titius tooke banner turnetitius backe put forward againe badde hym meddle hys owne matter wente ſo farre compaſſed hys enimies compelled ſende helpe wherein canidius canidius greate credite wyth antony dyd well hée ſente fewe ſoone put backe vtterly hadde bin loſt hadde antony come wyth hys legion time abated courage enimie notwithſtandyng romanes ſlayne thrée thouſande romanes ſlayne fyue thouſande hurte gallus wounded foure dartes dyed antony antony vveepeth went wéeping comforting deſired content well well great lone bare ſouldyoures vnto compted one beſt captaynes time enimies ſo encouraged victory wayted camp night thinking romanes would haue bin gone morning number much encreaſed king ſent horſemens gard perſon came fight himſelfe ſo nowe fortie thouſand horſemen antony woulde haue gone among souldyoures blacke gowne friend woulde antony lamenteth ſuffer ſo went generall like prayſed hadde done well rebuked done otherwiſe prayed pardon puniſh euery tenth man deſired leaue ſorrow held hand vp heauen ſaying anye diſdeyne god remained hys antonyes prayer former fortune deſired might fall vpon ſo romanes army might ſaued haue victory next day went warily contrary theyr looking parthian came • rolling downe hill thinking haue gotten pray haue founde warre romanes policie romanes tooke archer ſuch middeſt battell cauſing thē knéele ſtouping couered ſhields vppon parthian arrowes ſlided parthian thinking romanes ſtouped wéerineſſe made ſhoute came vpon ſtaues whiche time romanes roſe ſo encountred parthian repulſed droue away thus troubled dyuers dayes made little way nowe wante campe coulde gettevvant romanes camp corne cattell ſpente partly loſſe partlye carrying wounded ſicke men barly lofe wasbarly bread hearbes venemous fren • ye camp ſolde waighte ſiluer eate ſtrange hearbes rootes ſome brought preſent death kinde madneſſe coulde nothing elſe roll ſtones ſo campe almoſt occupyed picking turning ſtones remedye thys wyne whyche wanted hoſtvvine therefore hadde vomited melancolie dyed manye thus dying parthian ſtyll commyng vpon antony oftentimes cryed oh tenne thouſande meaning tenne thouſand greekes vnder leading xenophon paſſed ſafe farre longer way deſpight enimiesthe 〈◊〉 xenophon nowe parthian perceyued could preuayle againſte romanes breake order alwayes put backe began deale gently againe wyth forragiers ſhewing ſtrings bowes vnbente make ende onely fewe median ſhoulde followe tayle kéepe townes ſpoyling theſe wordes made romanes glad antony minded goe champion way leaue hil • e entred way one mithridates antony vvarned couſin moneſis fledde antony came vnto required ſpeake one coulde parthian tong whome alexander antioch friende antonyes appoynted tolde moneſis good antony ſent ſhew vnder hilles ſaw nexte vnto playne way ioyne parthian lay ſecrete beguile againe faire word therfore woulde ſaue himſelfe hoſt ſhoulde leaue way hilles déede ſhoulde finde laboure thirſt way ſhould eſcape craſſus miſfortune ſaide went way antony communicated wyth friendes mardus affirmed moſt lyke truth therefore ſayd beſt go hils though paynefull ſhoulde lacke water one daye nowe antony toke way commaunded euery man carrie muche water coulde lacke veſſels andvvater moſt part carryed ſallets parthian ſpies told whiche way antony went contrary theyr manner came vpon night breake day ſet vpon rereward wéeryed labour watching compelled march reſiſt enimie foreward come floud whiche cléere ſalt whosalt vvater ſoeuer dranke full payne mardus gaue warning souldyoures would ruled antony ranne aboute praying refraine paſſe little floud healthſome water ſo choſe way parthian could follow cauſe souldyoures haue ſome ſhadow blew retreat pitched tent done parthian going backe wonte mithridates came agayne ſpake withmithridates alexander telling hym souldyoures reſted ſhould remoue paſſe ouer next floud ſo farre enimie would followe antony heard tooke many cuppes gold alexander giue mithridates antonyes giftes many could carrie away antony departed hadde much ado enimies followed ſo hard ſacked hys antonyes treaſure ſpoyled carriage tooke table plate golde many hadde anye thyng kylled ſpoyled whereby thought armye diſordered ſcattered ſo much antony called one chamber hym wylled commaunded hym kyll hym ſhoulde vppon antony dread hys oth take away head mighte knowen dead antony ſorrowe mardus dyd comfort affirming floud hande whiche hée knew coldneſſe aire felte antony cold ayre • oke • vvater bring quiet commaunded campe euen breake daye parthian againe charged vppon tayle defence whome ſhotte ſent battell defended ſhieldes parthian durſt come handſtrokes ſo time foreward come floud • uer antony ſent firſt hurt ſicke ſouldioures appoynted horſemen encounter enimie whiche meane wente ouer might haue leyſure drinke parthian ſawe floude vnbente theyr bowes ſayde romanes myghte nowe drinke leyſure ſo deſerued theyr vertue romanes béeyng paſt floud marche order yet truſting parthian ſifth daye theyr laſt fyghte came floude araxes diuideth medium armenia bycauſe thys araxes diuideth armenia atropatia floud harde paſſe agayne afrayd 〈◊〉 theyr enimies • ayne awayte paſſing quietly ſoone came lande reioyced ſ •• sea embraced one another weeping ioy followed another inconuenience countrey plentifull souioyoures taking muche fell many diſeaſes 〈◊〉 dyed antony muſtered men finding wantedlo ••• 〈◊〉 twenty thouſand foot • men foure thouſand horſemen halfe dyed diſeaſes • e citie phra • ti b •• comming ſeauen twenty dayes whiche hadde fought eyghtéene time parthian whome coulde haue perfite victory bycauſe king armenia forſooke whoſe army hadde bin moſt expert haue dealte parthian wherefore euery man counſelled antony reuenged king antony vſing policy ſhewed courteſies men countrey ſent ſo fayre meſſages king came vnto whome co ••• itted carryed alexandri • triumphed ouer hym antony taketh king ar • ••• • fl • ght ant •• yes triu • p • diſpleaſant romanes 〈◊〉 thing gréeued romanes antony woulde defraude countrey pleaſe concubine winter ſo greate loſt eyghte thouſande coulde come caſtell called leuce great agonyes till cleopatra come like fooliſhe yong mā gaue himſelfe wantonnes riot running table ſea ſide euery antonyes • ond •• ſſ • day ſée ſhe come ſhe came ſhe brought muche apparell money gyue soul • youres ſay antony toke hir▪ gyue romanes variance fallen betwéene king parthia medium ſpoyle romanes goodes median king ſent antony come agayne woulde ioyne wyth antony c • lled med ••• agayne power great antony little glad héereof bycauſe helpe median mighte bée meane hym conquer parthia ſo intended make new • urney rome oct • uia deſ • red goe hir huſbād antony c • ſar content ſo muche pleaſure ſiſter take occaſion c octauia 〈◊〉 newe voyage ſmelling matter wrote vnto know whether ſhe ſhould ſend thing whiche ſhe brought ſaye many coates souldyoures great plenty cattell money reward captaines two thouſande freſhe souldyoures gard perſon well ſet hym niger meſſengerniger cleopatra heard fearing octauia came ſhe would put hir conceyt ſhe beſtirred hir ſhe pined hirſelfecraft cleopatra ſhe wepte wayled woulde néedes dye antonyes ſake ſayd would take iourney hand blamed antony rude hard harted h • e would put ſo louing lady ſo great quéene danger hir life eyther wiues ſake anye cauſe ſo muche antony made tame foole deferred vnto antony doteth next ſommer expedition returned alexandria winter cleopatra octauia returned rome hir brotheroctauia willed hir goe hir owne houſe ſhe went antonyes houſe ſhe kept ſo good order cheriſhing well child fuluia hir ſelfe aggrauate fault antony woulde forſake ſo vertuous amodeſtie octauia romane lady egiptian ſtrāger octauia deſired hir brother none cauſe warre hir would moue ſhe ſhould beare blame therefore •• requeſts ſhe help antonyes friend whereby vnwillingly ſhe hindered antony nowe ſo fonde waxen hée woulde haue cleopatra called name goddeſſe iſis antonyes fo • lishneſſe iſis caeſarion quéene aegypt cyprus affr • ke caeloſiria caeſarion whome thought ſhe hadde iulius caeſar hir companion theſe kingdomes ſonnes hadde hir called king king aduiſe ſhould ſend cleopatra away fledde caeſar bycauſe cleopatra began maligne bewray antony teſtament priuie kept antony teſtamēt bevvrayed▪ uirgines ueſtalles whome caeſar ſente haue would deliuer put ſtrength nauie hee vnderſtoode captaines nauie found fault lacke good ſeamen ſupplied want roges cariers harueſt men laborer waſted graecia yet nauie furniſhed many ſhippes voyde vnable fight fighte pharſall fielde caeſar fought with▪ pompey caeſar while antonie lay anchor actio actio whiche nicopoli paſſed ſea get towne epirus whiche called toryne antonie beyng afeard enimietoryne ſhould
