concerning domitio contrary cleopatra opimō ſicke tooke litle boate fled caeſar yt although gréeued antonie notwithſtanding ſent goodes ſeruants bicauſe openly knowē fled ſo grieued died king amintas deiotaras went caeſar alſo bycauſe antony nauie ſufficient cōpelled looke truſt army land canidius yt general footemē perſuaded wiſecanidius ſend cleopatra home go thracia macedonia try ye mater lād dicomes king getes redy help great nūbers yt ſhold ſhame refuſe y• fight ſea bicauſe caeſar y• practiſe reaſō ye sicilian war ſhould great blame vnto vſe force lande wherein moſte experte ſuffer ſame antonie heareth good counſell abuſed ſea cleopatra vrged fight ſea although ſhe deſpayred victorie ſecretely prouided meanes antonie danger flée away time antonie ſome daunger certaine narow ſpace grounde betwéene nauie ouer whiche maner paſſe without feare whiche caeſar aduertiſed layde wayte whiche little quicke tooke came antonie hardely eſcaped ranne away determined fight ſea burned vnprofitable veſſels kepte gallies beſt ſorte whiche put twentie thouſand footemen two thouſand archer certayne captayne bene good ſeruitoura good requeſt old capitayne graunted expert soldiour till caeſar might bée pacified many ſhippes burden ſome frendes come fight declaryng nauy loſte thought army lande ſafe wherefore wrote canidius make haſte macedonia bryng armie aſia caſe antonie notsoldiours good opinion antonie proued chaunce warre full many tyme souldiours thought ſtill hée woulde come among ſo muche caeſar ſente meſſengers reiected ſo continued ſeuen dayes capitayne canidius antony footemen yeldeth ſtolne away night left comfortleſſe yéelded conquerour ſayled vnto athens makyng vnitie gretians diſtributed corne among afflicted kynde exaction ſeruitude antonie might bée ſafe inuaſion bycauſe firſt ſhippes came euill lucke antonie hoped hys footemenne ſafe actio hée cauſod hyr leaue • enſed mouthes floudde nilus beyng done antonie antonie folovveth trade timon buylded houſe sea lanterne ramped aboute ſeparating himſelfe company men affirmyng hée woulde folowe trade timon ſurnamed hater men forſaken fréendes deceyued ſuche menne brought aduauncement hée tooke ingratitude ſo harte hée woulde refuſe men ſocietie euen timon dyd citizen athens called houſe timons tabernacle timons tabernacle firſte brought hym newes loſſe hys footemen actio canidius hymſelfe ſhortly waseuill nevves one tolde hym herode iewe gone caeſar certayne legion prynces dyd lyke none theſe thyngs dyd moue beyng well wyllyng leaue bothe hope care contented hymſelfe timons tabernacle beyng otherwiſe perſwaded cleopatra came courte alexandrîa gaue hymſelfe feaſting banquettyng ſo alexandrian dyd nothyng elſe antony renueth riot great whyle make good cheere maner cleopatra camp returned court tooke cleopatra armes kiſſed hir recommended vnto hir fought beſt ſhe gaue head péece coate armour golde yet night fledde caeſar antony challenged caeſar againe fight hande hand caeſar aunſwered many wayes antony dye ſeing way ſo honourable dye fight antony determined ſet vpon caeſar sea land ſupper bad mē drinke make merry coulde tell ſhould antony cheereth men ſo ſerue lord himſelf ſhuld liue whē wept word ſayd would leade thē fight ye might rather hope glorious death thā ſure triumphāt victorie midnight wasa noyſe citie night ſvveete muſicke heard ouer al ye citie ſuch pleaſant noyſe muſicke went vſed yt ſacrifice bacchus wēt forth y• citie enimies camp expounded god moſt ſerued alſo forſake ye morning brought forth footemen placed thē vpō hilles citie ſtood ſée yt ſucceſſe nauie comming nigh yt enimie ſaluted thē friend like antonyes ship forſake ſo yéelded thē perceyued antonyes horſemē fled caeſar alſo footemen fight ouercomehis horſemen forſake done retired ye citie cry betrayd cleopatra thē againſt whome made war hir ſake antony complayneth cleopatra cleopatra ſleeth antony meſſage cleopatra afrayd furie got hir hir scpulchre cauſing bridge drawne kept cloſe ſhut done ſhe ſent one tell ſhe dead whē heard ſayd tēpteſt thou antony thē wēt chāber vnharneſſed ſaying cleopatra tormented without thée wil ſoone thée antonyes greefe ſo great captayne ſhould preuēted thée y• art womā ſuch caſe fortitude hero faithful ſeruāt ſworne kill whē ſhould commaund ſaith time thée toke ſword turned face killed himſelf fell dead hero antonyes man killeth himſelfe antonyes féete ah good eros quoth antony thou couldeſt abide doe thou haſt taught ſelfe ſo thruſt ſword belly layd downe vppon antony thruſteth ſvvord himſelfe bed ſtroke ſo great could diſpatch hym fore commaunded make end went chamber leauing cry lamenting til diomedes came cleopatra bring antony todiomedes hir hearing ſhe aliue commanded caried hir antony caried halfe dead sepulchre armes y• dore monument cleopatra would open lot downe ſhéetes line heaue vp whyche ſhe hir two woman onely hir pitifull ſight ſée bloudy yéelding ghoſta pitifull ſight halled vp ſo hardly holding forth hand ſtretchyng himſelfe toward hir well could pore womē hauing ſtrēgth ynough till cleopatra hir hāds bē ding downeward much might got vp yt cry vpon hir haue pitie vpō whē ſhe ſhe layde vpō bed lamenting tearing hir mourning wéede wiping bloud frō face called lord huſband emperour forgetting hir owne ſorow cōpaſſion ſomewhat cōforted deſired cuppe wine eyther thirſt yt might ſooner diſpatched whē vvords antony death dronke wiſhed hir prouide hir ſelfe ſo wel ſhe could hir honor ſaued among caeſars friēds truſt proculeius moſt ſhe ſhuld afflict hirſelfe thisproculeius great alteratiō rather comfort hirſelfe yt ſhe dealt yt moſt mighty ful power romane thorough cowardiſe ouercome romane ſaid yelded antony dyeth ye ghoſt whē proculeius come frō caeſar whē antony ſtrickē himſelfe drawē cleopatra derceteus onederceteus gard toke bloudy ſword caried caeſar telling caeſar vveepeth antony ſtood whē heard went cloſet wept antonyes chance bin valiāt mā cōpanion many battels red letter friendes declaring proudely arrogātly anſwered gentle letter cōmanded proculeius yt could get cleopatra aliue feared deſtructiō hir treaſure thought would ſmal honor might bring hir triūph wold talke wt proculeius wtin far ſo hardly hir voyce could heard hir requeſt hir kingdome might eſtabliſhedrequeſt cleopatra hir child proculeius bad hir good chéere remit al caeſar marking ye place ſent word caeſar ſent gallus togallus talke hir purpoſe prolōged cōmunication till proculcius hauing got ſcalling ladder two got y• window antony taken went ſtreight ye place proculeius getteth ſecret scpulcre cleopatra wher ſhe talking wt gallus thē one ye womē cryed vnhappy cleopatra thou art takē aliue thē ſhe would haue ſtrickē hirſelfe ſhe ware dagger proculeus ranne quickly proculeus ſtayeth cleopatra •• om •• lling hirſelfe embraced hir hand ſaying cleopatra doe iniurie ſelfe caeſar taking acte clemencie caſting infamie vnfaithfulneſſe tooke dagger hir cut hir garment ſhe ſhoulde haue poyſon hir caeſar ſent freemade man epaphroditus commaundement ſhoulde epaphroditus care caeſar keepe cleopatra aliue anye feare willed riſe ſaying forgat firſte alexander fame caeſars mercy alexā •• ne builded citie beautie thirdly arrius ſake body antony caeſar contente ſhe ſhoulde burie ſhe hir owne hand labour whereof cleopatra buryeth antonyes body princely cleopatra kept killing hir ſelfe hunger getting agew ſhe glad ſhe hadde ſuche cloke refrayne meate kill hirſelfe hunger whiche perceyued caeſar threatned hir loſſe hir child ſhe contente reléeued againe fewe dayes caeſar came ſée hir comforte hir lying homely hir night gowne lept bedde fell downe caeſar commeth cleopatra caeſars feete trembling voyce heauie chéere hir body deformed hir owne ſtripes whereof printes ſéene hir eye ſonke hir couloure ſwart yet dyd hir behauiour declare hir grace extinct whiche dyd appeare forepined waſted corpſe caeſar willed hir ſit ſate hir ſhe making excuſes ſhe done al feare antony whiche caeſar reproued ſhe cleopatra ſubmit▪ caeſar gaue hir wholly mercy toke note ſuche treaſure ſhe one hir treaſurers seleucus corrected ſhe hidde ſomewhat ſhe lepte vnto knocked aboute pate whereat caeſar ſmylingshe beateth one hir ſeruants blaming hir caeſar ſayd ſhe gréefe ſéeing thou doeſt diſdeyne viſit wofull eſtate accuſed ſeruants kéeping fewe woman thyngs wherewith would winne thy wife liuia thy ſiſter octauia make thée fauourable caeſar glad theſe word thinking ſhe deſire liue granted hir al beyond hope thinking hadde deceyued hir ſhe caeſar granteth thing cleopatra deceyued cornelius dolabella noble yōg mā caeſars camp great deſire cleopatra caeſar gaue leaue come tell hir would go home lād syria dolabella ſent cleopatra ſhe hir child ſhould ſent italy ſhippe ſhe vnderſtoode ſhe deſired caeſar ſhe mighte firſte celebrate antonyes funerall wherwith content came graue hir woman ſayde late noble antony burie cleopatra celebrateth antonyes funerall thée frée honor thy buriall captiue garded ſhould conſume wretched body much lamenting thée whiche reſerued ſhewed triumph thée honour hand thou ſhalt looke ready caried away thée nothing ſeparate v lyuingvvords cleopatra death muſt parted thou romane muſt lye héere vnhappy egiptian italy ſo farforth partaker thy countrey god thyng oure god haue deceyued v héere forſake thy wife aliue neyther ſuffer triumph made thée burie cloſe héere thée infinite gréefes none ſo great ſhorte time haue lyued without thée ſhe ended theſe lament put garland kiſſed graue ſhe commaunded bath made readye hir ſhe waſhed ſhe wente meate greate chéere cheſt brought countrie hir man gard aſking toke away leaues cleopatra deceyueth caeſar ſhewed figges maruelling forme greatneſſe man ſmiled deſired take thēthe gard deceyued ſuſpecting nothing bad carrie ſhe ſent caeſar hir writing ſealed remoued hir two woman ſhe ſhut dores hir letter come caeſar redde founde hir onely requeſt hée cleopatra laſt requeſt caeſar greate petition buryed antony whiche hée ſaw ſuſpected mynded haue gone ſtreight thither hymſelfe yet firſt ſent ſée done ſhe diſpatched ſuddaynely ranne thither founde alteration gard opened dores found hir dead lying bedde gold moſt royally cleopatra foūd dead vpon ded gold hit tvvo vvomen • ir one hir woman called iris lay dead hir féete whoſe name charmium ready fall downe dead trimming crowne vpon hir head cryed well done charmium yea weli quoth one deſcended ſo many progenitours king ſhe ſaid thus much ſhe fell downe dead bed ſide ſay serpente called aſpis brought among figges couered wyth aſpis brought amōg figges ſting hir death leaues whiche ſting hir death whoſe nature giue heauineſſe ſléepe without ſhrinking marke ſkinne onely putting forth gentle ſweat face ane trance hard wakened ſaye two little ſpots hir arme whiche caeſar eyther • eléeued elſe would ſo haue beléeued hir image yt brought triumph rome ſet forth serpent two markes hir arme howſoeuer caeſar • ory ſo chanced yet highly commend hir noble mind cauſed hir royally layd antony hir woman nobly buryed alſo cleopatra xxxix yeares age hadde raigned xxij whereof xiiij antony liued liij yeares age antony cleopatra moſt lvj antonyes image throwen downe cleopatra remoued archibius hir friend obteyned caeſar thouſand talent antony ſeauen childrē thrée antonyes child wiues whereof attilus eldeſt killed caeſar reſt octauia brought vp hirs attilus betrayed hys scholemaiſter theoderus tooke goodly iewell hys necke killed required denyed cauſed hanged ceſarione cleopatra firſt caeſar beyng alſo betrayed ſcholemaſter whō ſhe ſent great caeſar beſto •• eth cleopatra child treaſure india ſlayne ſhe dead hir doughter called cleopatra hir name maried flouriſhing king iuba promoted antonie ſonne fuluia ſo high favour next agrippa liutas child chief shéehe vſeth one antony ſonnes great fauour marcellus two daughter one ſonne named marcellus caeſar adopt made ſonne law daughter giuen agrippa marcellus dying ſhortly mariage octauia deſired agrippa mighte marrie hyschaunge mariage daughter antonie hyrs hir daughter beſtowed vpon domitius aenobarba druſus liuias ſonne ſteppechilde caeſar came germanicus claudius germanicus diedemperours antony iſſue claudius emperoure germanicus came caius emperour alſo agryppinae e domitio aenobarba marrie claudius emperour adopted domitius calling nero germanicus emperour thus antony race diuerſe emperours iſſued albeit himſelfe lamentable end haue hearde cauſe romane ſtate reſtored common wealth agayne anthony cauſe alteration romane eſtate noble brutus proteſted died al whoſe execration came vpon antonie died eyther god woulde plague antony euill life would chaunge ſtate mighty cōmon wealth whiche worlde ſuche becke might doe woulde whoſe outragious dealing wel foreine ciuill murder pleaſed god puniſh ſo great alteration elſe ſome ſecrete determinatiō natiuitie ſonne ieſus chriſt lord caeſar monarche without competitor yet childe leaue adopted tiberius wiues ſonne whome ſhe might ſée emperour thought ſhée holpe diſpatche caeſar time title augustus giuen thing neuer done anyauguſtus romane onely augmentyng encreaſing empire rome alſo de •• nation deſtinie aſſigned vnto hée ſhutte gate ianus temple generall peace folowed ianus temple shutte onely tvvice • token generall peace world diſpoſed himſelf ſet good order citie made many good lawes preſeruation ſame whiche time diuerſe tokēs appeared cōming greater prince prince prince king king borne worlde time glory god higheſtbyrth ieſus chriſt peace earth men good great enuie iulius caeſar great vncle procuredenuie neuer fell vpon either bicauſe men weary tumultes ſaw wryte euerye nation ſelfe nowe haue tolde howe great border empire compaſſed ſea trauaile land ther parte mauritania goeth towarde weaſte aethiopians deſert wylde parte lybia eaſte aethiopians thys pontus ſome place goe beyond rule nation bee beyonde rene getes bee beyonde hister call dacies theſe boundes land neare coulde gather ilandes sea cyclades sporades h • ade echi • ade tyrrenides • eſia whatſoeuer name haue libya ionia aegipt • ro sicilie otherwiſe called sea al theſe ſubiect romanes excellencie named y• romanes great ilands cyprus creta • hodes leſbus euboi • sicelie sardus cyrnas whatſoeuer elſe paſſing north • ae •• y• ile brittaine yt greatneſſe maye ſome continent haue ye beſt parte halfe reſte paſſe parte haue fruitfull thē great al theſe natiōs yt greateſt labour thē conquere italy could hardly 500 yeares halfe yt tyme vnder king e • p •• ſed king ſworne woulde receiue vſed rule beſt meane hadde yearely choſen twoo hundred yeares v c empire waxed moſte greate lordes ••• nite raine power ſubdued moſt nati ōs thē caius caeſar getting vpper hand made ſure ſtate kept ſtill forme name commō wealth made himſelfe monarchie ouer ſo rule hath continued one thys daye whome call king thinke • •• e olde othe name emperoures whiche title rule army tyme purpoſes bée king emperoures haue continued thys tyme aboute two hundred yeares whiche citty hath bin chiefly • tiſied reuenue moſte encreaſed thing long ſure peace brought perfect felicitie emperoures haue made ſome theſe theyr dominion force haue holden reuolte • therefore good ſkill hadde rather kéepe moſt profitable aboute sea encreace extende theyr dominſon barbarous nation poore vnprofitable whome haue ſéene embaſſadoures come rome yéelde themſelues ſubiect receyued emperoure vnprofitable many nation appoint king bycauſe empire hadde néede ſome ſubiectes muſt kepte ſhame forſake though pore greate armyes euery place circle kéepe ſo greate lande ſea one place neuer monarchie ſo great continued ſo long ſtate grecia man begin frō tune darius army moſt flouriſhed vnto time phill •• amyntas ſonne though put togither power athonians grecia darius firſt king perſia cyru • ▪ daughter vvi •• lacedemonians thebanes ſhall appeare ſo mighty thing contended rather • ig • itie among themſelues thā get dominiō thought matter ſo noble maineteine libertie againſte ſtrange king moleſted ſome ſayled farre sicel •• hope rule ouerthrowen went aſia little returned cōclude power grecian thoughthe ath • ni • n vver • ouerthrovven italy • ōtētions y• rule proceded ſurely grecia ſhewed would kéepe ſeruitude vnconquerable muche could philip alexander thynke haue done euil vnworthy thēſelues empire ofthe povver grecia aſia cōpared leaſt y• feates vertue europe weakenes faintneſſe nation whichthe rule aſia preſent wrighting ſhal declare romanes battels got ſo many nation aſia cōmaund although defended y• • ced • nians greateurope labour europe libya dominiō aſſyrians median perſians thrée greateſt power til alexander philip ſonne though recken y• c yeares y• cōtinued cōpare romane empire y• greatnes ofaſia empire leſſe halfe thinke well conſidered romanes reach frō weſt ocean hill caucaſus floud euphr ••• aeth •• pians aegipt arabia eaſt ocean boundes ocean ſunne riſing ſetting rule inward • ſea ilands brettanes ocean median perſians moſt ſea perſ • c •• si • eaſt hath red ſea vveaſt arabia gulfe pamphilia one ile cypre berie little ionian ſea ſea perſis greate matter macedonian philippe little power andmacedonia phillip ſome ſubiects labour trauaile philippe accompted light onely aboute grecia one region alexander greatneſſe multitude felicitie ſpéedyneſſe dominion ſhorte ſpace became infinite incomparable bycauſe ſhort time like brightalexander lightning whiche beyng diuided manye prouinces part continued noble good whyle king dyd maintaine two hundred thouſande footeinen fortie thouſandthe povver king aegipt horſemen thrée hundred elephant vſed warre two thouſande armed chariot ſo muche armoure woulde ſerue thrée hundred thouſande beſides prouiſion lande two thouſande ſmall veſſels galley little greate thouſande fyue hundreth double furniture eyghte hundred ſhippes ſhewe whiche vſed pompe ſtems ſternes golde ſeauen hundred fortie talent egipt treaſure al whiche appeareth prince recordes yet extant ſeconde king egipt alexander al moſte able ſpende moſt bountifull beſtow moſt deſirous get lefte behinde prince 〈◊〉 lagus vvas mightieſt alexander muche inferiour mutuall diſcorde poſteritie onely deſtruction great kingdomes came nothing romane empire paſſed greatneſſe felicitie continuaunce wiſedom senate neither wanted theyat 〈◊〉 lake 〈◊〉 al canne novve 〈◊〉 manhoode patience painefulneſſe til eſtabliſhed power gaue place miſfortune loſte ſometime twenty thouſande ſometyme fortie fiftye thouſand battaile▪ diuerſe tymes citie daunger famine peſtilence ſedition yet woulde abate ambition ſpace ſeauen hundred yeares ſtryuing paine perill till brought dominion kéeping ſtil • one • rade▪ heigth receyue moſte ample fruit wiſedome happineſſe theſe thing many gretians romanes haue put writing hiſtorie farre excéeding macedonian haue conſidered valiauntneſſe would ſée euery nation penne hath carried lybia vberia iberia sicilie macedonie embaſſages confederacy ſundrye nation brought againe forced man sicilie carthage eftſoones carried mee away theſe vnperfect til gathered partes howe tthey ſent ambaſſadours armyes si • ily iland til conquered thē many ambaſſages many league made betwéen ouerthrowes bothe ſides giuen till carthage ouercome africa made prouince carthage reſtored againe ſtate nowe haue done like euerye prouince bycauſe would know romaine euery might ſée manhoode fayntneſſe al natiōs vertue fortune conquered whatſoeuer matter chaunced thinking woulde acceptable alſo vnderſtand romaine actes thys ſorte haue written euery nation ſelfe leauing write done meane time placyng ſeuerally ſet time euery thing thought much moſte notable expreſſe diſtance time firſte romaine one name al afterthe romaine haue diuerſe name came another length thirde alſo added ſome known ſome marke body vertue mind grecian ſurnames ioyned name time wyll put chiefly noble men may betterthe diuiſion vvorkes knowen moſt name one ſhal moſte fitte thrée bokes declare romaine doings italie call thrée romaine actes italian multitude matter thus diuided firſte conteyneth reignes ſeauen king therefore call hiſtorie romane king followeth booke matter done italy beſide dwell coaſt ionia booke difference called romanes warre king laſt land samnite next ionian ſea nation moſt fierce warlike fighting romanes foureſcoresamnites novve abruzo part kingdome naples yeares till grecian fellowes inhabite italy ſubdued booke difference two called romanes warres samnite haue ſeuerall title romanes warre galles sicilian iberian hanniball carthage macedonia ſo forthe order whiche order time done though many thing happened way ciuill ſeditions warre among themſelues moſt horrible reſt ſhall declared name chiefe doer ſame marius sylla pompey caeſar antony caeſar auguſtus killer caeſar elder ſhall ſhewed antony caeſar whiche made end ciuill warre aegipt came vnder romanes dominion warres diuided bookes nation name captaines ciuill laſt booke ſhall declare army haue reuenue take euery nation▪ charge ordinarie garriſons ſea ſuche ſéeing ſhall wright vertue ſhall fitte beginne theyr originall haue written theſe thing many knowe haue ſhewed tell playnely▪ alexandria accepted countrey exerciſed appian co • n • ellou • emperoures 〈◊〉 cauſes rome cauſes juſtice touching emperoures til pleaſed thinke ine worthy ſeruice know reſt may learne bookes haue written ¶ romanes warre mithridates king pontus appian alexandria romanes ouercome mithridates king xl • j yeares warre made bithinia cappadocia nation bordering vppon thē inhabiting ſea called •• xinu • ſubiecte vnto ſame warre wonne cilicia thoſe yet obedience syria phoenitia coeloſiria paleſtina c •• le one pa • te syria vvhich hollovv ſo ſignifyeth vvord midde land floud euphrates béeing vnder mithridates violence victory ſome put tribute ſome afterward paphlagonia galatia phrygia myſia ioyning phrygia lydia caria ionia reſt aſia aboute pergamo old grecia macedonia whiche mithridates hadde gotten recouered ſoone agayne manye appointed tribute neuer payd yt thinke call chiefly greate warre victory alſo greate captayne pompey proper language name greate day number nation toke recouered long time fortie yeares boldneſſe payneſulneſſe mithridates mightie appeared aſſayes aboue foure hundreth shippes owne fiftie thouſand horſemen two hundred fiftie thouſande footemen engine munition accordingly king prince confederate armenian • ythian pontus fenne • otis thence ſtreightes thracius ſente romane 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 novv ſt • eightes 〈◊〉 captaynes warre togither ſtirre spayne againſt made amitie french moue agaynſte italy filled sea pirate cilicia pillers hercules whiche made trafficke ſayling could bée one citie another wrought great famine euery place generally lefte nothing vndene vndeutied coulde done ſtirre vp greateſt motion among men eaſt weaſt either made warre ſent ayde robbed vexed neyghbours warre variable end brought romanes greateſt dominion rule ſtretched weſt floud euphrates eaſie deuide ſeuerall nation done togither one wrapped another thoſe could ſeparated told particularly greekes thinke thracian ſerue troy vnder rheſus rheſus killed diomedes night whiche matter rheſus king thracia 10 iliad homere telleth verſes fledde month pontus moſt ſtreight ſayle thracia wanted shippes remaine tooke lande named bebrycia aſia leſſe bebrycia ſhippes wente beyonde byzance part thracia called bithinia inhabite floude bithia driuen famine returned bebricia named byzantium novv conſtant tinople bithinia ſtead bebricia floud whichē dwelled ſo name vnlike time changed bycauſe much difference betwéene bebricia bithinia ſome thinke ſuppoſe bythis ſonne iupiter call hir seta vvas fiſter rheſus thrace firſt raigne héere ſo name gyuen land thought good ſhew firſte bithiania king romanes number nine fortie order méete make ſome mention theſe matter romanes pruſias called hunter marriedpruſias cyrigus daughter perſeus kyng macedonie romanes perſeus making warre long pruſias ſtoode neuter perſeus ouercome mette romane captaines wearing romane garmente called toga hauyng ſhoes afterthe romanes vvere called tog •• greekes 〈…〉 italian manner hys head ſhauen wyth cappe whyche manner goe made frée teſtamente béeyng euill fauoured man beholde little ſhorte one méeting wyth ſpake romane tong freemade man romanes call libertus appearing ſightethe behauioure pruſias diſguiſed libertus ſeruant made free laughed ſent rome laughed alſo pardon long vexing attalus king aſia pergamo waſted hys lande aſia whyche senate rome heard ſente pruſas hée ſhoulde moleſt attalus friend confederate romanes thought muche obey embaſſadours ſharply commaunded obey senate come thouſande horſemen confynes decide matter willed attalus bée many deſpiſing ſmall number wyth attalus thynkyng myghte entrappe hym ſente hys embaſſadoures afore though woulde followe thouſandethe craftie • • pruſias horſe bringing army went battell attalus embaſſadours hearde fledde euerye man coulde tooke carriage romanes deſtroyed towne nicephor • burned shippes beſéeged attalus pergamo romanes heard thys ſente embaſſadoures commaunded pruſias reſtore attalus loſſes pruſias afrayde obeyed wente hys waye payne put vpon hée ſhoulde preſently gyue hym twentye armed shyppes time fiftie talentes shyppes gaue hande talentes pruſias forced recompence attalus payde time hated ſubiects crueltie ſonne nicomedes well beloued bithinians wherefore pruſias ſuſpecting ſent lyue rome vnderſtandyng well beloued wylled hym obteyne pruſias practiſeth kill ſonne nicomedes senate releaſe money ought attalus ſent mena deale commaunded mena coulde gette hym diſcharged money ſhoulde ſpare nicomedes coulde ſhould kill hée ſente thys purpoſe certayne greate shyppes two thouſande souldyoures mena bycauſe penaltie forgiuen attalus hadde ſente andronicus tell payne leſſe ſpoyle neyther durſt hyll yong man whome ſawe worthy loued honoured goe agayne bythinia yong man knowing tarrying came talke good conſpired againſte pruſias tooke practiſe embaſſadour attalus ſhould perſuade get nicomedes kingdome bythinia met togither bernice little citie epirus nighte wente shippe conſulted done ſecrete nighte day come nicomedes came forth ship cladde nicomedes shevveth himſelfe king king robe purple crowne head andronicus méeting ſaluted king ſent forth fiue hundreth souldioures ready mena diſſembling though ſéene nicomedes till ranne two thouſand though bin diſcontented béeyng come talke ſayde haue two kinges one home going •• en • souldyoures muſt néedes foreſee ſafetie coniecture well eſtabliſh ſecuritie well appoynting whych two haue raigne one olde yong bithinians hate olde loue yong chiefe romanes loue yong man andronicus defendoure hath promiſed attalus friendſhip hauyng greate kyngdome ioyning bithinia olde enimie pruſias ſayde thus withall declared crueltie pruſias miſchiefe done men common hatred bithinians againſte perceyued abhored wickedneſſe pruſias ledde ſtrayght nicomedes ſeconde andronicus called king garded two thouſand attalus receyued yong man gladly required pruſias giue yong man ſome city dwell landes finde aunſwered would ſhortly giue attalus kingdome whoſe ſake inuaded aſia ſaid thus ſente rome accuſe attalus nicomedes call iudgement attalus wente armie bithinia whome bithinians little little reuolted pruſias diſtruſting men hoping romanes woulde deliuer hym danger obteyned fiue hundred thracian diegelies hys father lawe theſe onely committed body fleeyng caſtell nicaea pretor rome bringing pruſias nicaea vvas firſt called 〈…〉 aftervvard nicaea 〈…〉 vvife meſſengers senate ſpéedily bycauſe fauoured attalus laſt brought senate commaunding chooſe embaſſadors might ende warre choſe thrée men whiche one head ſtricken ſtone andembaſſadors laughed euill fauoured ſcarre left another féete feſtered ſore thyrde compted ydiot ſo muche cato ieſting embaſſage ſaide neyther minde féetecato head embaſſadors went bithinia commanded ceaſſe warre nicomedes attalus diſſembling obey senate bithinians ſet ſayde coulde longer beare crueltie pruſias eſpecially knowen againſt embaſſadors bycauſe romanes hadde yet heard matter departed nothing pruſias mithridates béeyng hys familiar bloud royall perſia antigonus dreamed ſowe grounde wyth golde mithridates dyd carrie golde pontus whendreame antigonus reaped wherefore hée tooke hym woulde haue kylled hym fledde wyth ſyre horſe fenced place cappadocia many reuolting hym thys tumulte macedonie little little gotte cappadocia nation confynes pontus greately enlarging hys realme hée lefte hys chyldren raigned one another tyll ſirth fyrſte mithridates whiche made warre romanes stocke kynges cappadocia pontus conuning thynke bée knowen diuided kingdome ſome reigning cappadocia ſome pontus thys dioniſius eupater romanes commaunded hym gyue place kingdome cappadocia ariobarzanes ſought thought himſelfe nygher kingdome mithridates elſe bycauſe ſuſpected kyngdome mithridates growyng ſo greate vnder hande woulde diuide partes hée ſuffered agaynſte nicomedes nicomedes pruſia hys ſonne romanes appoynted reigne father kingdome ſent socrates brother nicomedes called chreſtus armie socrates toke kingdome chreſtus good profitable bythinia himſelf time mithrias bagoas expuiſing ariobarzanes romanes ſet kingdome cappadocia put ariarathes romanes reſtore bothe nicomedes ariobarzanes proper kyngdomes ſendyng certaine embaſſadours purpoſe whereof manius acilius chiefe commaunded lucius caſsius litle armie pergamo aſia helpe alſo mithridates eupator hée beyng offended romanes cappadocia beyng put phrygia wée haue ſhewed gréeke matter helpe caſsius manius armie gatheryng greater galatian phrygian ſent nicomedes bithynia ariobarzanes cappadocia perſuaded bothe beyng neyghboures mithridates moleſt hys countrey prouoke hym warre romanes woulde mayntayners bothe alyke affected durſt prouoke mithridates fearyng hys mighty power ambaſſadours • rgyng nicomedes promiſed gyue embaſſadours muche money hys reſtitution souldiours yet hée ought beyng debte romanes money lente hym hys matter vnwillyngly hée inuaded mithridates lande ſpoyled farre citie amastris none amaſtris ch aunſwered pelopidas certayne romanes fauoured nicomedes faſhion heard controuerſies ſomewhat moued wordes pelopidas bycauſe mithridates yet league romanes ſtoode doubt aunſwere preſently hauing wiſedome conſidered matter aunſwered thus neyther haue mithridates romanes aunſvvere ſuffer thing wrongfully nicomedes neyther ſuffer warre made vpon nicomedes thinke good romanes nicomedes ſhould hurt thus ſayde pelopidas woulde haue made aunſwere ſentence ſo doubtfull wente ſeate mithridates ſawe manifeſtly iniured romanes ſent ſonne ariarathes great army reigne cappadocia expelled ariobarzanes kingdome pelopidas commyng agayne romane officer ſaid thus mithridates hath borne hāds romanes ſpoiled phrygia cappadocia haue heard hurt nicomedes hath done ſée let paſſe appealing amitie leage though accuſers accuſed aunſwere thinke profitable romane ſtate nicomedes ſhoulde hurte though iniured romanes cauſe thing done cappadocia againſte ſtate rome thorough youre contempt v ſubtill aunſweres mithridates hathe done thys ſendeth embaſſadoures againſte youre senate whome ſendeth worde aunſwere attempt begin thing kindle warre withoute common conſent romanes mithridates hathe father kingdome conteyning length twenty thouſande furlong gotten many nation hym colchos warlike nationeight theſe furlong maketh mile gréekes dwel pontus barbarian next hath friend ready thing paſt repente yée eyther forbidd • nicomedes moleſt friend doe promiſe mithridates ſhall ayd againſt italian breake fayned friendſhip▪ let v goe iudged rome ſayde pelopida bycauſe ſéemed preſumptuous▪ commaunded mithridates ſhoulde deale nicomedes cappadocia woulde ſette ariobarzanes kingdome agayne pelopidas ſhoulde depart frō camp returne embaſſadoure except king woulde ſtand order thus aunſwered▪ ſente hym awaye wyth kepers▪ ſhoulde corrupte none wentethe embaſſadors make vvarre vvithout conſent senate ſayde tarrying senate wyll warre people conſente gathered army bithinia nicomedes came wyth fiftie thouſand footemen ſixe thouſand horſemen greate army ready mithridates owne two hundreth fiftie thouſande footemen fortie thouſande horſemen mithridates force thrée hundred armed shyppes hundreth gallyes wyth munition accordingly chiefe captaynes neoptolemus archelaus bréethren greateſt parte ledde himſelfe ſonne arcadia brought ayd tenne thouſand horſe armenia leſſe •• winne heartes enimies manius campe takena third curteſie mithridates romanes diſcontented sangaris othervviſe called corallus lentocephale fledde floud sangaris paſſed ouer night ſaued himſelfe multitude ſhippes rhodians arte ſetting vpō nauy diſordering thē ſo toke one galie men much munition ſpoyle brought hir hauen ignorāt yt great galie taken enimie ſent vj ſwif • eſt recouer hir damagoras admiral wēt thē mithridates ſent xxv hym gaue place till night waxing darke king ſhippes retourned ſet vpon tooke two chaſed two lycia returned nighte ende fight betwéene mithridates rhodians doone againſt hope rhodians fewneſſe mithridates multitude fight king ſayling encourage men ſhippe chia hys nauie cruſhed king ſhippe confuſion whiche kyng diſſemblingthe king shippe crushed chaunce puniſhed captaine maiſter offended xian thys time king footemē brought great ſhips pery riſyng vpon driuen rhodes rhodians quickly comming vppon yet troubled ſtrome tooke ſome cruſhed ſome ſome burned tooke four hundred priſoners mithridates preparyng sambuca vvas engine vſed ſiege city bycauſe rope vvere ſtretched ſtrings inſtrument muſicke ſo called fight ſea againe force towne made certaine engin called sambuca carried two ſhips fugitiues tolde ſide hill might ſcaled temple iupiter tabyrius weake wall put army ſhips night gaue ſcaling ladder commaunded goe ſilence till fire made temple crye loude coulde bee made ſome aſſaulte towne ſome force porte ſilence drewe nighe watche rhodians knowing made fire army mithridates thinking bin fire temple déepe ſilence cried togither well scaler marriners thethe rhodians put kyngs men avvaye rhodians cried faſt chearefully came togither y• wal ſo king men nothing night daye putte backe althoughe sambuke affraid rhodians much caſting many dartes arrowes ſhotte beeing iſis goddeſſe aegipt broughte againſte temple iſis souldiours many ſcalyng ladder ſhippes came forth woulde haue giuen aſiaulte rhodians defended themſelues manfully till engine brake waight viſion iſis thought caſte greate fire vpon mithridates deſpairing enterpriſe ſayled rhodes patara ſiege cut holy woode latone patara cittye lycia make engins till feared viſion left woode leauing pelopida continue warre lycia hée ſente archilous grecia winne force friendſhip ſo much poſſible committing many thing captain trayned furniſhed army paſſed time woman stratonicede ſate iudgement thought watch make mutinie helpe romaine while hée thus occupied theſe thinges done grecia archelous ſayling great nauie well victualled tooke delos reuolted athens place aegian ſea ariſtion occaſion money plaieth tyrā ariſtion man athens two thouſand y• gard mony aristion vſing purpoſe played tiranne country ſome athenian killed oute hand fauourers romaine ſome ſent mithridates yet ſcholer epicurus learning alone athens critias beyng profeſſours philoſophie critias tyrannes italy pythagoras ſchoole grecia called ſeauen wiſe men rule theyphiloſophers tirannes tooke vpon vſed tyranny cruellye y• vnlearned tyrannes therefore doubt ſuſpition philoſophers whether vertue pouertie lacke experience comforted themſelues philoſophie whiche many priuate poore couering néede ſapiēce ſpeake bitterly againſte rich men prince cōtempt rich rule opinion rather enuy caried vnto bée ſlaundered wiſely contempne one maye thinke bée ſpoken aristion philoſopher occaſion matter moued acheans lacedemonians relent archelous theſpia free tovvne boeotia magneſia ionia demetriada theſſalie boeotia except theſpia whome beſéeged time metrophanes ſente mithridates another armye make warre vppon eubea dimetriades magnetia reſiſted mithridates brittius comming macedonia ſmall nauie fight sea ſinking one greate shippe foyſte killed metrophanus beholding afrayde fledde hauing good wind brittius could ouertake tooke scyathus receypt barbarian rouers hanged vp scyethu • •• •• e ſlaues cutte hand frée men turning boeotia thouſand horſemen footemen comming macedonia cherona foughte thrée dayes ariſtion 〈◊〉 archelous equall indifferent fortune ſides lacedemonians acheans come ayde ariſtion archelous brittius thinking himſelfe weake match pire • novve portolione port athens able hold four hundred shippes went pire • till archelous came kept sylla béeyng choſen generall warre againſte mithridates tooke iourney italy fyue legion ſome bandes companyes arriued grecia gatheryng money mon victual aetolia theſſalia thoughte ſufficiente wente attica againſte archelous came boeetia ſauing reuolted ſo greate citie thebe lightly taking thebe boeotia mithridates parte againſte romanes nowe ſwiftely turning archelous sylla came tryall went attica ſending one parte armye againſte citie beſéege ariſtion wente pireo archelous within walles heygth whereof fortie cubites béeyng worke pericles made greate ſtone pireus vvas made p • nacles vvalled tvvo myles length megara achaia ele • ſina attica ſquare athenian made warre pelopeneſians bycauſe putte victory pireo made ſtrong sylla come wall gaue aſſaulte forthwith muche hurte béeyng done ſydes cappadocians manfully defendyng béeyng wéery wente eleuſina megara made engine againſt pireo mountes rampires artificer ſtuffe yron ſlings ſuche broughte hym thebe cut downe wodde academia made greate engine toke away academia vvas shadovvie place mile athens long ſides caſt ſtones timber earth vppon rampire two ſlaues athens pireo fauouring romanes fidelitie ſlaues romanes foreſéeyng theyr ſafetie anye thing ſhoulde happe wrote pellet leade euer ſhoulde done threwe romanes ſlings thys béeyng often done come knowledge sylla hauyng regarde matter founde thus written morrowe footemen ſhall come vppon face youre labourer horſemen ſhall ſette vppon ſydes romanes therefore layde ambuſh ready enimie thought haue come ou y• ſuddayne ſuddaynelye dyd ſette vppon kylled many droue sea thys ende thys attempte nowe many greate tower béeyng ſette vpon mounte archelous dyd make lyke ſide furniſhed wyth weapon ſente power chalcidonia ilandes armed hys mariner woulde hazarde archelous hadde greater armye sylla nowe muche bigger midnighte iſſued wyth lyghtes burned one greate engine belonged sylla tenne dayes made another ſette archelous erected tower agaynſt wall another army beyng come vnto hym mithridates whiche dimoxetes ledde brought forth fighte wyth whome mixed hys ſhotte ſtoode vnder wall warder myghte throwe vppon enimies ſtoode gate wyth fyre lokyng token ſallie forthe fyghte long tyme equall nowe one another gaue place barbarian beganne flée tyll archelous commyng vppon made turne agayne whyche greately afrayed romaine ſo fledde murienas met themromaines flee returne agayne reproued ſorte vvere noted • ſome covvardlineſſe called v • • pera • returned bande come foragyne reproued ſéeing fighte ſo hotte gaue couragious onſet vpon mithridates menne killed two thouſand droue walles archelous woulde haue tourned backe againe fyghte tarrying long bycauſe earneſtneſſe ſhutte oute taken rope sylla releaſed rebuke noted bycauſe fought valiauntlye rewarded souldioures wyth gyftes accordingly winter come hée placed hys army eleuſine andeleuſine made ditche highe place sea ennimies horſemen ſhoulde eaſilye breake vppon whyche hee working euerye daye diuerſe ſkirmiſhes ſometime aboute ditche ſometyme walles ennimyes commyng vſyng ſtones dartes pellets▪ sylla wanting shippes ſente rhodes rhodes coulde paſſe bycauſe mithridates helde sea hée commaunded lucullus diligēce lucullus noble manne rome generall thys warre sylla goe priuilye alexandrîa syria gather armye kynges citties ſende rhodians hée fearing sea beſette wyth shyppes tooke light veſſell chaunging shippe shippe vnknowne came alexandrîa bewrayers pireo wrote againe pellet nighte following archelous woulde ſende athens want corne vpon ſoldiors backes sylla laying wayte tooke corne carrier ſame daye minutius didde hurte neoptolemus chalcide novve negropon • ey chiefe cuttie e barbariās leapt forſaking wall though al bene takē turning force killed ye leader thē ſcaled flung downe headlong getting gate hadde néere hande burned one romaine tower scylla come army fought wyth nyght day greate labour ſaued archelous made tower wall againſt romaine might fight togither vpon tower whiche ſo oft ſo furiouſly harde tyll scylla▪ caſte twentye greate pellet ſling killed many ſo beate arthelous tower vnprofitable archelous fayne lie behind wall feare citie preſſed hunger ſlaues ſignifyed againe pellet victuall ſhoulde ſent nighte cittie archelous ſuſpecting ſome treaſon battayle sylla delayed conſidering place multitude ennimies followed archelous went calcide expecting time place ſawecherona vnquered cherin •• hilly place whiche wer ouercome could flée plain nigh •• men redy prouoke archelous fight againſt wil playne commodious marche forth retire pleaſure wheras archelous baſet ſhe hils ſo coulde vſe men would altogither place inequalitie ground▪ ſhould turne harde place woulde hinder flight waying matter sylla taketh aduantage▪ place th • ſe difficulty gaue ſhe onſet knowing great multitude would litle profit archelous think romanes would haue fought therfore kept campe neglygently whē battel begon felte hardeneſſe place perceyued late ſente horſemen kepe returning oriuen hils ſent l • armed chariot ſée could violence breake cut maine battel romanes theythe armed▪ chariot defeated ſuffred paſſe front ende diuiding themſelues ouerthrowen ſhot vnweldy turne though archelous might thus haue kepte campe ſoone hils defence yet ſet whole multitude order came vpon sylla ſodeyne theſe ſtreight place bycauſe hand firſt brought forth horſemen grat violence cut aſunder romanes battayle eaſilye compaſſed ſmall number fighting valiātly kept themſelues ring greateſt daunger fought vnder galba •• ortenſius againſt whome archelous fought himſelf barbarian ſight ſhewed great manhoode till sylla came thyther horſemen archelous thinkyng sylla hée came ſhewe enſignes rayſing ſo much duſte leauyng hys compaſſing went hys battayle sylla brought horſemen beſte twoo newe bandes lay ambuſhe charged vpon ſettyng themſelues order yet al come compaſſing due forme fronte brake ſo confounded turued flée whiche followed beginnyng victory thus murena lefte wing furthered thethe ouerthrovv archelaus ſame luſtily encouraging men manly folowed chace wing archelous turned midde battayle holde fledde alſo sylla foreſéene fel vpon enimie hauing frée place turne playne flée hilles ſlayne folowed ſome fell hādes ſome wiſer got campe archelous ignorant feates warre commaunded turne vpon enimies way obeyed readily wāting captaines ſet order knowing proper enſignes beeing fouly diſordered wanting place bothe fighte flée beeing driuen ſtraighte chaced killed eaſe ſome ennimies could kill againe ſome themſelues cōfuſion ſo ſtraight place went againe gate gathered togyther rebukyng ſhutte rehearſing theyr countrey goddes naturall familiaritie ſo much enimies diſdayne deſtroyed tyll archelous ſéeyng néede opened gate late receyued running diſorder romanes perceyuing callyng one vehemencie ſwifteneſſe gotte cāpe thē fled puniſh death beyng ſo counſayled friend ſéekers life traytours kingdome puniſh two thouſand talent tenor letter would haue ſent embaſſadours zenobius woulde ſuffer armure gone chiefe child taken away fiftéene thouſande whereof moſt part horſemen among diogenes archelous ſon footemen fledde campe sylla fearing leaſt archelous woulde flée againe thalcida hauing shippes night ſet watch y• playne day fully furlong frō archelous caſt trench comming forth exhorted earneſtly army finiſh reſt al battel ſeing enimies durſt come brought trēch archelous like mutation among enimies neceſſitie captaynes palladium ſent heauen thinke ſome ſuppoſe palladium image minerua ſente heauen vnbroken couered walles fell excepte diomedes vliſſes carried away warre troy thys fimbria againſt iliū ciii olimpiad thē ending ſome thinke thouſand fifty yeares agamemnon mithridates heard loſſe orchomeno conſidering multitude hadde ſente grecia continuall greate ouerthrowes ſent archelous make truce good manner could come parley ſayde sylla mithridates auntient friend sylla hath made warre couetouſneſſe generalles archelous sylla content leaue warre thy vertues ſake thou wilt commaund ſhall iuſt sylla wante ship money none ſent bycauſe enimies iudged rebell hauing gathered money pythians olimpians epidaureans giuen them▪ reaſon holy thing halfe theban land ſo oft rebelled hauing army valiant experte leade agaynſte rebellion hys enimies bent peace ſayd mithridates bin iniured ſhould haue ſent embaſſadoures doyng iniurie hath inuaded many land men hathe ſlayne many common holy thyngs city proper goodes hathe ſpoyled béeyng like vnfaythfull friendes v whome hathe killed many ſlayne prince banquet night wiues child hath ſhewed v rather crueltie nature neceſſitie warre vſed italian aſia kindes euils deſtroying murthering men woman child ſlaues nation italy ſo great hate againſte italy alleadgeth auntient amitie faſhion hathe loſt hundreth thréeſcore thouſand men maketh mention wherefore reaſon would ſhould take vnfaithfull yet thy ſake vndertake get forgiueneſſe romanes repente doyngs diſſemblethtalke peace alſo loke thou wel archeloe conſider preſent ſtate well thy ſelfe conſider howe hée hath vſed friend haue vſed eumenes maſſiniſſa hee ſpeaking thus archelous diſdeynefull brake tale ſpoken proue ſayde woulde neuer betray army committed yet hope peace thy hand thou makeſt reaſonable cōditions sylla ceaſſing ſayd archeloe mithridates doe deliuer vnto nauie thou haſt deliuer captaines embaſſadours priſoners fugitiues ſlaues fledde frō v let go chians beſide forth hath made captiues pontus take garriſons euery place except thoſe breaking peace defray charge warre whereof hathe bin cauſe conteyne himſelfe within limit father dominion truſt perſuade romanes remember hathe done thus ſaid archelous tooke garriſons euery place reſt ſent king sylla ſomewhat vacation ſpoyled enetanes dardaneans eiutians nation 〈◊〉 • eople paphlagonia nigh macedonian alwayes moleſting macedonia exerciſed ſouldyoures gotte money likewiſe embaſſadoures nowe come mithridates agréed thing hauing excepted paphlagonie ſaying mithridates mighte haue would make peace generall fimbria sylla angry ſaid would puniſhe fimbria well ynough whē come aſia would ſée whether mithridates hadde néede warre peace ſaid thus went cypſela thracia ſent lucullus afore abydus whether come daunger rouers many time brought nauie shyps cyprus phoenitia frō rhodus pamphilia ſpoyling many coaſtes enimies ſkirmiſhing king shyppes sylla cypſelos mithridates pergamo mette agayne talke commyng playne fewe mithridates recorded father •• • e confederacie accuſed romane embaſſadoures lieuteuantes whiche hadde vſed vniuſtly ſetting ariobarzanes cappadocia taking phrygia hym winking nicomedes dyd hym open iniurie quoth money taken well thyngtalke peace betvvene sylla mithridates romanes moſt blamed bycauſe corrupt money warre broken youre generalles ſoeuer haue done defence hathe bin rather neceſſitie mithridates ſayde thus hee ceaſſed sylla thus aunſwered although thy comming peace yet doeſt renue matter refuſe ſpeake briefely lieutenant cilicia ſette ariobarzanes cappadocia decrée romanes thou diddeſt obey thou ſhouldeſt haue ſpoken againſt wrangled afterwarde ſwarued order manius manius actes reproued gaue thée phrygia money iniuſtice indifferente thou doeſt confeſſe thou gotteſt vnlawfully giuing money manius thing done money reproued v senate diſſolued done reaſon whereof woulde make phrygia tributarie vnto béeyng gyuen vniuſtly thée lefte frée reaſon doeſt thou vſurpe thing haue taken warre wyll yet haue thée rule nicomedes accuſeth thée alexander woundyng hys bodye ſendyng socrates chreſtus kyngdome reuenge inuaded thy realme dyd thée wrong thou ſhouldeſt haue ſente embaſſadoures haue tarried aunſwere thou dyddeſt make ſpéedy reuengeance nicomedes dyddeſt thou inuade ariobarzanes hadde done thée wrong thou hadſt begunne romanes compelled couenantes reſtore hym béeyng reſtored defend thou madeſt warre béeyng thus perſuaded hope thou didſt ouercome romanes thou ſhouldeſt reigne ouer making theſe pretence thy purpoſe whyche haue thys coniecture warre thou madeſt league wyth thracian scythian sauromatians ſendeſt king thy neyboures thou madeſt shippes gatheredſt maiſters mate time doth bewray thyne intente thou hardeſt italy reuolted frō v wayting trouble thou didſt inuade ariobarzanes nicomedes galatian paphlagonia thou dydſt inuade aſia lande thou hadſt got didſt thou againſt city ouer thou madeſt ſlaues fellowes debt ruler giuing libertie releaſſing debt agaynſt grecian ſmall occaſion thou didſt kill ſixetéene hundreth prince galatia whome feaſt thée thou didſt murther italian nation one daye thou didſt kill drowne wiues childrē ſparing fledde holy place howe greate crueltie great impietie extremitie hate didſt thou ſhow agaynſte v gathering euery man mony thou didſt ſayle europe greate armyes forbiddyng kyngs aſia enter europe thou wert come thou didſt ouercome macedonia oure prouince thou tokeſt grecian theyr fréedome neyther didſt thou repente thée make archelous meane thée tyll hadde recouered macedonia delyuered grecia thy violence ſlayne hundreth ſixtie thouſand thyne army taken thy campes theyr munition therfore maruell thou doeſt iuſtifye thy ſelfe thoſe thyngs thou deſireſt forgyuen archelous whyche farre thou didſt graunte nigh thou doeſt call queſtion whoſe tyme paſt thou making warre reſiſting mightily reſiſt thée ende sylla ſpeaking anger king afrayde graunted confyrmed condition made archelous deliueryng shyppes thing went pontus father kingdome onely thus firſte warre betwéene romanes mithridates ceaſſed sylla encamping two ſurlongs fimbria commaundedvvarre betvveene 〈◊〉 sylla hym deliuer army whiche helde agaynſt lawes taunted rule lawfully beſéeged sylla many openly forſaking called reſt counſell exhorted tarrie ſayde fimbria forſaken woulde fyght countreymen tore garmente beſoughte refuſed alſo many ſtill went went tentes captaines winning ſome money called agayne counſell commaunded ſweare enetans cryed muſt call ſweare name called bin benefited hym firſt nonius nonius refuſeth ſvveare priuie doings refuſed ſweare drewe hys ſworde threatned kill hym tyll crye made ceaſſed feare hyred ſlaue hope libertie money goe fugitiue kyll sylla béeyng thyng troubled beyng thereby ſuſpected taken confeſſed syllas army rage diſdeyne ſtanding aboute fimbria hys trenche dyd reuile hym call atheniona fewe dayes king ouerathenion ſeruantes sicelie rebelled fimbria deſpayring came wall deſyred ſpeake wyth sylla vvill ſpeake vvith fimbria sylla ſente rutilius place chiefly gréeued fimbria would ſpeake denyed enimies deſired pardon hadde offended yet yong man rutilius ſayd sylla would let goe quietly sea would giue place aſia sylla lieutenant ſayde would find better way went pergamo temple aeſculapius kylled hymſelfe wounde béeyng ſufficiente badde hys p • ge diſpatche fimbria killeth himſelfe▪ kylled hys maiſter fyrſte himſelfe thus ended fimbria muche miſchiefe aſia mithridates whome sylla gaue freemade mē bury ſayinghi b • ly given b • rye • othervviſe marius vſed rome woulde follow cinna marius rome kylled many men woulde ſuffer buried receyuing fimbria armye came vnto hym ſette hys owne commaunded curio reſtore nicomedes ariobarzanes cappadocia wrote senate thyngs ſeemyng declared rebell ſetling prouince recompenced ilians chians lycian rhodians magneſians others confederate good ſuffered whiche cauſe heethe revvardes faithfull people diſmiſſed frée regiſtred friendes romanes reſt ſent army proclaymed ſeruantes hadde freedome mithridates ſhoulde reſtored theyr maiſters whereof manye diſobeying ſome city rebellingthe punishment reuolting people followed great ſlaughters frée bond diuers occaſions walles many pulled downe made ſeruile people many cappadocians faction men city ſharply puniſhed chiefly epheſians impudently reuile romanes cōmandemēts proclamation made chiefe euery citie ſhould come sylla epheſus come common hall thus ſayd vnto firſt came aſia army antiochu • king sylla epheſi •• syria ouerrunne driuing away makyng aly taurus limit kingdome toke holy floud running taurus made lefte frée excepte ſome gaue eumenes rhodes confederate tributary tenant proofe whereof toke licians rhodians making complaynt thus wée help ariſtonicus four yeares againſt v after▪ attalus philomêter left kingdome v teſtament till ariſtonicus taken many came againe neceſſitie feare thus doyng foure twenty yeares comming great rich ſubſtance well publike priuate thorough peace abundance wrangle agayne wayting trouble italie ſome brought mithridates ſome receyued came moſte cruell men one day killed italian chyldren mother ſpare fledde temple goddes whiche ſome puniſhment haue mithridates beyng vnfaythfull •• llyng murder baniſhments makyng diuiſions landes releaſing debtes libertie ſlaues ſome putting tyrannes cauſing many robbery ſea land experience may know compariſon gouernour haue receyued reiected beginner theſe thing haue bene partly puniſhed v payne muſt publique haue done lyke may correſpondent haue done romanes vſe wicked murder ſudden confiſcations riſings ſeruants barbarous thing minde abhorreth regarde ſhalbe nation name greece glorie aſia fréendes romanes honour ſake wée put vpon tribute fiue yeares onely brought preſently expences warre haue beſtowed reſt take order make diuiſion accordyng city declare frendſhip ſhall kéepe theſe order appoynt puniſhment enimies sylla ſayde thus diuided payne embaſſadours ſente mony city beyng poore oppreſſed debte ſome let ferme theatre creditours ſome common houſes wals porte thing publique without deſpite souldiours gathered money brought sylla aſia inough euils full manifeſt robbery rather like army thā pirate mithridates long ſet thē ſea waſted al thing long kéepe beyng moſte aboundant onelyinconueniences aſia iaſſus▪ ile ca • troubling men ſea ſpoyling porte townes city euidentlye iaſſus samos clazomene samothracia sylla taken temple samothracia robbed value thouſand talent eyther willingly leauing puniſhe offendoures bycauſe ſedition rome wente grecia thence italy army haue writtē y• bookes ciuil diſſentiō ſecond warre mithridates beganne occaſionthe ſeconde vvarre vvith mithridates▪ colchis next pontus murena l ••• e sylla two legion fimbria ſhewed certayne formes warre deſire triumph mithridates gone pontus made warre vpon colchians boſphoriā • colchians deſired ſonne mithridates might giuen king whome receyued obeyed mithridates killeth ſonne forthwith king hauing ſonne ſuſpitiō coueted whole kingdome ſent held cheynes gold killed done muche good ſeruice aſia againſt fimbria againſt boſphorians hée gathered gret army made great nauie mightineſſe whiche preparation rayſed opinion againſt boſphorians againſt romanes reſtored cappadocia ariobarzanes kepte parte ſtyll archelous fleeth frō mithridates comana citie dedicate bellona murena cauilleth archelous ſuſpition granted grecia néeded sylla making peace archelous perceyuing fearing fledde murena whome incenſed perſuaded againſte mithridates murena entered cappadocia comana greateſt citie vnder mithridates hauing holy temple treaſure killed certaine horſemē mithridates embaſſadors alleaged y• leage anſwered none ſuch sylla wright confirmed word ſo left whē murena ſard thys hée fell ſpoyle refrayning holy money wintered cappadocia mithridates ſent rome senate sylla cōplayne murenas doings y• time paſſed floud aly great thē déepe bicauſe y• raine calidius commeth rome vvith counter • e • commaundement ſpoiled 400 mithridates townes king yet méeting loking embaſſadors rome hauing got great bootie went phrigia cappadocia whither calidius came rome touching mithridates complayntes brought decrée onely ſayde vnto midſt hearer y• senate cōmanded ſpare king confederate hadde ſaid thus ſéene ſpeake alone murenas ceaſſed inuaſion ſtill moleſted y• land king euidently perceyuing vſed enimie romanes bad gordius take nigh townes gathered many beaſtes cariage munition priuate men ſouldyours camped floud ouer agaynſt murena neither began y• fight til mithridates came great army mighty fight floud mithridates murenas fleeth violence paſſed floud otherwiſe good murena fled king force ſtrong hill hauyng loſt many departed mountaynes withoute anye way phrigia followed oppreſſed victory euident quickly gotten ſoone ſpred abroade turned many mithridates putting murenas garriſons euery place wt great ſpéede make ſacrifice iupiter y•
