aire ſo hote ſacrifice make cuſtome hys countrey sylla cōtent yt mithridates league ſhould haue war made vpō ſent aulus gabinius cōmand murena moleſt mithridates ſhould agrée mithridates 〈…〉 refuſeth mithridates gold ariobarzanes mithridates y• méeting making ſure ſonne ariobarzanes iiij yeares age y• meane holding ſtill cappadocia getting feaſted put gold y• cup y• meate ieſters ſingers al vſe y• gabinius touched none thus y• ſecond war mithridates end y• thirde yeare quiet ſubdued boſphorus apointed thē ſon macharis king inuaded acheans aboue colchos ſeme fledde troy loſt theyr way loſing twoo partes hys armie fighte colde deceiptes returned ſente rome haue league ratified ariobarzanes ſente alſo eyther hymſelfe ſtirred others hée receyued cappadocia mithridates kepte yet better parte hym sylla commaunded mithridates gyue place cappadocia hée ſo ſente embaſſadours cochieus came troy haue condition peace regiſtred sylla dead senate aſſembled bycauſe vacation ſent tigranes ſonne law inuade cappadocia tigranes perſuaſiō mithridates inuadeth cappadocia himſelf cautele vnknowen romanes armenian compaſſing cappadies neſte ledde away thrée hundreth thouſande men armenia made dwell place firſt toke crowne armenia hys name called tigranocertos whiche citie tigranes theſe doyngs aſia sertorius captayne spayne dyd ſtirre place againſt romanes made senate counterfeyte romanes two faction mithridates ſendeth sertorius lucius manius l fanius perſuaded mithridates ioyne sertorius putting hope greate parte aſia nation perſuaded ſent sertorius ledde embaſſadoures senate made glorious tale renoume ſpredde farre p • ntus beſéeged romanes weſt eaſt couenanted giue mithridates aſia bithinia paphlagonit cappadocia gallogrecia ſent captayne marcius varius lucius manius l fanius counſel theſe dyd mithridates begin thrid laſt war romanes loſt al kingdome sertorius dead spayne general ſent rome firſt lucullus admiral syllas nauie pompey vnder whome mithridates hadthe thirde vvarre vvith mithridates nigh floud euphrates pretence violence war againſt mithridates fall romanes mithridates hauing proued ſo oft romanes medimnus vvas meaſure contayned ſix • modij modius contayned ſyxe sextures vvhych commonlye called bushell calybes people poute dig yron naked heniochi people ponius liuing theft thermodon thinking war made without cauſe ſodaine would appeaſed made al preparation hee coulde try whole reſt ſomer al y• winter made ſhippes armoure brought ſea ij c medimnes grayne got confederate beſide hys former power chalibyans armenian scythian taurians achuians heniochans leucoſyrians inhabite floud thermodon called land amazones theſe gotte aſia going europe sarmatians baſileans iazugeans coralleans al nation thracian inhabite aboute hister rodope aemos basternans moſt valiaunt people theſe hadde mithridates europa hadde gathered hundreth fortie thouſande footemen ſixtéene thouſande horſemen another great number venturer piouers victualer spring come viewed nauy ſacrificed mithridates •• ſouldiours iupiter warriour vſuall ſacrifice neptunus caſt ſea chariot white horſes wente paphlagonia taxilus eumocrates generalls come made ſolempne oration armye ſetting forth progenitor himſelfe verye highly enlarged kingdome little great neuer ouercome romanes preſente whome accuſed ambition vnſatiableneſſe whiche ſaid haue made italy countrey ſeruile repeated laſt condition whiche woulde ſubſcribe séekyng tyme inuade againe making cauſe warre hee extolled power prouiſiō ſhewed romanes trouble moleſted spayne sertorius home italie ciuil warre therefore ſaide thorough negligence sea hathe long tyme béene full pyrates confederate haue none willingly auye wil vnder ſée theſe noble men ſayde hée ſhewing varius lucians enimies country friend v ſaid thus ſtirred armye hée wente bythinia nicomedes beyng dead without chylde leauyng nicomedes leaueth kingdome romenes cotta fleeth kingdome romanes cotta preſidēt man litle ſkill warre fledde calchida power bithynia agayne vnder mithridates romanes fléeing cotta calchide mithridates comming thither cotta nudue commeth chalcide vvhere port coloyſe lette dovvne many romanes ſtayne lacke experience came foorth nudus admirall part army tooke ſtronger parte fielde whiche beyng driuen hée fled gate chalcide many hedge great paine gate great thruſt would get ſo darte caſte vayne folowed wherefore kéepers beyng afrayde gate let barres fall tower tooke vp nudus capitaynes rope periſhe betwéene fréendes enimies holdyng vp hāds mithridates vſing courſe good fortune brought ſhippes day porte breakyng barre yron burned foure enimies ſhippes tooke thrée ſcore neyther cotta nudus reſiſtyng kéepyng thēelues within walles thrée thouſand ſlayne romanes lucius manlius senatour mithridates loſte twentie basternians firſt wente porte l lucullus beyng conſull choſen generall warre lucullus generall brought one legion rome two fimbria beſide two hauing thirtie thouſand footemen ſixtene hundred horſemen encamped agaynſt mithridates cyzico vnderſtandyng fugitiues king thrée thouſande men victual brought forager ſea ſayde aboute would take enimies without payne bad remember lucullus eſpieth aduauntage eſpied hill fitte campe might get forage kéepe enimie entended get winne victorie without daunger beyng one way ſtraight mithridates kepte ſtrength ſo taxiles capitaynes aduiſe lucius manius came frō sertorius made league mithridates sertorius dead reuolted ſecretly lucullus ſayth beyng receyued perſwaded mithridates lette romanes mithridates abuſed go campe would two legion fimbria would ſtraight reuolt come kyng néede vſe force ſlaughter might ouercome without fight mithridates conſenting vnwiſely vncircumſpectly ſuffered romanes paſſe ſtreight without feare encampe hyll hauyng whiche might haue victual behinde brought without feare mithridates beyng ſhut fennes hilles floudes could haue none lande litle neyther hauyng way eaſily force compell lucullus hardeneſſe paſſage whiche power hée neglected winter beyng hande commyng sea woulde fayle lucullus perteyued hée put fréendes remembraunceerrours mithridates promiſe hée ſpake bée performed mithridates mighte peraduenture haue paſſed thorough middes hys enimies hys multitude hée lette paſſe alſo gaue himſelfe onely gettyng cyzico thynkyng remedy bothe wante harde cyzico iland citie propontide great renovvne way hauyng plentie souldiours wente aboute meanes poſſible nauie hée encloſed double wall entrenched reſt citie ſet vp many rampiers engine vpon tower rammes couered one called helepolis hundred cubites vpon helepolis engine beate vvall tower ſet caſting arrowes ſtones diuerſe weapon porte two gallies ioyned togither bare tower bridge caſte engine nigh wall ready hée ſente thrée pryſoners cyzicus ſhippes citie holding vp hand praying ſpare people daunger till liſistratus liſiſtratus captaune came walles trumpette exhorted beare patiently miſchaunce mithridites deceyued purpoſe hée brought engine ſhippes threwe ſodenly bridge vpon wall foure men ranne vpon whiche cyzians amaſed ſtraungers gaue place commyng forth tooke courage againe killed thoſe foure without threwe fire pitch vpon ſhippes made tourne theyr engine enterpriſe ſea cyzians better day third time brought al engine lande within labouring putting backe violence rammes bet ſtones put collats brake dint peltes wooll thethe valiantnes cyzians fierie dartes quenched vineger water clothes caſt againſt ſayles wrapped togither ſtopped throwe lefte nothing vndone menne might doe although ſuffered labour reſiſted euill yet night parte wall burned fell manne durſte enter heate cyzianes made vp night long great ſtorme wind breake reſte king engine reade cittie dowrie iupiter proſerpine cyziens honour hir moſt god feaſt day came ſhould ſacrifice blacke cowe hauing one made one paaſte blacke cowe came ſea whyche going vnder barre hauen ranne cittie camea ſacrifice proſerpina temple ſtoode aulter cyzians ſacrificed good hope mithridates friendes counſelled go cittie holy would went dindimus high hill made trench cittie ſet tower mine digged wall ſente hys horſes leane lacke meate lame labour bythinia lucullus mette wente rindacus killed toke many priſoners men fiftéene horſes ſixe thouſand many beaſts burden time eumachus captaine mithridates ranne ouer eumachus killeth romanes • ſau • people aſia leſſe phrygia ſlewe romanes woman child inuaded piſidus iſaur • cilicia till one prince galatia deiotar u ſtopped courſe killed manye done phrygia winter come mithridates without victual wont come sea wherefore hys armye famyſhed many dyed eate dead men barbarouſly eate hearbes ſicke caſting dead bodyes vnburyed broughte peſtilence hunger mithridates continued hoping get citie engine dindymus ciziceans dindymus hill idea defeated purpoſe burned engine made many ſalyes vpon enimies féble hunger mithridates intended flée night ſhippes par •• armye wente land lampſaco came floud aeſepus whiche growen high lucullus aeſepus floud leſſe niſia▪ flovving hill ida ſet vpō paſſing killed many thus ciziceans eſcape greate preparation king owne manhoode helpe lucullus oppreſſed famine whiche cauſe make playes day whiche call lucullus playes mithridates conueyed lucullus playes away army come lampſa ••• beſéeged lucullus lampſatians alſo shippes ſente committed tenne thouſande beſt guided varius ſente sertorius alexander paphlagonian dioniſio eunuch ſayled nicomedia winter weather deſtroyed many whē lucullus wrought feate lād famine gathered ſhippes aſia betooke lieutenant triarius tooke apamea killed many fledde apamea coaſt bythinia temple barbas tooke pruſiade builded vnder hill nicea garriſons pruſias called chius mithridates fléeing lucullus tooke enimies shippes thirtéene porte achaia ouertoke varius alexander dioniſius lemnus lennus novv statimene monument philoctetes deſert ile alter philoctetes ſerpent braſſe bowe breſtplate tyed bendes ſéene ſhewe calamitie ſayled vpon wyth great haſt contempte remayning ſtill ſente forth two shyppes ſtayd reſt prouoke come comming defendyng themſelues land ſayled ile shippes • et footemen lande whiche made take shyppes woulde come aflote fearyng lucullus army lucullus ouercometh three captaynes mithridates ſayling lande folowed lande ſea hurte great ſlaughter flighte among varius alexander dionyſius eunuche taken hidde caue whiche dionyſius hauyng dronke poyſon thought died lucullus cōmaunded varius killed ſéemely bring romane senatour triumph alexander kepte pompe lucullus wrote victorie letter wrapped laurell romanes manerletters laurell victory wente bythinia mithridates ſayled pontus two tempeſtes mithridates hath loſſe ſea ••• ed ro • er barke sinope vvas vniuerſit • e loſt ten thouſande men thréeſcore ſhippes reſt ſcattered winde droue owne ſhippe falling leake went rouers barke fréends againſt going rouers ſet ſafe sinope frō whence went amiſo trie ſonne law tigranes armenian machares ſonne reyguing boſphoro hée ſente bothe ſhoulde prouide helpe scythiās diocles fleeth lucullus confines hée ſente golde many giftes diocles fledde lucullus hys golde giftes lucullus goyng forwarde boldely victorie ouercame euery thyng wente winnyng wealthy countrey bene long without warre ſlaue ſolde foure drammes oxea dramme vvas romane penny goates ſhéepe garment al thing like value lucullus • reged amiſon eupatoria whicheeupatoria mithridates buylded next amiſo named eupatoria▪ himſelf made king palace army beſieged themiſcyra name one amazones themiſcyra region pontus •• • dde thermodonta lying themiſcyra ſette vp tower made trench wrought ſo great •• ne • ightyng vnder grounde themiſcyrians opened aboue threw beares wilde beaſtes ſwarmes bées vpon workemen amiſus went way worke amiſians defendyng themſelues many • imies iſſuyng prouokyng alſo fight hande hande mithridates ſent much vi • ual armure munition cabeiris wintered gathered army • cabeira tovvne higher aſia fotemen fortie thouſande horſemen foure thouſand spring come lucullus wente againſt king mountaynes whyche hadde garded kéepe lucullus make continuall 〈◊〉 happe ſhould b • man king bloud named phoenix chiefe gard lucullus approched made fire mithridates yéelded himſelfe power lucullus ſo without ſtoppe went cabeira hauing fighte horſemen kyng lucullus ouercome one fight horſemen▪ pompey generall horſe brought king aunſvvered boldly princely ſaying king ouercome retired hilles pompeyus captayne horſemen taken broughte mithridates wounded aſked thanke woulde giue ſaued anſwered thou art friend lucullus giue thée great thanke thou béeſt enimie deliber thus aunſwered pompeyus barbarian woulde haue king haue killed king ſayd would hurte vertue deſtitute fortune preparing continually fight lucullus refuſing ſought way come vpon hill certaine scythian named olcabas hadde bin long fugitiue lucullus bycauſe hadde ſaued many fight horſemen hée admitted lucullus table priuie counſell ſecretes octauius fleeth lucullus came tent midde day reſt would haue gone force girded ſhort ſworde manner angry kepte backe ſaying hadde earneſt thing tell therefore woulde haue awake aunſwering thatnothing ſo good health ruler nothing ſo good lucullus health tooke hys horſe fledde mithridates eyther meaning euill ſuſpected hys doyng anger compting himſelfe diſhonored accuſed another scythian called sobadacus woulde flée lucullus therefore sobadacus taken whereas lucullus woulde goe playne bycauſe enimies horſemen better could ſée none way foūd caue hunter wilde beaſtes expert vnknowen wayes whome paſſed ſecret wayes came vpō head mithridates came downe auoyding fieldes horſemen encamped flaſh water enimyes face wanting victual ſente cappadocia corne ſkirmiſhed enimies made flée till king came camp haſt amazed made themthe romanes great feare ac • turne ſo afrayd romanes fledde vp mountaynes perceyue enimies ceaſſed thoughte fledde enimies well chaced ſo greatly made afrayde mithridates ſent letter euery victory great part mithridates vvrighteth victory horſemen beſt lay awaite brought victuall lucullus cappadocia hoping bring thē famine themſelues cyzico great argument ſo bycauſe lucullus cappadocia frō might ſhutte king horſemen méetyng firſt forragers ſtreight place would tarrie till came open place made horſes ſtreight vnprofitable vnto romanes therefore quickly order helpe place came forthe fighte killed king men holpen ſtreyghte way fotemen droue ſome vpon fellowes ſome made flée heapes flong downe eſcapinga right romane forragers king horſemen ſtreight night ranne camp affirmed onely ſaued nature made loſſe greater mithridates lucullus ſhoulde knowe loſſe thinking lucullus lacke horſemen woulde hauethe king feare ſette vpon determined flée feare told friend tent warning giuen ſente away theyr geare haſtily night cariage made great thruſtingthe king army fleeth togither gate whiche armye perceyuing knowwing caried coniecturing worſe feare gréeued token giuen brake vp trenche fledde aboute fielde confuſedly euery man well coulde without captaynes ſtaying warning mithridates hearde theſe haſty diſorderly doings ranne tent among would haue ſayd ſomewhat man giuing eare hym beyng 〈…〉 thruſt 〈…〉 flyo •• thruſte people fall getting horſe hee fledde mountaines lucullus vnderſtāding feate y• forager ſéeing flight enimies ſent many horſmen follow bringing footemen cariera reſte campe commaunded ſpoile kylled al ſeeyng veſſels gold ſiluer coſtly garmentsthe ſouldiours • lvvayes gyuen ſpoyle forgot commaundement taken mithridates chaūced cut burden one mule bare golde falling ſo buy let king go fledde comans thence mithridates fleeth tigranes vvho vvoulde ſee hym tigranes tenne thouſande horſe woulde ſee hym commaunded vſe like king hys townes wherefore mithridates deſperation kingdome ſente bacchus eunuch palace kil ſiſters wiuesthe king ſēdeth kil ſiſters vvlues daughter concubine wer diſpatched ſome ſword ſome poyſon ſome halter pitifully capitaines mithridates garniſons ſawe moſte parte yeelded lucullus ſetting thing order ſayled aboute citties pontus tooke armaſt heraclea sinope helde iuſtily ſea fought valiantly while beſteged burned great ſhips fled ſmala dreame lucullus ſaueth citie sinope antolycus vvas one liued • lucullus lefte citye frée againe reaſon dreame whych ſay antolycus didde make warre hercules againſte amazones driuen tempeſt sinope tooke cittie ruled sinopeans hys image greate veneration whiche fledde wrapped linnen bound faſt cary lucullus knowing nothing hauing hearde hee thought ſawe hym call nexte daye commaunding carried image ſhewe hee ſaide ſame ſée night dreame cauſed sinope bee ſtill inhabited amyſios alſo oute whyche fledde ſca vnderſtanding inhabited athenienſes lord ſea made populare ſtate ſometime obeyed sinope reſtored libertie perſian king reſtored libertie alexander ſubiects againe king pontus taking pittie deſirous honour example alexander athenienſes nation hée lefte libertie wyth ſpéede reuoked sinopeans owne cittie thus reſtored taking made league machare mithridates ſonne king boſphorus offring crowne golde ſoughte mithridates tigranes come aſia whyche dydde owe fourthe parte fruit sylla putte vppon payne hée tooke taxe houſes ſeruauntes made ſacrifices victorye thoughe warre hadde beene fyniſhed ſacrifice ended marched two choiſe lucullus vvyth ſmall armye againſt greate king legion fiue hundred horſe againſt tigranes woulde deliuer mithridates paſſing euphrates requyring anlye money barbarian wente men made warre vpon thought good intermedle betwéene tigranes lucullus man durſte tell tigranes lucullus commyngtelli • g truth euill revvarded tolde fyrſte hanged one troubled hys city hearde ſente mithrobarzines wyth twoo thouſande horſe ſtoppe lucullus courſe hée appointed mancaeo mancaeus keepeth chiefe cittie kéepe tigranocerta whiche cittie haue ſayde king builded owne honor whiche called noble appointed paine whoſoeuer broughte hysthe defence tigranocerta goodes thither ſhoulde confiſcate hée made wall aboute fifty • cubites hyghe bottom whyche full ſtables horſe suburbes hee hadde builded hys pallaice garden verye faire parkes fiſhepondes harde bee made ſtrong forte whiche committing mancaeo rode aboute countrey togather men lucullus firſt conflict ouerthrewe mithrobarzane chaſed sextilius ſhut mancaeus tigranocerta ſpoylyng place without wall entrenched forte cittie broughte engine vndermined wall thus sextilius occupied tigranes gathering two hundred fyfty thouſand footemen fyftye thouſande horſemen ſent ſixe thouſande horſe afore tigranocerta paſſing thoroughe romanes carried away kyngs concubine taken reſt armie tigranes ſente agaynſte lucullus mithridates commyng fyrſte hys ſight counſelled hym fyghte romaynes range hys horſemen waſte countrey driue famine coulde mean hée vſed lucullus cyzico loſte hys féeble armye tiranes laugheth mithridates quicke ſaying tigranes tigranes laughed counſell came forth order battaile ſéeyng little number romanes ſayde theſe bée ambaſſadors many ennimies bée fewe lucullus hadde perceiued fytte hill beyond tigranes lucullus vvinneth hill commaunded hys horſemen giue charge front tourne giue place purpoſe bring army oute order meane tyme ledde footman hill perceyued ſawe ennimye diſordered runnyng partes thoughe hadde victorie carriage vnder hill cried haue gotte victorye fellowes firſte hée ſette vppon carriage fléeyng confuſion ranne vppon footemen footemenne vppon horſemenne ſo fowle fléeyng oute hande gone farre purſue romaynes killed tournyng vppon diſordered carriage came driuen among thē al afflicted none knowing ye lucullus hath victorye truth ouerthrow began excéeding ſlaughter without anye ſpoile lucullus forbiddē threat therfore treading vpon bracelet chaines continued y• murder hundred twenty furlōgs til night came vpon thē returne ſpoyled lucullus contente victorie manceus lefte tigranocerta vnarmedthe valiantnes greeke ſouldiors al gréeke mercenarie ſouldiours ſuſpected fearing taken got ſtaues went togither wer quiet manceus came vpon barbarian armed wrapped cloakes aboute theyr armes ſtead tergales courage fought againſt euer killed kepte armoure diuided betwéen thought got ſufficient tooke ſome little tent called romanes receyued thus tigranocerta taken ſpoyled verye riche new builded inhabited moſte honorably tigranes mithridates went gathering another army whyche made mithridates generall thynkyng fytte beeyng taught owne loſſes hee ſente alſo parthian requiring aide lucullus ſent ambaſſadors alſo requiring kyng eyther toa policie parthian king help medle either ſecretly promiſed performed none mithridates gathered armour euerye cittie manner armenian campe whyche hée choſe thréeſcore tenne thouſande footemen halfe horſemen lette go theſe diuided band company italian diſcipline tooke trayned men pontus lucullus comming towarde mithridates helde footemen halfe horſemen vpon hill reſte horſemen tigranes ledde méeting wyth romaine forager ouercome whiche romanes foraged ſafely euen place next mithridates encamped rayſyng muche duſte perceyued tigranes came whoſe purpoſe haue ſhutte lucullus middſt perceyued ſent beſt horſemen encounter tigranes farre coulde compell leaue raungyng kéepe campe prouoked mithridates fight encamped tigranes amd mithridates flyelli could moue tyl famme oppreſſed diſolued al purpoſe tigranes went furtheſt parte armenia mithridates ponius reſt hys owne army hauyng foure thouſand many tigranes lucullus folowed driuen alſo want mithridates outgoing mette mithridates ouer throvveth fabrus fabio lefte lucullus ouerthrew hym killing fiue hundred fabio taking freſh ſeruauntes fabius ouerthrovveth mithridates vvhich ſore hurt campe foughte againe whole day fighte doubtfull till mithridates hurt knée ſtone vnder eye darte caried away ſpéed many dayes one refrayned fight feare king health multitude hurte agarians nation scythia cure mithridates vſing agarenes king pluſitions poyſon serpent medicine cauſe euer king fabius came triarius another captaine lucullus owne army receyued power authoritie fabio long mithridates comminga maruelous vvinde breaketh fight fight ſuch winde neuer felt tore tentes beate beaſtes abroade ſtroke downe ſome men thus went backe told triarius haſt ouerthrovve • lucullus comming triarius deſirous fight came ſet vpon former watch night fight equall king wing got better diſperſed enimies driuing footemen foule mire wera romaine captaine like ſeruant vvoūdeth king killed bycauſe could ſtirre horſemen ſent chaſed playne vſing valiauntlye brunt victorie til captaine romane band running ſeruant gaue great wounde thyghe bycauſe thought hée could ſtrike harneſſe backe next ſtreight killed mithridates carried y• hinder part king frends cauſed retreat blowē ſoldiours hauing manifeſt victorie folowing egrely bycauſe ſtraunge called wer much troubled feare leaſte ſome inconuenience badde • ene timotheus king phiſition ſtopped wound ſhewed king vnto thē aboue come thethe kyng shevved ſouldiours field ſtoode thronging aboute bodye euen alexander india macedonian afrayde ſhewed ſelfe cured shyppe mithridates came hymſelf blamed cauſed fight ende daye ledthe romaynes forſake campe great number romayne captaines flaine army againſt romaynes campe fled fearfully whē y• dead ſpoiled thē found xxiiij tribune cl centurians ſuch number captain ſeldome hath bin found ſlaine romaine army mithridates went armenia romaynes call armenia leſſe taking victuall coulde carried could burned lucullus whome thoughte follow hym ſhold haue none romane senator named attilius fled attilius killed ſuſpition countrey bicauſe condemned great credite fauor mithridates taken one would betray bicauſe senator king would put torture killed coūſell tormented cruelly frée made men ſuffred al departe vnhurt bicauſe maiſters cōmandement lucullus encamped nigh mithridates lieutenāt aſia ſent proclamed army romaynesdi •• entiō vvyth romaynes accuſed lucullus bicauſe made war longer oughte army ſhold go hym didde obey haue goodes confiſcate whiche béeing tolde armye went al away ſaue fewe poore fearing lucullus lefte alone paine tarried ſtil lucullus thus war betwéene lucullus mithridates ſurely ended finiſhed broke vp italy rebelled moleſted ſea full théeues famine oppreſſed thinke good take another ſo great warre hande till deliuered thoſe incommodities mithridates heard went cappadocia fortified kingdome romanes winking hys doings till ſcoured ſeas whiche done pompey y• worker aſia war mithridates began againe pompey ſent general therfore bicauſe y• act pompey ſea hée came againſte mithridates parte pompeis feat put none proper writing ſhortely repeate run euer mithridates made mithridates filleth ſea vvith pyrats firſt war againſte romanes ruled aſia sylla buſied grecia thinking ſhould long holde aſia ſpoyled euery place haue ſaide ſet pirats ſea whiche firſt fewe litle boat vexed ſuch met war grew gotten great ſhips taking great gaine ceaſſe though mithridates ouercome made truce fled y• loſte liuyngs country thorow war fallen extreame pouertie left land ſought commoditie y• ſea firſt brigandine foiſts little galley roued archpirats leader general army vnwalled citties ſpoiled appointed neyther woulde haue thē chaſed ſo▪ ſhould carried one another without profitte méete mighte ſerue one anothers turne ſhut vp within compaſſesthe maner appo •• mēts pompey hauing thus fledde chaſe ſhould exceed far bethe diligence pompey caried aboute fighting mighte ſpéedily done ſayled hauing ouerſéene weaſt fortie dayes came rome thence brunduſe brunduſe eaſt ſo long way afrayde ſodayne quicke paſſage great preparation feare glory▪ inſomuche pirate hoped haue bin good truely haue put paine ynoughe beyng afraid left expugnations city reſorted wonted holdes hole sea ſcowred pompey without fight rouers taken captaines euery place part wente cilicia great army many engins thinking ſhould haue hadde manye fyghtes beſiegings rocky tower néeded none glory greate power makingthe pira •• gyue ouer afrayde thinking came fyght ſhoulde finde gentleneſſe fyrſt deliuered cragus cragus anticragus▪ hilles • lycia parte taurus anticragus greateſt fort mountaine men cilicia order yéelded themſelues alſo muche armour ſome ready ſome made readye deliuered ſhippes ſome vpon ſtocks ſome apte ſayle braſſe yron gathered purpoſe ſailes cable diuerſe matter number priſoners ſome band ranſome ſome worke ſtuffe pompey burned ſhips toke priſoners ſente theyr countreys manye founde gra •• made bycauſemany reſtored beyond hope thought dead pirate ſéemed come warre malice lacke liuing hée commaunded inhabite mall •• • dana epipha ••• anythe pirate appoynted inhabite hard place coaſt cilicia place deſolate voyde men hard parte cilicia ſome ſent • yma • hai • thus pyrats warre thought moſt daungerous ended dayes pompey ſhippes tooke •• xij deliuered three hundred ſixe city fortes ſtrong place 120 pirate ſlayne fighte 〈◊〉 theſe thing done ſpéedely beyonde opinion romanes highly extolling pompey yet cilicia thoſe generall warre againſt mithridates▪ like authoritie ruler alone would inuade make warre make friend foe r • whome thought good armye italy gaue authoritiethe large commiſsion pompey whiche neuer ſo giuen none peraduenture called great warre mithridates ended captaynes pompey gathering hys armye aſia dyd encamp confynes mithridates mithridates hadde choyce army hys owne thirtie thouſande footemen thrée thouſande horſemen defended place whiche waſted lucullus want victuall wherfore many fugitiues wēt ſome threwe downe headlongs ſome pulled eye ſome burned therefore fewer fugitiues wēt frō feare puniſhmēt cō • umed want therfore ſent embaſſadors pompey knowe condition might make peace anſwered thouanſvvere pompey mithridates deliuer fugitiues commit thy ſelfe v mithridates heard aſked y• fugitiues thought whē ſaw afraid ſware would neuer make peace romanes couetouſneſſe deliuered none nothing pryuye thus didde pompey laying ambuſhe horſemen bad go front king battaile prouoke came foorth gyue place thoughe ouercome andfight horſemen bryng place ambuſhe whyche retournyng mighte gette kynges campe fledde whyche hadde beene done déede king fearyng hadde broughte oute hys footemen ſo retired thys ende fyrſte attempt horſemen betwéene pompey mithridates king moleſted want compelled go backe ſuffer pompey come parte thinking waſted place ſhoulde ſuffer many inconueniences prouided victuall come behind hym going eaſtwarde againſte mithridates made many tower trench againſte compaſſed ſpace fyue hundred furlong coulde nowe eaſilye come victualls king ſtoppe entrenching▪ eyther feare ignorance euils nowe come vppon oppreſſed againe wyth want kylled beaſts cariages onelye horſes ſpared whiche ſcarcelyethe king fle • th hurt none tooke pledge went way long toke sinope coueting amiſus made warre caluiſio lieutenant time caeſar pompey debate till aſander priuate enimie droneaſander aſia romanes otherwiſe occupyed made warre caeſar ouercome pompey returning aegipt hill scotio father ouercame trian • ouercome fledde sinope thouſand horſemen caeſar hauing leyſure follow ſente domitius againſt whome deliuered citie vppon condition peace went away horſemen whoſe horſe killed much gréeued conueyed ſhippe fledde pontus gathering ſome • ythians sauromatians tooke theudocia panticapaea old aduerſarie aſandro comming againe vpon horſemen wantyng horſe vſed fight foote ouercome pharn • ce alone fighting valiauntlye till hée wounded died pharnaces ſlaine priuie • • fiftye yeares olde x • yeares king boſphorus pharnaces loſte kingdome whiche c caeſar gaue mithridates pergamo holpen hym well aegipt nowe frée pontus bythinia preſident ſent euery yeare coutries pompey giuen although caeſar blamedspiritual office comagene taking pompey parte againſt yet let haue ſauing ſpiritual office comagene tranſlated archelous nicomedes long bothe theſe thoſe c caeſar antonius gaue wer made prouinces romaynes augustus caeſar hadde w ••• e aegipt romaine taking lighte occaſions againſte euery man therfore dominion encreaſyng thys warre mithridates pontus euxinus ſandes aegipt floude euphrates hiberians pillers hercules maye wel called greate victorie pompey captaine euen ſo haue alſo affrica sirene appion king houſe lagida baſe gaue teſtament aegipt left compaſſe inwarde ſea ⸪ ende romaine ciuill vvarres vvith king mithridates ¶ romanes warre spanyardes appian alexandria mountaynes pyrene ſtretche • toſc • ne ſea north ocean celtes iberia parte spayn • eyther fide iberu • floud novv ebr • ce •• iberia part vvhiche novv called arragon called galles inhabit part toward eaſt iberian celtiberians toſcane sea alſo pilloures hercules north ocean towarde weaſt ſo iberia compaſſed sea except moū taines pyrene greateſt higheſt hilles europe nation make nauigation compaſſe come pillers hercules doe go winter weaſt ocean paſſe brittayne whyche doe brittayne novve englande commoditie tydes going comming paſſage made ſayling halfe day place ocean neyther romanes themſelues none empire haue paſſed therefore greatneſſe iberia called spayne confedered one prouince almoſt incredible spayne great region • ight furlong maketh mile brea • th terme thouſand furlong length muche manye nation inhabite diuers name many nauigable flouds people inhabite firſt got ſuche matter minded ſhew ſo much may apperteyne romanes ſaye ſuppoſe celtes paſſed pyrenian hilles aud dwelled among inhabitant countrey whiche manifeſt name celtiberians came phoenitians long ſayling often thither thinke inhabite part likewiſe grecian ſayled tarteſſus arganthonius king ſame tarteſſus novv tareſſa germania arganthonius lyued hundred fifty yeares ſtay iberia ſuppoſe arganthonius reigned spayne tarteſſus whiche citie sea coaſt nowe named carpteſſe beléeue temple hercules builded iphenia place calledthere vvere diuers hercules vvhereof one vvas tirus borne • leria another th • be borne al • umena pillers whiche day ceremony vſed manner phoeni • ians borne tirus borne thebe counted god countrey leaue haue care ſearch antiquity coaſt ſo plentifull rich carthagies deuiſed get romanes ſubdued one parte vexed continuall inuaſions till romanes put poſſeſſed al place townes ward came empire muche labour long time whiche reuolting diuers time againe ſu •• ued romanes diuided region thrée part ſent many preſidents got euery place warre kepte carthagies iberian celtiberians ſhew volume romanes firſte made warre carthagies firſt vvarre carthage fo • si •• l •• bycauſe warre made spayne muſt nedes ſhew hiſtorie whiche wright spayne cauſe haue comprehended booke warre sicelie • doe betwéene romanes carthagies iſlande romanes ſayled sicelie ſubdue place firſt warre carthagies sicelie dominion iſland olimpiades vvhich vvere playes made euery fiue yeares honour •• piter inſtitute hercules olimpia citie • lide amilchar 〈…〉 carthagies broken truce made warre sicelie cauſe whereof amilchar ſurnamed romane merchantes warre theſe cauſes amilchar barcha accuſed ofin firſt vvar vv •• care th • gy contrary faction whome came ſo greate detriment citie fauoure gouerned common wealthe whereof h • ſdruball called greate oneh • ſdruball whome giuen daughter marriage well beloued people pardoned alſo choſen captayne togither hanno called great againſthanno numidian accuſation yet depending whyche amilchar muſte gyue accompte doyngs warre warre numidia ended hanno called ca • thage certayne complayntes amilchar remayned captayne army alone hauing wyth hym aſdr •• • hys ſonne lawe wyth thys armye ſayled g • • •• de • novve cale • bee evvo • land ••• theſt part • ra • • next ſtre • ghte •• lla • ar moleſt iberian ſpoyling theyr lande hadde deſerued anye ſuch thing ſoughte occaſion abſente hys countrey making warre wynne fauour people deuiding pray gaue parte souldyoures parte hée ſente carthage parte gaue chiefe citie fauoured hym whileſt dyd thus certayne greate men others iberia conſpired togither • kylled hym thus ſent certayne carte laden wyth wodde whyche followed wyth armoure thys carthagies laughedstratageme iberian fyrſte perceyuing policie perceyued fygh • e begunne iberian ſelte carte fyre whereby ox dryuen vpen numidian fire diſperſed euery ox ra •• e hyther thyther muche diſordered affi • cane brake aray whereby iberian came vppon amilchar •• yne kylled amilchar barcha reſt fought carthagies béeyng allured pray iberia ſente another arm • aſdruball barchas ſonne law andaſdruball committed rule army ioyned anniball ſonne barcha lieutenant wiues 〈…〉 part ibe ••• afrayd ſent four embaſſadors rome wherfore romanes willing power carthagies growe much ſent embaſſadors c • thage agréed iberus ſhould end carthagies dominion spaine andthe coad • tiēs romanes ſhould make warre vpon ſubiects beyoude floud carthagies g •• beyonde floud moue warre saguntines greeke people iberia ſhoulde frée liue owne lawes whiche expreſſed league made betwéene romanes carthagies done ſlaue killed aſdruball whoſe maiſter cruelly kylled aſdruball killed before▪ whileſt taking order parte iberia obeyed carthage gone hunting whome ann • ball tormented moſt cruelly kylled army made anniball barcha captayne yong man welbeloued enimies amilchar barcha senate carthage agréed fearing power aſdruball amilchar laughe anniball rong man beganne • moleſt lawe friendes accuſing ſame • aults accuſed deade vſing people fauour whiche hated loſſes tyme barcha aſdruball required thoſe gift barcha anniball ſent ſpople ennimies ſent anniball helpe • hewing alſo would deſpiſed father ennimies except hée hadde nowe ſome regard might defene matter vnknowne anniball knew well ynough beginning deceyts would vppon thought good ſuffer ſuche enmity continuallye ſeare father grandfather done liue lyfe lighteneſſe carthagies vſ • ng vnthanke fullye ſyde hadde doone well common wealth rumor anniball childe hys anniball vvas • vv •• ne hys youth bee • n ••• ye romaine father commandement y• brought hym place hée made ſacrifices made hym laye hand vppon altare ſweare ſo ſoone rule common wealth ſhoulde bée mortall ennimie romanes therfore purpoſed put country great continuall danger feare might preſerue hys friend matter per • therfore ſaw aff •• ca good ſtate iberian vnder carthagies lyke continue obedience thoughte ſhoulde winne unmortall fame made warre agayne vppon romanes feare whereof carthagies ſhoulde occupied mighte good fortune ſuboue hys countrey empire worlde hée hoped romanes broughte downe none ſhoulde able matche wyth hym cha • nced otherwiſe yet hys enterpriſe ſhoulde honorable beginning myght bréede eſtimation paſied floude iber •• cauſed torboletanes whych nexte saguntines anniball pic •• th • ua •• el▪ g • •• te • ▪ 〈…〉 come comylaine saguntines made r • de vpō • one hurt perſ • aded ſēt theyr ambaſſadors carthage wrote letter priuilye whiche ſignified romanes practiſed • iberian carthage iuriſdiction reuolte saguntines didde procure ſame romaynes deceit left vndone wrote many letter till senate appointed saguntines ſhoulde profitable common wealth hee haning got occaſion practiſed torboletans agayn ſhould come complaine againe saguntines alſo ſent fiftéene ambaſſadoures hym anniball wylied declare controuerſies anū • ered woulde make romanes judge commanded anniball go hys campe night paſſing ryuer inuaded lande ſet hys artillerie agaynſt sagunt beſteged citie could take compaſſed ditche wall trench placing many garriſons continued ſiege fewe dayes wente came dyuerſe tymes saguntines great feare theſe ſodaine euils ſent ambaſſadours rome whome senate ioyned ambaſſadoures ſent firſte anniball putthe romaine ambaſſadoures forbidden •• ter anniballs campe remembraunce league would obey ſhoulde go carthage aceuſe hym wyth theſe ambaſſadoures went iberia came shyppes campe commanded anniball go ſurther wherefore went carthage wyth saguntine ambaſſadors ſhe •• ed league broken ſide accuſed saguntines ſaide done hurte subiectes saguntines contrary ſide called iudgement romanes ſayde iudgement vame matter muſte bee tryed force whiche romaine vnderſtoode ſome thought ayde bée ſente hand • saguntines ſome denyed affyrmyng saguntines comprehended league butthe romaynes helpe saguntines lefte frée bothe beſ •• gers beſieged muſte vſe lawes whiche ſentence pr • ua •• ed saguntines deſtitute help romanes oppreſſed famine continuallye aſſaulted annibal hearing cittie riche full golde gaue time reſt commaunded golde ſiluer publique priuate broughte market mixed lead yron ſhoulde bée vnprofitable annibal bycauſe hadde rather dye ſworde hunger mydnyght moſt darke came aſſailed watch carthagies looking ſuch thing killed many while ſome ſought ſome putte armour ſight long many carthagies ſlaine saguntines • whoſe decay beyng ſéene wals ſome woman leapt top houſes ſome hanged themſelues ſome killed firſt little childrē themſelues end sagunt great mighty city annibal vnderſtoode cone y• mony tooke many youth left tormented annibal nameth sagunt carthage spart • gena killēd thinking good citie ſituate ſea fertile ſoyle vnhabited made inhabitation carthage whiche nowe thinke call carthage spart • gena romaine ſent ambaſſadours carthage whiche ſhoulde require annibal breaker league vnleſſe wold confeſſe done ye common conſent except theythe manner romaine de ••• ance carthage wold deliuer hym denounce thē war preſently dyd ſo carthagies would deliuer annibal gaue deſyaunce ſaide done ſorte carthage ſcorned romane ambaſſador hee tooke vppe •• irt gawne ſaide garment carthagies bring war peace choſe wil aunſwered giue v thou liſteſt giuing war cried al one voice receiue ſent hannibal ouerrun al iberia league broken wherfore raunging euerye got ſome flattery ſome threat ſome force gathered many ſouldioures ſhewyng purpoſe didde hys meaning goe italy ſende ambaſſadors galles ſearch way alp carry army rome leaue aſdrubal spaine romaynes thinking muſt make war carthagies spaine affrica ſuſpecting comming italy ſente tiberius 〈…〉 affrica one hundred thrèeſcore twoo ſhips two 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 longue generalles didde labya ſhewen booke libyan warres ſente 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈…〉 scipio thréeſcore shyppes ten thouſande ſ •• temen ſeauen hundred horſemen whome ioyned 〈◊〉 brother c • cornelius scipio one 〈◊〉 〈…〉 heard marchants 〈◊〉 anniball comming italy paſſed alpes • ra ••• ſhoulde haue taken italian vnp • c •• ted deliuered army hys brother galley ſayled 〈◊〉 captaynes ſucceeded hym thys war tyll anniball driuen italy ſixteene yeares ſhewed v booke followeth wherein alſo wee ſhewe annibals actes therefore name booke annibals name cneus warre romanes didde nothing worthy wrytyng till brother retourned vnto hym hys tyme expired romanes ſent conſulls hys ſucceſſors make warre againſte anniball hée vnderconſull ſent againe spaine ſo twoo scipio • didde make warre agaynſte aſdruball spaine carthagies prouoked fight syphax kyng numidia called home aſdrubal wt part armye wherby scipio eaſily gette reſte spaine mayne citties yéelded fréely apte gouerne armyes alſo perſuaſion winne city obedience carthagies compounding syphax ſente aſdruball spaine wyth menne wyth thyrtye elephantes adioyning two captaines mago aſdrubal gyſgons ſonnes tyme scipio ſharpe warre yet ſuperiors whiche manye ſouldiours carthagies elephant conſumed till winter beyng come carthagies went winter turditanes pub scipio ſtayed ca •• ulone cncus orſonae ſhewed pub scipio killed aſdrubal comming went citie wyth fewe ſée enimies power going far vnaduiſedlye circumuented contrary horſemen killed al cneus scipio knowing chaunce hys brother ſent hys ſouldiors fetche artillerie wyth 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 killed affricanes made fraye whiche cneus vnderſtanding came foorth haſte light harneſſed helpe hys men wherof former killed putte backe scipio driuen tower whiche ſette fyre burned hym hys companye thus two scipio killed men certainly great worthineſſe greatly loued lamented spaniard committed themſelues ſakes romaine obedience knowen rome romanes tooke grieuouſly ſent marcellus little come sicilie claudius wyth nauy ten thouſande footemen two thouſand horſemen mony victuall ſufficient make warre spaine whiche notable thing done carthagies encreaſed much nowe wellnigh gotten spaine romaynes béeing dryuen little ſtreight ſo caſte pyrene hils whiche rome hearde grieued afraide leaſt while anniball waſted thoſe region whiche ſides italie army ſhoulde inuade another way therfore thoughe woulde neuer ſo muche coulde leaue spaine fearing warre spaine woulde ſtretch italy therefore appointed day determine generall war spaine whiche prouince none nowe offered hymſelfe trouble feare senator ſtill feare till cornelius scipio ſonne publius carnelius scipio offereth ſeruice time feare ſlaine spaine yong man xxiiij yeres age wiſe accompted noble mind ſtep forth boldly ſpake lamentably harde happe hys father vncle affirming alone left reuenge death thing added great eloquence vehemenete ſo bythe 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 diuine inflamation promiſed reſtore onely spaine alſo take carthage wherefore thoughte boaſte muche lyke young man got fauoure people whiche ſtroken greate feare • eare better hope promiſed comforted ſo spayne decréed vnto hym foreſyght would ſome thing worthy nobleneſſe hys mynd antients call greatneſſe minde raſhneſſe rather courage scipio perceyued ſpake people ſorte ſpake himſelf adding youth ſhould impedunent man exhorted eldersthe modeſtle scipio take prouince woulde willingly gaue place whē man found take went eſtimation admiration men prouince whiche hée led • footemen fiue hundred horſemen annibal vexing italie greater number could ſpared mony wage furniture eightéene galleis wyth hée ſayled spaine reteining footemen horſemen left putte muſtered purged whole army ſpake nobly ſo hys fame wente ſhortelye ouer spaine whiche wearye carthagies rule vertue scipians ſtucke mindes thought houſe scipio ſent god whiche thyng scipio vnderſtanding pretended thing diuine inſtigation vnderſtoode hys enimies lodged foure ſundrye place euery campe fiue twenty thouſande footemen two thouſande horſe al mony munition well sea land alſo captiues pledge spaine cittie béefore called sagunt nowe named carthage mago kéep treaſure x mē thought good make •• ſt attempt moued ſmall number great abundance ſeate cittie forte receipte warre ſea land againſt spaine ſhorter paſſage liby • theſe conſiderationsthe diligence scipio conferring wyth man marched ſunne ſet riding night toward carthage daye made ditche tre • che carthagies amazed ſame daye prepared giue aſſaulte ſette engins ſcales scipio beſiegeth nevve carthag • againſt al part one wall lowe compaſſed poole ſea wherefore place negligently kepte ſouldiors y• made ſtrong yt night arrowes ſtones scipio tooke ſtreightes porte enimies ſhips ſhould eſcape hee truſting vertue haped take citie day commanded part ſouldiors mount engine throwe vpon enimies aboue run engine wall lawe ſorce ſide mago placed r men gate taking occaſion ſhould ſally ſwords bicauſe thoſe ſtreights thei could vſe ſpears cōmaunded kéepe wals tower engine ſtones dart arrow boldlye abyd y• n̄ght alarm made part omitted endeuor while ſtones arrow caſt hand engine vſed ſlings euerym • n beſt kinde armoure coulde handle band scipio hardly handled y• carthagies kept gate iſſued ſwords made hotte fray brought engine much hurt tooke till romaynes whoſe courage encreaſeth •• p • ril • made retire defended wall ••• • •• ed fought without ſl •• ng romaynes mighte eaſ ••• e ſette engine wall agaynſt hadde ſkirmiſhed wente vppe wall ſo againe r • • ne putte fighte scipio looked aboute exhorted places▪ perceiued toward y• ſouth ye place wall low ye water fall frō according courſe ſea ſo ye breaſt •• legge whiche thing perceyued matter diligently examined ſpent reſt day ſea encreaſe going aboute encouraging ſouldyoures doe souldyoures ſayde nowe time whileſt help god commeth v ſcale wall ſide sea openeth way vnto v goe ſaying thus toke ladder firſt beganne mount ga • others ſtaying ſouldyoures takyng matter hand romanes got vp whome perceyued vpon certayne tower badde trumpetours drummes goe vp wall encourage romanes wyth noyſe thing affraying enimie fledde citie bin taken ſome romanes fought ſeme ranne opened gate scipio entred army nevv carthag • taken mago yeeldeth citie fledde houſes place mago broughte ſouldyoures market place whiche béeyng ſoone ouercome fledde caſtell scipio aſſaulted able defend men vtterly diſcouraged yéelded scipio ſo greate citie beyng taken one day fourth day comming extolled infinite prayſe men beléeuing thing rather councell god menan opinion scipio thing inſpiration god ſo perſuaded himſelfe opinion mainteyned life taking beginning time cauſe hée woulde many time goe alone capitoll ſhutte dores taught god wherefore day scipio▪ image broughte capitoll whereas others taken common place scipio hauing taken citie whiche ſhoulde receptacle ſtorehouſe thing warre peace whiche greate plentie armoure ſhotte engine furniture name thirtie thrée ſhippes corne manye thing layde vp common market beſide ••• rie golde▪ ſiluer well coyned vncoyned pledge spayne captiues rome made ſacrifice god ye next day triumphed prayſed ſouldyoures hée turned tale towneſmen renuing memorie scipio deliuering bondage w • ē came countreys mighte winne hym theſe thing thus done rewarded moſt liberallyrevvards romanes firſte mounted vvall • grounde golde vvas giuen firſte mounted wall ſeconde gaue halfe ſo much third others like proportion yuorie gold ſiluer left pray put ſhippes ſent rome thrée dayes togither holy dayes made bycauſe ſéemed citie reſtored auntiente dignitie ſo manye euils spayne carthagineans aſtoniſhed great acte done ſo valiantly ſo ſpéedely scipio leauing ſtrong garriſon citie commaunded parte wall next fenne made higher went ſubdue reſt hiberia going himſelfe ſome ſending friēds taking force reſiſted carthagies captaynes aſdrubals one ſonne • ilcare hauyng army ſtrangers furtheſt part spayne ſonne giſgo exhorted city remained carthagies obedience continue ſame greate armye ſhould come ſhortly help ſent another mago next place gather men entred countrey lerſanes reu • lled carthagies beſéegelerſan • •••• granata citie scipio comming vpon wente granata ſet camp citie next day eaſily ouercome scipio put campe got grannata mago occupyed gathering souldyourescerbona yet spayne cerbona power hée myght encounter romanes many spanyardes ioyned mago many numidian commaunded maſsiniſſa aſdruball kepte campe footemen theſe nation mago maſsiniſſa horſemen camp army thus scipio diuided horſemen ſent one part lelio againſt mago went agaynſt maſsiniſſa fight long ſharp dangerous numidian ſetting going backe comming againe fighte ſhotte scipio gaue token hys souldyoures romanes ſhoulde follow fyghte ſpeares numidian deſtitute ſhotte putte flight retired tentes scipio encamped tenne furlong ſtrong place deſired whole ſtrength carthagies lxx thouſande footemen fiue thouſande horſe thirtie elephant scipio third part therefore doubtfull durſt ioyne whole battell continued ſkirmiſhing whoſe victuall béeing almoſt ſpent army beginning lacke thought vnhonorable departe doe nothingthe valientnes scipio therefore making ſacrifice bringing armye mighte well hearde framing countenance looke though bin inſpired god ſaid accuſtomed angell hadde bin exhorted fighte reaſon whereof ſhoulde rather truſt power god scipio taketh occaſion euery thing encourage souldyoures number men chiefly bycauſe attemptes brought good effect power diuine multitude souldyoures make credite wordes hée cauſed ſouthſayers ſhew ſacrifices while ſpake thus hée eſpyed certayne birdes fléeyng vnto whome turning hym ſelfe badde souldyoures beholde ſaying god dyd ſende token victory alſo way birdes flewe turned hys bodye one rapte diuine furie wyth hys eye fixed cryed wherfore armye turned hither thither euerye man exhorted certayne victory ſawe thing come paſſe woulde ſuffering courage ſouldyoure relent made delay one taken one diuine furie token ceremony theyr good lucke ſhewed ſayd muſt obeyed y• battell muſt made whē souldyoures refreſhed thēſelues cōmanded take armor cōmitted y• horſemē sillano • otemē l • lio martio aſdruball mago maſsiniſſa whē ſaw taken though fayned flee turne againe romanes continually heeles kepte ſhooting bycauſe ſo nigh footemen ouerlayd libyan continued day although scipio ranne aboute exhorted fight▪ would neuer giue fierce onſette til delyueringthe courage scipio horſe ſquire toke ſouldioures target wente alone middeſt betwéene army cry helpe romanes help scipio perill therefore nigh ſeing ſo great perill hearing moued ende fighte cerbona whiche victorye doubtfull 〈…〉 victory • cerbona eight hundred romanes ſlaine tenne thouſand fiue hū dred enimies time carthagies made haſt gone scipio followed endamaged al wayes poſſible come place ſtrong well watered full neceſſaries ſo matter required ſéege scipio left sillanus hold wente winne reſt spaine carthagies beſéeged sillanus remoued went cales paſſe sea sillanus done much hurt could returned army scipio aſdruball amilchars ſonne whiche gathering men north ocean called brother anniball come italy ſo ſoone could whiche mighte doe aſdruball paſſeth mountaynes vnknowen scipio paſſed pirenian hilles nexte north celtiberians ſo romanes ignorant aſdruball came italy great iourneys meane ſeaſon liuius comming rome tolde scipio senate minded make hym captayne warre carthage thing scipio loked truſting woulde ſo ſent laelius fiue shyppes king syphax many giftes remember vnto friendſhip bin betwéene scipio aſke came africa whether would friend romanes whiche syphax bycauſe matter greate importance two gallies onely laelius wente vnto came porte carthage whiche come brought gallies vnknowen syphax againſt scipi • hauing benefite winde full ſayle entred port syphax receyued courteouſly talking priuately giuing faith ſent away commaunded carthagies layd new traynes againſte ſtayd perill scipio eſcaped came coaſt went thence ſaid whileſt scipio syphax ſate table wyth aſdruball hadde aſked many queſtions heethe opinion • carthage embaſſador • scip •• greatly wondered ſight modeſtie turnyng friend ſayd man ſcared onely warre alſo table time ſome •• erians celtiberians yet ſerue vnder hanno whome martius encounter kylled thouſande fiue hundred reſt fledde home ſeauen hundred horſemen ſeauen thouſand footemen hanno martius droue hyll wanting neceſſaries ſent martius compoſition whome hée commaunded delyuer captayne hanno ſugitiues •• en tell meſſage ſo tooke hanno hearing matter deliuered fugitiues martius▪ required alſo captiues whome receyued commaunded souldyoures bring certaine ſumme ſiluer playne bycauſe fitte aſke pardon keepe highe place whiche deſcended martius ſayde vnto well worthy deathethe victorie martius euery haue youre countreys ſubiect v rather make warre againſt v oure enimies yet content giue leaue goe ſafe putting youre armour whiche hearde gréeued denying ſharp fight made halfesouldyoures vvill deliuer armoure ſlayne halfe eſcaping mago long come hannos campe wyth ſixtie shippes hearyng hys calamitie returned gades beyng wante put greate feare hée reſted sillanus ſente citie caſtaces héecaſtaces receyued enimie ſette hys campe towne made scipio knowe ſending afore fytte ſéege followed way gotteilliturga citie illiturga whyche tyme olde scipio friende romanes hée ſlayne reuolted priuily pretendyng receyue romanes army friende delyuered carthagies wherfore scipio béeyng angrie ouercame foure houres tooke héere scipio hadde wounde hys necke ſo greate scipio vvounded hée woulde departe fyghte tyll hée hadde gotte citie thys cauſe armye deſpiſing pray kylled woman child vtterly deſtroyed came caſtace beſéeged thrée partes dyd aſſaulte hée myghte gyue caſtaces tyme repente bycauſe heard aboute ſuche matter hadde kylled captain garriſon reſiſted deliuered citie scipio leauing certaynethe caſtaces yeelde scipio honeſt man citie kéepe wente towarde carthage ſending sillanus martius sea ſpoyle waſt could citie called aſtapa whiche alwayes ofaſtapa carthagies deuotion ſawe beſéeged knewe came vnder romanes power ſhoūlde ſolde ſlaues brought theyr goodes rich market place compaſſing ſame wyth wodde badde wiues child goe vp ſware fiftie chiefe citie citie taken ſhoulde kyll wiues chyldren ſette thethe deſperatiō aſtape •• wodde fyre burne themſelues hadde called god vnto witneſſe ſame iſſued vppon martius looking ſuche thyng whyche violence ſhotte horſemen putte flighte footemen ſtayd aſtapeans fought valiantlye withoute hope remedye romanes number aſtapeans inferioure vertue ſlayne fiftie whyche citie kylled woman chyldren kindled fyre lepte martius maruelling vertue refrayned burning houſes theſe doyngs scipio fell ſicke martius ruled scipio ſicke army ſo souldyoures ſpente vppon pleaſure thought hadde receyued worthy rewardes theyr ſeruice bycauſe hadde nothyng lefte whome scipio aſcribed glory hys noble actes reuolted martius hadde campe ſhortly rewarde willed ſo ſoone might come carthage forage theſe letter redde ſome ſuſpected ſome euill thinking hurt thought good giue credite agréed goe carthage whither scipio vnderſtoode comming leucon fight compulſion araſchians aſſembled night numanti • ▪ ſtrong citie choſe arathon leucon captaines warre fuluius came thither thirde daye camped foure twenty furlong citie maſsiniſſa ſent thrée hundred horſmen thirtye elephant come went ſtraight fight fuluius vvinneth looſeth placed elephant backe army fight begonne opened way elephants▪ celtiberians ſawe horſe afraid fled walles romayne elephant ſhoulde brought wal fierce fight till one elephant hurte heade ſtone wall begannean elephant hurt loſeth victorie rage vnruly furie turne vpon fellow thruſting treading downe euery one met difference betwéene friend foe reſt elephant made afrayde lyke trode thruſte downe romaine ſouldiours whiche thing elephant feare w • nte doe taking euerye man theirelephants common enimies ennimye wherefore falſhoode called common enimies therfore romanes without order fled away numantines ſaw walles came forth chaſed flewe foure thouſande tooke thrée elephant muche armour many enſignes celtiberians flight romaine two thouſand killed fuluius hadde gotten ſlaughter beſieged axenium cō monaxenium market enimyes thinges ſell▪ good loſe men retired night bleſus killed campe wherefore hée ſente bleſus capitayne horſmen nation nigh friend wanted horſemen bande horſe way fell ambuſhe celtiberians▪ whiche beyng knowne friendes fledde bleſus fought killed many romanes whiche loſſes ouerthrowes ocile cittie ocile galacia whiche romanes treaſure munition yéelded celtiberians fuluius diſtruſting himſelfe afraid al thing kepte within campe winter defending well héethe mountain cauſe colde hote country coulde getting victuall▪ yet greatly troubled lacke bitterneſſe colde wherfore many souldyours partly goyng wood partly ſharpneſſe great colde periſhe yeare following claudius marcellus came fuluius claudius marcellus place bringing eighte thouſande footemen v c horſemen againſte whome enimies likewiſe ha • ſaide traines ocile taken pardoned another crafte auoyded went ſtreight ocile camped power fortune fauouring hym tooke cittie firſte aſſaulte whome pardoned receiuing ſome pledge thyrtie talentes golde thys modeſtie hearde nergobriges ſente meſſengers marcellus nergobriges vſe crafte know might haue peace commaunded ſende hundred horſemen promiſed ſo doe yet folowed tayle armye tooke ſome cariage notwithſtanding came brought hundred horſemen ſaide hurte carriage done errour ſome knewe couenauntes marcellus made hundred horſmen priſoners ſolde horſes ranged lande gaue pray ſouldioures encamped cittie ſawe engine broughte trench made ſente oute heraulte wearing woolf ſkinne aſke pardon whichethe vvar vvas ended brought rodde called caduceum vvherof embaſſadours peace called caduceatores denyed giue except aruacceans bellans titthians woulde ſewe whiche thoſe nation willinglye praying reaſonable payne beyng putte vppon mighte broughte league gracchus denied bicauſe hadde bin ſtrife marcellus ſent ambaſſadoures part rome diſpute controuerſies ſecretly wrote senate compounde matter deſired war might ended time thinking would glory ambaſſadoures friendes receyued theembaſſadors diuerſely vſed rome cittie enimies lodged without cittie manner senate would haue peace grieued brought ye romanes power nobilior would haue done generall spaine therefore senate aunſwered ambaſſadors marcellus ſhould declare pleſure forthwith ſent army spaine thensouldiours ta •• lotte▪ firſt time ſouldiors wer takē lot choice béene manye reproue conſulls vſyng themſelues truely ſincerely choiſe ſoldiors might ſēd lighter enterpriſes cauſe req •••• therfore ſéemed good take ſoldiors lotte whome l lucullus made generall cornelius scipio lucullus scipio lieutnant ſhortely gotte carthage numantia while lucullus comming marcellus proclaimed warre againſte celtiberians whome rendred pledge requiring yet deteyned hym long wente embaſſadoure rome cauſe vncertaine ſuſpition beléeued much thing happened perſuaded theſe people committe matter didde could marcellus procureth peace make end warre lucullus came thoſe controuerſies fyue thouſande aruacceans tooke nergobrigem marcellus wente numantia encamped within fyue myle citie droue enimies wherfore linteuon captain numantines cried ſaidlinteuon woulde deale marcellus come talke hée ſaide would leaue bellans titthians aruacceans marcellus accepted willingly commaunded money pledge deliuered receyued let thoſe people go frée end warre bellans titthians aruaceans comming lucullus lucullus partly deſire glorie partly néede poore ledde armie agaynſt vacceans whiche lucullus needie vaccei people iland neather spaine people celtiberia next aruacceans notwithſtāding senate determined nothing euer bin enimies people rome therefore paſſed floude tagus came tagus floud ta • luſitama citie cauc • encamped towne aſked came purpoſe moleſted carpetanes dvvel •• oud taio quiet reſt anſwered hee came helpe carpetanes iniured returned ye city romanes wente forrage kylled many vnderſtoode army brought forth mette fought caucaeans better til caucaeans ſlayne citie ſhotte fayled fledde good firme battell ſo thruſting together gate thrée thouſand ſlayne next day olde men came forth beſought lucullus tell might doe kéepe romanes fauour required pledge c talentes ſilner y• horſemen ſhoulde ſerue graunted ſaide woulde put garriſon citie denye put two thouſand choyce ſouldyoures citie whome commaunded take walles whiche béeyng done brought army killed without reſpect age thus extreame crueltie ſlaine callingextreame iniurie done romanes lucullus vpon god faith oth whiche romanes ſworne charging romanes infidelitie murthered twenty thouſande fewe except ſtrong rocky place lucullus ſpoyled citie gaue prey souldioures purchaſing immortall infamie name rome countrey aſſembled came playnes hils ſtrong townes carrying ſo muche could burning reſt lucullus ſhoulde haue profite lucullus made long iourney hard deſerte way came citie called enderacia theenderacia whiche twenty thouſand footemen fledde two thouſand horſemen lucullus ſuche fooliſhneſſe inuited compoſition whome obiected calamitie vacceans aſking woulde exhorte ſuche amitie lucullus angry obiection manner naught whereas ſhould rather angry themſelues waſted land▪ beſéeged citie made many trenches▪ continually prouoked fight one faire armour came many time forth horſehacke prouoked romane fighte hand hand man anſwered laughed ſcorned romanes wente leaping reioyeing home doyng oft gréeued scipio yong man came scipio fighteth combate killeth spaniarde forthe toke matter hande benefite fortune ouercame greate ſtraunger ſmall ſtature gaue courage romane night diuerſly affrighted horſemen barbarian whiche gone foraging romanes came coulde get citie ranne vpon camp great alarm citie like greate vehemence romanes made afrayde ſore troubling romanes afflicted wyth watche night compelled watche armoure accuſtomed meates countrey hauing neyther wyne ſalte oyle vinegre eatevvant ſalte ſodden wheate barlie muche fleaſhe dere hare without ſalte fell flixes whiche many dyed thus continued tyll hadde brought trench due height whiche done beat downe one part romanes perish wall entred citie valiantly repulſed retire vnawares fell fenne greate parte periſhed barbarian night following made vppe theyr wall length ſides oppreſſed wyth famine scipio promiſed ſhould fraude treatie whome faith giuen opinion hys vertue ende thys warre ſhoulde deliuer celtiberians c • ficeme gold tenne thouſande souldioures coates certayne number caitell fiftie pledge gold ſiluer lucullus could haue whoſe cauſe made warre thinking spayne bin full thoſe people hadde neyther doe theſe celtiberians much eſtéeme ſuche thing wente toward pallantia whiche citie pallantia citie • igh 〈◊〉 greater name power whyche many fledde therefore many counſelled leaue he▪ bycauſe hée heard was▪ wealthy riche followe councell went forage euer pallantine horſemen vpon ſo lacke victuall fayne remoue camp ſo ledde army ſquare battell pallantines euer following till came floud orius orius turditanes people granata went away midnight returned turditanes land wintered end hadde warre whiche lucullus made vacceans without authoritie senate therfore ſhuld come iudgemēt accuſed c ¶ notwithſtanding another part spayne called luſitania lyuing luſitania novv portugall owne lawes certayne captayne africa ſpoyle countreys obeyed romanes whē romanes killed ouerthrowen manilius calphurnius piſo romane captaynes killed ſyxe thouſande beſide terentius varro treaſourer whiche thing affrican proude runne ouer countreys ocean vettones hither spayne vvhome hearbe fetonie named captaine killed blaſtophenicians ſea ioyning vettones vnto beſéeged blaſtophenicians ſubiect romanes whyche ſay anniball mingle ſome carthage generation therfore called blaſtophenicians thys captayne hurte head ſtone dyed hys placeceſſaro ſuccéeded another called ceſſaro hée foughte wyth mummius come rome wyth another armye whome beingthe romanes ouerthrovven vnder mummius ouercome mummius chacing hym returned vppon followed diſorderly kylled tenne thouſande recouered hys prey hys owne campe whyche hée hadde loſt beſyde ſpoyled romanes campe tooke theyr enſignes whyche ſhewing throughout spayne made laughingſtocke romanes mummius nowe campyng ſtrong place exerciſed souldioures whyche hadde lefte whyche fiue thouſande durſt bryng playne tyll hadde recouered theyr courage luſitanes albeit inhabite ſyde floud tagus yet tooke armes waſted cuneans tributary cuniſtorges celtiberia romanes canchenus béeyng theyr captayne tooke cuniſtorges theyr greate citie paſſed sea pillers hercules ſo ſome wente affrica ſome beſéeged citie ocilis mummius followed nine thouſand footemen fiue hundred horſemen killed fiftéene thouſande waſted countreys many deliuered ocile ſéege méeting raunged yt countrey deſtroyed ſo meſſenger left prey couldevictorie mummius carryed diſtributed souldioures reſt burned honor god ruler warre thing triumphed rome returne attilius ſuccéeded one rode killed ſeuen hundred luſitanes deſtroyed great citie called oſtrace tooke countreyoſtrace aboute yéelding feare whiche ſome nation bottanes ſo ſoone attilius departed hys • ottanes winter ſtation reuolted beſéeged certayne romanes tributary whome seruius galba ſucceſſor attilius would haue put ſéege ſodayne gone one night day fiue hundred ſurlongs ſhewed himſelfe luſitanes put ſouldioures wearie seruius galba taketh much vvearie ſould youres loſeth iourney fight forthwith put enimie flighte fooliſhly followed souldioures weake wearie barbarian ſéeing ſcattered manye time reſting fainteneſſe turned gaue charge vpon killed ſeauen thouſande galba horſemen recouered himſelfe citie carmena gathered eſcaped whencarmena twenty thouſand tributarie ſouldyoures went border cuneans wintered cuniſtorge cuneans lucullus made warre vacceans withoute authoritielucullus senate comming time turditania vnderſtoode luſitanes made warre vppon neighboures therefore ſent ſome beſt captaynes killed fiftéene hundred paſſed water others fledde hill compaſſed trench mountes killed great multitude entring luſitania waſted one parte galba another ſente embaſſadors confirme league made attilius broken receyued friendſhip compounded maſter wyth alſo fayned ſory kllwel▪ continuall wante driuen ſpoyle ſo breaking league made warre know quoth cōpelled barenneſſe want countrey▪ put plentifull ſoyle diuide thrée ſeuerall place full abundance allured thys hope went owne houſes whome diuided thrée partes ſhewed playne ſtay till came ſhew place ſhoulde buylde citie come firſte willed leaue armour friend encloſed ditch trench ſent ſouldyource cauſed kylled one eſcaping calling vpon god breach faith like ſecondeanother manifeſt •• iurie lucullus thirde one vnderſtoode anothers calamitie thus reuenged fraude fraude following barbarian vſe reſpect y• honor rome eſcaped among whome viriatus captayne luſitanes viriatus greate feates killed many romanes thoſe thing done afterwarde ſhewe bookes galba paſſed lucullus couetouſneſſe diſtributed fewe thing among ſouldyoures tooke reſt hymſelfe although moſt riche romanes galba deſcribed man peace profite appeared would refrayne periurie lie hated men accuſed yet rich whereof great plenty euer quitte diſcharged long many remained vnfaithfulneſſe lucullus galba▪ gathering togither number tenne thouſande waſted lande turditania agaynſte them▪ vettilius another armye wente ioyning spayne whych tenne thouſande wente agaynſte waſted turditania kylled many droue caſtell woulde tarry muſt periſhe hunger departed muſt fall romanes handes ſo narrow place wherefore ſent embaſſadoures vettilius humble wiſe deſiring haue place tovettilius inhabite henceforth theſe might tributary rome whyche accepted ready come forth viriatus eſcaped galbas crueltie andthe policie hardineſſe viriatus put remembrance romanes falſehoode tolde oft hadde bin deceyued colour promiſe romanes army nowe lyke vnto deceytefulneſſe galba lucullus woulde ruled hym woulde tell might eſcape ſafe béeyng moued hys wordes conceyuing good hope choſe hym theyr captayne therefore hadde placed horſe front battell though woulde fyghte commaunded ſo ſoone tooke hys horſe diuide themſelues diuers pathes flée ouer hylles well could tribola andtribola tarry hym tyll came kepte wyth hym choyce horſemen euery number lepte horſebacke fledde ſpeede vettilius afrayde followe thus ſeparate diuided many partes ſtayed ſée viriatus woulde doe abode ſtill hys ſwifte horſe nowe commyng vpon romanes going backe comming agayne vppon ſpente ſo whole daye nexte alſo goyng comming playne coniecture thoughte gone come ſure place midnighte wyth moſt ſpéede dyuers hard wayes got tribola romanes coulde ouertake hym partly weight armoure partly ignorance way partly diuerſitie theyr horſes thus viriatus ſaued hys men deſperation themſelues thys policie wanne hym greate fame ouer place aboute ſo came vnto hym great number kepte warre wyth romanes thrée yeares togither well knowen warre muche troubled ſame ende daungerous vnto ſtirre spayne cauſe continued longer vettilius followed came tribola viriatus layde ambuſhe hyll whyther knewe thattraynes romanes vettilius come fledde vettilius paſt ambuſhe turned ambuſhe came forthe beſette romanes kylling takyng throwing headlong hygh place vettilius taken whome vettilius taken killed taker knewe ſawe hym fatte olde man thought hym regarde kylled hym tenne thouſande romanes ſcarſly ſixe thouſande ſaued themſelues tagus camped hill full oliues yet called name venus plautius finding héere deſirous heale former wounde gaue battell wherein ouercome great loſſe men fledde ſhame kepte plautius onescome ſtrong city men wont winter durſt neuer come forthe sommer viriatus raunged countrey toke money owner ſaue theyr harueſt whyche denyed hym waſted rome knowen ſente q fabius maximus paulus q fabius maximus aemilius ſonne ouercame perſeus kyng macedonia gaue hym authoritie gather men hymſelfe bycauſe late hadde gotte grecia car • hage made proſperous ende thirde warre macedonia gyue ſome reſpect olde souldioures come thence hée tooke vp two legion yong men vnexpert warre ſente ayde hys friendes came orſona citie spayne orſona contente hys armye fiftéene thouſande footemen two thouſande horſemen whyche place myndyng beginne warre tyll hadde trayned hys souldioures wente gades ſacrifice hercules viriatus méeting ſome gone foraging kylled viriatus ſpoyleth romanes moſt parte putte reſt feare called agayne theyr enſigne theyr captayne ouercame ſpoyled greate prey maximus come ofte fielde prouoked hym fyghte maximus thoughte good auenture whole fyght continued exerciſing hys souldioures ſuffered hys ſouldioures ſkirmiſhe meane myghte trie hearies hys owne hys enimies maximus refuſeth fight till trayned men ſhoulde goe victuall hée garded wyth many ſhotte horſemen riding ſéene father paulus doe macedonia winter paſt hadde ſufficiently exerciſed hys souldioures ſeconde whome viriatus ouerthrowen putte flighte doyng thé partes belongeth generall ſo two city hel • toke one burned came ſucceſſor • aemilianus quintus two romane legiōs ſome friend eightéene footman thouſand ſixe hundred horſemen wrote micipſe king numidia ſo ſoone time would ſerue ſend elephant part armiemicipſ horſes tooke large place encampe fortified béeganne firſte • ame viriatus put flight chaſe romanes followed hym oute order perceyuing turned vpon killed thrée thouſanderomanes killed chaſed reſte campe whiche hée aſſaulted founde fewe gate reſiſte hym fledde tentes feare whence generall captaines could hardly remoue fight fannius ſonne lawe laelius behaued hymſelfe valiauntlyefannius ſaued hys companye great ſcorne enimie went forth ſo ſpéedily folowed could tell way became caepio waſted country vettones gallecians many followed viriatus ſpoyled portugall againſt sextus iunius brutus ſent wearye long waye inn brutus rodes spain • whiche tagus l • darias betis nauigeable floudes conteyne ſtaide following lyke théeues conueyed themſelues ſight moment wherefore brutus thought great labour ouertake doe greate diſhonor ſuppoſing finall glorie ouerthrowing went ſpoile campes bycauſe thought might ſo chaſtice alſo get great bootie ſouldiors furder bande robber woulde ſcatter ſhoulde thinke daunger theyr ſeueral countreis wyth entent purpoſe ſpoiled whatſoeuer way woman came warre huſbandesvaliant 〈◊〉 killed ſhewed ſuche conſtancie woulde ſpeake worde ſlaine many went mountayns wyth much coulde carrye whome deſiring peace hée gaue diuided land paſſed floude orius waſted greate regionorius required hoſtages yéeded ſo came floude lethe firſt romane thought paſſage paſt gone forth came tonibene battarans riuer nibene ledde hys army againſte battarans bycauſe intercepted victualls theſe bée people goe alſo woman armed warre good courage abide death • oldly▪ ſparing themſelues neyther • léeing fight lamenting dye woman taken would kil themſelues ſome child alſo rather ſhoulde bée •• aues manye citties helde brutus rebetled ſhortely ſubdued hym againe theſe cauſes came labrica ofte made peace labrica diſobedient deſired pardon woulde doe thing commaundement required hoſtages romaine r • nneawaies armour laſtly ſhould leaue cittie al whiche hadde done called
