mutinie endured vttermoſt moſte ready abide daunger created tantalus captaine theytantalus went towarde • gunt cittie annibal deſtroyed reſtored called carthage name country driuen thē • e caepa alwaies backes paſſed floude betis béeing wearye yéelded himſelfe army caepa tooke al hys armor appoynted good land lyue ſhoulde driuen robbe nowe oure hiſtory ſhall retourne warres vacceans numantines viriatus cauſed reuolt caecilius metellus ſent rome men ſhortely ouercame vacceans whereby reſte diſco •• ted put feare c ¶ remayned yet termantia numantia hyllyhere vvanteth termantia numantia place diuided two floudes compaſſed hylles thicke wooddes bending playne onely one waye part fortified many ditch pill • ur ouerthwart numantines good eight thouſand mē bothe horſe foote ſo ſmall number ſuche manlineſſe put romanes muche paine metellus ende winter deliuered army q metellus aulus ſucceſſor thirtie thouſād footemen two thouſand horſmen wel armed practiſed chere vvanteth ¶ pompeius campe numantia thence went certaine place numantines deſcending hil deſtroyed horſemen ranne hée retourned broughte foorthe batayle fyghte playne enimies comming gaue charge vpon hym though bin afraide retired vnto hil till brought thē place ditch ouerthwart beames layde ſo pompey perceyuing pompey looſeth theſe ſkirmiſhes ouermatched inferioure hym tourned hys armie towarde termantia thinking doe better fought loſſe ſeauen hundred beſide termantines put tribune flight comming victual one day giuyng thrée onſets romaynes droue thrice ſharpe rocky place threwe many footemen horſemen togither horſes hylles rockes ſo reſte afraide remayned al night armor day comming foorth order battaile fought doubtfullye till night ended fight pompey night made haſt malia wyth horſemen whiche place numantines helde garriſon malian killing garriſon treaſon malia nove malgrad • • deli • ered •• pey deliuered citie pompey receyuing armoure pledge went sueditania certayne capitainesue •• ta • • ta • ginus named tanginus ſpoyle wyth armie pompey fought ouerthrewe tooke manye hys ſouldyoures ſuche manhoode theſe théeues none themmanhode th •• ues woulde lyue captiue ſome killed themſelues ſome theyr maiſters ſome made hole • hip caried thē ſincke pompey beyng returned numantia went turne floude playne waye mighte preſſe citie famine townſemen droue labourer worke andthe romaine killed comming bandes without trumpet threwe dart arrowes vpon ſhould▪not tourne floude fought hande came aide pioners dro • e campe encountring wente forage killed manye tribune leader giuing charge • ſide romanes made ditche killed one thouſand four hundred capitaine whiche diſcommodities certaine mencounſellours ſent pompey senate came pompey helpe hym theyr counſel alſo young ſouldioures yet exerciſed gathered old bin nowe ſixe yeares abroade wyth • olde ſouldioures pompey hauing receyued ſo manye diſpleaſures remayned winter campe recouer eſtimation curſedly vexed colde warding watching nature countrey beganne béeflixe among romane ſoldiours perceyued taken wyth flyxe manye dyed anye ſouldiours ſhoulde goe oute campe victuall numantines lying awayte woulde ceaſe hurte romanes ſhot dart numantine h • rt • romanes coulde abide woulde néedes go againſt come traines muche harme againe numidian méeting wyth brought victuall deſtroyed many aſwell noble men pompey therfore vexed ſo many euils counſaile senatours remoued ſhoulde lye reſte wynter ſure place spring city bycauſe succeſſoure come afraid accuſed beganne practiſe ſecreatly numantines alſo loſſe many chiefe citizen coulde tyll ground want victuall ye continuance war longer thought ſent ambaſſadors pompey openlye ſpake yt ſhould yeeld themſelues ſaid knew none way howe agrée dignitie romaynes pri •• ly tolde condition pompey practiſeth peace vvith numantines woulde vſe ſo thing agréed yéelded hym pompey required pledge fugitiues whiche receiued required alſo thirtie talentes ſiluer numantines paide fiftéene preſently pompey looked reſte ſucceſſour popilius lena come numantines popilius paide pompey deliuered feare warre knowing compoſition made vnlawfull done wythout romanes conſent ſucceſſor come denyed pompey goeth frō peace made agréement numantines proued witneſſe preſent men degrée senatours tribune alſo capitaines hys horſemen therefore popilius ſent bothe partes rome pleade matter senate senate thought beſte holde war ſtill numantines meane ſeaſon popilius entred lande luſones luſones neighbour numantines returned dooyng nothing c hostilius mancinus ſuccéeded went rome mancinus came fight oft ouercome length loſt many kepte within camp rumor cantabrans vacceanes would come helpcantabri ••• ſcage enimie wherefore night without lighte fled abandoned campe nobilior beyng ſhutte neyther hauing fortifyed place otherwiſe able defend numantines beſéeging armye hard ſtate leaſt hée ſhould make diſhonorable peace made league amitie betwéene romanes numantines equall condition bound himſelfe whyche thing knowen rome ſory bycauſe league ſhamefull therefore aemilius lepidus mancinus maketh peace diſhonourably aemilius another conſull ſente spayne mancinus called iudgemente whome embaſſadors numantines followed aemilius looking aunſwere rome wéerie reſt ſuch generalles driuen deſire falſe gloriegeneralles prouinces profite profite triumph went prouinces coū trey profite pretēding falſe crime againſt vacceans accuſing holpen numantines victual inuaded land beſéeged chiefe citie pallantia whiche offended againſt league ſent brutus ſonne law partes spayne make partaker warre cinus caecilius came embaſſadors rome ſhewing senate dote ſo many loſſes receyued spayne aemilius would ſowe new warres declared decrée senate ſhoulde make warre vpon vacceans hauing begunne warre ſent brutus abroade bycauſe thought senate knowe vacceans helpe numantines victuall money ſouldyoures fearing alſo lefte warre spayne would reuolt done feare ſent embaſſadoures without delay ſo wrote senate fortifyed certaine caſtell beſtowed time gathering men victuall flaccus ſent foraging falling traynes came vpon word craftily caſt forthethe army ſaued vvorde aemilianus wonne pallantia whiche souldioures made crie manner victorie barbarian hearing beléeuing true afrayde departed meane flaccus deliuered men perill forage ſpoyle ſéege continuing long pallantia romanes wantedpallantia victuall hauing conſumed cattell waxed ſo weake ſome dyed hunger captaynes aemilianus brutus ſuffered want long could lēgth ouercome miſchiefe aemilius commaunded breake vp therefore tribune centurians went aboute campe commanded ſouldioures departe beforecovvardly departure romanes day ſo forſooke euen ſicke woūded ſouldyoures embraced recommended themſelues vnto departing confuſedly without order men flée pallantines ranne vpō euery much troubled following morning till night darke romanes ſcattered wente diuers place l •• ke ſerued pallantines lefte chaſing béeing called frō purpoſe power god theſe thing chanced aemilius lepidus whiche romanes vnderſt •• de put aemilius prouince conſulſhippe aemilius put frō office ſo hée returned priuate man rome puniſhed numantines mancinus heard senate broughte forth capitulation league layde blame vpon pompey ruler prouince hym whome receyued rude cowardly army y• whiche oft euill handled ouercome made peace wyth numantines thereto compelled pompey hadde done whoſe league affirmed warre vnlucky romanes romanes angrie yet pompey acquit accuſed ſame afore senate decréed mancinus made ſo diſhonorable league without conſent senate ſhould giuē numantines old st 〈◊〉 conſull vvas deliuered samnite example gaue captayne samnite bycauſe agréed ſo ſhameful peace cōmanded furius leade mancinus spayne depriued al thing naked mancinus deliuered numantines calphurnius receiued numantines againſt whome calphurnius piſo made generall entred land numantines waſted part pallantines ſpent reſt time harborough carpentania people rome wéerycarpentania long tedious warre numantines might ended choſe cornelius scipio cōſull againe y• wōne carthage one y• could ouercome y• numātines could conſul age yong decrée y• senate made tribune ſhould diſpenſe law yeare reſtore ye yeare following thereforea diſputation make scipio conſull scipio made conſull made ſpéede goe againſt ye numantines ledde none ſouldioures choyce bycauſe wer troubled war alſo bycauſe many spaine ſome voluntary ſent king city conſent senate led many ſeruants frō rome made one band fiue c company philoni • band friend friēds called philonida band friēds felows whē appointed four ſouldiours couſin • uteo wēt afore great ſpéede • uteo army vnderſtood corrupted ydleneſſe riote ſedition knowing could ouercome enimies except reſtreined kept ſouldiours awe y• temperance integritie gouernemēt ſoone come put merchant harlot ſouthſayers whome ſouldioures feare would aſke many queſtions forbad thing brought camp neceſſary forbad ſacrifices bowel whereof thing come enquired would ſuffer ſlaues drudge cō manded scipio reformed camp coke ſouldioures camp ſell beaſts burthen except fewe néedefull would haue ſouldioures haue coke forbad inſtruments veſſells kitchen carried ſpit panne veſſell drinke would haue thē eate fleſh otherwiſe dreſſed ſodde roſt appointed meaſure diet forbad thē featherbed firſt yt lay vpō bed hay forbad ſouldiours iourneys ride aſſes mule ſaide little good hoped man warre could go afoote likewiſe reproued y• vſed miniſters hote houſes called thē mule yt wāted hāds néed rub thē thus made ſouldiours obediēt temperate litle little acquainted thē reuerēce feare hard heare quarels grāting thing yt iuſt oft yt ſentence mouth eaſie fauourable affable captaynesfauourable captaynes profitable enimie though beloued ſouldyoures ſet little hard ſeuere haue ſouldyoures ready obediente aſſayes whiche though thus inſtructed yet durſt bring fielde till exerciſed much labour therefore going dayly one field another made diuers campes one another whiche defaced called souldyoures worke agayne digge ditch higher fill againe make high walles pull downe againe ſtode morning till night ouerſee pioners made iourney went ſquare battell ſhoulde ſcattered ſuddaine attempte happened rode army ſometime hindermoſt bad ſicke ſhould borne horſemens horſes tooke burden mule much laden diuided borne footemen kepte himſelfe houſe ſommer troupe horſemen ſent eſpye commaunded returne ſtand without trēch till another bande horſemen viewed labour worke diuided among pioners ſome make trench ſome ditch ſome walles ſome pitch tentes euery certayne time appointed doe perceyued armye made fierce obediente paynefull ſommer encamped nygh numantia yet chooſe place ſtrong camp numantia novve ſome called caeſar auguſts ſome •• wont diuided men leaſt anye loſſe ſhould happe firſt ſhoulde contemned neyghboures whiche wont laugh neither encounter enimie waying nature end warre ſtrength numantines leaſt would come vpon force therfore commaunded waſt thing corne cutte whileſt gréene waſted muſt néedes goe way went numantia playne ſhorter many perſuaded go way whome scipio ſayd conſidered way returnehard vvay ſure enimie full ſhotte come ſight citie backe returne ſafely againe ſaid laden victual wéery ſhould farre weake beſide haue beaſtes burden carte carriage ſo fighte ſhoulde hard vnequall ouercome ſhould great perill ouercome ſhould haue great gayne folly put hymſelfe perill ſmall matter euill captayne fighteth without profite valiante wiſe entreth danger fight conſtreined neceſſitie brought example phiſitians come cut burne till haue tryed ſicke place wyth medicine ſaid cōmanded captaines leade y• way cōmanded goe lande vacceans numantines victuall fieldes waſted alſo corne gathered vſe ſouldioures burned reſt pallantines laide many awayte vnder certaine hilles adioyning playne called coplanium openly moleſted thē werecoplanium harueſt therefore scipio ſente rutilius ruffus hys tribune committed warre wrighting wyth four band • orſe ſtop rangings therefore ruffus began rutilus ruffus danger follow 〈◊〉 chace • ppe hilles ambuſh whiche diſcouering themſelues ruffus commanded mē neyther followe encounter enimie holde ſpeares poylite scipio ſéeyng ruffus going hilles appointed began follow wich army fearing worſt come place traynes diuided horſemē commanded giue onſet vpon enimie wayes caſt dartes returne righte ſoft pac • behinde mighte ioyne meane brought horſe ſafe playne scipio would remoue water hard •• paſſed myrie enimie lay hidden knowen lefte way ledde hys army another longer way ſure deceyts went night commanded many welles made thirſt moſtsalt vvater part y• ſalt water found neuertheleſſe neuertheleſſe army wēt ſafe though great payne ſome horſes mule killed drought entred land cauceans whome lucullus inuaded contrary league cōmanded crier goe quietly euery one hys owne thence wente numantines grounde winter remained till iug • rtha nephewe maſsiniſſa iugurth came xij elephant archer ſlingers well armed occupyed waſting ſpoyling countreys nigh almoſt entrapped uillage enuirened great fenne one ſide scipio like entrapped y• hilly place y• y• traynes layde scipio hoſt diuided two partes entring towne leauing enſignes without went ſpoyle horſemē rode towne beſet ambuſh defended thēſelues scipio y• enſignes called y• ſouldioures trumpet y• could come horſemen ranne help thē diſtreſſe moſt part ſouldiours come towne made enimie flée yet follow thē fewe killed ſides tenne beſide pinnacle tower diſtant equall ſpace fenne nexte wall bycauſe coulde compaſſe wall made trench high wall might ſerue wall scipio y• firſt thinkea vvall camp dunas compaſſed citie beſéeged wall whiche refuſe fight floud dunas ranne campe commodious numantines bring victuall receiue men ſwimme vnder water ſend boates full ſayle winde bigge rowe time ſerued bycauſe bridge coulde made vpon breadth vehemence scipio cauſed two caſtels made either ſide banke betwéene hāged certaine long beames rope let goe y• water beames laide plate ſwords euery ſide weapon pricking whiche continuall courſe water turned ſuffer enimies shippes ſwimmers paſſe thing scipio moſt deſired none ſhould go beſéeged tell donepolicie scipio abroade whereby ſhoulde deſtitute councell comfort theſe thus much fauoured numantines moued theyr citie help numantines auntientes certified scipio therefore scipio eyght houre night tooke iourney day lucia • éeged citie required head youth giuen thelucia towneſmen anſwering fled threatned ſpoyle cittie vnleſſe obeyed whiche citizen featingfoure hundred yong men h • d cut brought foorth foure hundred young men whoſe handes cutte went away great ſpéede next day betimes campe numantines oppreſſed famine ſent fyue men numantines ſue peace scipio commiſſion know woulde yeelde would vſe mercifully content moderate fine auarus chiefe man highe courage muche ſet valiantnes entente numantines affirming offende ſo greateboſting • r time daunger fyghting wiues child libertie theyr countrey wherefore scipio ſaide hée ſhal almoſt rightful thing thou noble man ſo great vertue wilt pardon ſo noble people appoint v paine ſhal able beare knowe mutation fortune ſafetie oure country v thée take cittie content moderate puniſhement thou haſte v contempt thou maiſte hope ſée periſh ouerthrowne defending ſelfe auarus hadde ſaide thus scipio knowing captiues done cittie ſaide woulde haue fréely yéelde themſelues cittie armoure whiche tolde numantines thoughte ſo inflamed anger greate deſire libertie bycauſe neuer bin acquainted obey taken rage furie killed auarus companyethe numantines kill vvent peace bringers euill newes conſpiring scipio ſaue themſelues long victualls faylyng hauing neyther fruite cattell hearbes firſte eat leather mollifiedthe neceſſity numantines water neceſſitie haue done leather failed eate deade men fleſhe ſodden roſte hauing reſpecte ſicke ſtronger forced weaker thinking nowe none acte cruell violent mindes turned wilde creature body beaſtes meate eate therfore killed hunger conſumed peſtilence hear beardes horrible length yéelded scipio whiche commaunded ſame daye bring armour place appointed next day come themſelues another place aſſigned deferred daye confeſſing yet many city loue libertie would end liues ſword famine numantines kil themſelues▪ deſired time kill themſelues ſo greate loue libertie ſo gret vertue barbarous litle citie whiche flouriſhed peace wer eight thouſand good men whiche thinges done againſte romanes euident many league made lyke equall condition coulde neuer brought doe nation captaine generall néede rehearſe yet scipio fielde lx men many time prouoked numantines fight scipio better wyſer general thoughte good deale thoſe wylde men force armes conquere famine whiche thing • uitable whiche euill numantines coulde bée taken▪ theſe thing ſay numantines conſider ſmall number ſufferaunce labour noble actes long inuincible therefore numantines ſo determined dyu • rſlye killed themſelues reſte thirde daye came place appointed al vgly filthie horrible beholde bodiesa pitiful yelding numantines foule full heare wyth long nayles full filth ſtincke worne garment euill ſauoures whiche thinges miſerable ennimies yet feareful looke vpon therefore beholden romaine wyth admiration conſidering ſtraunge affection theyr body felt ayre dolour labour whiche ſuffred▪ alſo conſcience one eaten anothers fleſhe scipio chooſing oute ſome pompe hys tryumphe commaunded ſolde cittie vtterly deſtroyed generall romanes theſe two city taken harde wonne carthage greatneſſe cittie power thereof decrée romaine preſerued commodity lande ſea numantia hée raſed little citie helde fewe whiche romanes determined eyther bycauſe irefull harde nature againſte tooke violence bicauſe ſome ſay thought glorie greater greateſt calamity therefore day called affricane iuſte antiochus would enioy y• place romanes takē philip finally ſaid bée doubted antiochus ſhould bring ſuch nauye armye medium aſia ſea inuade europe builde citties ſubdue thracia lay platthe anſvvere antiochus another warre anſwered thracia belonged anceſtors lacke quietneſſe reuolted nowe hauing leyſure recouered reſtored lyſimachia dwelling ſon seleuchus would leaue city aſia frée would thanke y• romanes ptolomie quoth kinſman ſhortly ſhal father law wil cauſe giue thankes doe doubt alſo right romanes meddle aſia ſince doe deale italy thus breaking vppe without anye concluſion vttereda report death ptolomie manifeſt threatnings one againſte another reported thought ptolomeus dead wherfore antiochus went ſpéed toward egipt get kingdom voide prince epheſus annibal carthage came fléeing country hate enimies accuſing romanes contentious ſéeking warre coulde liue reſt carthaginenſes agrée romaynes confederate antiochus receyued annibal gloriouſlye fame valiantneſſe hadde aboute vnderſtanding lycia ptolomie aliue refrayued egipt thought take cyprus ſteade ſayled thither great anticchus hath •• ipvvracke • sarus ſpéede winter floude sarus wrecke loſte many ſhippes diuerſe men friend ſayled seleucia syria repaired ſhaken nauie made mariage child antiochus laodice ioyning matr •• onye nowe bycauſe knewe euident warre woulde folowe betwéene romanes allied himſelfe wyth kyngs neighboures ſent cleopatra called syra ptolomei antiochus maketh allyance vvith▪ neyghbours giuyng coeloſyria hir dowry whiche hée taken hym ſo pleaſe young man hée mighte quiete war romanes antiochida hée ſent ariarathes king cappadocia lefte eumenes king pergamo enimies refuſe alliaunce▪ perceyuing meante make warre vpon romanes purpoſe would make affinitie refuſe brother attalus philetayrus dyd maruel reiected alliaunce ſo greate king hys neyghbour ſéeking aunſwered lyke war would beginning woulde equall ſides time romanes woulde ouercome good condition taking paine quoth romanes conqu • rors ſhal hold kingdom ſurely antiochus ouercommeth feare al wil taken away neighboure feare haue kyngdome muſte kyng vnder theſe conſiderations refuſe mariage antiochus ſtraight went thence helleſpont ſayled heleſpont th • ſtreight • alip •• cherroneſus ſubdued ouerthrewe manye place thracia made frée grecian y• inhabite thracia granted many thing byzantine hauing cittie verye commodious bizane novv conſtantinople theſe called french greekes mouth ſea galathians pleaſed wt gift drew feare alſo ſocietie determination thinking good confederate bigneſſe body wente epheſus ſent ambaſſadoures rome antiochus ſendeth ambaſſage romanes lyſias egeſeanactes menippus déede féele mind senate word menippus ſaide king deſirous romanes amitie woulde confederate woulde accept yet maruell would require leaue city ionia loſe tribute deale certain aſia forgo thracia euer bin hys progenitor whiche thing friendes conquerours commaunde conquered senate perceyuing comming eſpiall ſhortelye aunſwered antiochus ſuffer gréeke citties aſia frée refraine europe ſhall friende romanes anſvvere romanes thus romanes anſwered made none ſhewe cauſe antiochus minding firſte inuade grecia begin warre againſte romanes aſked annibals opinion thethe opinion anniball touching vvarre matter ſaide grecia eaſy ouercome bycauſe long affliction war made home moſte grieuous dearth followeth abroade tollerable neither ſhould ouercome romanes grecia ſéeing myght haue ſufficient prouiſion helpe home therefore opinion ſhould inuade romanes italy whether went ſhoulde fynd romanes weaker home abroade haue ſaide experience italy x men take fitte place write friend carthage ſtir people reuolte ſory angry romanes full hope hart wyll thinke againe get italy king hearing aduice well thinking acceſſe carthage make muche furtheraunce thys warre badde hym ſend • letter hys friendes eute hande hée ſente thoughte ſure romaynes lying wayte euery war yet proclaymed many diſcord carthage common wealth hauing firmeneſſe certentie ſhortly deſtruction carthage yet ſent ariſton merchant tyrus vnder pretence marchandiſe friendes exhorting anniball ſendeth ariſton practice carthage vnderſtoode inuaded italy ſhould ſtirre people carthage reuenged ariſton ſo annibals enimies perceyued ariſtons purpoſe made much adoe innouation ſhoulde followe diligently ſought ariſton friendes anniball ſhould beare blame ſecretely night ſette vp athe deuice ariſton ſaue annibals friend writing common houſe whiche anniball exhorted senate reuenge countrey vnder antiochus ſo done ſayled away daye come ſuſpition taken annibals friend bycauſe matter belonged ſtate people ful vprore angry romanes able hurte thus went matter carthage romanes ſente embaſſadors scipio scipio goeth embaſſadour antiochus ouercame carthagies proue king minde eſpie preparation founde king gone piſidia tarried returne epheſus meane piſidia countrey aſia nigh • ycaonia pamphilia time many time talke anniball ſéeing carthage league antiochus yet manifeſt enimie blamed would flée countrey ſeing romanes offended againſt carthagies ſince league made make anniball ſuſpected king déede ofte reſorting anniball brought ſuſpition vvith antiochus talking though anniball circumſpect man yet foreſée king heard ſuſpected anniball ſo ready truſt beſide enuie hatred grewe againſte leaſt heenuie ſhould haue prayſe thing done among otherthe talke anniball scipio touching beſt captayne talkes ſay one betwéene scipio anniball scholehouſe many learne preſente heare touching excellencie captayne whereas scipio aſked whome thoughte beſt captayne anſwered alexander macedonia scipio ſtayed gaue place alexander aſked whome hée thought ſecond next alexander ſayde pirrhus epirota putting vertue captayne boldeneſſe found couragious kyng hée scipio gréeued againe aſked whome thoughte bée thirde thinking verily woulde haue named aunſwered ſelfe béeing yong man ſubdued spayne mine armie paſſed alpes italy firſte hercules ſo haue done inuaded none durſt doe thyng ouerthrewe foure hundred townes broughte youre citie many time daunger hauing neyther money men ſent carthage scipio perceyued dyd ſo purpoſe aduance himſelfe ſmyled ſayde place wouldeſt thou haue put thy ſelfe anniball thou hadſt bin ouercome perceyuing emulation ſayde woulde haue ſet ſelfe alexander dyd anniball continue lofty talke yet ſecretely pleaſe scipio making hym better alexander thys talke ended anniball deſired scipio hys lodging scipio ſayde woulde come gladly ſhould cauſe ſuſpition betwéene antiachus romanes thus theſe noble captaynes ended theyr malice warremalice endeth ſome vvhen watter ceſſeth ended ſo dyd flaminius antiochus ouercome anniball fledde ſauing himſelfe bithinia ſente embaſſadour purpoſe pruſia iniured anniball commaunded romanes feared bycauſe power carthage abated kylled poyſon pruſias conſente whyche ſayde hée warned oracle thys ſort lande libyſſa ſhall couer annibals bodyoracle annibals death thoughte ſhoulde haue dyed libya libyſſus alybiſſus floud bithinia countrey called libyſſa floud remembrance haue made noble myndes ofnoble mind anniball scipio cowardly heart flaminius antiochus comming piſidia towarde epheſus gaue audience embaſſadoures rhodians promiſed rhodians byzantine cyzioneans gréeke city aſia ſhoulde frée entred league romanes aet • lean ionian would grant ſo bycauſe moſt part bin vſed obey barbarous king aſia romane embaſſadoures bringing nothing paſſe came doe thyng déede eſpie returned rome embaſſadors aetolians came antiochus whiche thoas chiefe offering leading theyr armie wiſhing woulde ſayle grecia ſure thing tarrying hys armie come high aſia ſettyng forthe theyr owne ſtrength promiſed ayde antiochus • perſuaded aetolians lacedemonians philip kyng macedonie angry romanes ſo hée woulde make hys voyage wyth ſpéede hée moued lightely woulde ſtay haſt although hearde aſia hys ſonne dead tenne thouſande ſayled eub • ia whyche gotte yéelding feare micithion captayne ſetting micithio killeth romanes romanes killed delos aminander king athamanes people aetolia megalopoli • one arcadia another aſia counterfet philip vpon romanes delos whyche holy place apollo kylled part part toke alyue aminander kyng athamanes came league antiochus occaſion one alexander maecedonia béeing brought vp megalopoli made frée common wealth fayned himſelfe come alexander ſonne philip gyue credite hys deuice named hys child philip alexander apamea whome married amynander philip hir brother going hir marriage perceyuing amynander weake man little experience remayned wyth hys brother lawe gouerne kyngdome philip antiochus promiſed reſtore kingdome macedony owne meane athamaneans confederate alſo thebanes wente thebe ſpeake people thus raſhly ſo great war put truſt aetolians thebanes amynāder conſulted whether better inuade theſſaly hand tarrie till winter paſt anniball conſultation ſaying nothing king cōmaunded ſay opinion firſt thus ſpake thou mayeſt eaſilie ouercome theſſalians eyther anniball shevveth opinion touching vvarre winter people hauing bin much vexed turne thée ſo doe romanes innouation commeth come owne power giuing credite aetolians perſuaſion lacedemonians philip take part lacedemonians enimies heare ſo acheans philip ſée great ayde vnto thée warre thy ſide make great power whatſoeuer part taketh mine aduiſe thou ſendeſt thine army ſpeede aſia put thy truſt amynāder aetolians army come ſend italy béeing occupyed trouble home may leaue vntouched afraide themſelues may vexe men manner held v ſpake afore muſt vſe one halfe oure na • ie waſt coaſt italy halfe muſt haue flote vſe occaſion ſhall require thy ſelfe thy footemen muſt remaine part grecia next italy making ſhewe inuaſion néede inuade indéede induce philip meanes poſſible agrée thée ſhall much auayle part taketh warre bée broughte thou ſhalt ſende thy ſonne seleucus thracia moleſt euils home profitable thine enimies abroade thus anniball ſaid beſt enuie fame wiſedome well king himſelfe anniball ſhoulde ſéeme paſſe arte warre haue prayſe ſhoulde done hys counſell reiected ſauing polyxenides ſent aſia polyxenides army romanes hearde entring antiochus grecia killing taking romanes delus determined warre thus antiochus romanes warrethe vvarre beginneth growing long ſuſpition one another firſte breake déede bycauſe antiochus rule many nation high aſia inhabite ſea coaſt ſauing fewe entred europa hadde dreadfull name greate preparation otherwiſe hadde done many notable thing gotten y• name greate romanes thoughte warre would daungerous long continuance philip macedome ſuſpition ouercome long league cartheginians great truſt anniball antiochus ſubiects ſome dōubt leaſt glory antiochus ſhould make ſéeke new attemptes therefore ſen • e garriſons euery one gouerneconſuls proconſuls officer ſixe ax peaceable manner ſente captaynes armyes whome call ſixe axies bycauſe conſuls hadde twelue twelue roddes olde kyngs vſed bycauſe theſe officer halfe authoritie hadde halfe theforeſight rhodians ſhewe greate feare carefull italy leaſt ſome diſturbance mighte happen eyther violence fauour antiochus ſente greate bande footemen tarento bée ready aſſayes nauie ſayled ouer coaſt great feare antiochus firſt hadde thus home giuen order thing begynning gathered theyr army againſte antiochus themſelues hadde twenty thouſand theyr confederate twice ſo many whyche woulde paſſe ionia thys preparation ſpente whole winter antiochus wente theſſalia come vnto cynoch • phalia macedonian hadde greate ouerthrowe cynochephalia place people like dogges head antiochus b • •• e • h dead romanes honorably buryed th • ſe laye vnburyed thynkyng thereby winne macedonian withdrawe philip hadde lefte hys souldyoures vnburyed ſerued vnder hys standerd philip hearyng thys greate perplexitie wyth hymſelfe whyche parte ſhoulde take yet dyd cleaue romanes ſtreyghte ſente bebius captayne romanes bebius lying farre come hym certayne place aſſuring hym hée woulde take romanes parte againſt kyng whyche bebius thanking hym theappius bolde ſende appius claudius macedonte theſſaly two thouſande footemen appius tempe perceyued antiochus lay wyth army tempe pleaſant place ſo muche prayſed poet antiochus remoueth caught loue vvhen vvas aboue fiftie yeares age calcide novv negroponte made many fyres couer fewneſſe hys armye antiochus thynkyng bebius philip hadde bene come togyther afrayde brake vp hys campe making winter pretence wente calcida hée caughte wyth loue mayde béeyng aboue fiftye yeares age hauyng ſo greate warre hande hée woulde néedes marry hyr make paſtymes whereby hée broughte hys armye greate ydleneſſe change winter spring come hée wente • arnania • arnania parte epir • bringing foorth good horſes perceyued hys armye vtterly vnprofitable ydleneſſe repented hym hys marriage feaſtings hée hadde gotten ſome countrey hys obedience ſubdued reſt hearing roman • paſſed ionia hée returned chalcide romanes wyth diligence two thouſande good horſemen thirtie thouſande footemen ſome elephantes acinius manius glabrie béeyng generall brunduſe arriuing acinius manius glabrio appolonia novv • allona appolonia wente theſſalie delyuered city theyr enimies founde garriſons macedonian put philippus magalopolis taken priſoner hopyng yet kingdome macedonia tooke thrée thouſande antiochus men whyles manius philip inuaded athamania made ſubiect amynander fleeing ambracia whyche antiochus hearde ſpeedy doyng thyngs hee feare bycauſe ſuddayne change alteration vnderſtoode annihall gaue hym good counſell therefore hée ſente one another polyxenida ſtirre ſpéede hée gathered many hée coulde place thys done hee hadde owne footemen tenne thouſande fyue hundred horſe wyth whyche ſome confederate tooke thermopyle hys enimies might haue harder paſſage hée tarrie hys armye aſia thermopyle ſtreighte long paſſage whyche thermopyle long • ill grecia vvhere ſtreight paſſage • ho • e vvaters tichiunta callid •• mu rough sea withoute porte dothe partly compaſſe fenne déepe without way two toppes hathe rockes hylles one called tichiunta callidromus place hathe welles h • te water thereof called thermopyle antiochus made wall double placed engine wall ſente aetolians toppes mountaynes man ſhoulde paſſe called atropos xerxes came agaynſte leonida thexerxes leonida captayne l • cedemonians man kepte hylles • tolians placed one thouſande eyther toppe wyth reſt beſéeged citie heraclea heraclea many city • name manius perceyued thys preparation enimies hée gaue order fyghte nexte morning commaunded two hys tribune marcus cato lucius valerius ſhoulde aſſayle nyghte whychethe order romanes hylles woulde coulde dryue • tolians toppes lucius repulſed ti • hiunta • tolians béeyng good hym marcus cato wente cato dothae great fea • e▪ againſte callidram • paſſed enimies aſléepe laſt watche hadde greate conflict ſtriuing gette high rocky place enimies kéepe hym backe manius ledde hys armye face antiochus diuided ſmall bandes ſo coulde doe ſtreightes kyng commaunded lighte harneſſed target men fyghte mayne battell whyche hée placedthe order king battell camp righte ſide ſette ſlingers archer hygh place elephantes lefte ſyde bande euer hym wylled ſtande sea ſide fyghte begunne ſhotte running hyther thyther dyd muche trouble manius hée • eſiſting manfullyheere italian miſſeth ſo doth latine gyuing backe agayne commyng hée put • e flighte battell macedonian opening themſelues receyued cloſed agayne thruſt forthe theyr long pykes 〈…〉 togyther order thys manner lacedemontans vnder alexander philip dyd troublethis vvas called phalanx macedonian legion among romanes enimies • r •• approche pykes ſo long ſo many ſuddayne ſéene fléeing cry aetolians dryuen antiochus campe whyche firſte knowen whyche ignorance cauſed trouble doubte till cato appeared followyng wyth greate ſhoute béeyng come kyngs campe antiochus menne hadde hearde muche romanes valiantneſſe afrayde acknowledgedthe fight vvas firſt made betvveene romanes antiochus theyr owne ydleneſſe delicateneſſe wynter paſſed cauſe thys time worſe doe theyr office ſéeyng perfitlye number cato hadde feare thinking beyng afrayde campe fledde order keepe away enimie romanes comming vppon entred campe wyth another • oule fléeyng antiochus menne manius followed scarpheia killing taking ſome comming scarpheia scarpheia 〈…〉 king cape ſpoyled ſpoyled kyngs campe droue aetolians romanes campe taken abſence preſently fighte ſlaine romanes twoo hundred folowed chaſe antiochus loſt tenne thouſand taken king himſelfe thethe king flyeth firſt change ranne fiue hundred horſe velatia neuer ſtaying velatia calcida epheſus eubia velatia 〈…〉 yong vv •• e olde antiochus newe wyfe ſo hir name ſhippes • ledde admirall romanes taken ſome came laden victual rome victorie heard ſéeming happily ſpéedily obtained gaue thankes god men beyng gladde firſte triall ſo good ſucceſſe warre ſo fearful fame antiochus requite philip true confederacte ſent histhe romanes gratifye phillip ſonne demetrius pledge marius releaſed phoceans calcideans followed antiochus feare • tolians togither phillip inuaded ouerthrewe citties tooke damocritus damocritus generall hidden threatned flaminius would encampe tiber went calipolis hyll called coraca higheſt callipolis cittie •• e alſo hardeſt paſſed al verye rockye army laden ſpoil • many fell harde way intothe romanes paſſe hilles laden loſſe ſtony partes tumbled downe armor burden • tolians might haue troubled appeared ſent ambaſſadours rome peace antiochus greate diligence called hys armye land ruler ſea ſide preparing nauye whyche polixenides outlawe rhodes admiral • ayled polixanides admiral king cherroneſu • fortified ſent garriſon sestus abydus whiche romanes muſte paſſe aſia made lyſimachia ſtore houſe warre bringing thither muche armoure victualls thinking romanes would ſoone great power na • rom • aynes appoynted l ••••• scipio brother publi •• 〈…〉 publi scipio ſent aſſa scipio ouercame carthage • fyrſte named affricanus ſucceſſoure • nius thys warre béeing conſull bycauſe hée practiſed experienced warre ſente hys brother wyth hym counſelloure theſe brother prepared themſelues liuius hadde chardge italy ſente ſucceſſoure att • lio nauye ſtrayght wyth owne shyppes whiche hee ſcowred coaſte itali • certaine lent carthagies ſome friendes hee ſayled pirae • ▪ receyuing nauye atilius carthagies lende shippes romanes • ircu • wyth foureſcore one armed shyppes e • menes followyng hym wyth fyftye hys owne halfe béeyng armed arryued phocida ſubiect antiochus feare receyued nexte daye wente foorthe fight ſea polixenides admirall antiochus came foorthe wyth two hundred shyppes lighter enimy whych happy greate shyppes romaynes béeyng yet practiſed séeyng twoo carthagies commyng hée tookethe fight sea bothe wyth three hys emptye lybians béeing leapte sea liuius great vehemence gaue fyrſte charge vppon theſe thrée wyth hys admirall ſhip goyng far afore reſt nanye▪ • earing thys one shyppe dyd caſte theyr hooke yron shyps beeing grapled togither ſeemed fyght vpon lande romanes béeyng valyant bourded ouercame wyth one ſhip carrying awaye twoo returned th • ſkirmiſhe fyghte whole nauyes foughte togyther romaynes béeyng better ſtrength courage bycauſe heauineſſe theyr veſſells coulde ouertake lyghte shyppesthe romaine haue victori sea fledde whyche dydde wyth ſpéede epheſus▪ romanes went xio whither ſeuen twenty rhodian shippes theyr friend came antiochus hearde thys fyghte ſea hée ſente annibal ſent shippes ••• ſeth part annibal syria ſhyppes phoenitia cilicia came rhodians droue pamphilia taking parte hys shyppes lying wayte publius scipio came aetolia conſull hauingcourage scipio armye manius hée diſdayned make ſiege citties aetol • ſmall matter gaue leaue ſende another ambaſſage rome hée would trye antiochus brother office ſhoulde ende ſo paſſed macedonia thracia helleſp • n • whyche paynefull harde waye vnto hym notwithſtanding phillippe macedonie guide hym making brydges preparing victual twoo scipions releaſed philip releaſed hym reſte money hadde paye ſo order senate founde hym faithful ſente pruſias kyng bythinia declaryng howe manye kyngs romaynes hadde aduaunced confederate nowe philippe macedonie whome ouercome late graunted kingdome reſtored ſonne pledge forgaue mony oughte pruſias hearde ioyned againſt antiochus pruſias ioyneth vvith romaine liuius admirall romane nauye heard scipions commyng left pauſimachus rhodiane rhodian ſhips aeolide parte owne n • uy withsc •• u rh ••• ion al reſt ſailed helleſpont receiue army sestus rhateion porte acheans yéelded byd •• diſobeyed beſieged liuius gone▪ pauſimachus made manye diuiſes inuentions ſundry engine faſtened yron veſſells carrying fyre • long shippe ſtaues heaue vppe manye▪ fyres sea caſte oute owne ſhippes hée ſhoulde ioyne ennimyes while thus deuiſing polyxenides admirall ofa falſe countrey man antiochus radian alſo baniſhed hys countrey certayne cauſes went aboute deceyue hym promiſing deliuer hym antiochus nauy woulde helpe reſtore hym hys countrey ſuſpected crafty ſubtil man tooke good héede polyxenides didde write letter hys owne hande treaſon departed epheſus ſent army forragyng faſhion pauſimachus ſéeyng hys departure thence truſting man treaſon woulde wryte hys owne hande whych lyke done diſſembler gaue credite kept leſſe guarde ſent men forrage abroade alſo polyxenides perceyued deceyued gathered hys army ſent nicander pirate wyth fewe samos come vpon pauſimachus backe lande mydnyghte ſet forwarde mornyng watche beyng aſléepe hée aſſayled hym taken thus ſodainelye vnprepared commaunded hys ſouldioures leaue ſhippes reſiſte enimy lande nicander came vpon thethe rodian shippes diſtroyed falshode backe thinking land beſet alſo onely hée ſawe many mo beyng yet night returned agayne hys ſhyppes wyth muche adoe firſte fought firſte fell vſing himſelfe valiauntlye eyther taken ſuncke ſauing ſeauen carryed fyre wyth whome none durſte meddle flame fledde reſt polyxenides ledde awaye pryſes epheſus thys victorye phocea againe samos cyme reuolted cyme aeolia • •• ochus liuius beyng nowe afraide hys shyppes hée lefte aeolide ſayled thither haſte eumenes hym rodians ſent romanes twentye shyppes making delaye wyth good courage ſayled epheſus preparing themſelues fight none came againſt lefte halfe ſhippes good time ſea halfe ſpoyled coaſte enimie tyl nicander romanes driuen shippes came vppon lande taking praye droue shippes came samos▪ nowe time liuius office expired tyme seleucus antiochus ſonne inuaded eumenes eumenes beſieged lande beſieged pergamo ſhutting men within cittie wherefore eumenes ſayled wyth ſpéede elaea whyche porte towne kyngdome l aemilius regulus wyth ſuccéeded liuius matter ſea came eumenes hys confederats one thouſand footemen adiophanes hundred choiſe horſemen whoſe generall diophanes hée perceyued souldiours seleucus play drinke paſſed little required pergameneans ſally vpon enimy durſte armed hys thouſandthe valiantneſſe acheans footemen hundred horſemen leading wall ſtoode quietly enimies lookyng ſtil vpon ſo yet durſt ſet vpon dinner gaue ye onſet vpō ye warder arming thēſeluesthe covvardi •• pergama •• taking horſes fléeing folowed béeing confuſion durſte abide hadde noble victorie pergamenians cry oute wall yet durſte come foorth hauing ſlaine manye coulde ſhorte onſet carying away ſome horſes men priſoners tooke hys place next day brought acheans y• wal pergamenians durſte yet come seleucus many horſemen drewe neare prouoked hym hee ſtoode ſtill wall kept charge seleucus hadde tarryed tyll middaye hée tourned seleucus king ſonne▪ wente awaye diophanes ſet vppon hindermoſt ſcattered hurte many whyche béeyng done hée retired wall vſyng thys manner continuallye alwaies laying wayte went forrage wood ſo troubled made seleucus leaue pergam • droue hym place eumenes betwéene romanes polyxenides long myoneſus▪ lie epheſus fyght ſea myoneſ • whiche polixenides hadde ten hundred armed ſhippes lucius romanes admirall hadde 83 whiche fyue twenty rhodians whereof eudorus beyng capitaine left wing ſée polixenides much aboue romanes feared bée incloſed therefore ſayled aboute lighte ſhippes well practiſed sea ſhippes carryed fyre ſet vppon polixenides flaming euery ſide fire durſte deale wyth bicauſe fire circle ſayled auoyding kéeping ſeathe fight ſea ſtroke ſides till one rhodian ſhippe fell vppon one sydonian shippes wyth ſuche vehemence anker fell sidonian shyppe rhodian helde faſte togither fight ſhyppes mouing bin vpon lande commyng either ſide many helpe fellowe noble fyghte ane th • midde battell shyppes antiochus beyng lefte naked romaynes ſayled forwarde encloſed theyr vnexperte ennimyes whyche perceyued turned fledde whyche king loſte nine twentye whereof thyrtéene taken menne romanes loſte twoo polixenides hauyng taken one rhodian went epheſus fyghte sea myoneſium antiochus heard fortified cherroneſus lyſimachia verye ſtronglye thinking greate matter indéede héepe romanes paſſyng wyth theyr armye reſte thracia ſhoulde haue harde painefull way except philip conuey antiochus beyng ••• y lighte ſoone chaunging hearde loſſe myoneſus hée vlterlye dyſmayed thoughte god againſte hym romanes hadde better ſea beyonde reaſon whiche thought himſelfe mighty anni • al ſhutte vppe pamphilia philip conducting romaynes vnknowne wayes whome thoughte woulde rather haue remembred hurte hadde theſe thinges béeingin calamity ſenſe fayleth meruellouſly troubled god taking wi •• hym commonly hapneth calamity left cherroneſus fondly enimies ſighte regarding howe greate preparation victuall armoure money antiochus giueth ouer munition whyche hée dydde burne lefte whole ennimyes forſooke lyſimachians thoughe cittie hadde bene taken whyche fledde vnto hym theyr wiues child wéeping onelye hys care kéepe romaynes abydus putting reſte abydus aſia ouer againſt •• ſtus europe hope thys warre altogyther neyther dydde hée kéepe paſſage god taking ſenſe hym went midde lande ha •• e preuente hys ennimye leauing guarde scipions hearde thys departure went lyſimachia haſte tooke armoure money cherroneſo quicklye paſſed helleſpont voyde defence came sardies kyng perceyued hée confounded vtterlye deiected laying hys owne faultes vppon fortune hée ſente heraclides byzance scipions make ende warre granico floud little aſia offering smyrna alexandrîa granico lampſaco whiche warre béeganne halfe expences warre hée willed 〈◊〉 néede graunte citties ionian eoleans tooke romaynes parte thys warre whatſoeuer thyng scipions antiochus ſeeketh peace woulde require thys wylled heraclides ſpeake • penty • • ut priuatelye offer publius scipio promiſe much money antiochus alſo libertye hys ſonne antiochus taken grecia ſayling calcide tohere author ſeemeth take one another scipio yonger priſoner antiochus diametriade ſon scipio tooke deſtroyed carthage ſeconde time ſeconde man named affricanus ſonne paulus ouercame perſeus macedonia beyng scipio ſiſters ſonne degrée hys ſonne adoption scipions openly made thys aunſwere heraclide antiochus haue peace muſte leaue citties ionia aeolia countrey aboute taurus defraye whole charge warre whiche hath bin cauſe yet priuatelye publius ſaide thus antiochus offered theſe condition peace hée hadde lyſimachia cherroneſus romanes woulde willinglye haue accepted peraduenture hadde forbidde onely paſſe helleſpont nowe vppon landethe romaine haue bridle horſe ſafe place hadde onely bridle ſay alſo mounted horſe bridle woulde accept ſuche condition wordes giue kyng thankes hys great offer woulde gyue hym greater ſent ſonne preſent time would wyſh take condition béefore driuen proofe greater burden publius hadde ſaide thus went elaea healthe leauing cneus domitius legate brother antiochus phillippe macedonie thinking coulde taken hym war propounded gathered armye plaine uf thyatira farre hys enimies ſente scipio ſonne elaea bée counſelled elaea ile propontide tovvne e • ld • bringers kyng ſhoulde fighte tyll hee came againe campe antiochus giuing credite hym encamped hill sipyl • defenced hys campe wyth ſtrong wall put floud phryg •• betwéene enimies domitius deſirous trie fight himſelfe paſſed floud boldly going within two myle halfe antiochus encamped foure dayes togither either ſet men order camp neyther thē beginning fight fifth day domitius ſet order againe came forth proudely antiochus came againſt remoued camp nigher one day béeing paſt proclaymed hearing enimies hée would next day fight whether antiochus woulde hée antiochus prouoked fight troubled changed purpoſe might haue kept within camp manfully reſiſt theſe till publius come thought ſhame refuſe fighte number wherefore toke order battell came forth laſt watch yet nighte eyther thus arayed themſelues tenne thouſand romane footemen helde left wing floud tenne thouſande italian appointed alexander philip ſtandeth middeſt diuided thouſand ſixe hundred ten part euery parte theſe front fifty men middeſt two thirtie y• ſide eyther part two twēty ſight phalanx like wall therefore gathered togither archer dariers lighte harneſſe commaunding goe againſte chariot ſhoote agaynſte horſes men horſe chariot ſtriuing hys yoke reſt chariot made vnprofitable many time breaketh romanes made flée followed great battell macedonian ſette horſemen ſtreight place guadrate voyde horſemen eyther ſide receyued ſkirmiſhers fought front diuiding themſelues cloſing againe domitius horſemen lighte harneſſe eaſilie compaſſed thicke ſquare neither fitte gyue onſet enlarge themſelues ſo broad manfully abode much force greeued experiēce could good ſtand receyue ſtripes wound enimies euery ſide ſtretched forthe pike ſquare manner chalenged romanes trie manhoode hand hande hadde ſo much prayſe yet march forth fote heauie harneſſed ſeing enimies horſe chiefly ſhould diſſolue ſure aray romanes came vpon woulde fight fearing experience ſtrength ſo valiant men running aboute dyd ſhoote dart neuer miſſed ſo many cloſed ſo little roome neyther could auoyde dartes approch threw vpon wherefore endured long time neceſſitie gaue backe turned way threat orderly fearefull romanes neither durſt ſette vpon hurte could go till elephant brake vppon macedonian battell whiche woulde romanes cittie ſlaine foure twentye horſemen thrée hundred footemen chiefly whome antiochus ſlewe eumenes loſte fiftéen horſemen kyngs loſſe hys confederate iudged fiftie thouſand could well numbred multitude elephant ſlaine ſaue fiftéene taken thys victorie ſo noble beyonde reaſon ſome thoughte beyng lyke ſo fewe ſtraunge country ſhould ouercome ſo many eſpecially macedonian phalanx furniſhed full men whiche valiauntneſſe terrible thought inuincible friendes antiochus accuſed raſheneſſe falling romaine vnſkilfulneſſe fooliſhneſſe beginning lefte cherroneſus lyſimachia oute hys handes full munition money thethe errours antiochus romanes came alande trye neglected guarding helleſpont whiche romanes thoughte could eaſlye paſſe force blamed alſo laſt ouerſight making chief ſtrength vnprofitable plaeing ſo ſtreight putting truſt mingled multitude men freſh ſoloures men experience time acquainted warre continuaunce ſame endued valiauntneſſe courage theſe ſpéeches made antiochus romanes encreaſed incourage thought nothing harde bothe vertue fauoure god make opinion felicitie ſo againſt ſo many expedition firſt fight ſtraunge land ſhould ouercome one daye ſo many nation ſo princely power vertue hired ſoldioures glorie macedonian great dominion king hadde gotten ſurname great ſpéeche talke king antiochus great greate word among romanes thus gloried themſelues conſul brother publius come recouered elaea anſwered antiochus ambaſſadors required learne antiochus ſhoulde friend romanes publius anſwered thus vnto antiochus hathe bin cauſe bothe theſe former troublesanſvvere king ambaſſadours thorowe hys ambition hauing greate kyngdome romanes ſuffring haue tooke ptolomie hys kinſman friend romanes caeleſyria inuaded europe nothing ſubdued thracia fortified cherroneſus builded lyſimachia came grecia made grecian bond romanes made frée til ouercome battaile thermopylei whence though fled lefte ambition ouercome diuerſe tymes v ſea paſſed helleſpont deſired peace condition whereof throughe pride contemned gathered mighty army gret preparation made war againe againſte v compulſion broughte trye better till ouercome hys greate loſſe fitte ſhould ſet greater puniſhement vpon ſo manye tymes hathe violentlye dealte romanes wil inſolēt felicitie aggrauate others calamitie therefore giue ſame condition appointed adding fewe whiche profytable v ſhall commodious ſafety tyme come refraine al europe aſia ſide taurus condition peace theſe limites ſhall appointed deliuer al elephantes hath many ſhips ſhall commaunde hereafter haue elephant ſhips ſhall appoint deliuer xx pledge preſident ſhall preſcribe giue expences warre begun hym fiue hundred talent euboea preſentlye senatethe leaſt talent vvas lx • ſhal approue league ij v c friendſhip senate ſhal ratifie thus scipio determine ambaſſadoures accepted paide parte mony hande deliuered twenty pledge whereof antiochus king yonger ſonne one whome scipioni antiochus ſon • ſent cilicia limite antiochus kingdome doe paſſe niake warre kéepe twelue armed ſhips onely rule ſubiectes obedience warre made vpon vſe harborowe romanes receiue fugitiues change pledge euery iij yeares thermo tribune ſente hym thys ende warre betwene romanes antiochus called great ſéemed obtained kindeneſſe hee ſhewed scipio reſtoring hys ſonne ſome accuſed scipio two tribune noted hym corruption prodition hée deſpyſyngscipio • accuſed contemning accuſation come court daye afore ouerthrowne carthage ſent make ſacrifice capitoll came himſelfe pallaice judgement goodly ſhew ſad mourning like accuſed man euery man wondring fauouring hym worthye man greate courage cleare conſciencethe courage scipio beganne ſpeake ſaide nothing accuſation made rehearſall life ſeruice al act howe manye warres finiſhed countrey whome ouerthrowne howe ofte victorye ſo muche pleaſure • earers noble declaration hiſtorie came warre carthage moſt delated manner thereof wyth great vehemence audience people ſaying daye romanes conquere made carthage obey til moſt terrible vnto day goe ſacrifice capitoll many loue country accompany ſacrifice made hauing ſaide thus went forth capitoll paſſing complainte people followed ſo manye judge prayſing open voice ſaide like while ſacrificing accuſers diſcoraged durſt proſecute cauſe purpoſe blame people fauoure perceyuing life price ſuſpition calumniation scipio ſéemeth wiſe ſtoute behauioure contempte accuſation aristides béeing accuſed ariſtides ſo conſtant scipio socrates fraude socrates thinges whereof hée charged neyther anſwering like diſcredite ſauing socrates ſpeaketh pleaſeth plato yea couragious epiminondas ruler booetians pelopida thebanes hadde ſente gyuing either armye helpe areadians • ſenians warre laconian bycauſe thynges 〈◊〉 •• done entended accuſed called home deliuered army ſucceſſoures ſixe moneths whiche time expelled lacedemonian garriſons placed arcadian epaminondas compelling companion doe promiſing doyng therof ſhoulde hurtefull come home accuſers proſecuting matter againſte euerye condemned dye lawe iudged hym die violence would rule man office eſcaped vſing lamentation many wordes laying al blame epaminondas ſo willed ſay would affyrme condemned dye ſaide confeſſe againſte lawe rule thys tyme compelled whome epaminondas • ne anſvvere haue deliuered nowe deſire pardoned hauing tranſgreſſed lawe beſéeche ſeruice haue done woulde wr • ie thus gote victorie l • nitra brought countrey sparta ſelfe whiche coulde abide thoſe enimies ſtraunger ware lacedemonian hatte condemned countrey offending lawe benefite countrey hauing ſaide thus came tribune offered bodye woulde take judge reproch thys ſpéeche maruell anſwere reuerence perſon accuſed durſte abide triall ran court theſe euery man may iudge liſteth manlius ſucceſſor scipio went lande taken antiochus gaue order galathians toleſtouij vvere people came spaine dvvell bithinia aided antiochus called tolestouians fléeing myſios olymp •• followed painefully thorough mountaines killed chaſe ſuche ſlaughter bloudſhed could numbred multitude tooke priſoners fortie thouſand burned armour ſolde body nexte barbarians▪ bycauſe coulde carry ſuche company aboute warre tectoſagans trocmans put daunger deceite mo • ius dāger whiche eſcaped returning againe vppon remayning ſtaying bycauſe ſo many brought ſhotte commaunding diſcharge vppon neither togither nighe enimie arrow ſhot vaine thickeneſſe enimies ſlewe eighte aly • flond running taurus thouſande chaſed flonde alys ariarathes kyng cappadocia confederate antiochus afraide praying peace prayer ſending two hundred talentes didde ouerrunne hys lande wente helleſpont greate rich infinite moneythe error 〈◊〉 muche ſpoile armye laden ſurely vnwiſely sommer woulde go ſea regarding waighte carriage coulde leade hys army continewe abide ſo long iorney marching war going home ſpoyles went thracia ſtreight long harde waye hote sommer neither ſende philip macedonie conducte neither diuided army many part might go lighter readye purpoſes diſtributing burden ſeueral band might better kepte caryed al togither beape ſo long way middeſt ſo neither went behind could helpe time lenath ſtraightneſſe way wherfore thracian ſetting vpō fl • nks euery loſte greate parte pray common treaſure army reſte ſaued himſelfe macedonie well perceyued howe much pleaſure philip ſhewed scipions howe muche antiochus e •• ed leauing cherroneſus thus manlius wente macedonia theſſalie theſſalie epirus epirus ſayled brunduſe ſending hys armye euery manne home went rome rhodians eumenes king pergamus aduauncing themſelues ſeruice againſt antiochus▪ eumenes went rome rhodians ſent ambaſſadours romanes gaue rhodians lycia caria whycherevvards g • rhodians long tooke bycauſe hadde warre wyth perſeus macedonie ſeemed enclined hym eumenes gaue reſterevvard eumenes revvardes greekes taken antiochus excepte gréekes payde anye tribute attalus father commaunded pay eumenes tribute paide antiochus forgaue graunted liue frée thus romanes diuided conqueſt antiochus antiochus great dieth greate deade seleucus hys ſonne ſuccéedyng hym hée ſente brother antiochus pledge rome putte hys ſonne demetrius hys place antiochus come athens seleucus killed one heli • • rius aboute eumenes attalus droue heli • • ru oute kingdome whiche hée vſurped • leutus killed reſtored antiochus haue hys friendſhippe nowe growne ſome ſuſpition romanes thus antiochus ſonne greate antiochus kyng syria syrian called notable bicauſe whē antiochus noble kingdome rauiſhed others ſhewed natural king making league eumenes raigned ouer syria nation aboute mightilye made tymarxus lieutenaunt babylon heraclides hys treaſourer beyng brother great fauour wyth hym made warre vppon artaxes king armenia whome hée hadde taken hée antiochus ſecond dieth dyed leauing antiochus ſonne nine yeares age father vertue syrian called eupater lyſias broughtantiochus eup • ter vppe child romanes heard antiochus deade ſo ſoone little tyme gote great fame glad demetrius ſonne seleucus brother antiochus notable nephew antiochus great couſin child pledge rome thrée twentye yeares age requyred admytted kyngdome neare denyed hym thinking good luſtye young man ſhoulde raigne childes place vnderſtanding manye elephantes syria shyps agréede ſent ambaſſadoures kyll elephantes burne shippes grieuous thing ſée thoſethe driuen away libyan deſired ſo muche place inhabite coulde compaſſe hyde bull laughter made •• fling ſpéeche phoenitians aſhamed denye ſo little matter chiefly maruelled howe cittie could made ſo carthaginian whyche without feare ouertunne italie bycauſe vexed home warre made vppon woulde ſende annibal thus obtained ſende scipio libya ſuffering gather men italy yet waſted annibal graunting leade ſuch would willingly goe hym vſe yet sicelie gyuing leaue prepare tenne gallies make ſupply thēthe ſlender ſetting forth scipio ſo great vvarre take sicelie money gaue none except man friendſhippe would contribute vnto ſlenderly began warre firſt redounded great honour thus scipio inflamed god againſt carthage gathering vij thouſand horſe footemen moſt ſayled sicelie hauing hymthe pollicie scipio arme 300▪ italian guarde thrée hundred choſen yong ſtriplings hée commaunded folow without armoure appointed thrée hundred wealthy sicilian come day aſſigned furniſhed good armour horſe coulde come graunted would giue ſerue place content brought forth thrée hundred vnarmed willed chaunge willinglye deliuered horſe harneſſe ſo scipio 300 italian many sicilian well furniſhed goodly horſe armoure gaue great thanks thē continually moſt ready ſeruice carthaginian hearing ſent aſdrubal giſcanes ſon ligurie part italie vvhich novv longeth genowais hunt elephant ſent mago made vnderſtanding grieued iniury made daughter yong man yet thought beſte countrey diſpatche maſsiniſſa ſhould go libya iberia death father ſent ſome conducte commaunding ſecretely coulde kil maſsiniſſa perceyuing fledde gotte hys maſsiniſſa eſcapeth traynes father kingdome gathered horſemen continuall exerciſe day night vſing wt much ſhot horſebacke giue onſet retire charge againe fight conſiſting ouercome méete romanes syphax carthaginiās many moe chariot cariage aboundaunce maſsiniſſa would himſelfe beginthe manner maſsiniſſa vvarre labour hauing horſemen cariage forrage might eaſily flie turne vpon enimies retire ſtrong place many time circumuented diuided armie might better flée partes hiding himſelfe fewe till might come night day appointed thyrde man dyd lye hidde haue enimies camping neuer ſtayd campe euer led army vnknown wher ſo enimies coulde come hand kepe backe came foode euery day could get night field town citie catching ſpoyling euery thing diuiding hys companion wherefore many numidian came vnto wagies appointed take gayn much better thus maſsiniſſa warre carthaginian whē scipio made thing ready sicelie ſacrifiſed iupiter neptune came toward libya 52 long haue sicili • sardinia ilands iberia conſent hereto would help • againſt practiſed alſo winne maſsiniſſa vnto offeringthe practiſe syphax confirme kingdome maſsilia thrée ſiſters giue whiche woulde agréed battel syphax ſhould ſet vpon •• ege aſdrubal ſhould force scipio campe shippes ſhoulde fight wyth ſhyppes nexte daye romanes bycauſe ſo fewe ſhoulde able reſiſte night maſsiniſſa vnderſtanding certaine numidian tolde scipio hée maſsiniſſa ſaueth romanes frō greate danger doubt afrayde leaſt armye muche diuided ſhoulde weake pointes called captaines night counſell ſawe ſome doubte hée ſaide boldeneſſe ſpéede friendes fight deſperationthe oration scipio touching ſodaine aſſalting ennimye nowe beſéemeth v let v go ſet vpon enimyes ſhall winne thereby learne ſodayne comming vpon ſhal amaze ſtrangeneſſe feate fewe woulde auenture vppon ſo many ſhall diuide oure army manye partes vſe togither wée ſhall ſet againſte enimyes agaynſte▪ firſte wée ſhall chooſe lodged ſeuerallye ſhal equall euerye parte • et v onely preuent boldeneſſe good lucke god graunte v ouercome firſte ſhall contemne reſte firſt ſet vpon time manner aſſault ſhall take thinke good tel mine opinion al agréed time ſaid matter ſoone go méeting beyng yet nighte whiche thyng wyll fearefull leſſe prepared n •• e confederate able helpe darke let v preuent purpoſe inuading v morrowe bée thrée campes shyppes farre fighte wyth shy • night aſdrubal syphax farre aſunder aſdrubal heade warre syphax ſhall dare nothing nighte man barbarous full daintineſſe feare let v go againſte aſdruball oure armye ſhall appoint maſ • iniſſa • ye wayte syphax hap come foorth contrarye oure opinion let v goe foote aſdrubals campe aſſaulte round wyth good hope luſty courage preſēt moſt • horſemen cannot vſe thē night wil place farre compaſſe camp enimies wée driuen backe maye receyue v flée oure friend ouercome may chaſe deſtroy hauing thus ſaide ſent away captaines arme hoſte ſacrificed boldeneſſe feare ſodainethis eare 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſuch cōmeth cauſe vnk • ovven ſtaied iu •• • r put among ti •• • feare without cauſe ſhoulde happe armye continue bolde reſt thirde watche ſignified wyth trumpet maruellous déepe ſilence ſo greate armye went till horſemen compaſſed ennimies footemen went trench broken ſhowte made manye ſoundes trumpes horne make terror droue watche place tooke trench pulled rampire boldeſt ranne ſet tent afyre libyan beyng waked offeare carthagies camp ſléepe terror running order order taking armor obeying commaundements confuſion neither generall himſelfe certainly knowing done romanes tooke leapte oute arming themſelues great turmoile ſet manye tent fyre killed ſome came ſome made afrayd crye enimie fight moſte fearefull buſineſſe nyghte ignorant euill indéede thinkyng campe hadde béene taken fearyng fyre burnyng tentes leapt themſelues wente fielde ſure place came partes miſerably killed fell romaine horſemen compaſſed al diſpatched syphax hearing crye nighte ſéeyng firean victorye romanes came foorth ſent certaine horſemen helpe aſdruball vppon maſsiniſſa came ſodainely killed hand daye come syphax hadde learned aſdrubal gone part army deſtroyed part taken ennimye ſome diſperſed romanes campe munition departed fledde midde land feare leauing behinde hym thinking syphax fleeth ouerthrowe carthaginian scipio would followe ſo campe furniture maſsiniſſa tooke thus romanes little part one night take two campes ouerthrew two army greater themſelues died romanes aboute hundred enimies little leſſe thirty thouſand priſoners two thouſande ſixe hundred taken ſixe hundred horſemen yéelded scipio retourned elephant ſome wounded ſome killed scipio golde ſiluer armoure much yuorie horſes wel numidian whiche hée scipio revvardeth hys ſouldioures hadde gote one victorie moſte noble caſting carthaginian knées gaue gift ſouldioures ſent moſte precious thinges rome exerciſed hys ſouldioures chearefullye thinkyng anniball woulde ſhortelye come oute italie mago liguria thys dydde scipio aſdruball generall carthaginian fighte aſdruball fleeth condemned ryſeth againſte hys countrey anea night hurte fled anea fyue hundred horſemen gathered ſome hyred ſouldieures eſcaped fight numidian called bondman libertye heard carthaginian determined deathe euill generall choſen hanno bomilchares ſonne place made army hys owne receyued malefactours ledde mighte haue reliefe trayned hauing thrée thouſande horſe eight thouſand footemen hauing truſte onely fight kepte long hid romanes carthaginian scipio led army walles carthage boldlye called fight none came forth amilchar admirall carthage hundred ſhippes came vppon nauy scipio thinking deſtroye abſence hoping eaſily take twenty gallies hundred scipio ſawe vnder ſayle ſent ſhut mouth porte greate shippes ſhoulde lye anker diſtaunce one another gallies might come gate néede ſhoulde require ſhoulde faſten tye ſhips togither wyth ſayle yardes might wall came furthered worke carthaginian receyued ſea lande scipio ſaueth romane shippes wall ſhot artillerie ſhippes bruſed weary went away night going romane galleis wente ſpaces appointed ſette vpon weake retired one tooke voyde men broughte hir scipio went wintring harbour romanes plenty ſea vticenſes carthaginian want robbed merchantes till romane ſhippes ſent scipio whiche ſet place kepte ennimie robbing hunger toward end winter syphax neare maſsiniſſa deſired thirde part maſsiniſſa romanes againſt syphax romanes armye ioyned hys receiued leading lelius purſued syphax fléeyng till hée came floude ſtayed fight numidian manner made ſhotte thick one againſte romanes couered theyr ſhieldes went fight syphax came fury vppon maſsiniſſa fighte betvveene tvvoo king syphax maſsiniſſa went cherefully againſt fight greate betwéene syphax men fléeing paſſed fioude whoſe horſe hurte ouerthrewe maiſter maſsiniſſa ran maſsiniſſa taketh syphax vpon hym tooke one ſonnes ſente ſtraight scipio ſlaine ten thouſand syphax ſide romanes lxxv maſsiniſſa thrée hundred syphax foure thouſand taken priſoners whereof two thouſand fiue hundred maſſulians whiche fled maſsiniſſa syphax maſſiniſſa deſired laelio receyued hée killed ouerranne maſſulians land syphax parte wherof appointed maſsiniſſa parte receyued ſubmiſſion diſobedient ſorte deſtroyed cyrtis novve conſtan • vvhere iug • rth killed adh •• b •• came ambaſſadoures cyrtis deliuer palaice syphax ſome came priuately maſsiniſſa sophoniſba syphax wife excuſe neceſſitie mariage maſsiniſſe receyueth hir gladly went againe scipio priuie meſſage •• ō sephoni • b • maſsiniſſa leauing hir cyrta ſée beſt done hereafter scipio ſayd syphax spirite tooke thée thou waſt friend praying come libya breake thy faith god thou diddeſt ſweare god breake wt romanes chooſe make warre carthage againſt romanes ſéeing carthaginian long thyne enimies ſaid sophoniſba daughter aſdruball whome loued loſſe ſhe louing hir country ſo deatly able perſwade man ſhe liſt turned hir coūtry ſo greate felicitie hath brought ſo great miſery therefore counſell thée nowe put syphax biddeth scipio bevvare sophoniſba sophiniſba ought ſure vnto kéepe sophoniſba leaſt ſhe turne maſsiniſſa ſhe wil cannot hoped ſhe wil take romanes part ſo greatly doth ſhe loue hir citie ſpake eyther truly gelouſie maſsiniſſa hinder much could scipio perceyuing syphax bee wiſe scipio vſeth syphax friendlye cyrus craeſus expert coūtry led made priuy mind counſel cyrus vſed craeſus king libya laelius come ſaid heard much sophoniſba bée many reported scipio commanded maſsiniſſa deliuer sophoniſba syphax wife refuſing excuſing done afore scipio maſsiniſſa loath leaue sophonisba commanded ſharply withholde violence romane priſoner bring hir forth alleadge ſay could went maſsiniſſa romanes deliuer sophoniſba priuily came firſte hir brought hir poyſon told hir ſhe muſt preſentlye drinke remayne flaue romanes ſpeaking tooke horſe shée ſhewing cuppe hir nurſe prayed hir bewaile hir nobleshee dyeth l •• e noble harted ladye death drunke poyſon maſsiniſſa ſhewed hir romanes buryed hir honorably retourned scipio prayſed hym tolde rid euill woman crowned hym ſeruice againſt syphax gaue many gift syphax come rome ſome thought syphax ſent rome good ſaue hym bicauſe bin friend romanes iberia ſome thought puniſh bycauſe made warre againſt friendes ſicke ſorrow dyed aſdrubal hauing wel exerciſed hys ſouldiors ſent mago y• generall syphax dyeth priſon carthaginian would make fellow y• war ſhe wing many iberian scipio man woulde corrupte golde promiſe might burne scipio camp time preſcribed would
