came vpon day weary way watch thyrſt annibal loth come fighte yet bycauſe ſhoulde wante water tarryed fledde enimie woulde take courage ſet vpon hym conſidering thought good neceſſitie try put order fifty lxxx elephant placed battel ſpaces betwéen make moſt terrible third gym • • • ilands called • • eares novv ••• c • nicorea e • camas parte armye celtians ligurians theſe myred archer ſlyngers maerruſia gymnaſias thē ſeconde army whiche carthagians libyan third folowed italie truſted moſt bicauſe feared caſe horſe men aboute wing thys annibals order scipio xxiij thouſande horſemen italie scipio order rome thouſand fiue hundred maſsiniſſa many horſemen numidia lacamas another prince ſixe hundred horſe ſet footemen thrée battels anniball made particion betwéene bandes horſemenne might paſſe eaſily made euery bande defence front ſtrong pertches layde ouer yron two cuvits long thicke kepe backe elephantes engine warned footemen giue place furie thoſe beaſtes caſt dartes vpon faſt coulde nigh cutte ſinowes coulde thus placed scipio numidian horſe placed wing acquainted fight fury elephant italian horſe bicauſe vſed ſet laſt readye paſſe diſtances footemen bidden firſt violence elephant ſorts horſmen company ſhotte ioyned annoy beaſtes thus horſemen ſet right wing gaue laelius left octauius middeſt annibal kepe glorie hauing horſemen attending vpon helpe nede ſhould annibal thrée thouſand scipio two thouſande thrée hundred italian armed sicelie ready encouraged men scipio called god witneſſe army againſt carthaginian offended ofte brake promiſe scipio ſouldiours required hys army loke number enimies owne vertue number ouerthrowen euen lande ouercome haue anye feare doubte muche neceſſitie muſt haue haue bin ouercome thus scipio encourage ſtirre fewe number annibal recorded feates hadde done italie enterpriſe moſte annibal ſouldiours great renoume among numidian among italian italie ſhewed fewe enimies exhorted worſe fewe moe countrey declare vnto ſouldiours daunger greatneſſe preſent fight annibal ſhewed carthage libya tryed thys fighte whether ſhoulde ſlaues ouercome rule hereafter ouer wonne scipio tolde hys defeated ſafe returne dyd ouercome great dominion ſhoulde fall vnto reſt preſent paynes going home country renouine euer thus eyther encouraging went fight annibal ſounded firſt scipio commaunded aunſwere elephant beganne fight moſt terrible manner ſpurred prickes rider numidian h ••• ementhe elephant put backe vvings ranne threwe dartes thicke vppon ſo wounded fledde troubled parte kepers led away firſtthe elephant trouble romanes fotemen battel enterpriſe elephant wing army midde battel romaine trode downe footemē vnacquainted fight ſo heauy harniſed could hardly giue place goe forewarde tyll scipio scipio leaueth horſe fight vvith b • ephan • broughte foorth italian horſemenne placed behynde ſhotte commaundyng leaue horſes afrayde goe aboute ſhoote elephant firſt alighted wounded elephant came afore ſouldiours encouraged therby hurtyng beaſtes made alſo go battel fighte cleared beaſts nowe men horſes right wing romaine whyche laelius ledde putte flighte numidian agaynſte maſſiniſſa wounded maſsintha prince annibal comming maſsiniſſa vvoū deth maſsintha quickly vnto ſette againe fight left battayle▪ whyche octauius gouerned much adoe ennimies french ligurians scipio ſente thermus helpe wyth choyſe men anniball hauing ſtayde lefte battayle roade ligurians frenchman brynging another bande libyan carthaginian whiche scipio ſawe came againſte scipio annibal fighte another band theſe two moſte noble captaines dyd thus contend euidente emulation care ſides diligence lefte eyther parte laboure ſharper exhortation vehement fight beyng long doubtfull captaines hauing pittie weary ſouldiours coupled togither ende mighte ſhorter threw one another scipio hytte annibals ſhielde annibal ſtroke scipio • horſe horſe wounde ouerthrewe scipio hee mounted agayne threw annibal miſſed hurt horſe next maſsiniſſa vnderſtanding came thyther romaynes maſsiniſſa commeth danger scipio vvas ſéeing theyr capitayne fighting lyke souldiour toke courage agaynſt enimies putte backe chaſed anniball ryding aboute vaine praying ſtaye perſwading turne agayne fight annibal greate doubte broughte italian romanes skil • ight came hym yet ſtyrring place ſuccoure fighte hoping breake romaynes araye eaſily bycauſe folowing ennimye ſéeing deuiſe called one another diligently chaſe put themſelues againe order fighte nowe hauing horſe ſhotte ſpent fought togyther blade great ſlaughter manye woundes grones fell ſhoutes dyd kyll tyll romaynes putte backe made flye alſo victorye euident annibal ſéeing annibal renevveth fight numidian horſemen ſtande ſtyl ranne prayed forſake hym perſwaded brought againſt chaſed thinking notable feate againe firſte mette maſſulians fought maſsiniſſa annibal fighteth fighte onely betwéene maſsiniſſa anniball fiercelye going maſsiniſſa ſtroke annibals target hitte maſsiniſſas horſe foote flewe vppon anniball killed horſe comming vppon hym dartes receyued vppon hys ſhielde drewe one ſtucke vppon threw annibal miſſing killed nexte horſe drawing another wounded arme went oute battell whyle •• pi • hearde scipio commeth reliefe maſsinaſſa afrayde maſsinaſſa came fraye found maſsiniſſa horſed going field againe hauing tyed wound fight equall agayne ſore fides eyther afrayde capitaynes tyll annibal dydde ſee iberian frenchman ne ſtaying vppon hill • rrour battel roade bring forth againe foughte knowing cauſe thinkyng going bin flying lefte fighte willyngly fledde diſorderedly lookyng toward annibal euery man coulde thus brake romaine fielde hadde bene fully gotte purſued order neyther vnderſtanding annibals purpoſe returned spaniard frenchman wherefore scipio called men againe chaſe ſpéede ſet order came hyll wherefore mighte eaſily reſiſt annibal • yeth annibal deceyued laſte hope fledde vtterly diſpayring thing manye horſemen followed ſpecially maſsiniſſa beyng grieued wounde euer hande deſirous haue brought priſoner scipto night diuided annibal flyeth thonne annibal darke twentie horſemen could folow fled cittie called thonne whither vnderſtoode many horſemen b • utia iberia come field fearing iberian barbarous cruel doubting brutians italian countrey men scipio leaſt woulde leade scipio forgiuen faulte againſt itali • priuily fled one horſeman truſted beſt running three thouſand • urlongs two nightes annibal cōmeth haſt adrume •• two dayes came citie ſea called adrumet • parte armye victuall ſending aboute gathering fledde made armoure munition scipio hauing got ſo noble victorie burned vnprofytable scipio • e • deth lal ••• vvith nevves rom • ſpoyle beyng gyrded romanes generalls went ſent rome ten talent golde ij v c ſiluer wrought iuorie moſt noble priſoners l • lius meſſenger victorie reſte tooke honor ſouldiours gaue giftes beſte maſsiniſſa crowne went tooke city ende annibal scipio fighte libya firſt time fought togither dyed romaynes two thouſand fiue hundred maſsiniſſas enimies fiue twenty thouſand priſoners taken eighte thouſande fiue hundred iberian thrée hundred yeelded scipio numidian eight hundred maſsiniſſa neyther carthaginian romanes yet hearing carthage ſent mago gathering yet frenchemen inuade italie hée coulde ſayle liby • wyth hys hyred ſouldioures romanes intercepting theſe letter ſent scipio army horſe footemen shyppes money scipio ſent octauius carthage ſēdeth scipio peace lande carthage hymſelfe went water carthage vnderſtoode annibals ouerthrow ſēt ambaſſadours pynneſſe hanno magnus aſdrubal haedus chiefe ſet vp banner peace ſtemme held vp hand scipio deſiring pardon hée carthage • ueth peace willed go campe placed vpon highe ſeate gaue audience teares fell grounde taken vp officer commaunded ſay woulde annibal 〈◊〉 ſpake parte romanes hanno manye wiſe carthage cleare oure ſelues faulte put vppon v embaſſadoures oure people driuen hunger offended ſaued ſent home yet wée muſte blame carthage ſome deſired peace firſte andpeople free citties diſobedent kepte firmely city ſoone drawne worſt whiche pleaſant preuayleth euer multitude whiche haue proued beyng neither able perſwade ſtay accuſe v take frée ſpéeche v iudge v romanes obedience counſell ſéemeth ſaulte ſlowe obey blame hunger neceſſitie droue v cō ſtrained act ſo deſire peace gyue ſo much money deliuer al long ſhips ſaue fewe yéelde great parte oure dominion ſweare ſend othe rome ambaſſadors yet willingly offend manne may blame god chiefly ſtorme droue corne carthage beſide ſtorme hū ger tooke cannot conſider well men thing beyng néede thinges require good reaſon rude myſerable multitude iudge v vniuſtlye miſerye confeſſe pray forgiueneſſe juſtificationiuſtification submiſsion • offend ſubmiſſion offende mercy proſperitie ought readier beholding chaunces men conſidering ſodaine mutation crie pardon yeſterday able hurte citie carthage greateſt mightieſt libya ſhippes money elephant army foote horſemen many ſubiects haue flouriſhed theſe 700 yeares ruled al libya nation ilandes ſo great part ſea comming againſt many time contention nowe neyther shyppes elephant horſe ſubiects whiche haue taken v haue hope helpe haue euill vſed whiche conſideryng marking alteration ought vſe felicitie temperately doe ſhall ſéeme worthye magnanimitie romanes fortune carthage ſometime put mutation • ate miſfortunes voide enuy may without blame afore god deſerue prayſe men feare nowe carthaginian wyll rebel ſo great repentance paine former follie doth fall vppon good counſell kéeper innocencie wiſe men offendoures repent haue ſuffered like conſtant theyr dueties neuer ſuche experience neither fit folow carthaginian whome accuſe cruelty wickedneſſe miſery want calamitie beginning offence proſperitie pleaſure vſe humanitie ſhall honorable profitable aucthoritie rather ſaue kill ſo greate cittie bée nowe better judge youre commodity wée bring twoo thynges aſſurance thereof worthineſſe dominion carthage ſomtime hath youre moderation towarde men beyng ioyned wyth armes hath brought ſo great empire power condition gyue v peace take whiche ſay committing haedus ſaide thus muche ceaſed scipio willing auoid conferred officer determined called ſaid worthy pardon ſo • ſte haue broken peace scipio embaſſadoures carthage laſtely de •• ied oure embaſſadoures ſo manifeſtly wickedly offending againſte v neyther purge youre ſelues ſhewe matter contrary worthy extreame puniſhement néede accuſe confeſſe flée prayer woulde haue lefte name rome got victory haue done ſuche thyng embaſſadours yet rome broken league violated oure embaſſadors citie deliuered béeyng dryuen myne armye ſente vnhurte made warre v therefore ought thinke gaine whatſoeuer receiue hauing condē ned ſelues ſaye thinke good senate ſhall determine ſhal pleaſe wée giue peace agayne carthaginian gyue youre long shyppes vnto romaynes except ten elephant haue thoſe tooke pay thē loſt iudge doubt priſoners run awayes ſo many annibal brought 〈…〉 thus within thirty dayes peace made threeſcore dayes mag • ſhall departe •• g ••• take garriſons oute city whiche without •••• p ••• nicia deliuer pledge haue euery yeare ſhall bring two hundred talentes euboea fity yeares ſhall h • frenchman ligurians ſhal make warre vpon maſs ••• ſſ • friend carthage war againſt common conſent ſhall haue citie ſo muche lande phoenician ditche ſayled libya ſhal friend romaynes bothe ſea lande senate confirme confirme romanes ſhall go libya hundred fiftye dayes haue truce ſend rome ſhall giue v hand hundred fifty oſtages ſuch child ſhall chooſe ſhall giue expences warre thouſand talent victuall army peace concluded ſhall receiue pledge scipio ſaid thus embaſſadours bare fault carthage people reſorting manye dayes counſell beſte ſorte thought good accept condition putte al hazarde ſticking ſomewhat corne ſhoulde go away people conſideringpeople reſiſte peace preſent perill taking awaye reſiſt grieued ruler ſhould take away corne romanes famme giue ſteade citizen truce ſtoode aboute euery threatned burne houſes ſpoyle ende knowing annibal hadde gathered ſixe thouſand footemen fiue hundred horſemen ſtaying citie named marthma called counſell theſe matter came ſober ſorte afraide man warre woulde haue ſtirred people perſwaded verye annibal perſu • ſa • deth peace grauely receiue peace people outragiouſly ſpake euill threatned till noble men fledde ſome maſsimſſa ſome romanes willingly deſpayring citie carthaginian vnderſtanding annibal hadde gathered corne plentifullye storehouſe made muche adoe tyll gote diuided among meane time newes come rome newein place greeke texte vnperfect peace scipio made carthage matter debated senate houſe one senatoures ſaide thus wée ſhoulde agrée peace iniuriousdiſcorde senate houſe touching peace vniuſte • scipio whiche ſuſpecting ſéemeth declared minde vnto v added wée made delay woulde make peace like hée conſidereth matter better ſéeth bycauſe hath al wée doe otherwiſe ſhall offende hys eſtimation good citizen noble capitayne prouoked v vnwilling ſende affrica hauyng army v gette one himſelfe hathe promoted v ſo farre could hope therefore wondered ſo faint beginning warre nowe ſo earneſt vehement nowe man thinketh bée well yet feareth carthaginian breake thys league nowe moſte like wyll kéepe peace ſo ofte afflicted breaking henceforth kéepe juſtice better beyng fallen knée vnrighteouſneſſe like counſell nowe deſpiſe carthaginian power againe feare might rebell eaſie v kéepe ſhall riſe deſtroy preſently nowe wil fighte deſperation might kepe vnder feare haue euils ynow without v wyth whome neighbour grieued crueltie maſsiniſſa man moſte faithfull v ſhall euer lye wait thē man contemne al thinketh may ſuccéede scipio hys owne commoditie haue like ſucceſſe hée hath ende ſhall citie happe take ſhall deſtroy vtterly bicauſe ſpoyled ſhips victualls whiche content deliuer muche morecontention rome peace vvith carthage wil auoide anger god hate men shall giue maſsiniſſa thoughe friend yet made ſtrong let contende togither common weale rome wil wee make rent country armye ſhall kéepe therevvhat conſidered vvarre ſpende reuenne ſhall ſtand feare manye nighe nation barbarian ſend inhabitant middeſt numidian beyng moſt ſtrong barbarian alwaies worke oure wo get better hande ſhall terrible hatefull v euer hauing ſo gret land much better whiche scipio iudge perceyuing thoughte good v heare prayer carthage therefore let v conſent prayer generall thus ſaid p cornelius cornelius lentulus kinſman conſull p cornelius ſpeaketh againſt peace scipio offered carthaginian thoughte good ſuccéede scipio ſpake agaynſte thys ſorte warres onely profite conſidered bicauſe hathe bin declared cittie yet power bée maintained ought take away vnfaithfulneſſe togyther power might vnfaithfulneſſe ſhall neuer take away tyme ſo fit v deliuered feare carthage thys preſent bée poore weake growe ſtrength againe yet doe ſwarue conſideration juſtice thinke oure cittie ſhall ſéeme deale • ute reaſon carthaginian weale doe iniurie deſpite al men wo fal prayer obtaine forſake agréement againe neyther haue regarde promiſe reſpect othe whome wée muſte ſaue feare god enuy men thinke god themſelues haue brought carthaginian point ſuffer wickedneſſe violating peace made v sicilie iberia italie libya ſelfe haue wrought great miſchiefe trouble v ſhewe ſome example ſtrange nation come may ſée agrée carthage ſhoulde puniſhed deſtroyed sagunt noble citie iberia confederat sigunt novve called mur • edre manifeſt ſaide vnto sicilie receiued youre pledge ſhould haue reſte oure commaundements vtica choice ſpéedye bringing pledge praiſe néedeth armour kéepe peace purely deliuer youre publike priuate armoure euery man hathe bring v youre ſhot munition thus ſaide ambaſſadoures ſaide woulde obey thys alſo afraid aſdrubal béeing condemned proclamation leading xx men encamping carthage woulde reūſt broughte order conſulls cenſorinus eloquent fellowe ſtoode vp ſeuere countenaunce ſaid thusthe carthaginian commā ded forſake citie praiſe carthage obedience readineſſe deliuering pledge armour men neceſſitie ſhorte ſpéeche behoueth forſake carthage dwel wil four ſcore furlong ſea determined deface carthage while ſaying thys held vp hand crie heauens called vppon goddes men deceyued wiſhed euils vppon romanes mē would die beſide themſelues prouoke romanes hate embaſſadors fel vpon earthe hand head beate ſome tore garment defiled body driuen beſide themſelues paſſion paſte great ſilence aſtoniſhmēt appeared though bin dead romanes amazed conſulls knew ſtricken wyth ſtrange commandement wold paſſion timeso • aine paſion perceiuing well greateſt grief doe ſtrike moſt vehemently firſt time neceſſitie cauſeth boldneſſe obey thus carthaginian aſflicted ſilence féeling greater matter ceaſed diſdainefulneſſe fel wéeping lamenting themſelues child wiues name country though hadde hearde woulde haue remoue ſhall ſéeme angry men holy thing god sepulchre cittie hathe offended romanes haue regard good fame rightwiſeneſſe workes ſhewe modeſtie proſperitie add vſe toward take remembre iupiter goddes yet haue carthage doe bring euills vppon youre child blotte good fame firſt vppon v deface youre glorye wyth ſuche acte euill done euill bée hearde begon firſt afore lyuing haue béene manye warres betwéene gretians barbarian manye béetwéene romanes others yet neuer anye defaced citye giuing handes afore fight deliuering theyr armour child hurte worlde ſufer patiently bringing goddes ſworne fortunereuengement belongeth god man moſte fearfull goddes reuengeaunce felicitie wée beſéeche diſhonoure ſelues vpon ſtate hath proſpered neyther bring youre felicitie infamye giue v leaue ſuffer v haue oure cittie ſende embaſſadoures againe senate make interceſſion ſée little diſtance time bringing heape long torment ſhorte duety thing come youre power doe either nowe ſhortly let pittie humanitie preſent ſaid hanno conſulls euidently ſéemed ſad ſpake bycauſe could graunt nothing made end cenſorinus ſaid senate hathe commaunded néede wéethe romane conſull carthaginian ſpeake much hathe commaunded muſt obeyed neither ſtaye haue commaunded bée doone commaunde oure ennimyes wée doe ſpeake muſte done bycauſe common profit talke bothe muche carthaginian refuſe ſpeake reaſon perſwaded rather compelled sea putting insea occaſion offence mynde power dominion ſtirreth offende fal aduerſitie haue ouercomesicilie spaine sicilie done ſayled spaine tooke tyme truce ye robbed merchaunts chiefly cure might knowne ye drowned till ye taken paide sardinia penaltie loſte sardinia sea whiche naturally prouoketh men couet much bicauſe ſpéedy commoditie athenienſes seaman didde winne muche loſte sea like marchauntes gaines hathe great encreaſe loſtesea like marchauntes know whome nowe named dilating theyr dominion ionian ſea ile sicilie ceaſe coueting hadde loſte power athenienſes • oſt al couering much ſea giuen porte shippes ennimies receyued garriſon cittie pulled downe long wall made dwell vppon highe lande whiche ſaued moſte parte surer life carthaginian vppon lande labouring earth quyetneſſegaine vppon •• nd leſſe ſure peraduenture gaine leſſe ſurer leſſe dangerous certainly huſbandry merchaundiſe cittiea citie ſea like shippe ſea ſéemeth rather ſhippe ſea bicauſe high wals therfore cenſorinus remoued ſea carthaginian whē y• winde blew toward romanesthe carthagies burne part romanes nauy filled boates flaxe bruſhe within wals enimyes ſhould ſée carthagies bolder vppon manlius night ſome armed ſome vnarmed carying bridge aſſaulted next trenche manlius beganne pull downe rampire ſouldiours within beyng troubled nighte time scipio came horſemen contrarye parte enimies feared carthagies comming vpon retired citie fight ſouldiours diſordered night scipio thought haue ſaued againe nobly manlius kepte campe ſure making wall rampire erecting tower towarde ſea ſhippes brought victual turning lande ten thouſande footemenne two thouſande horſe waſted countrey gathering woode corne victuall one tribune another ſerue turne phameas captaine thephameas horſemen yong deſirous fight vſing little light horſes fedde graſſe none ſuffer hunger thirſte néede kéeping ſecret vallies wood whē ſaw thē negligēt came foorth ſodayn like eagle ſpoyled retired whē scipio cōmaunded ye army wold apeare scipio led people euer order horſemen kéepingthe circumſpection scipio horſebacke raunging woulde diſſolue hys order beſet field would ſpoyle horſemen armed footemen roade bandes kepte forager lefte companie went compaſſe therfore phameas wold come vponenuie againſt scipio often done scipio great glorye captaynes enuying gaue friendſhip betwéen aunceſtours phamea grandfather scipio libyan fledde tower fortes scipio iuſt promiſe many ye country tribune would couenaunt depart aſſaile thē went scipio would ſend home therfore ſuch fame valiātneſſe faith would truſt except scipio gaue word ſo honoured enimies comming foraging libyan aſſaulted caſtle nauy night cōfuſion great eſcries yt carthagies made cauſe ye terror mālius kept mē within knowing matter scipio takyng two bandes horſemen came forth burning lightes commaunding men fight bycauſe darke onely run wyth fire ſéeme ye afray enimy ſo carthaginiās made afrayde wayes fledde citie thys alſo redounded muche scipio glorie wherefore well ſpoken euerie man thought worthy ſonne paulus conquered macedonie scipio whoſethe progenie scipio family adopted manlius going nepheris againſt aſdrubal scipio notnepheris contente ſéeing al wooddes hylly place high place gotten thrée furlong aſdrubal cōming riuer muſt aſcend aſdrubal ſtayd counſelled retire another time pollicie ſhould fitte match aſdrubal tribune ſpeaking againſt enuy malice thinking scipio counſel • ected good counſell giue place ſight enimye whereby might contemne ſet vpon flying hée againe deſired put campe hyther ſide riuer put might haue place reſorte nowe hadde none wherevnto might flye laughed one threatned caſte away ſworde manlius scipio rule therefore manlius went verye ſkilfull warre aſdruball encountred greate ſlaughter ſides aſdruball ranne caſtle perilthe romanes ouerthroven aſdruball wayted ſet wente repenting done retired floud order floud hard paſſe bycauſe fewe fourdes painful wer forced break order whych aſdrubal ſaw came downe manfully killed many reſiſte fledde thrée captaines ſlaine brought army conflicte scipio thrée hundred horſemen scipio ſaueth conſul army manye coulde get togither diuided thrée company gaue charge vpon enimie greate vehemence portion darting retyring vppon agayne returning ſo tolde halfe ſhould aſſayle enimies throw dartes circle e • done libyan without ſtaye ſhotte continuallye turning vppon scipio leſſe trouble paſſe riuer scipio rode ſtroke verye ſore foure company beginning fray put floude enimies ranne hill aſdrubal beſieged vnknowne romanes till ſtayed knewe ſome thoughte good goe waye aduenture many fewe scipio tolde acounſell doyng marter begonne good counſell muſte hadde ſo manye menne enſignes daunger vtterme •• e boldeneſſe muſte vſed choſe certaine troupe horſemen ſaid would returne gladly die tooke two dayes victuall ſtreight went forth army afraide leaſt alſo ſhoulde periſh came hill beſieged great ſpeede tooke hill oueragainſte diuided little valley libyan didde giue hote charge vpon beſieged thinking scipio coulde ſuccoure ſo long iorney ſéeing bottomes hill compaſſing valley omit occaſion ranne tooke place aboue enimies beyng • eſet rounde aboute fled without order scipio ſuffering go fréely bycauſe great deale thus scipio ſaued theſe alſo deſperation scipio ſaueth 4 band vver daunger army ſawe come farre beyng ſaued beyond hope hauing ſaued made great reioyce thoughteopiniō god vvorking scipio god wrought grandfather ſéemed knowe come manlius led army cittie againe putting great faulte woulde obey scipio counſelled retire army allgriefe ••• vnburied ſouldioures muche grieued killed laye vnburied ſpecially tribune therfore scipio loſed priſoner ſent aſlrubal praying bury tribune hée ſought among dead body found ring golde tribune army weare gold inferiourstribunes vvere ring golde • yron hée buried either acte humanitie cōmon among warrior reuerencing ſeruing scipio glorie romaynes come aſdrubal phame •• troubled yet afraide loſſe ſome iſſued oute carthage killed ſome cariage time senate ſent certaine men ſée campe marke euery thing diligently manlius counſel tribune left enuy beyng extinct vertue al army teſtified actes scipio done thēa general good reporte scipio ambaſſadors returne tolde senate diligence experience scipio goodwill army toward senate glad bicauſe many loſſes ſent maſsiniſſa required ſend friendlye aide againſte carthage found embaſſadors decayed age infirmitie hauing many baſe ſonnes whome giuen much thrée lawfull diuers conditiōs called scipio amitie maſsiniſſa maketh scipio hys executor betwéene grandfather counſeller hys child kinſmen went oute hande hée came maſsiniſſa dying commaunded child obey scipio ſhoulde take order ſaide hée maſsiniſſa dyeth fortunate mā died man thinges fortunate whome god graunted recouer father kingdom carthaginian syphax encreaſe greate parte mauritania sea dominion cyrene land cauſed great portion cyrene novve corene conrayning prouince fyue citties inhabited many numidiās liued hearbs vſed tillage left treaſures mony army well practiſed ennimies tooke syphax priſoner hand beyng cauſe variance carthage left weake romanes hadde body big ſtreng nature laſte age tried fight till hys death woulde leape horſe without ſtirrops may great coniecture hys good health hauing many child maſsiniſſa 900 yeares age childe foure yeares olde ſometime dying hadde tenne little one lefte one foure yeares age 900 year olde thus maſſiniſſa theſe yeares body dyed scipio gaue baſtardes gift legitimate treaſures reuenue haue name kyng commonthe order scipio tooke vpon maſsiniſſas child micipſa geloſſa maſta • ab • diuided thing among thoughte good micipſa oldeſt moſte diuide kingdome ſubſtaunce maſſiniſſa child preſently made geloſſa companion warre founde oute traynes whiche phameas many time vexed romanes ſtayed winter scipio phameas encamped nighe togither hauing middeſt valley could paſſed doe thing one againſt scipio fearing ſome traine might laide went viewe wyth thrée friend phameas ſawe came toward one scipio thinking wold ſay ſomewhat rode towarde one alſo might heare one another scipio ſaide carthaginian gonethe talke betvvene scipio pharmeas doſt thou conſider thine owne health ſéeyng thou canſte doe nothing common wealth howe quoth ſée paſſage without waye ignorantly going ye night might haply fal ſome traynes blew retreate day come aſdrubal angry taking megara many priſoners thethe crueltie aſdrubal romaynes brought wall romaynes carthagies thus ſtirre haue hope fight came otherwiſe tocrueltie oute time paſſe thoughte carthagies conſcience theſe horrible actes made fearefull ſteade bloud hated aſdruball hadde taken awaye hope made ditch part towarde carthage fenſed wall fiue twenty furlong higth twelue foote beſide tower hold ſet diſtaunce wal breadth halfe ſo much higth tower middeſt higheſt kepe woodde foure ſquare whiche might ſée done cittie dyd twentie dayes nightes armye labouring working fighting turne greatly paſſing forthe great trēch scipio mad • victual brought army within trēch ſer ued long wall againſt enimie woulde take reliefe brought carthage land alſo except part called necke water dyd beate carthage euery chiefe cauſe hunger deſtruction multitude thestraightneſſe victuall carthage citie fielde neyther coulde brought thys flege ſtrangers comming warre victuall libya little ſea wynde woulde ſerue reſte came lande whiche waye ſtopped ſore vexed famine bythias captaine horſemen ſent victual long tyme neyther durſt come neare paſſe scipio trenche ſeldome ſlowly ſent foode ſhip albeit romanes nauy laye towne continuallye many bicauſe ſea dangerous tempeſtuuos could approche cittie carthagies walkes andthe vvay victuall carthage waues great bycauſe rocke therefore hoyes bithyas merchant came gaine caring nothing perill obſerued winde greate made full ſayle gallies able folowe blowen ſuch vehemence ſea whatſoeuer theſe ſhips brought aſdrubal diſtributed aſdrubal feedeth ſouldioures vpō thirtie thouſād war little regardyng people wherefore ſoare troubled wyth famine scipio perceyued purpoſed ſhutte mouthe porte towarde weaſte farre lande hée made long trenche beginnyng ſtreighte betwéene fenne sea called longue wrought ſea ſtopped paſſage making ſure great thicke ſtones famine diuerſe euils ranne vpon romanes engine night lande way ſhippe ſea ſhallowe naked linckes light ſhould ſéene far came ſea man would haue thought ſome breaſtes wadedthe carthagies run vpō romanes munition vvith deſperatneſſe ſhalows ſome ſwamme til came engine threw fire perceyued receyuing much hurt bycauſe naked much boldneſſe ſtroke breaſts face dartes ſpeares woulde giue place wilde beaſts offering themſelues ſtrikers til ſet artillery fyre driuē romanes away kepte confuſion wasfeare romanes campe scipio forced kil ovvne ſolliors kepe ſrō flying ſuche feare trouble camp whole army hadde béene furie naked enimies wherefore scipio afraide came forth horſmen commaunded beate would leaue flight ſome beare downe killed till retourned camp neceſſitie ſaue themſelues watched night armes fearing deſperation enimies burned artillerie ſwamme home againe daye carthaginian ſure engine builded vppe fore parte wall againe made many tower vpon certaine diſtaunce romanes made engine erected trenche againſt towersthe carthagies trenche gotten making fire worke pitche ſulphure threw vpon y• enimie burned many tower chaſed carthaginian fledde ground ſlippery bloud myre left chaſe themſelues scipio end miageth carthaginian lande scipio hauing got trench compaſſed ditch wyth wall ſtone verye neare farre ennimies wall vppe put foure thouſand whiche much paſſe enimie throwing dartes weapon vpon contempt bicauſe like heigth ſure hit thus sommer ſpente winter come scipio determined take carthaginian al power friend lande ſente ſome one way ſome another himſelfe went nepheris water diogenes fauoured aſdrubal lay camp ſent c lalius thither land whē come encamped two furlong diogenes left geloſſa moleſtthe aſiaulte •• pheris diogenes continually returned carthage ſo vſed go betwéen carthage nepheris ſée doings two diogenes tower fel wherfore scipio went laid choice ſeuldiors behind ambuſh brought 3000 tried men againſte front willed giue aſſault broken tower al ranckes ſtil following one another former putte backe ſhould hinder followed crie greate fraye hotte al libyan turned defence thē thouſand appointed thē came forth ſéene firſt entred ſoone perceyued wherfore libyan fled ſéeing many wer thinking bin many mo • thā celoſſa ſet vpon thē numidian elephāts made great ſlaughter ſo killed lxx wyth nepheris tak •• vvith grea • ſlaughter thinking craſſus proude prouince greater felicitie could hap vnto prouince inſomuchas could bée quiet made great auauntes brag among friendes otherwiſe al life verye ſmal boaſter ſetter forth hymſelfe mithridates alſo winne bactria indus beyonde sea yet decrée warre parthian contained euery man feare craſſus would meddle caeſar wrote letter prayſing hys purpoſe prouoking hym warre atteius tribune didde ſtop voyage wyth threat manye conſented grieued anye man ſhoulde make warre vpon men offended nothing alſo league craſſus afraide prayed pompey caeſar ſtirreth craſſus vvarre paribians helpe ſet forwarde great people opinion notwythſtanding ſawe manye readye reſiſt exclame gentle looke countenance appeaſed thē y• quiet ſuffred paſſe yet atteius ſtopped firſt voice forbidding proteſting go reſiſtaunce therefore thought paine ſhoulde long iorney ſhoulde come blowes enimies woulde abide whereas nowe otherwiſe ſuppoſed great trauaile daunger hande inſomuche ſome officer camp thought good ſtaye craſſus take newe aduiſe matter ſecreatlye maiſters sacrifice ſhewed manye euill harde token appeared craſſus sacrificessacrifices shevve euill token hée neither woulde heare exhorted hym goe forwarde among whych artabaſes king armenia didde let prouoke art • baſe • king armenia • nd dued vvith le ••• ng vvhom antony took treaſon caried triuniphe alexandria pleaſe cleopatra craſſus armenia whereby ſhoulde leade armye onely ſafely miniſtring thynges alſo thorowe mountaynes continuall hill place comberſome parthian horſemenne wherein conſiſtes theyr ſtrength▪ cr • ſſus praiſed good wyll hym goodly preparation yet hée ſayde hée woulde enter meſepotan • ia lefte many good romane souldiours armenian went way craſſus •• dde armye ouer bridge manye terrible •• •• token craſſus folish vvorde pa •• eth craſſus ſhoulde haue repeated declared made afrayde would frowardneſſe laſt hadde killed ſacrifice make ſol • mne viewe armye miniſter giuen bowel fell handes whiche preſent moſt grieued ſmiled ſaying theſe • e incommodities age weapon ſhall neuer fal hāds craſſus excuſeth •• vveakenes ledde army floude hauing ſeauen legiens little leſſe foure thouſande horſe number ſhotte equal ſkoutes went ſée way returned brought worde countrey voyde men print horſe féete gone backe whereat craſſus tooke good hope ſouldiours beganne craſſus vaine hope seleucia plentifull place deſpiſe parthian afrayde come handes yet caſsi •• others ſpake craſſus perſwading ſtaye menne ſome cittie garriſon till better inſtructed enimies force would go seleucia floude ſhoulde haue aboundaunce ofthe counſel caſsius folovved victual ſouldiours ſolde alſo defence ſafegarde armye enuironed floude▪ béeyng euer equall fyghte wyth enimye face craſſus conſidering pondering theſe thing acbar • vſeth craft vvith craſſus came preſident arabi • acbaros name ſubtile diſſembling manne greateſt prouoker euyll fortune • ente theyr deſtruction hadde ſerued vnder pompey knewe receyuiug ſome humanitie hys hande ſhewing friende romaine ſente craſſus y• conſent king counſel turne coulde floude foote hils playn field might compaſſed deuiſed thing rather come fight • yth ſhe romanes hande acbarus came craſſus ſayde probablye firſte prayſe pompey benefactoure craſſas blaming hauing ſo greate power acbarus deceyneth craſſus loſt time delay preparation though néed armour rather handes • ooif • e f •• te againſt mē alreadye ſéeke gather moſte precious rich carrie • ythia hircania ſayde wyll • ythia aſia hir • ania play • region moſt aboundant fighte muſt quicklye whole power gathered king taking harte againe nowe suren • sillaces commeth make warre againſt king ſéene al theſe lye king went ſtreight power inuade armenia fa •• bian king inuadeth armenia ſē deth surenas againſt romanes puniſh artabaze • ſent surenas againſte romaynes contempt ſome ſaye like would contemne craſſus ſent againſt hym one chiefe romaynes go againſt artabazes deſtroye townes armenia thinke afrayde daunger laye wayte ſée ende appoynted surena beyng otherwyſe expert acquainted wyth war surenas none common ſorte rich surena • ſen • againſt craſſus glorye bloude nexte king chiefe parthia ſtrength youth beautye goodlyneſſe bodye inferiour none carried alwayes thouſand laden camel two hundred chariot concubine thouſand men armes light horſemen tenaunts ſeruantes leſſe ten thouſand horſe touching bloud giuen beginningthe nobility surenas ſet crowne vpon king head▪ new king made▪ called orodes exile hys kingdome orodes brought exile suren •• toke great citie seleucia firſt ſ • aled walles owne hande repulſed reſiſted yet thyrty yeares age yet greateſt glory wiſedome experience litle beguile craſſus firſt thorough pride boldneſſe afterthe text varieth hys feare aduerſitie eaſily entrapped acbarus hadde brought craſſus floud playne fieldes wythout woodde water wythout ende reſte appeared trauelled wyth thirſt dificultie alſo vncomfortable proſpect eye ſéeing neyther trée riuer apparaunce hyl growing graſſe ſhape like ſea fearful deſarts beſette armye cra • te beganne eſpied furthermore came meſſengers artabazes artabazes ſignifieth inuaded king armenia ſhewing deteyned greate warre orodes hauing inuaded coulde ſende helpe craſſus yet wiſhed hym anye wiſe turne make waye armenia togither mighte goe againſt orodes king part ••• orodes alwayes marche encampe ſo hée might auoyde horſemen go hylles craſſus writing nothing againe anger ſtraungeneſſe aunſwered craſſus maketh frovvard aunſvvere nowe leyſure deale armenia returned would puniſh artabazes treaſon caſsius agayne grieued leauing craſſus woulde heare good counſel playnely rebuked acbarus craſſus miſ • iketh iourney naughty wight moſt wicked mā brought thee v paſſion witchcraftes haſt thou made craſſus leade army deſarts vglye wilderneſſe fitter archtheefe numidia chiefe generall romaine arbarus crafty man dyd ſpeake fayre comforted arbarus deceiueth reſt exhorted endure whyle riding among ſouldiours • ſted thinke goyng campania fountaines riuers ſhadowes brooke brayes oſtanes wayes doe remember go confines arabia arabia tvvo part b • r • nne aſsiria furtheſt part sy ••• aſsiria thus acbarus playe ſ • holer among romaine craft perceyued road vnknowen craſſus agréeing though woulde prouide defeate enimies ſayde craſſus thatmore token • uil daye came abroade purple manner romaine general blacke garmente changed againe perceyued enſignebearers could without great laboure pull vppe enſignes ſtucke ſo faſt craſſus laughing went faſter bad legion follow horſemen came ſome eſpyes bin abroad haſte ſhewing felowes killed enimies eſcaped ennimies came great power ſpéed troubled craſſus moſt ſo ſet men order orderlye caſsius moued ſ • legion thinne could fill playne fear compaſſing diuide horſemen wing altered made ſame ſerue wayes ſquare battayle euerye •• de going twelue bandes troupe horſemen part ſhoulde voyde helpe horſemen eueryſide like defended fight appointed one wing caſsius yong craſſus went middeſt▪ thus marching came riuer call baliſſus great full water acceptable thebaliſſus ſouldiours hote dry iourney ſo greate payne p ••• rie water manye captaines thoughte good ſtaye til certaine knowledge come▪ enimies force purpoſe daye come goe againſte craſſus commaunded ſonne horſemen wyth hym go ready fight badde • •• ▪ eate drinke kept order well done hee led leyſure pauſing▪ ſhould fight much ſpéede haſte tyl ſawe enimies ſo great ſhewe neyther appearing many fearefull romaynes sir •••• putte multitude behinde hydden bryghtneſſe •• • arne ••• • lo •• ſkinnes come nygh token giuen captaines firſte filled allthe parthian manner going fight playne wyth barbarous noyſe fearefull ſhoutes parthian go battell wyth horne trumpet drummes many place made leather hollow▪ ſtretched yron barres beatē vpon continually maketh noyſe holow déepe like roaring wilde beaſtes intermedled ſharpneſſe thunder nothing could harde ſence hearing bringeth moſt trouble minde ſooneſt moued moſt troubleth vnderſtanding romanes aſtoniſhed noyſe parthia threw away couers harneſſe ſodainely appeared ſhyning • • armoure made beſte ſtéele bright horſemen barded capariſon likewiſe goodlieſt greateſt wassurenas surenas fineſſe w • manniſh aray like glorie valiauntneſſe rather decked median faſhion trymming perſon diuiſiō haire parthian vgly purpoſe terrour ſh • dding courſe breaking harneſſe bearing alike vnarmed well armed parthian diſtant little beganne ſhoote ••• ntures directing ſhotte romanes battayle ſo thicke coulde myſſe thoughe woulde gyuing continuall hurte woundes ſtrong great bowes violence drawing driuing arrow ſtronger vndoing romanes continuing order ſtroken trying go vpon ennimy kéepe cloſe againe ſuffered alike parthian ſhotte fledde thinkethe parthian manner vva •• e beſte • eate according scythian moſte wiſe parte hurte ſaue themſelues hid ſhame fléeing pretence long romanes hopedthe parthian •• e shotte ſhot done would haue come hāds abode ſaw number camells come laden newe ſhotte • whiche firſte ſpente arrowes wente receiue craſſus himſelfe thought woulde haue ende wherefore ſente meſſengers ſonne ſhoulde ſet vppon ennimie béefore incloſed moſte buſy vpon hym rode come vpon backe yong man tooke xiij c horſe whereof thouſand caeſars • ight band next footemen badde ſet vpon • r enimies parthian foremoſte either bicauſe myrie grounde ſome ſaye bycauſe woulde drawe craſſus pollicie farre coulde turned fledde young craſſus • rying thoughe theyyong▪ craſſus vvith cenſorinus • gaba •• u would haue turned againe gaue chaſe cenſorinus • gaba •• u theſe paſſed valiantnes ſtrength cenſorinus order senatoure eloquent friend yong craſſus like age horſemen going footman folowed courage fearefulneſſe hope thoughte haue victorie chaſe gone farre perceyued deceit ſéemed •• ée turned againe many •• comming ſtayed thinking woulde haue come handes bicauſe ſo fewe ſet men armes vpon romanes horſe confuſedlye rode vppon troubling playne rayſing heapes sande making full duſte romanes coulde neither ſée ſpeake driuen thruſtethe romane • killed togyther ouerthrowen dyed eaſily ſhorte death ſhriking ſorowfull manner laboring breake arowes woundes prouing violence pul forked heades enited vaines ſtnowes fore lamented themſelues many thus dead aliue vnprofytable helpe andromanes vnable helpe publius exhorted ſet vppon men armes ſhewed handes nayled ſhieldes theyr féete faſtened grounde coulde neyther flye fight brought horſemen fiercely vpon weake ſtryking defendyng weake little ſpeares vpon ſtrong armour ſtéele galatian ſtryken long ſpeares vpon vnarmed body truſted muche maruellous feates toke ſpeares bare men horſe could moued waightthe valiantnes galatian harneſſe many left horſes ſtroke enimies horſes belly payne threwe theyr ryders trode vpon enimies tyll dyed alſo heate thirſt moſt troubled galathians accuſtomed neyther many hauing lefte horſes ſtaues fought contrary therfore could haue gotten legion hauing publius craſſus ſore vvounded publius among euill beſtadde wound ſéeing hyll ſande farre went thyther putting horſe middeſt defending outwarde partes target thoughte mighte eaſilye put backe barbarian came otherwiſe paſſe béeing playne former kepte hindermoſt hurte went mounting ground daunger came behinde moſte none eſcaped al ſhotte indifferently lamenting deathes voyde reuenge glorie publius carria great▪ aſis irna two men grecian dwelling carria ieronimus nichomacus moued goe flye irna towne helde romaynes anſwered wasa noble anſvver yong man deathe ſo grieuous feare whiche publius woulde leaue dyed therfore prayed ſaue themſelues gently ſent away coulde vſe hande hurte arrowe therfore commanded page take ſword runne therowe ſydethe death p craſſus tvvo friendes cenſorinus died ſort magabactus killed himſelfe ſo dyed moſt noble reſt parthian killed ſpeares fighting themſelues onelye fiue hundred taken aliue hadde cutte heades publius craſſus hope company tourned toward craſſus ſtoode ſorte hadde ſente ſonne encounter parthian one hadde tolde hym greate fléeing ſore chaſe ennimies ſawe came vppon went alſo part beganne take comforte leading army riſing place thinking ſon would haue come ſtraight chaſe firſte ſent publius tell daunger taken enimies ſlaine hardely eſcaping ſhewed publius vndone craſſus perplexed except ſpéedy great helpe ſent nowe craſſus dynerſly troubled could ſée reaſon howe vſe matter one ſide feare whole deſire ſaue ſonne doubting might helpe helpe yet ende went forward power nowe enimies come terrible shewt declaryng victorie ſtriking many armenian feared romanes looking battell brought head publius vpon ſpearsthe parthian shevve ſpight point approching nighe deſpight aſking parent kinred could thinke ſonne craſſus ſo cowardly lewd man young man ſo noble renowmed vertue fight moſt al grieuous romanes directing breaking hart anger reuenge oughte vtterly feare dreade craſſus ſhew ſelfe moſt noble ſuch caſe ſay went aboute hoſte cried craſſus shevveth himſelfe noble▪ romanes proper loſſe greate glorye fortune rome kéepe vnbroken aud vntouched haue pitie haue loſte ſo good ſonne ſhewe youre anger vppon ennimies take away ioy reuengethe vvordes craſſus comforte ſouldioures crueltie diſmaide done great feat muſt ſometime ſuffer lucullus ouercame tigranes without bloudeſhed scipio antiochus aunceſtors loſte thouſande shippes sicilie italy manye capitames army woulde lette loſſe get victorie againe romanes haue come ſo great dominion fortune ſufferaunce manhoode calamitie craſſus ſaide encourage didde ſéea declaration romanes faintneſſe many willingly heare hym therefore badde make noiſe whiche bewrayed faintneſſe army made ſéeble weake crie whiche anſwered barbartans wyth chearefull bolde ſounde comming togither ſhotte enimies troubled romanes ſides comming vppon ſpeares face droue litle roomth yet ſome fléeyng death ſhotte came oute fight hande little purpoſe ſo diſpatched greatethe fight mortall woundes many time ſharpe long ſpeares paſſing thorowe horſe man thus night brake battaile ſaying wouldethe parthian reſte arſaces gratifie craſſus one night bury ſonne conſider hymſelfe whither better go arſaces led thus going place nigh hande greate hope romanes hadde heauy night neither burying deade healing hurte ſome dying lamenting themſelues thing appeared wythoute helpe remembred day woulde bring care ſhoulde goe awaye night thoſe huge playnes carry hurte ſouldioures would lette vnto lefte behinde woulde crie diſcloſe theyr going away althoughe thoughte craſſus authour al euill yet deſired ſée hym heare hym ſpeake hée himſelfe face couered darke example cōmon ſort fortune wiſe want wiſedom craſſus exemple fortune mutabilitie ambition contente one chiefe greteſt among many thouſands ſuche bicauſe iudged inferior onely two men thought hymſelfe leaſt octauius legate caſsius raiſed badde good chéere ſawe vtter deſperation worde ſpoken copenio good craſſus thinking well bicauſe ſodaine ſtraunge ſpéech gathered men togither went méete craſſus way receiue ſouldiors cittie parthian hearing going awaye night folow daye come one men could ſpeake tongue wall commaunding ſpeake latine call craſſus caſsius tell surenas woulde ſpeake ſo tolde craſſus meſſage receiued shortly came certaine arabian knewe craſſus caſsius hauing bin camp fight ſéeing caſsius vpon wall ſaide surenas would make friendes king ſaue ſo woulde departe meſopotamia ſo better trie vttermoſt caſius accepting requiring time place craſſus deceipt surena méete togither anſwering ſo doe departed surenas hearde meſſengers glad place beſieged willed parthian next daye goe greate crie require romanes woulde haue peace parthian ſende craſſus caſsius bounde king grieued deceiued counſelled craſsus leaue long vaine hope armenia ſaue himſelfe let none carrenans knowe made knowne andromachus falſe fellowe whome truſted craſſus deceiued andromachus made guide way ſo nothing kepte parthian tolde andromachus cuſtome fight night ſure thing thē craſſus went night ſhoulde farre folowing fléeing capitaines andromachus ledde romanes way waye laſte putte fenny marriſh place ſhould hard footmē folow thought wel andromachus turning compaſſing followed therefore caſsius went againe carras caſsius retourneth y• guids arabian willed make haſt moone paſte scorpion ſaide feare sagittarie went syria fiue hundred horſes hauing gote good guide went hilly place whiche called synacha ſafe daye hadde sy •• cha 〈…〉 ouertaken aboute fiue thouſande octauius good man leader daye come craſſus weary iorney fenne ſtrange way ledde andromachus foure bandes legatemen fewe horſe fiue sergeant whome hauing weary iorney ſcarcely ſtaying reſt ennimies hand hadde myle halfe ioyne octauius therefore little hyll able kepe horſe backe otherwiſe ſure ioyning synaces ſtretching long ſpace thorowe octauius cōmeth helpe craſſus large field nighe octauius might ſee daunger firſte octauius went fewe ſaue hym reprouing themſelues folowed kept ennimies hyll compaſſed craſſus middeſt defended tergats ſo ſhot parthian ſhoulde hurte generall fighting ſlaine surenas craſſus continually deceiued make war continually romanes would bée gladde friendeſhip vſe craſſus gently wente tolde barbarian ceaſſed fight surenas chiefe went quietly hill vnbent bowe offred righte hande called craſſus truce ſaying agaynſte king proued force power nowe hée ſhoulde willingly féele clemencie mildeneſſe béeing confedered ſuffer goe ſafe surena ſaide gladde woulde haue followed craſſus credite thoughte ſodaine change taken therefore thoughte good take aduice yet ſouldiours cried angry obiecting woulde caſte villainouſly ſlaine ennimies durſt go talke vnarmed beganthe wanton writing aristides mileſia therein lie founde carriage reſcius miniſtred great matter reproue blame romanes euen warres doe refraine ſuche fonde manner writing seleucians aeſopus ſéemeth wiſe kinges houſe parthia cōmeth oute mileſia league betvveene▪ king armenia parthia barbarian kinges learned pacoro wantonneſſe parthia ſo many wagon concubine behind certaine ſhewe newe forme ſtraunge fight mortall daungerous thoughe fore part fayre fearful cruell carrying ſpeares bowes horſes tayle hoſte ending dauncing ſinging ſaying woman al kinde lewdneſſe rustius blamed parthian ſhameleſſe rebuke mileſians ſome king called aſacides haue come ye mileſian ionian ſtrumpets done orodes made league artabazes armenian gaue ſiſter wife ſonne paecoro many feaſtes betwéen friendſhips inſomuche came gréeke paſtimes orodes learne tongue doctrine greece artabane • made tragedy wrote hiſtories whiche ſome ſaued craſſus head brought doores table ſpredde ſetterforth tragedy called iaſon trallia agaue hir fury killed hir ſon play bringing craſſus heade silaces bringeth craſſus heade pentheus vvas ſonne agaue ſhewed bacchus euripides touching agaue well liked sillaces came dyning parlour making reuerence threwe caſsius heade middeſt parthian making reioice ſhowte ioy miniſters putte silaces king commaunding iaſon deliuered preparation pentheus one dauncers taking craſſus head ſung theſe verſes like man caught furie bring circuite mountaines newe killed game bleſſed happy hunting al repeate came aboute agayne quyre ſhoulde ſyng mine mine rewarde maxarthes leapte forth ſet table tooke head ſaying appertained hadde king glad giuen rewardthe killer craſſus revvarded country maner iaſon gaue talent thys maner play trauaile craſſus ende tragedie orodes crueltie surenas periurie pompey ruled sic • lie ſent againe aſia ventidius repreſſe parthian cō mingventidius forewarde fauour made holy miniſter former caeſar thing cōmō friendly antonie made miniſter diuine caeſar ciuil▪ moſte greate matter prophete aegipt cunning men natiuities eyther gratifye cleopatra tell truth ſpake antonie southſaye • fréely ſaying thy fortune moſt noble great ouerlayde caeſars counſelled farre coulde yong man thine angel ſayd wiſe mā feareth angell appeared antonie gaue credite antony angel afraide octa 〈…〉 u angel thought better aegiptian committyng thing caeſar ſayled grecia whyleſt athene firſt newes came ventidius good procéedings ventidius hath good lucke parthia y• ouercome parthian ſlaine labinius phraartes chiefe captaynes king orodes feaſted grecian made ruler athenian ſchole went warre ware garlande holy oliue according oracle carried hym veſſel ful ye foūtain clepſidra tolde y• ventidius ouerthrown pacorus clepſidra vvas vvel caſtle athens king ſonne great armie parthian inuading syria agayne cyriſtica many ſlain among pacorus ſlaine whiche pacorus one firſte acte one nobleſt ſhe romanes reuenged miſfortune craſſus droue parthian againe medium meſopotamia ouercome thrée battells togither ventidius ventidius leaueth furder againſte parthian feare antony enuy samoſata bringeth forth earth ſetteth vvater afire parte syria called comagene refrayned followe parthian fearing enuy antonie reuolted recouered againe beſieged antiochus comagenus cittie samoſatis offring thouſand talent doe antonie ſhould command ventidius badde ſende antonie hand ventidius wold haue antiochus make peace acte mighte redounde honoure leaſte ſhoulde ſéeme done vētidius ſiege continuing longer inhabitance deſperatiō peace turning courage antonius deceyued hope returneth doyng nothing ventidius triumpheth parthian octauius antonie fortunate lieutenaunts themſelues soſius canidius phraartes killeth father orodes heartes antonie content let▪ antiochus go thrée hundred talent tarryed syria returned athens rewarding ventidius worthie ſent triumphe day triumphe parthian man baſe byrth comming ſo great eſtimation waighty matter antony friendſhip vſing wiſely made ſaying caeſar antonie found true fortunate captaines themſelues soſius antony lieutenaunt syria dydde many thing canidius lefte armenia ouercame hiberian albanian king droue farre iberia nighe hyll caucaſus full veni •• e vvhence came novv inhabite spaine antonie vvoulde giue revvarde comparable king perſia lariſſa many name one aſia nighe tralus arethuſa one syria another lubaa hierapolis meſopotamia caucaſus whereby antony name renoumed among barbarian phraartes killed father orodes taken kingdome many parthian fledde away moneſius noble mighty man fledde antonie waying man fortune themistocles comparing power king perſia gaue thrée city lariſſa arethuſa hierapolis called bambyce moneſius called home againe king let goe meaning ſo deceiue king hope peace deſirous recouer enſignes craſſus captiues aliue ſent cleopatra aegipt went arabia armenia gather power confederate king many greateſt artabazes armenia giuing ſixe thouſande horſe ſeauenforces antonie bactrians people scythia asſia thouſand footman muſtred men lx footemen romanes ordinarie horſemen iberian frenchman ten thouſand nation thirty thouſand horſmen ſhotte ſo great preparation power made bactrians indian afrayde aſia ſhake ſaye cleopatra made come cleopatra cauſe decay greate preparation little profite making haſte winter hir tooke due time warre vſing al thing confuſedly one wittes abuſed ſorceries witchcraft antonie abuſed cleopatra hir thought make haſte hir get victorie ennimies oughte haue wintredeight furlong maketh myle armenia reſted weary army gone viij furlong parthian come winterings inuade medium beginning ye spring would tarry time ſo led army armenia lefte hande came atropatea waſted region atropatea part parte medium hauing engine neceſſarie ouerthrowe city followed campe thrée hundred chariot whiche one called ramme length foureramme engine beate vvalles cittie antony leaueth hys artillerie behinde phraata beſieged ſcore foote broken coulde made againe bicauſe ledde armye countrey plaine barren wood length hardneſſe left thē behind impediment haſte appointing • captain kepe ſame beſieged phraata greate cittie whiche wife child king medium antony error féeling want engine knewe erred leauing behind therefore would winne citie mountes whiche great labour ſlowe diuiſe nowe came king phraartes great army hearing thethe artillerie taken keeper killed leauing cariage engine ſent many horſmē thē statianus chiefe romanes killed ten thouſande statianus polemon killed barbarian tooke engine deſtroyed manye people whiche polemon king made antony army afraide might receiue ſuch loſſe beginning artabaſſes armenian king dyſpayring romaine returned artabazes forſaketh romanes home army albeit ye cauſe war beſieged truſted vpon parthian ſo muche vſed ſpitefull language antonie thinking good ſouldiours courage ſhoulde abated lying ydly loke tenne legion three bandes guarde hys horſemen wente forage thinking ſo prouoke hys enimies fighte deale orderly gone one onely dayes iourney ſawe parthian fetching compaſſe ſeeking ſtoppe waye hée commaunded token fight giuen campe leauied though woulde fight marche paſſed barbarian ſette like creſcent commaunding horſemen footemen ſo nigh mighte fight horſemen ſhould turne vpon parthian parthian maruel good order romanes iudge romaine order better reaſon behelde marching wyth equall diſtaunce quietlye ſilence ſhaking weapon token giuen went ſhoute horſemen turned vppon enimie receyued defence although within ſhotte footemen came crye claſhing armour horſemen parthian gaue placethe romanes haue victorie ſmal accompt diſorder fledde came handes antonie followed chaſe hauing greate hope make ende eyther whole warre great part folowed chaſe footemen ſixe mile horſemenne thrice ſo muche found taken thirtie ſlayne foure ſcoure euerye manne thinking harde caſe hauing victorye ſhoulde kyll ſo fewe looſyng theyr engine ſo manye ouercome fell greate diſcourage doubte themſelues next daye paſſed phraartes campe waye founde firſt fewe enimies laſt inuincibly hurte prouoked euerye ſet vpon ſo hardly muche adoe romanes went campe citie haddethe romaine hardly gette campe mace ſallie put ſome romanes trenche antony ſo angry puniſhed euery tenth mā deaththe romaynes puniſhed lod according deſerte taking euery tenth lotte hadde forſaken place inſteade wheate hée gaue barley warre painefull bothe continuance fearefull antonie perceyuing hunger would folowe coulde get forage without death hurte ſouldiors phraates knowing parthian rather doe thing lie fielde land winter afraide thatautumne craftie practiſe romanes hold tarry woulde leaue hym ayre begynning chaunge time equall day night hande deuiſed crafte beſt parthian vſed romanes gently foraging encounter ſuffering carry away ſome thing prayſing vertue men moſte valiaunt warre great eſtimation king wel worthy meane comming nearer togither ſuffring horſemenne paſſe ſpake euill antonie bicauſe phraates woulde gladly haue peace ſpare ſo good ſo many menne giuen none occaſion would tarry abide two gret harde enimies winter hunger whichevvinter hunger tvvogreat enimies coulde hardely eſcape thoughe parthian would ſuffer many declaring antonie deceiued hope antony deceyued deferred ſende heraulte parthian king till knewe thoſe wel willing barbarian ſpake ſo muche king conſent affirming promiſing ought doubt dreade ſent one friendes againe requiring receiue enſigns captiues might thought altogither ſaue himſelfe eſcape parthian aunſwering ſhoulde paſſe departe ſhoulde haue peace ſafete •• wherefore wythin fewe dayes brake vppe went way whereas eloquent perſwading wente 〈…〉 people armye hys oration ſhame heauineſſe omitted antonie committeth ſpeeche ſouldiours another contrary vvonte ſpeake multitude commaunded domitius aenobarbus angry though deſpiſed parte content perceyued matter therefore thought rather graunt obey generall béeing aboute leade playne barren waye mardi people hyrcania mardus taketh vppon leade armye beſt vvay man kinde called mardus acquainted parthian faſhion faithfull romanes fielde engins came antonie willed flée right hand hill caſte armye laden harneſſe weary iourneys ſuche mighte horſe ſhorte phraates vnder ſhewe beneuolence went aboute ent • • woulde leade hym ſhorter way ſhe whiche ſhoulde haue ſufficiencie thing antonie heard tooke counſel ſaid would ſéeme diſtruſte parthian touching peace ſhortneſſe way plentifull townes inhabited hée mardus bounde prayſed mardus requyred ſaith offred till brought armenia bound ledde ij day quietlie done antony harder ſet floude impdeiment vnto willed antonie 〈…〉 ennimie farre while ſet hys men order commaunded ſhotte encounter beholde parthian appeared came woulde haue compaſſed diſſolued army ſhotte comming vppon hurte done ſides retyred afterfrench horſmen came againe french horſmen encountred putte backe ſo day attempte antonie learning ſhoulde placed manye ſhotte onely taile • one ſhe ſides fifth daye flauius gallus good souldioure forwarde feates warre required antonie giue ſome ſhotte hys rerewarde horſmen hys fore warde woulde good ſeruice gaue kept backe ennimies nowe returning footemen following fighting courage whenthe • • hencite gallus ſoberneſſe titius leader • aile ſaw go far called hym backe would ſay titius take enſigne turne backe rebuke gallus woulde loſe ſo manye ſo good men rebuked agayne badde medle owne matter ſo titius went way gallus ſetting vppon face compaſſed backe beſette rounde aboute ſente helpe bringing footemen among whiche canidius canidius committeth greate errour man great fauour antonie ſéemed committe greate erroure oughte haue broughte forthe whole battaile haue ſent forth band one ready help another whiche weake haue ſupplied perceyued wanted little whole army putte worſte flight antonie hadde brought legion ſet face third legion paſſed among fledde ſtayed enimie chaſe ſlaine leſſe thana ſlaughter romanes thrée thouſande came tentes wounded fyue thouſande gallus among ſhotte thorowe four arrowes coulde healed woundes antonie went comforted wyth teares bad good antonie comforteth menne cheare chearfully taking hande prayed hym comfort himſelfe diſeaſed calling chiefe generall ſaying well whole generally antonie verye good captaine captain y• led noble armi▪ neither ſtrēgth patience boldneſſe thoſe dayes hundreth fortie furlong thinking enimies woulde haue come ſo ſoone diſcouraged neyther drinke muſte fight • went former chaunced méete floudde whoſe watervvater ••• tful colde cleare ſalte venemous • e enimy fore warde going little floud appeared horſemen kéeping enimies caryed ouer ſicke men firſt while theſe fighting leiſure quiet drinke parthian ſaw floud vnbended bow badde romanes go boldely commending much theyr vertue paſſed quiet gathered togyther againe great truſte parthian went ſixte day laſt fighte came floude araxes cōmeth hyll euphrates dothe araxes diuiding medium armenia appeared déepe ſwift ſaide enimies came ſet vpon paſſage quietly paſſed come armenia thoughe ſéene land ſea knéeled downe teares embracing one another ioye ranne togither nowe going plentifull country ſlaine enimies 〈…〉 ore halfe diſeaſes going • h 〈…〉 ſea ••• twentie day ouercame parthian eightéene battells victory ſubſtāunce ſuretie made ofte ſmall chaſes well perceyued artabazes armenian cauſe antonie coulde bring war end ſixtéene thouſande horſe hée led medium might haue done beſt ſeruice againſt parthian armed like accuſtomed fight wyth •• ed romanes fight ſhould haue chaſed ſo ouercome could haue bin bold ſet vpon againe ſo oft army anger moued antonie reuenged king vſing diſcretion neyther blame defection change wonted humanitie honor army yet weake néedy afterwarde come againe armenia fayre word promiſes perſuading come handes toke carried bounde triumph alexandrîa moſt grieued romanes goodly antonie taketh king maketh triumph alexandria vvhiche grieueth romanes comely thing country ſhould tranſlated alexandrîa cleopatra ſake thus betwéene king medium parthia fell variaunce begonne ſay romanes ſpoyle median king dā ger thereby looſe kingdome ſent antonie promiſing make war power therefore antonie broughte greatehope ſuppoſed wanted nothing ouercome parthian horſmen archer ſaw offred gratify without aſking prepared go armenia ioyne median floud araxes moue warre called backe interceſſions octauia cleopatra deferred median til next ſommer although parthian diuiſiō yet going made league maryed one daughter ſonne cleopatra returned againe ciuil warre end romanes vvar vvith parthian ¶ romanes war illyriās appian alexandrîa grecian thinke illyrian illyria novv slau •••• chaonia part moū taines theſprotia next chaonia▪ paeonia parte macedonia breadth length illyria haue dwelling beyond macedonia thraecia chaonia theſprotia floud hister greatneſſe reacheth macedonia mountaines thracia paeonia alpes thrée day iourney length muche greater thrée partes grecian thinke romaynes meaſuring ground thinke ſixe thouſand furlong length thouſand two hundereth breadth affirme countrey haue name beginning illyria ſonne polyphemus polyphemus illyrius ſonne polyphemus celte part fraunce lion taulantij vvent illyria macedonia builded •• iſſ • per • hab • fled aetolia • hillai ilanders autarians vvere moſt vvarlike people illyria firſt ſubdued scordiſcians laſt • romaine parthene macedonia da • aretians thracia galatia celtes illyrius gallus came sicelie gaue name celtians illyrian galatian like well opinion haue bene taught hereof ſaye illyrius theſe folowing achilles autarius dardanus medus taulātius perrhebus theſe daughter partha daorta daſera others came taulātians perrhebians achilleians autaricās dardauans parthenians daſaretians darſians autarius pannonius paeonius scordiſcus paeonius tribalus theſe natiōs haue name theſe antient beginning great countrey illyria whiche scordiſcians triballians ſo greate poſſeſſion fought ſo long togither till triballians lefte fled celtes beyond hiſter nation thought mightye tyll time philippe alexander ſo deſtroyed hath man left scordiſcians become noughtescordiſcians paeonians alſo ouercome romaine came lēgth dwel ilands hiſter continuaunce tyme ſome went abroade inuaded vttermoſt part paeonia wherfore scordiſcians amōg paeonians likewiſe ardeians inuaded beſte parte autarians groundes nexte coaſte beyng ſeamen droue away liburnians l • burn • light shippes name good ſhippes another nation illyria robbing ionium ilandes ſwifte ſhippes wherefore romaynes call ſhippes ſpéede liburnians ſaying autariās came vtter deſtruction wrath apollo celtians wyth cymbrians encampe delphos cymbri came frō north saxon n •• • onne fraunce vvhere marius ouercame punishment god diſpearſed fledde many fight ſtroken raine tempeſt lightning wer left came home foūd ſuch corruptiō made frog water periſhed vapor whiche ſo infected countrey illyria autarians moſt plagued fled bycauſe man durſt receyue went xxij dayes togither comming fennie grounde vnhabited buylded citty next baſternia • aſturn • • e floud b • riſthenes scythia ſaye alſo apollo dyd deſtroy celtians theyr city ende plague fled left theyr houſes came illyria offered whō • ke ſickeneſſe ſoone ouercame handling • irene hill diuideth fraunce spaine thing toke infection fledde pirene moued toward eaſt romanes afraid foughte excéeding battayle ſente conſuls againſt leaſt ſhoulde paſſe alpes come italy romaine hauing syllenus •• • lius c • p •• conſuls ouerthrovven cymbrians c loſſe armye name celtians ſtroke al italy feare till choſe marius generall ouercame libyan nu •• dians maruſians valiauntly ouerthrow celtians many tymes marius ouerthrovveth deſtroy haue ſhewed booke celtian end celtians illyrian wickedneſſe yet withholde wicked handes holy thing scordiſcians medan dardanās ranne ouer grecia macedonia ſpoyled temple againe beſieged delphos loſing many men ſlaine two thirtie yeare warre betwéene romanes celtians late ſacrileage made warre l scipio beyng captaine lordes macedonia grecia ſaye neyghboures felowes wickedneſſe ayding left scipio remembring plague autarians whiche vtterlye deſtroyed illyria scipio ouerthrowe scordiſcians corruption one •• uſe ciuil diſcord rome could eſcape wente danubi • ilands thereof corrupted couenaunt holy gold made league medan dardanans many italian ſhew wrytings ſtate rome ſtroken ciuil diſcorde vntill came rule one theſe thing illyria founde among grecian haue writtē large romanes cal theſe illyrian rhae • ia alpes part vvhich novv guſoni noricia novv ba •• ni •• novv ioſua ceruia alſo paeonians beyonde rhetians noricians miſians dwel europe al nigh inhabite right hand hiſter common name although many come toppes deſtroyed reſte flodde wooddes againe leauing citie whoſe name terponus terponus caeſar tooke burne neither thinking alſo woulde render didde went cittie whiche call metulio chiefe city iapodans metulio ſcituate vppon two hilles wooddy place betwéene whiche little valley goeth youth number thrée thouſande well practiſed armes eaſily repell romanes walles romanes ſet vppon mounte whiche within withoute runnyng daye nighte didde muche hinder hauyng ſome engine whyche hadde gotten warre whereby made romaynes lye hadde gotten theyr enginesengines taken place vvhere brutus caſsius made mountes vvals break ſette two mountes againſt whiche made alſo foure bridge walles readye caeſar badde ſome goe ſide citie drawe citizen aſunder willed goe vppon bridge ſtoode looked vppon highe tower done barbarian came reſiſte gaue aſſaulte wall laying traynes behinde beating bridge long ſpeares waxed fierce two bridge broken thirde lyke fall romanes ſuche feare none woulde go fourth caeſar rebuked tower woulde neuerthe boldneſſe caeſar auguſt • ſooner goe wherefore tooke ſhield ran bridge agrippa hierom lucius capitaines volas one guard theſe iiij▪ fewe tergatebearers went bridge caeſar metulians afraide next day ſending embaſſadors peace promiſed deliuer v c pledge receiue garriſō leauing higher hill al went y• garriſon cōmanded thē leaue armor grieued putting wiues child woman killed themſelues child ſome broughte child aliue threw thē fire al youth metulians periſhed battaile vnprofitable ſort fire city ſo burned great tokē lefte metulians ouercome reſt iapodans yéelded caeſar thus iapodans beyond alpes became ſubiecte romanes caeſar gone poſſemans poſſenians▪ metulians rebelled marcus elbius ouercame killed thē cauſe rebellion made reſt ſlaues romanes hauing gone twice againſt ye segeſtanes neither tooke hoſtages paeonians vvaye segeſtanes thing elſe wherefore boldened caeſar went againſt paeonian land wer yet obedient romanes land woddy ſtretcheth alōg iapodans dardanans paeontans haue city land houſes togither common juſticepaeonians haue city common place iuſtice muche people vvithout head caeſar burneth village prince rule ouer c fighting baſtarnans dwell beyond hiſter floude place called danubius going lower place hath name hiſter sa • u rē nethhiſter danubius caeſar ſhippes floude might bryng victuall armie danubio caeſar would haue citie segeſta went forward segeſtanes ſent embaſſadourssegeſta vnto know ſhould doe willed thē receyue garriſon deliuer pledge might haue daci scythian europe novv vallachia citie ſtore houſe warre againſt daceans much corne could bring chiefe men thought good people began rage cared thethe people segeſta refuſeth garriſon hoſtages bicauſe ſhould great mē garriſon came could abide ſée ranne vpō furiouſly ſhutte gate ſhewed themſelues agayne vpon walles wherefore caeſar made bridge euer floudde rayſed trench ditch ſhut citie erected two mountes hindred much might could defeate mountes threwe fire burning linkes vpō frō higher place ayde comming nation paeonians againſt whome caeſar layee ambuſhes ſo killed parte parte fledde ſo came helpe segeſtans enduring ſiege valiantly made one verſus captaine inuaded pomona citie yt liburnians defenſed trenche ditch got ſtrong place yt country al hillie toppes whereof ſtand vp like pynacles greater part thē citie reſt kept hil toppes ſo mighte eaſily ſée romanes armye caeſar deſſembled thoughe would encloſe al wall priuily bad bolde ſorte go mountaynes eſpie done going wood ſecretly night ſet vpon kepers yet aſléepe killed vvater fearing wayes would ſhut ſides got thē pomona caeſar encloſed citie two higheſt hylles yet holden enimies xl furlong meane ſeaſon gaue onſet vpon teutinus another captaine ofteutinus dalmatian warre celtes celtes firſt inuade romanes toke celta thoſe frenchman inhabite floud • gatona camillus rome without capitoll burned camillus ouercome dryue away came agayne another time dyd ouerthrow triumphed whē foureſcore yeares age thirde time came italy deſtroyed romanes vnder ti • u quintus generall boians moſt fierce nation celtes came bo •• vvere part french byons c sulpitius policie vpon romanes caius sulpitius dictator wente agaynſte vſed policie souldyoures front caſt dart ſtreight way ſet downe till ſeconde thirde fourth done like euery one ſtouping done ſhotte contrarie weapon mighte throwne • ayne laſt hadde throwne runne one force crye violence vpon enimie ſo ſhoulde affray came ſo ſuddaynely fight hand ſo greatethe french call dart geſa macedomans lariſſe romanes pila popilius camillus p aemilius brunt ſtrength weapon like dartes rome call geſe halfe ſquare ſtaffe péece yron ſquare alſo ſoft beſide poynt euen thus theſe boyans deſtroyed romanes armie popilius ouercame celtes camillus ſonne camillus ſame paulus aemilius ſette vp token victorie againſt celtes cōſulſhips marius greater number warlike age bée feared inuaded italy gallia ouercame ſome cenſuls ofthis gallia vvas vvhere novv lombardy c rome ouerthrewe army againſte whome marius went ouercame laſt greateſt fight galles done c caeſar generall fortiec caſar hūdred thouſands fierce nation ouerthrow tennethe victory caeſar yeares whiche man put togither one ſumme ſhall finde foure hundreth thouſande certen hundred thouſand ſlayne hundreth thouſande taken foure hundreth nation eight hundred city ſome reuoltyng ſome fréely yéeldyng brought obedience beforea • milianus marius fabius maximus • milianus leadyng meane armie ouercome hundreth twentie thouſande celtes loſſe fiftene men though wounded knée yet reſted ryde aboute encourage armie inſtructyng fight agaynſt barbarian ſometime carried hys chariot ſometime ledde hand caeſar makyng warre agaynſt firſte conquere luctians luctians heluetians tigrians novv lurick put romanes vnder yoke labienus ap claudius germanes paſſe greatnes deſpiſing death hope liue agayne triconi tigrians number two hundreth thouſande tigrians afore tyme piſo one caſsius leader ouerthrew romanes put vnder yoke aſpinus claudius wryteth olde monumentes labienus lieftenant ouercame theſe tigrians reſte caeſar ſubdued triconians helpyng conquered germanes ariouiſto whoſe greatneſſe paſſed greatneſſe haue moſte fierce maner hardy giuyng battayle afrayde death hope ryſe agayne abyde colde hunger néede requireth horſes many tymes fed ſhrubbes yet thought paynefull warre goyng order rage lyke brute beaſtes ſo conquered romanes patience ſufferaunce woulde runne romanes battayle great violence romanes kéepyng order diſcipline warre eaſily ouercame thē tymes killed lxxx thouſande caeſar belga scalde sequane inuaded belgian▪ whome mette paſſage killed ſo many made bridge body notwithſtandyng neruians made goe backe coming •• eru
